collection.name: The Honored Injil
collection.bismillah: In the name of Allah Most Gracious and Merciful

verse.content: This is the record of the ancestry of Isa al-masih, Ibn Dawood Ibn Ibrahim. 1 Ibrahim fathered Ishaq, Ishaq fathered Yacoub, and Yacoub fathered Yahuda and his brothers.

metadata.item: The word Ibn in this verse does not mean a literal son. In this case, Ibn Dawood means the descendant of Dawood who had the legal right to be king. This genealogy is the genealogy of Yusif, the step-father of Isa and the husband of Mariam (the mother of Isa). A stepson of someone who had the right to be king could also be king.
The word Ibn here does not mean a literal son. In this case, Ibn Ibrahim means a descendant of Ibrahim. In other places, it means a believer in Allah.
The verse numbers come at the end of the verse.
See the Tawrat, Genesis 21:3
See the Tawrat, Genesis 25:26
See the Tawrat, Genesis 29:32-30:24

verse.content: Yahuda fathered Perez and Zerah. Tamar was their mother. Perez fathered Hezron and Hezron fathered Ram.

metadata.item: See the Tawrat, Genesis 38:29
See the Tawrat, Genesis 46:12
See the Tawrat, Ruth 4:19

verse.content: Ram fathered Amminadab, Amminadab fathered Nahshon, and Nahshon fathered Salmon.

metadata.item: See the Tawrat, Ruth 4:19
See the Tawrat, Ruth 4:20
See the Tawrat, Ruth 4:20

verse.content: Salmon fathered Boaz. Rahab was his mother. Boaz fathered Obed. Ruth was his mother. Obed fathered Jesse.

metadata.item: See the Tawrat, Ruth 4:21
Her story is in the Tawrat, Joshua 2 and 6.
The Tawrat, Ruth 4:13-17,21
The Tawrat, Ruth 1-4 gives the whole story.
See the Tawrat, Ruth 4:22

verse.content: Jesse fathered Dawood the king, and Dawood fathered Sulayman. His mother was the former wife of Uriah.

metadata.item: See the Tawrat, Ruth 4:22
See the Tawrat, 1 Samuel 12:24
This story is in the Tawrat, 2 Samuel 11 and 12.

verse.content: Sulayman fathered Rehoboam, Rehoboam fathered Abijah, and Abijah fathered Asa.

metadata.item: See the Tawrat, 1 Kings 11:43
See the Tawrat, 1 Kings 14:31
See the Tawrat, 1 Kings 15:8

verse.content: Asa fathered Jehoshaphat, Jehoshaphat fathered Joram, and Joram fathered Uzziah.

metadata.item: See the Tawrat, 1 Kings 15:24
Or Jehoram. See the Tawrat, 1 Kings 22:50

The word fathered can mean 'was the ancestor of'. In this case, Joram was the great-great grandfather of Uzziah, (who was the son of Amaziah son of Jehoash, son of Ahaziah son of Joram. This genealogy was not intended to be totally inclusive, but rather to show the right of Isa to be king.
Or Azariah.

verse.content: Uzziah fathered Jotham, Jotham fathered Ahaz, and Ahaz fathered Hezekiah.

metadata.item: See the Tawrat, 2 Kings 15:7
See the Tawrat, 2 Kings 15:38
See the Tawrat, 2 Kings 16:20

verse.content: Hezekiah fathered Manasseh, Manasseh fathered Amon, and Amon fathered Josiah.

metadata.item: See the Tawrat, 2 Kings 20:21
See the Tawrat, 2 Kings 21:18
See the Tawrat, 2 Kings 21:24

verse.content: Josiah was the father of Jeconiah and his brothers at the time of the captivity to Babylon.

metadata.item: The word fathered can mean 'was the ancestor of'. In this case, Josiah was the grandfather of Jeconiah son of Jehoiakim son of Josiah. This genealogy was not intended to be totally inclusive.
Or Jehoachin.
The whole nation of Bani Israil was taken to Babylon after they were defeated by the Babylonians.

verse.content: After the captivity to Babylon, Jeconiah fathered Shealtiel, and Shealtiel fathered Zerubbabel.

metadata.item: The word fathered can mean was the legal father of. In this case, Shealtiel died with no children and his brother Pedaiah married his widow in obedience to the Tawrat (Deuteronomy 25:5-10) to have a child to inherit Shealtiel's property and his right to be king. See the Tawrat, 1 Chronicles 3:17-19.

verse.content: Zerubbabel fathered Abihud, Abihud fathered Eliakim, and Eliakim fathered Azor.

metadata.item: Or Abiud.

verse.content: Azor fathered Zadok, Zadok fathered Achim, and Achim fathered Eliud.
Eliud fathered Eleazar, Eleazar fathered Matthan , and Matthan fathered Yacoub.
Yacoub fathered Yusif, the husband of Mariam. From her, Isa, who is called al-masih, was born.

metadata.item: Some research into ancient languages has suggested that the Yusif mentioned here is the father or guardian of Mariam. If this is correct, both her father and husband were named Yusif. Yusif was a very common name in those days.

Yusif was not at all involved in the pregnancy of Mariam. Mariam was the only human being involved in her pregnancy with Isa. She was a virgin and Holy Ruh Allah caused her to get pregnant. Verses 20 and 25 also make this clear.
Al-masih is a title, not a name. As such, it is not capitalized. Al-masih means the one anointed with oil to show his appointment by Allah as king, habr, and nabi.

Yusif adopted Isa and brought him up. Yusif had the right to be king through his descent from Dawood, and an adopted son inherited that right from his adoptive father. So Isa had the legal right to be king over Bani Israil.

verse.content: So there are a total of fourteen generations from Ibrahim to Dawood, fourteen generations from Dawood to the captivity to Babylon, and fourteen generations from the captivity to al-masih.
The birth of Isa al-masih happened as follows: Yusif betrothed Mariam, and before they had sexual relations, her pregnancy from Holy Ruh Allah became obvious.

metadata.item: Al-Yahud had three steps to marriage: engagement, betrothal, and marriage. At betrothal, a couple was legally husband and wife, but they had not consummated the marriage. This was the stage of Mariam and Yusif.
During the betrothal period, some couples had sexual relations.

verse.content: Her husband Yusif was a righteous man. He did not want to scandalize her, so he decided to keep her apart and hide the matter.

metadata.item: During the betrothal period, the couple were considered husband and wife.
The Tawrat, Isaiah 42:3 describes a righteous or just person as having mercy.

verse.content: As he was busy thinking about these matters, an angel from Rabb Al-Alamin appeared to him in a dream and said, "Yusif, Ibn Dawood, do not be afraid to marry Mariam, because her pregnancy is from Holy Ruh Allah.

metadata.item: Allah often speaks to people through dreams. This is the first of four dreams that Allah gave to Yusif.

The word Ibn here does not mean a literal son. In this case, Ibn Dawood means the descendant of Dawood who had the legal right to be king. As such, when he adopted Isa, his adopted son Isa also had the right to be king.
Or take home as your wife.

verse.content: She will give birth to a son you will name Isa, because he will save his people from their sins."

metadata.item: Only seven people were named by Allah before their birth. These included: Ismail, Ishaq, Sulaiman, Yahya, and Isa.

verse.content: In all these matters, Rabb Al-Alamin fulfilled what he said by the tongue of the nabi,
"The virgin will become pregnant and give birth to a son, and they will call his name Emmanuel," which means: Allah is with us.

metadata.item: This is a quotation from the Tawrat, Isaiah 7:14.

verse.content: When Yusif woke from his sleep, he did what the angel commanded him, and brought her to his house.
But he did not have sexual relations with her until after she gave birth to a son, and he named him Isa.
After Isa was born in the town of Bait Lahm in Yahudia province in the reign of King Herod, majus came to Al-Quds from the East.

metadata.item: This is King Herod the Great, who ruled over Al-Yahud from about 37 BC to about 1 BC, according to the earliest manuscripts of Josephus, a Jewish historian of that age.
Most probably they came from south Arabia, where the gifts they brought were available, and still are produced.

verse.content: They started asking, "Where is the baby king of Al-Yahud? In the East, we saw his star rising. So we have come to bow down to him."

metadata.item: The acknowledgement by the majus that Isa was the king continues the theme from chapter 1.

Much research has been done about this star. The word for star in the original language included planets, and it seems this may have been the planet Jupiter. In the months preceding their arrival at Al-Quds, Jupiter had had three conjunctions with Regulus and the closest conjunction with Venus in history may have been about the time of his birth.
Bowing down was a way of honoring kings and people of high authority.

verse.content: But when Herod heard the news, he was disturbed, along with all of Al-Quds.

metadata.item: Herod was not one of Al-Yahud, so his kingship over Al-Yahud was of questionable legitimacy. A Yahudi king would have had a more legitimate claim to be king over Al-Yahud.
Herod was ruthless, and when he was upset, all of Al-Quds was concerned.

verse.content: So he gathered the leading ahbar and fuqaha and asked them about the place of birth of al-masih, the Expected King.
They said, "In Bait Lahm in Yahudia, according to what Allah revealed in the scroll of the nabi:
Bait Lahm in Yahudia province, you are not the smallest of the rulers of the province, since a ruler who will shepherd my people Bani Israil will come from you."

metadata.item: This is not literal rulers, but is figurative language meaning the cities or towns.
Or king.
This is a quotation from the Tawrat, Micah 5:2 and 2 Samuel 5:2.

verse.content: Then Herod brought the majus to him in secret and asked them what time the star appeared.

metadata.item: Before the birth of al-masih, the planet Jupiter had a conjunction with Regulus, the chief star in the constellation of Leo, the lion. Leo was considered the king of the constellations, and Jupiter was considered the king of the planets. This may have been the star the majus saw.

verse.content: Then he sent them to Bait Lahm and said, "Go and search for the boy. When you find him, inform me of the news. Then I can go and bow down to him also."
After hearing what the king said, they went out. The star that they had seen in the East went before them until it reached the place of the baby and it stopped above it.

metadata.item: It seems at the time of the visit of the majus, Jupiter was in retrograde motion and it stopped to move forward again.
They were traveling south from Al-Quds to Bait Lahm and the star was in the south.

verse.content: They were extremely happy to see the star.

Then they entered the house and saw the boy with his mother Mariam, and they fell down and bowed down to him. They opened their treasure boxes and presented gifts to him: gold, frankincense, and myrrh.

metadata.item: Isa was not a newborn infant any more. The trip of the majus could have taken several months.
These gifts were the products of Arabia (specifically the area that is now Oman).

verse.content: They were warned in a dream not to return to Herod. So they returned to their country by another road.

After they left, Yusif saw an angel from Rabb Al-Alamin in a dream saying, "Get up, take the boy and his mother, and flee to Egypt. Stay there until I command you, because Herod will look for the boy to kill him."

metadata.item: Herod was king over Al-Yahud, but he was not one of them. Hearing of king of Al-Yahud would have been a threat to his being king, so he wanted to eliminate the threat. He was getting old and was more and more fearful, and had killed many others whom he thought were threats to his remaining king.

verse.content: Yusif got up at night, took the boy and his mother, and they went to Egypt.
They stayed there until Herod died. So what Allah said by the tongue of the nabi was fulfilled, "I called my beloved amir from Egypt."

metadata.item: This is a quotation from the Tawrat, Hosea 11:1. It had a double meaning, neither of which was literal. It referred to Bani Israil and to al-masih.

verse.content: When Herod realized that the majus had deceived him, he was very angry. He commanded that all the boys in Bait Lahm and the surrounding area who were two years old or younger should be killed. That was based on the time the majus told him.

metadata.item: Possibly by agreeing to return if they found the baby king.
Isa was probably only about a year old, but Herod probably wanted to make sure he eliminated all possible threats to his throne. The magi may have told him about all the signs they had seen.

verse.content: This fulfilled what Allah had said by the tongue of the nabi Jeremiah,
"A sound was heard in the region of Ramah. There was mourning and deep wailing. Rachel was mourning for her children. She refused to be comforted, because they were gone."

metadata.item: This region was near Al-Quds.
Rachel was a wife of nabi Yacoub. Here it is used to refer to the descendants of Rachel, who lived in that area.
This is a quotation from the Tawrat, Jeremiah 31:15

verse.content: After Herod died, an angel from Rabb Al-Alamin appeared to Yusif in a dream and told him,
"Get up, take the boy and his mother, and return to the land of Bani Israil. Those who tried to kill him have died."

metadata.item: This is probably a reference to Herod and his soldiers.

verse.content: So he awoke and took the boy and his mother and returned to the land of Bani Israil.
When he heard that Archelaus son of Herod had become king over Yahudia, he was afraid to return. A warning came to him in a dream, so he headed to Al-Jalil province.
He came and lived in the town of Al-Nasira. What Allah had said by the tongue of the anbiya in the kitab was fulfilled, "He will be called Al-Nasiri."

metadata.item: This is a summary of several verses from the Tawrat, including Shaya 9:1 and 53:3. People from the town of Al-Nasira were considered ignorant and low-class.

verse.content: In those days, Yahya who did ghusl came calling people in the wilderness of Yahudia. He said,

metadata.item: Yahya was a common name. This Yahya is called Yahya who did (or does) ghusl to distinguish him from others of the same name, like Yahya the son of Zebedee who became a hawari.

verse.content: "Repent, since the kingdom of heaven has approached!"

metadata.item: The kingdom of heaven means the same as the kingdom of Allah. It is used only in the book of Matthew, which was written to Al-Yahud. Religious Yahudi people were afraid of dishonoring Allah by mispronouncing his name, so they often said "heaven" instead of the name of Allah.

verse.content: This fulfilled what Allah had revealed about Yahya in the scroll of the nabi Shaya, "A voice shouting in the wilderness: Prepare the way of Al-Mawla and make his sirat mustaqim."

metadata.item: Very few anbiya were predicted in the Tawrat (Isa and Yahya). Other people who were predicted but who were not anbiya were Josiah, a king of Bani Israil, Cyrus, king of Persia, and Mariam, the mother of Isa.
This is a quotation from the Tawrat, Shaya 40:3.

verse.content: Yahya was wearing a camel hair robe and a leather belt. He ate locusts and wild honey.
The inhabitants of Al-Quds and all Yahudia, and all the inhabitants of the plains around the Jordan headed to him.
They admitted their sins, and he did ghusl for them in the Jordan River.
He saw many of the Pharisees and Sadducees coming and asking for the ghusl of repentance. So he said to them, "Sons of snakes! Who warned you to flee from the coming anger of Allah?

metadata.item: These were people who were very religious. The message of Isa to them is that they needed to repent, just like everyone else.
The word sons is not literal. Here it means people who have the qualities of snakes -- evil and cunning.

verse.content: Produce fruit that is appropriate for repentance!
Do not think to say to yourselves: Ibrahim is our father. I tell you that Allah is able to make these stones sons of Ibrahim!

metadata.item: Father is not used in a literal sense. Here it means ancestor. Al-Yahud usually trusted in their ancestry and being part of the umma of Bani Israil more than their obedience to Allah.
The words sons is not used in a literal sense. Here it means descendants or true believers.

verse.content: The axe is now ready to cut the roots of the trees. So any tree that does not produce good fruit will be cut down and thrown in the fire.

metadata.item: Here the trees represent people. Yahya is saying that the people do not have much time left to produce good fruit. In fact, the nation of Bani Israil was destroyed about forty years later, in A.D. 70.

verse.content: I do the ghusl of repentance for you into water. But the one who is coming after me is stronger than I am. I am not worthy to carry his shoes. He will do ghusl for you into Holy Ruh Allah and into fire.
He is holding his winnowing fork in his hand, and he will purify his threshing floor and gather his wheat in his storehouse. But he will burn the hay with fire that cannot be quenched."

metadata.item: This was used to separate grain from inedible parts of the plant.
From the unusable parts of the plant.

verse.content: Then Isa came from Al-Jalil to Yahya for ghusl by him in the Jordan River.
Yahya objected, "I need to have ghusl from you. Do you come to me?"

metadata.item: Ghusl was for purification, and Isa was more pure than Yahya.

verse.content: Isa answered, "Permit this matter now so that we can truly fulfill the will of Allah." So Yahya permitted it.

metadata.item: The meaning may have been that Isa wanted to affirm the work of Yahya, who called people to repent and thus prepared a straight path for the work of Isa.

verse.content: After Isa did ghusl, he came out of the water and immediately the sky was opened. He saw Ruh Allah coming down on him like a dove, and he remained on him.
A voice shouted from the sky, "This is my beloved amir. I have rida with him."
Ruh Allah led Isa into the wilderness so that Iblis could tempt him.
After Isa did a sawm for forty days, night and day, he was hungry.

metadata.item: In this kind of sawm, a person does not eat any food, day or night, for many days. As a result, the digestive system basically shuts down. When a person is hungry at the end of this time, it signals that his body needs to get nourishment or it will start to die.

verse.content: Then Al-Shaitan the tempter came to him and said, "If you are the beloved amir of Allah, command these stones to become bread."

metadata.item: Iblis and Al-Shaitan are two names or titles for the same evil enemy of Allah and people.

The stones were round and flat, the same shape as the bread. The amir of Allah has the authority of Allah. Al-Shaitan was suggesting that Isa use his authority as amir without trusting Allah, the king. Physicians say that if Isa had eaten bread after 40 days with no food at all, he would have died, because his digestive system had shut down. After a fast like that, gradual re-introduction of juices and then fruits would have been necessary.

verse.content: He answered him, "In the Tawrat it is written: A person does not live by bread only, but by every word that comes from the mouth of Allah."

metadata.item: Allah does not have a mouth or a body, but the holy books use expressions like this to illustrate truth. The mouth of Allah refers to how he communicates to people. This is a quotation from the Tawrat, Deuteronomy 8:3

verse.content: Then Iblis took him to the holy city and made him stand on the top of the house of Allah.

metadata.item: Al-Quds.

verse.content: He told him, "If you are the beloved amir of Allah, throw yourself down, for it is written in the Zabur: He will command his angels to take care of you. On their hands they will carry you, so that your foot will not kick a stone."

metadata.item: This is only a partial quotation from the Zabur, Psalms 91:11-12. Context and accurate quotation of the complete passage are important to understand the meaning. Al-Shaitan left out an important phrase after "to take care of you": "to guard you in all your ways." The way Al-Shaitan used the verses implied that people can do whatever they want and Allah will protect them. The full quotation of the verses meant that Allah will protect people as they go through their lives trusting in Allah.

verse.content: Isa answered, "It is also written: Do not tempt Allah, your Mawla."

metadata.item: This is a quotation from the Tawrat, Deuteronomy 6:16.

verse.content: Then Al-Shaitan took him to a very high mountain, and showed him all the kingdoms of the inhabited earth, and all their majesty.

metadata.item: This was in a dream or vision, since there is no mountain from which all kingdoms of the earth can be seen.

verse.content: He told him, "I will give you all these if you kneel and bow down to me."

metadata.item: This would have been giving honor to Al-Shaitan.

verse.content: Then Isa told him, "Go away from me, Al-Shaitan! It is written in the Tawrat: Bow down to Allah your Mawla, and serve him only."

metadata.item: This is a quotation from the Tawrat, Deuteronomy 6:13.

verse.content: So Iblis left him, and angels came and took care of him.
When he heard about the arrest of Yahya, he went to Al-Jalil.
He came from Al-Nasira to live in the town of Capernaum at the shore of the lake, in the region of Zebulun and Naphtali.
This fulfilled what Allah said by the tongue of the nabi Shaya:
"Land of Zebulun and Naphtali on the road of the sea east of the Jordan River in the region of Al-Jalil belonging to the kuffar,
the people sitting in darkness have seen a great light. Light has shone on those sitting in the regions of the shadow of death."

metadata.item: This probably refers to spiritual darkness.
Isa is that light. See Yahya 8:1.
This is a quotation from the Tawrat, Shaya 9:1-2, and a reference to the Zabur, Psalms 23:1.

verse.content: Starting at that time, Isa preached, "Repent, because the kingdom of heaven has approached."
Isa was walking on the shore of Al-Jalil Lake, and he saw two brothers, Simon called Peter and his brother Andrew. They were throwing their nets in the lake, because they were fishermen.
He told them, "Follow me and I will make you gather people instead of fish."
Immediately they left their nets and followed him.
Then he walked further and saw Yacoub son of Zebedee and his brother Yahya in a boat with their father fixing their nets. He called them to himself.

metadata.item: This is a different Yahya than Yahya the son of Zakariyya, who did ghusl. This Yahya became a hawari.

verse.content: And immediately they left the boat and their father and followed him.
He went around in all the region of Al-Jalil, teaching in their houses of salat, preaching the good news of the kingdom of Allah, and healing all the sicknesses and diseases of the people.

His reputation spread through all Syria. They brought him those who had sicknesses and various pains, those who had been touched by jinn, the insane, and those who were paralyzed, and he healed them all.

metadata.item: The Roman province of Syria was roughly equivalent in area to the modern country of Syria.
Or epileptic. The word is literally moonstruck.

verse.content: So large crowds followed him from Al-Jalil, the Decapolis, Al-Quds, Yahudia, and the East Bank.
When Isa saw the crowds, he went up a mountain. There he sat down and his followers gathered around him.

metadata.item: It was the custom of teachers to sit when they taught.

verse.content: He began to teach them:
"Poor people who firmly hold the mercy of Allah in their spirit have a baraka. They have a portion in the kingdom of heaven.
Sad people have a baraka, because they will be comforted.
Gentle people have a baraka, because they will inherit the land.

metadata.item: Or the earth.

verse.content: People who are hungry and thirsty for righteousness have a baraka, because they will be satisfied.
Merciful people have a baraka, because they will be shown mercy.
People who have pure hearts have a baraka. They will be given insight and knowledge of Allah.
People who make peace have a baraka, because they will be called umara to Allah.
People who are persecuted because they are righteous have a baraka. They have a portion in the kingdom of heaven.
You have a baraka when people insult you, persecute you, lie about you, and treat you unjustly because you are my followers.
Be joyful and very happy, because your reward with your Rabb is great. This is the way they persecuted the anbiya before you.
You are the salt of the earth. But if salt is spoiled, how can it be salty again? It is no longer good for anything except to be thrown on the road to be walked on by people passing by.
You are the light of the world. A city built on a mountain cannot be hidden.

metadata.item: Al-Nasira was one city that was built on a small mountain.

verse.content: In the same way, no one lights a lamp and puts it under a basket. He puts it on a lamp stand to give everyone in the household light.

metadata.item: Most houses were one-room houses, so one light could give light to everyone in the house.

verse.content: So let your light shine to people so they can see you good works. Then they will praise the glory of your Most Gracious King who is in heaven.

metadata.item: This refers to the Arabic names Al-Rahman and Al-Malik, two of the 99 names of Allah. See the glossary for a discussion on this term.

verse.content: Do not imagine that I came to invalidate the Tawrat and the scrolls of the anbiya. I did not come to invalidate them but to fulfill them.

metadata.item: Sometimes the word Tawrat refers to all the revelation of Allah to Bani Israil. Other times, the revelation is divided into Tawrat and scrolls of the anbiya.
Some people wrongly imagine that Isa came with a message that was different from Musa and the anbiya, and that his message invalidated the Tawrat. Isa affirmed the whole Tawrat.

verse.content: I tell you a true saying: There is no substituting of the smallest letter or part of a letter from the kitab. None of it will disappear until the time of completion of all things, when heaven and the earth will disappear.

metadata.item: Or, "Amen I tell you." It was usual for people who heard a teaching to say, "Amen" (faithful) to what they had heard after it was said if they agreed with it. Isa was the only teacher who not only said this about his own teaching, but he said it before the teaching. By this Isa shows that his teaching is from Allah. This pattern is repeated in the teaching of Isa many times.
This referred to the y, which was the smallest letter in their language, and a very small part of a letter which made the difference between an r and a d, for example.
Allah is able to protect his words. People who say that mere humans could change his words do not believe in the power of Allah.

verse.content: Whoever ignores the smallest verse from the kitab and teaches that to people will be the least of the sons of the kingdom of heaven. Whoever obeys the verses of the kitab and teaches people to obey them will be great among the sons of the kingdom of heaven.

metadata.item: The word sons here is not literal. Sons of the kingdom here refers to citizens of the kingdom.

verse.content: I tell you: If you do not become more righteous than the fuqaha and the Pharisees, you will never be worthy to enter the kingdom of heaven.
You have heard that it was said to people long ago: 'Do not murder,' and also: 'The murderer brings his sentence upon himself.'

metadata.item: This is a quotation from the Tawrat, Exodus 20:13 and Deuteronomy 5:17
This is a reference to capital punishment for murder. There are many verses in the Tawrat that say this, including Exodus 21:12,15, Leviticus 24:17,21.

verse.content: But I tell you: The person who is angry with his brother brings the sentence upon himself. The person who insults his brother deserves to be answerable before the highest council. The person who says: 'You are stupid' will receive his reward: hellfire.
Suppose you are presenting a qurban at the place of sacrifice and remember that your brother has something against you in his soul.
Leave the qurban there in front of the place of sacrifice, go, and be reconciled to your brother. Then come and present your qurban.

Resolve your court case with your opponent quickly while you are on the road to the court. Otherwise, he will deliver you to the judge, the judge will deliver you to the guard, and you will be thrown in prison.
I tell you a true saying: You will never get out until after you have paid the last two fils you owe.

metadata.item: The fils was less than one percent of the daily wage of a laborer.
Sending debtors to prison was common in that time.

verse.content: You have heard that it was said: Do not commit adultery.

metadata.item: This is a quotation from the Tawrat, Exodus 20:14, Deuteronomy 5:18.

verse.content: But I tell you: Whoever looks at a woman and desires her has committed adultery in his heart.
Suppose your right eye makes you commit a sin. Pull it out and throw it away. It is better for you for one member of your body to be lost than for you to be thrown in Jahannam with a complete body.
Suppose your right hand makes you commit a sin. Cut it off and throw it away. Losing one member of your body is better for you than to enter Jahannam with a complete body.
If was also said: Whoever divorces his wife should give her a divorce document.

metadata.item: This is a reference to the Tawrat, Deuteronomy 24:1. It was a custom among Bani Israil previously to divorce wives with no paperwork. This would not allow the woman to re-marry.

verse.content: But I tell you: Whoever divorces his wife, except if she is not a virgin, pushes her into adultery. A man who marries a divorced woman commits adultery, too.

metadata.item: See footnote at Matthew 1:18. The reference here is to a couple who was betrothed, meaning they were officially married but they had not consummated their marriage. Divorce is permitted at this stage only. In Mark 10:11 and Luke 16:18, Greek and Roman marriage is the context and they did not have a betrothal stage. Thus, no exception is given.
The word adultery is used here, which implies that Allah considers the divorced woman still the wife of her first husband.

verse.content: You have also heard that it was said to people long ago: Do not swear falsely. Fulfill your vows to your Rabb.

metadata.item: This is a reference to the Tawrat, Leviticus 19:12, Deuteronomy 23:21,23, Numbers 30:2.

verse.content: But I tell you: Do not swear at all. Do not swear by heaven, because it is the throne of Allah.
Do not swear by the earth, because it is under his control. Do not swear by Al-Quds, because it is the city of the great king.

metadata.item: Some think this refers to Dawood, who was the greatest king over Bani Israil. Others think it refers to Allah, the greatest king of all.

verse.content: Do not swear by your head, because you are unable to change the color of one white or black hair.
Say, 'Yes' if you mean 'Yes', or, 'No' if you mean 'No.' Anything more than that comes from the evil, cursed one.

metadata.item: Al-Shaitan

verse.content: You have heard that it was said: 'An eye for an eye and a tooth for a tooth.

metadata.item: This was the standard for judges in sentencing. It is referred to in the Tawrat in Exodus 21:24, Leviticus 24:20, and Deuteronomy 19:21.

verse.content: But I tell you: Do not resist an evil person. Suppose someone slaps you on your right cheek. Turn the other cheek to him.

metadata.item: Some people had taken the standard for judging and had made it into personal permission to take revenge.

verse.content: Suppose someone files a court case against you to take your cloak. Give him your coat also.
Suppose someone forces you to carry his load a certain distance. Carry it with him twice as far.

metadata.item: Roman occupation soldiers could force a person to carry their backpack one Roman mile (about 1.5 km).

verse.content: If someone asks you for something, give it to him. If someone comes to borrow from you, do not turn your face away from him.

metadata.item: This may mean ask to borrow something, like the following phrase. In the language Isa spoke, there were two words for borrowing. The first was used for borrowing an item that would itself be returned, like a hammer. The second was used for borrowing a quantity of a substance and returning the same quantity, like a cup of oil.

verse.content: You have heard that it was said: Love your neighbor and hate your enemy. But I tell you: Love your enemies and pray in dua' for baraka on those who persecute you.

metadata.item: This is a quotation from the Tawrat, Leviticus 19:18.
Allah never commanded people to hate their enemy. This is a saying added by people.

verse.content: Then you will be umara to your Most Gracious King in heaven. He makes his sun rise on the evil and the good. And his sky rains on the pious and the unjust.
If you love those who love you, what reward do you have? Detested tax collectors do that!
If you greet only your brothers, what have you done more than others? Even the kuffar do that!
Be perfect, as your Most Gracious King in heaven is perfect.

metadata.item: Or mature or whole.

verse.content: "Be careful not to demonstrate your good works in front of people. If you do, you will have no reward from your Most Gracious King in heaven.

When you give alms, do not announce it publically. Do not attract the attention of people like the hypocrites do in the houses of salat and the streets. They want people to praise them. I tell you a true saying: They have received the praise of people, and they will have no reward from Allah.

metadata.item: This refers to voluntary gifts (sadaqat in Arabic). This is different from the required zakat or poor tax.

verse.content: When you give alms, do not let your left hand know what your right hand is doing.
Then the alms will be a secret. Only your Most Gracious King, the Hidden One, will know. You will get a reward from the All-Seeing One, the Knower of secrets.

metadata.item: This refers to the Arabic name Al-Batin, one of the 99 names of Allah.
This refers to the Arabic name Al-Basir, one of the 99 names of Allah.
Here and in verse 6 and 18, The Most Gracious King, the Hidden One, The All-Seeing One, and the Knower of Secrets are names or titles of Allah.

verse.content: In your salat and dua', do not imitate the hypocrites. They love being in the first row to do salat. They love to pray in dua' in the sight of people. They want to be praised by people. I tell you a true saying: They have received the praise of people, and they will have no reward from Allah.
When you do salat, enter your room and close your door. Pray in salat or dua' to your Most Gracious King, the Hidden One. You will receive a reward from the All-Seeing One, the Knower of secrets.
In your salat, do not repeat empty words like the kuffar. They think that they will be answered because they say many words.
Do not imitate them, because your Most Gracious King knows well what you need before you pray in dua' to him.
And do your salat like this: 'Allahumma, our Most Gracious King in heaven, let your holy name be praised.
May your kingdom appear, and may your will be accomplished on earth as well as in heaven.
Provide bread for us today.
Forgive us our sins as much as we pardon people who sin against us.
Keep us away from temptation, and rescue us from evil.
If you pardon people for their sins, your Most Gracious King in heaven will forgive you.
But if you do not pardon people, your Most Gracious King will not forgive your sins.

When you practice sawm, do not frown or let your faces look exhausted. This is what the hypocrites do to show people that they are practicing sawm. I tell you a true saying: They have received praise from people, and they will have no reward from Allah.
When you practice sawm, have an cheerful, lighthearted face.
Then only your Most Gracious King, the Hidden One, will see your sawm. You will get a reward from the All-Seeing One, the Knower of secrets.
Do not store treasures for yourselves in storehouses of this world. Moth and rust will spoil them, and thieves will steal them.

metadata.item: Clothing is one treasure that moths eat.
Metallic items can be destroyed by rust.

verse.content: Store treasures for yourselves in storehouses of the next life. No moth or rust will spoil them, and no thief will steal them.
Your heart will be wherever your treasure is.
The eye is the lamp of the body. If your eye is healthy, your whole body will be full of light.
But if your eye is evil, your whole body will be full of darkness. If your 'light' is dark, it will be very dark!

metadata.item: This can mean unhealthy or the evil eye, which is greedy, jealous, or envious.

verse.content: No one can serve two masters. He might love one of them and hate the other one. Or he might be committed to one of them and despise the other one. You cannot worship both Allah and money.

metadata.item: Some people worship money, and it is a god to them.

verse.content: Therefore I tell you: Do not worry about your life -- what you eat and what you drink. And do not worry about your bodies -- what you wear. Life is more than food and the body is more than clothing!
Look at the birds of the sky. They do not plant, harvest, or store food. But your Most Gracious King in heaven feeds them. You are more important than they are!
None of you can lengthen his life by one instant by worrying!
So why do you worry about your clothes? Think about how the lilies of the field grow. They do not spin thread or get tired.
But I tell you, even Sulayman in his greatest majesty did not wear clothing like one of them.

metadata.item: Sulayman was known for having the most riches and finest clothing in history.

verse.content: Allah gives clothes of such splendor to grass that lasts for one day in the field and is thrown into the oven the next day. You people have little trust. Will he not give you clothes even more?
So do not worry and say: What will we eat? Or: What will we drink? Or: What will we wear?
The kuffar seek after all these things, but your Most Gracious King in heaven knows your needs well.
Seek after his kingdom and his will first. Then Allah will provide all your needs.

metadata.item: The kingdom of Allah here refers to people who do the will of Allah voluntarily. Thus some people are part of the kingdom of Allah and some are not. This does not mean that Allah is not in control of sovereign over everything in the universe.

verse.content: So do not worry about tomorrow. Tomorrow is aware of its own burdens. Each day has enough evil of its own.
"Do not condemn anyone. Then you will not be condemned.
You will be condemned the same way you condemn them. The measure you use will be used with you.

metadata.item: The standard of judgment that you use will be used with you.

verse.content: Why do you look at the straw in the eye of your brother and not notice the piece of wood that is in your eye? Or why do you say to your brother: Let me take the straw from your eye, when the piece of wood is still in your eye?
Hypocrite, first take the piece of wood out of your eye. Then you will see clearly to take the straw from the eye of your brother.
Do not give holy things to dogs. Do not throw your pearls to pigs. Otherwise, they will step on them with their feet, turn against you, and tear you in pieces.

metadata.item: Dogs are unclean animals, and holy meat would be unsuitable to feed them. This may refer to people who do not appreciate the holiness of things
Pigs are unclean animals, and no animal appreciates a pearl. This may refer to people who do not appreciate wisdom.
Pigs are the ones who would step on a pearl.
Dogs are the ones who would tear you in pieces.

verse.content: Pray in dua' and it will be given to you. Search and you will find. Knock and it will be opened to you.
Everyone who asks will receive. Everyone who seeks will find. A door will be opened to everyone who knocks.
Suppose your son asks you for bread. Will you give him a stone?

metadata.item: Many stones were round and flat like their bread.

verse.content: Suppose he asks for a fish. Will you give him a snake?

metadata.item: Possibly a water snake or eel, which swims and has scales like a fish.

verse.content: You evil people know how to give your children good gifts. Even more, your Most Gracious King in heaven gives good gifts to the one who asks him.

metadata.item: Or righteousness

verse.content: In everything, treat people as you like them to treat you. This is obeying the Tawrat and the scrolls of the anbiya.

metadata.item: Sometimes the word Tawrat refers to all that Allah revealed to Al-Yahud. Other times it refers to the revelation of Allah to Musa. When it refers only to the revelation of Allah to Musa, the rest of the revelation to Bani Israil is usually called the scrolls of the anbiya.

verse.content: Enter through the narrow gate. The way to Jahannam is spacious and its gate is wide. Many people pass through that gate.

metadata.item: This may refer to entering the kingdom of Allah or entering Al-Janna.

verse.content: But the sirat to life is hard. Its gate is narrow. Few people are guided to it.
Beware of dajjals who prophesy. They come to you wearing skins of sheep. Inside, they are hunting like wolves.

metadata.item: On the outside they look harmless.

verse.content: You will know them by their fruit. Do you pick grapes from a thorn bush? Do you pick figs from thorny plants?

metadata.item: The fruit their lives produce, whether their character and actions are good or bad.

verse.content: Good trees produce delicious fruit. Bad trees produce evil fruit.
A good tree cannot produce evil fruit. A bad tree cannot produce delicious fruit.
Every tree that does not produce good fruit will be cut down and thrown into the fire.

metadata.item: This may refer to jahannam.

verse.content: Thus you can know them by their fruit.

metadata.item: Trees here represent people and fruit represents their life and character.

verse.content: Not everyone who says to me, 'Our master, our mawla' is worthy to enter the kingdom of heaven. Rather, worthy people do the will of my Most Loving King in heaven.

metadata.item: This refers to the Arabic names Al-Rahman and Al-Wadud, two of the 99 names of Allah. See the glossary for a discussion on this term.

verse.content: On the last day, many will say to me: 'Our master, our mawla, in your name we proclaimed prophecies, cast out jinn, and accomplished many works of power.'

metadata.item: *Yawm Al-Din. *

verse.content: But I will tell them in public: I never knew you at all. You are evil, corrupting people. Go away from me!
Everyone who hears my words and does them is like a wise man who built his house with a foundation on the rock.
The rain fell, the river overflowed, the wind blew against that house, but it did not collapse, because its foundation was on the rock.
But the person who hears my word and does not do it is like a stupid man who built his house on sand.
The rain fell, the river overflowed, the wind blew against that house, and the house completely collapsed."
After Isa finished his message, the crowds were amazed at his teaching.
He did not teach like their fuqaha. His teaching had authority.

metadata.item: The fuqaha taught by quoting the interpretations of other people, but Isa taught his own interpretation.

verse.content: When Isa came down from the mountain, large crowds followed him.
A man with leprosy approached him and bowed down. He said, "My master, if you will it, you are able to make me tahir."

metadata.item: Or some other skin disease. The word is a broad word. Such skin diseases made a person unclean.

verse.content: Isa stretched his hand and touched him. He said, "I will it. Be tahir." Immediately, he became tahir from his leprosy.

metadata.item: Here Isa shows his authority over sicknesses.

verse.content: Isa told him, "Be careful not to tell anyone. Instead, go, show yourself to the habr, and present the qurban that Allah commanded to Musa as a proof to them."

metadata.item: The details of the commands are in the Tawrah, Leviticus 14.

A person with leprosy was excluded from the society. When the person healed of leprosy was confirmed by the habr to be tahir from the leprosy, this would allow him to be re-admitted to the society. It would also be a proof to the ahbar that a person with leprosy had been healed. Al-Yahud believed that only al-masih could heal a Yahudi who had leprosy. Thus the ahbar should understand that Isa was al-masih.

verse.content: When he entered the town of Capernaum, a Roman officer came to him begging,
"Sir, my servant is lying at home paralyzed. He is suffering a lot."
Isa answered him, "I will come and heal him."
But the officer answered him, "Sir, I am not worthy for you to come under the shade of the roof of my home. It is enough for you to say only one word, and my servant will be healed.
My commander is above me, and soldiers are under my command. I tell one 'Go,' and he goes. I tell another 'Come,' and he comes. I tell my slave, 'Do this' and he does it."
Isa heard that and was amazed. He said to his followers, "I tell you a true saying: I have not found such great trust, even among Bani Israil.

metadata.item: The officer realized and trusted the authority of Isa, since he understood authority in general.

verse.content: I tell you that many will come from the East and the West and recline with Ibrahim, Ishaq, and Yacoub in the banquet of the kingdom of heaven.

metadata.item: People ate on very low tables or on the floor, and they reclined on their left sides and ate with their right hands.
Al-Yahud believed that only they would be in the kingdom of Allah, and that other people would go to jahannam.

verse.content: But Bani Israil will be thrown out of the banquet into the outer darkness. People there will cry and grind their teeth."

metadata.item: Probably a name for jahannam. Al-Yahud would have been shocked that Isa was saying that they were not guaranteed to go to Al-Janna, and in fact were going to go to jahannam.

verse.content: Then Isa told the officer, "Go. It will happen according to your trust." At that instant, his servant was healed.

metadata.item: Here Isa again shows that as king, he has authority.

verse.content: Isa entered the house of Peter, and he found the mother-in-law of Peter lying down. She was suffering from a fever.
So he touched her hand, the fever left her, she got up, and she served them.
At sunset, people brought him many other people who had been touched by jinn, and he cast out the spirits from them with a word. He healed everyone who had been sick.
This fulfilled what Allah had said by the tongue of the nabi Shaya, "He took our illnesses and carried our sicknesses."

metadata.item: This is a quotation from the Tawrat, Shaya 53:4. Isa was king and had authority over all sicknesses and jinn.

verse.content: Isa saw the crowds gathering around him, and he commanded his followers to cross to the other side.
A faqih approached him and told him, "Teacher, I will follow you wherever you go."
Isa answered him, "Foxes have holes, and birds have nests. But sayyid al-bashar has no place to rest his head."

metadata.item: Sayyid al-bashar is the most common title Isa used for himself. It had three primary meanings in the Tawrat. 1) Sometimes, it meant a human being, as in Numbers 23:19. 2) Many times, it was used to mean a nabi or rasul (93 times in the scroll of Ezekiel alone). 3) The person prophesied in the Tawrah, Daniel 7:14, who was coming to Allah on the clouds of the sky and whom Allah was going to give rule, kingship, and glory over all peoples, nations, and language groups forever in an eternal kingdom. When Isa used this title with the religious authorities, they understood this meaning.

verse.content: One of his followers told him, "My master, let me go and bury my father first."
But Isa told him, "Follow me, and leave the dead to bury their dead."

metadata.item: This probably means, let the spiritual dead people bury the physically dead people.

verse.content: He entered the boat and his followers went in after him.
Then a fierce storm blew on the sea. The waves rose so high that the boat almost sank. Isa was sleeping during this.
They came close to him, woke him, and said, "Our mawla, rescue us. We are dying."
He said to them, "You people have little trust. Why are you terrified?" Then he stood up and rebuked the winds and the sea. So it became completely calm.
His followers were amazed and said, "Who is this? The winds and the sea obey him!"

metadata.item: The authority that Isa had over the wind and seas showed that his authority was from Allah. See also verse 29.

verse.content: When they arrived to the other shore, the land of the people of Jerash, two men touched by jinn came out of the tombs and met him. They were very violent, and they prevented people from passing that way.

metadata.item: The province of Jerash extended to the edge of the lake.

verse.content: They shouted immediately, saying, "Beloved amir of Allah, have you come to torture us before the time?"

metadata.item: Allah will judge all people and spirits on Yawm Al-Din. The jinn seem to have thought that Allah sent his amir, who had his authority, to execute this judgment on them earlier than Yawm Al-Din.

verse.content: A flock of many pigs was feeding at a distance from them.
The jinn begged Isa, "If you cast us out from him, send us into the pigs."
So he said, "Go." So they left the men who were touched, entered the pigs, and the whole herd rushed from the edge of the mountain into the lake, and they drowned.
Then the herders fled and entered the town and told the people in it what had happened to the men who had been touched by the jinn.

metadata.item: The herders may have called the rest of the town to justify themselves that they were not responsible for the loss of the pigs, which may have belonged to several people in the town.

verse.content: So all the people in the town came to meet Isa. When they saw him, they begged him to leave the area.

metadata.item: It seems they were more concerned for their economic prosperity than for the men who had been touched by the jinn.

verse.content: So Isa got into a boat and crossed the lake, returning to his town.

metadata.item: Capernaum. Isa had moved from Al-Nasira, where he grew up, to proclaim the message of Allah here.

verse.content: People there came to him carrying a paralyzed man on his mat. When Isa saw their trust, he said to the paralyzed man, "I give you good news, my son. Your sins are forgiven."

metadata.item: The word son is not literal. Isa was never married and had no children. Isa said this to show compassion to the paralyzed man.

verse.content: Some of the fuqaha said within themselves, "This man speaks shirk!"

metadata.item: They thought no one could know if the sins of a person were forgiven except Allah.

verse.content: Isa knew their thoughts and asked them, "Why do you hide evil in your hearts?

metadata.item: Isa knew what was in their hearts.

verse.content: Which is easier? To say, 'Your sins are forgiven.' Or to say, 'Stand up and walk'?

metadata.item: No one could check to see if the sins of a person had been forgiven. But it was very easy to check if a paralyzed person had been healed or not. By healing the man, Isa showed that he had the authority for both.

verse.content: But I want you to know that sayyid al-bashar has authority to forgive sins on the earth." So he said to the paralyzed person, "Stand up, carry your mat, and go to your home."
So he stood up and went to his home.
When the multitude saw that, they were afraid and praised the glory of Allah, who had given a person this kind of authority.
After Isa left that place, he saw a man whose name was Matthew sitting in the tax office of the occupiers. He told him, "Follow me." So he stood up and followed him.

metadata.item: This is the same Matthew whose name is the title of this part of the Injil.

verse.content: Later, Isa was at home at the table with his followers. Many detested tax collectors and sinners joined him.

metadata.item: They were detested because they collaborated with the Roman occupiers and took extra from the people to keep for themselves.

verse.content: When the Pharisees saw that, they asked his followers, "Why does your teacher eat with detestable tax collectors and sinners?"

metadata.item: It was the habit of the Pharisees to avoid tax collectors, whom they detested, and those they considered "sinners" because they did not keep the traditions of the Pharisees.

verse.content: Isa heard and said, "Healthy people do not need a doctor. Sick people do.
Go and discover what this verse means: I want mercy, not a sacrifice. I did not come to call the righteous, but the unrighteous."

metadata.item: This is a quotation from the Tawrat, Hosea 6:6. It shows that Allah is more interested in mercy than religious practices.

verse.content: Then the followers of Yahya came and asked him, "Why do we and the Pharisees practice sawm, but your followers do not practice sawm?"
Isa told them, "Are the guests of the wedding sad when the groom is with them? But days when the groom will be raised from among them are coming. Then they will practice sawm.

metadata.item: One reason for practicing sawm is to show sorrow.
Isa was referring to his being raised to Allah.

verse.content: No one fixes an old robe with new cloth. The new patch will shrink, tear the old robe, and the tear will be worse.

No one puts new wine in an old leather container. If he did, the container would tear and the wine would spill. New wine is put into a new container. Then the wine and the container will both be preserved."

metadata.item: Wine expands as it ages. It stretches the leather of the container. But leather that has already been stretched once would break if it were stretched a second time.

verse.content: While he was speaking, an elder came to him, bowed to him, and said, "My daughter just died. But come and put your hand on her, and she will live."

metadata.item: Ilyas had done a miracle like this, and the elder may have thought that Isa could do it also.

verse.content: Isa and his followers stood up and followed him.
There was a woman there. She had been suffering from bleeding for twelve years. She came behind him and touched the edge of his robe.

metadata.item: This made her unclean.

verse.content: She had told herself, "If I touch even his robe, I will be healed."
Isa turned to her and told her, "My daughter, be encouraged. Your trust in me has healed you." Immediately she was healed.

metadata.item: The word daughter is not literal but is a way of showing compassion. Isa was not married and had no children.
Isa healed her disease and made her tahir.

verse.content: Isa arrived at the house of the elder, and found the house full of the noise of mourning and wailing.
He said to the mourners, "Go out. The girl did not die. She is sleeping." So they mocked him.

metadata.item: Sometimes the word sleeping is used for death when a person is not permanently dead. Since Isa was going to resurrect her, she was not permanently dead.

verse.content: After the crowd left, he entered her room and held her hand. Then the girl stood up.
The news about her spread throughout the whole region.
When Isa left there, two blind men followed him. They shouted, "Have mercy on us, Ibn Dawood!"

metadata.item: Ibn Dawood was a title of al-masih. It meant the descendant of Dawood the king who had the right to be king. When the blind men used this title, it showed that they acknowledged him as al-masih the king and trusted in his authority.

verse.content: When he entered the house, the two blind men came near him. Isa said to them, "Do you trust that I am able to do this?" They both said, "Yes, our master."
He touched their eyes and said, "It will happen according to the amount of your trust."
Their eyes were opened, and Isa warned them strongly, "Do not inform anyone."

metadata.item: Isa was not interested in popularity, but in people following Allah. Many people would come to Isa for healing but would not want to follow Allah.

verse.content: But they went out and announced the news about him throughout the whole region.
After the two men left, someone brought a man to Isa who had been touched by a dumb jinni.
When he cast out the jinni, the dumb man spoke, and the crowds were amazed. They said, "Bani Israil has never seen anything like this."

metadata.item: Al-Yahud believed that casting out a jinni which was dumb (it made the person unable to speak) was an ayah that only al-masih could do.

verse.content: But the Pharisees said, "He casts out jinn by the power of Iblis, king of the jinn."

metadata.item: This was the official position of the religious leaders of Al-Yahud. Since they decided to reject that Isa was al-masih, they had to explain how Isa could do an ayah that only al-masih could do.

verse.content: So Isa went around to the cities and villages. He taught in their houses of salat, announced the good news of the kingdom of Allah, and healed every disease and illness.
When he saw the crowds, he had compassion on them. They were discouraged and depressed like sheep without a sheep herder.
He told his followers, "The harvest is large and there are few workers.
Pray in dua' to the Rabb of the harvest to send workers to his harvest."

metadata.item: Allah is the Rabb of the harvest.

verse.content: After that, he called his twelve hawariyun to himself and gave them clear authority to cast out unclean spirits and to heal every disease and illness.
These are the names of the twelve hawariyun: The first was Simon, called Peter, Andrew his brother, Yacoub son of Zebedee, Yahya his brother,

metadata.item: There were two of the hawariyun that were named Yacoub. They were distinguished by their father's name. This name was common at that time.
This Yahya was one of the hawariyun, not the Yahya who did ghusl and was a relative of Isa. This name was common at that time.

verse.content: Philip, Bartholomew, Thomas, Matthew (who had been a detested tax collector), Yacoub son of Alphaeus, Thaddeus,

metadata.item: Thaddeus was also known as Yahuda son of Yacoub. Yahuda was a common name.

verse.content: Simon the Zealot, and Yahuda Iscariot, who later betrayed him.

metadata.item: This was the name of a political party who advocated overthrowing the Roman occupation. Simon was also called this to distinguish him from Simon Peter, the leader of the hawariyun.
Iscariot may mean "a man from Cariot." His name or title was used to distinguish him from Thaddeus, whose Yahudi name was Yahuda also. This name was common at that time.

verse.content: Isa sent these twelve and commanded them, "Do not enter regions of the kuffar, nor any Samaritan city.
Rather go to the lost sheep of the family of Bani Israil.
As you go on the way, spread the good news of the approaching of the kingdom of heaven.
Heal the sick, give life to the dead, heal people who have leprosy, and cast out the jinn. You received without cost, so give without cost.

metadata.item: Isa had authority over all these things and he gave the hawariyun the same authority.
Some people would take money for healing a person.

verse.content: Do not take gold, silver, or copper money with you in your belts.
Do not take provisions, an extra robe, shoes, or a walking stick for the road, because a laborer deserves his provision.
Whenever you enter a town or a village, look for a worthy person and stay with him until you leave the region.
When you enter a house, greet the household: Assalamu alaykum!

metadata.item: In other words, give them your peace.

verse.content: If it is a worthy household, your salam will stay on it. If it is not worthy, your salam will return to you.
If anyone does not receive you and does not listen to what you say, travel away from that house or that town. Shake off the dust from your feet.

metadata.item: This was like saying, "I will not take or accept anything from you, even the dust." It meant that they had had a chance to repent, but they had refused, so Allah was justified in punishing them.

verse.content: I tell you a true saying: The torment of the people of Lut, the people of the region of Sodom and Gomorrah, will be lighter on Yawm Al-Din than the torment of that town.
I am sending you out as sheep in the middle of wolves. Be understanding like snakes and simple like doves.

metadata.item: Sheep were defenseless against wolves.
Snakes were considered very clever.
Or innocent.

verse.content: Beware of people. They will deliver you to courts and whip you in the houses of salat.
They will drag you in front of governors and kings because of me. This is so that you can present your shahada about me to them and to the nations of kuffar also.
When they deliver you to the court, do not be worried about how to say it or what to say. You will receive the words in that hour.
You are not the speakers. The Ruh of your Most Gracious King will speak using your tongues.

metadata.item: This is another name for Holy Ruh Allah

verse.content: A brother will deliver his brother to death. A father will deliver his son. Sons will rebel against their parents and cause them to be executed.
All people will hate you because of my name. But whoever is firm and patient until the end will be rescued.
If they persecute you in one town, go to another town. I tell you a true saying: You will not travel through all the cities of Bani Israil before the coming of sayyid al-bashar.

metadata.item: Some people think that the coming of sayyid al-bashar refers to his coming in judgment in 70 A.D. Others think his coming is still future.

verse.content: A follower is not greater than his teacher, and a slave is not greater than his master.

metadata.item: Both of the titles teacher and master apply to Isa. If a person listens to his teaching but does not obey him, this is not enough. See Luke 6:46.

verse.content: It is enough for a follower to imitate his teacher and a slave to imitate his master. If they have called the master of the house Iblis, what will they say about the rest of the household?

metadata.item: Isa referred to himself as master of the house.
The followers of Isa.

verse.content: Do not be afraid of them. Everything that is covered will be exposed. Everything hidden will be known.
When I tell you something in the dark, tell it publicly in the light. When you hear something whispered, announce from the roofs.
Do not fear people who kill the body, because they have no power to kill the soul. Instead, fear the One who causes to die. He is able to destroy the soul and the body in Jahannam.

metadata.item: This refers to the Arabic name Al-Mumit, one of the 99 names of Allah.
Allah is the one who destroys soul and body in jahannam.

verse.content: Are two sparrows not sold for one dirham? But a sparrow never falls to the ground without the permission of your Most Gracious King.

metadata.item: The dirham was about one sixteenth of a daily wage of a laborer.

verse.content: But the hairs on your heads are all counted.
So do not fear. You are worth more than many sparrows.
If someone supports me in front of people I will support him in front of my Most Loving King in heaven.

metadata.item: Or chooses.

This refers to the Arabic names Al-Malik and Al-Wadud, two of the 99 names of Allah. Isa used this title to describe his unique relationship with Allah. Isa called him his Most Loving King, with Isa as his amir. See glossary for more information.

verse.content: But my if someone denies me in front of people, I will deny him in front of my Most Loving King in heaven.
Do not think that I came to bring peace on earth. I did not come to bring peace, but a sword.

metadata.item: There may be strife in a family when some members follow Isa and others reject him.

verse.content: I came to cause strife between a son and his father, between a daughter and her mother, and between a daughter-in-law and her mother-in-law.

metadata.item: It is not a command to cause strife in families, but rather children are commanded to obey their parents, and everyone is commanded to honor their parents. See chapter 15:4 and the Tawrat, Exodus 20:12.

verse.content: Thus the enemies of a person will be in his household.
Whoever loves his father, his mother, his son, or his daughter more than me is not worthy of me.
Whoever does not sacrifice himself, following the example of my death on the cross, is not worthy of me.
Whoever protects his life will lose it. Whoever loses his life in my sirat will protect it.
Whoever receives you receives me. Whoever receives me receives Allah who sent me.

If someone receives a nabi because he is a nabi, Allah will reward him with the reward of a nabi. If someone receives a righteous man because he is righteous, Allah will reward him along with the righteous people.
I tell you a true saying: Whoever gives even a glass of cold water to drink to one of these little ones because he follows me will never lose his reward."
When Isa finished his commandments to his hawariyun, he went out teaching and preaching in their cities.
Yahya was in prison. When he heard about the miracles of al-masih, he sent his followers to ask him,
"Are you the coming one who was promised or shall we wait for someone else?"

metadata.item: I.e. al-masih. This was a reference to the Tawrat, Malachi 3:1, the Zabur, Psalms 118:26, and the words of Yahya in the Injil, Matthew 3:11

verse.content: Isa answered them, "Go and tell Yahya what you hear and see:
Blind people see, lame people walk, people with leprosy are healed, deaf people hear, dead people are resurrected, and good news is given to poor people.

metadata.item: These ayat showed that the person doing them was al-masih. This is a reference to the Tawrat, Shaya 61:1

verse.content: The person who does not doubt about me has a baraka!"
When the followers of Yahya left, Isa began to speak to the crowds about Yahya, "Why did you go out to the wilderness? To see a reed blown by the wind?
Why did you go out? To see a man wearing fancy clothing? Those who wear fancy clothing live in palaces of kings.

metadata.item: The expected answers to both these questions would be, "Of course not."

verse.content: Then why did you go out? To see a nabi? Yes. I tell you, and he is more than a nabi.
In the book of Allah it is written about him: I send my rasul in front of you to prepare the way in front of you.

metadata.item: This is a quotation from the Tawrat, Malachi 3:1

verse.content: I tell you a true saying: No one born of women has appeared who is greater than Yahya who did ghusl. But the least person in the kingdom of Allah is greater than he is.

metadata.item: Some people think that Yahya was the greatest nabi or rasul because his message was to prepare people for Isa, who was the amir of Allah and his word.
This may be in reference to the privileges they have as members of the kingdom of Allah, which Yahya announced but he died before he could be a part of.

verse.content: Since the days of Yahya until now, people have been violently entering the kingdom of heaven. People who struggle take it by force.
At the coming of Yahya, the age of the Tawrat and the scrolls of the anbiya ended.

metadata.item: Sometimes the word Tawrat refers to all the revelations of Allah to Bani Israil. Here it is divided into the laws of Musa and the revelations to other anbiya.

verse.content: If you believe it, know that Yahya is like Ilyas, whose coming was promised.
Everyone who has ears should listen.
What shall I compare this generation to? They are like children sitting in the market calling to one another:
We played the flute for you and you did not dance. We mourned for you and you did not wail.

metadata.item: In other words, nothing suits you. Playing the flute and dancing were done at weddings, and mourning and wailing were done at funerals.

verse.content: Yahya came to you not eating or drinking, and you rejected him. You said: A jinni has touched him!

Then sayyid al-bashar came eating and drinking and you rejected him. You said: He eats too much and he is a drunkard. He is a friend to detestable tax collectors and sinners! But the correctness of wisdom is proven by its works."
Isa began to rebuke the cities where he had done most of his works of power, because they had not repented.

"Woe to you, town of Chorazin! Woe to you, town of Bethsaida! If the works of power that were done in you had been done in Tyre and Sidon, their people would have sincerely repented a long time ago. They would have worn burlap and sat in ashes.

metadata.item: These were ways people showed their sorrow for their sin and their repentance to Allah.

verse.content: But I tell you that the torture of Tyre and Sidon on Yawm Al-Din will be lighter than your torture!

And will Allah raise you, Capernaum, to the heights of Al-Janna? No! He will lower you down to Jahannam! If the people of Lut, the inhabitants of Sodom, had witnessed the works of power that you witnessed, it would have remained until today.

metadata.item: This refers to the Arabic name Al-Rafi', one of the 99 names of Allah.
This refers to the Arabic name Al-Khafid, one of the 99 names of Allah.
Sodom and Gomorrah (Al-Mu'tafikat) and the surrounding areas were destroyed by fire and sulfur sent by Allah from the sky.

verse.content: But I tell you that the torture of Sodom on Yawm Al-Din will be lighter than your torture."
That day, Isa said, "I give praise to you, Most Loving King, Rabb of heaven and the earth. You hid these secrets from wise, clever people and revealed them to simple people.
Yes, Most Loving King, everything has happened according to your rida.

My Most Loving King has delegated everything to me. No one knows the beloved amir except the Most Loving King, and no one knows the Most Loving King except the beloved amir and those people that the beloved amir wills to show him to him.
Everyone who is tired and burdened, come to me, and I will refresh you.
Carry my yoke of guidance and learn from me, because I am kind and humble in heart. You will find rest for your souls,
because my yoke is easy and my burden is light."
Then Isa passed wheat fields on Al-Sabt. His hawariyun were hungry, and they started picking the heads of grain and eating.
When the Pharisees witnessed that, they said, "Your helpers are doing what is prohibited on Al-Sabt."

metadata.item: There is a command in the Tawrat (Exodus 20:10) prohibiting all kinds work on Al-Sabt, including harvesting. It did not prohibit eating when hungry. The Pharisees had made their own sunan which said that picking heads of grain to eat was a kind of harvesting. Isa affirmed the commands of the Tawrat but rejected the rules of men.

verse.content: He told them, "Did you not read in the kitab what Dawood did when he, his companions, and his soldiers were hungry?
He entered the house of Allah and Dawood and his companions ate the bread that had been offered as a qurban to Allah. Only the ahbar are allowed to eat it.

metadata.item: The story of this is in the Tawrat, 1 Samuel 21:6. The point is that a human need is more important than a religious regulation.
This refers to the regulations in the Tawrat. See Leviticus 21:22 and 1 Samuel 2:36.

verse.content: Did you not read in the Tawrat how the ahbar violate Al-Sabt, within the house of Allah, and do not sin?

metadata.item: The duties of the ahbar included offering sacrifices on Al-Sabt (See the Tawrat, Numbers 28:4-9) and circumcising boys who had been born the previous Al-Sabt (see the Tawrat, Leviticus 12:30). The point is that the rules of men actually contradicted the laws of Allah in the Tawrat.

verse.content: I tell you that there is a person here who is greater than the house of Allah.

metadata.item: Isa in his role as sayyid al-bashar.

verse.content: If you had understood the verse: I want mercy, not sacrifice, you would not have condemned the innocent.

metadata.item: This is a quotation from the Tawrat, Hosea 6:6.

verse.content: Sayyid al-bashar is master of Al-Sabt."
Then Isa went away from there and entered their house of salat.
There was a man there who had a withered hand. They asked him, "Is it halal to heal on Al-Sabt?"
He said to them, "Suppose a sheep belongs to one of you, and it falls into a hole on Al-Sabt. Will you not grab it and pull it out?
People are worth much more than a sheep. So doing good is halal on Al-Sabt."
Then he said to the man, "Stretch out your hand." He stretched it out and it became straight and was made whole like the other hand.
Then the Pharisees went out and conspired to kill him.

metadata.item: The teaching of Isa was against their traditions and they may have feared that they would lose their positions and their power.

verse.content: Isa realized their intent, so he withdrew from there. Many people followed him and he healed all of them.

metadata.item: Isa was able to know the thoughts of people.

verse.content: But he commanded them strongly not to tell anyone about him.
This was to fulfill what Allah said by the tongue of the nabi Shaya:
"This is my slave, al-mustafa, my beloved. I have rida with him. I will send down my Ruh on him, and he will give news of justice to the nations of the kuffar.
He will not show enmity or shout. No one will hear his voice in the streets.
He will not break a reed that is almost broken, and he will not extinguish a wick that is almost extinguished. He will lead truth to victory.
The nations will put their hope on him."
They brought him a man who had been touched by a dumb and blind jinni. He healed him and the man was able to see and speak.
All the people were amazed. They asked each other, "Is he Ibn Dawood, the expected king?"

metadata.item: Casting out a dumb jinni was a miracle that Al-Yahud believed only al-masih could do. Al-Yahud cast out jinn by asking their names, but a dumb jinni could not answer them. Isa had authority even over the dumb jinni.
The common people made the obvious connection between Isa doing an ayah that only al-masih could do and Isa being al-masih.

verse.content: But the Pharisees heard about it and said, "He only casts out jinn by the power of Iblis, king of the jinn."

metadata.item: See notes for the Injil, Matthew 9:33-34

verse.content: Isa knew their thoughts, and told them, "Every kingdom that is divided against itself will be destroyed. Every city or house divided against itself will not remain.
If Al-Shaitan casts out Al-Shaitan, he is divided against himself. Then how can his kingdom remain?
Suppose I cast out jinn by the power of Iblis. Then when your sons cast out jinn, whose power do they use? So they will condemn you.

metadata.item: Sons is not literal, but here refers to the followers of the party of the Pharisees.
If the power of Isa to cast out jinn came from Iblis, then the followers of the Pharisees would also use this power.

verse.content: However, if I cast out jinn by Ruh Allah, then the kingdom of Allah has been set up among you.
How can anyone enter the house of a strong man to plunder his possessions? Only if he first ties up the strong man. Then he can plunder his house.
Whoever is not with me is against me. Whoever does not gather with me will be scattered.

metadata.item: There may be a reference here to the scattering of Bani Israil who did not believe in Isa in A.D. 70 when the Romans destroyed Al-Quds.

verse.content: Therefore I tell you that Allah forgives all sins and disbelief of people. But disbelief in Ruh Allah will not be forgiven.
Whoever says a word against sayyid al-bashar will be forgiven. But whoever says a word against Holy Ruh Allah will never be forgiven in this life or the next life.

metadata.item: The implied condition here is "if he repents."

verse.content: If you plant a good tree, it will produce good fruit. Or if you plant a bad tree, it will produce bad fruit. A tree is known by its fruit.
Sons of snakes, how can you speak good? You are evil. The mouth speaks from what overflows from the heart.

metadata.item: The word sons is not literal here. It means people who have the same character or qualities of snakes.

verse.content: The good man brings good out of the treasure of good in his heart. The bad man brings out what is stored in him.
I tell you that everyone will be judged on Yawm Al-Din for every careless word his tongue speaks.
You will be righteous because of your words, or Allah will be angry with you because of your words.
Some fuqaha and Pharisees spoke to him, "Teacher, we want you to do an ayah."
He answered them, "A sinful generation that commits adultery asks for an ayah. But the ayah of Yunis will be the only ayah they are given.

metadata.item: The word adultery is probably not literal here. It is probably spiritual adultery, unfaithfulness to Allah.

verse.content: Yunis remained in the belly of the whale for three days and three nights. In the same way, sayyid al-bashar will remain in the belly of the earth for three days and three nights.

metadata.item: This is a reference to the Tawrat, Yunis 1:17
Both Yunis and Isa came out from the place that would have been their graves after 3 days.

verse.content: The men of Ninevah will be resurrected on Yawm Al-Din with this generation and condemn it. They repented when they heard the warning of Yunis. But one who is greater than Yunis is here!

metadata.item: Their repentance is described in the Tawrat, Yunis 3:5-10.
Isa is the one who is greater than Yunis.

verse.content: The queen of Saba will be resurrected on Yawm Al-Din with this generation and condemn it. She came from the ends of the earth to hear the wisdom of Sulayman. But one who is greater than Sulayman is here!

metadata.item: The story is in the Tawrat, 1 Kings 10:1-13.
Isa is the one who is greater than Sulayman.

verse.content: When an unclean spirit goes out of a person, it wanders in deserted places looking for rest in vain.
Then it says: I will return to my house which I left. So it comes to the person and finds him like an empty, clean, neat house.

metadata.item: The word house is not literal. Here it means the person the jinni had left.

verse.content: So it goes and brings seven spirits who are more evil than it to accompany it. Then they enter him and live in him. The last state of that person will be worse than his first state. This is what this sinful generation is like."

metadata.item: Seven or eight jinn would cause much destruction in the life of a person. By rejecting Isa, Al-Yahud brought on the destruction of Al-Quds and the umma of Bani Israil in 70 A.D.

verse.content: While he was speaking to the people, his mother and brothers came and stood outside the house. They wanted to talk with him.
Someone told him, "Your mother and brothers are standing outside, and they want to talk with you."
He answered him, "These people are my mother and brothers.

metadata.item: The people listening to the words of Isa and following him.

Obviously, the words mother and brothers are not literal here. The physical mother and brothers of Isa were outside, and the spiritual brothers and sisters and mother of Isa are the believers who listen to his words and follow him.

verse.content: Everyone who does the will of my Most Loving King who is in heaven is my brother, my sister, and my mother."
Isa went out on the same day and sat at the lake shore.
Great multitudes crowded around him, so he got in a boat and sat down in it. The crowds were standing on the shore.
He started speaking to them in stories about many things, "Listen: A farmer went out to sow.

metadata.item: Farmers took a handful of grain seeds and threw it onto the good soil. Unfortunately, some grain fell on other places.
