verse.content: As he was sowing, some seeds fell beside the road. The birds flew down to the seeds and ate them.
Some of the seeds fell on rocky ground with shallow soil. They sprouted immediately, because the soil had no depth.
But at sunrise, they were burned and dried up, because they had no root.
Some of the seeds fell among weeds, which sprouted and choked them.
Some of the seeds fell on fertile soil, and the seed produced one hundred, sixty, or thirty times as much as was sown.
Whoever has ears should listen."
Then his followers came to him and asked him, "Why do you talk to them with stories?"

metadata.item: Up until this point, Isa had been teaching clearly. But after the religious authorities had rejected his message, he started telling stories. A story means something to a person who understands the meaning, but if it is not explained, most people will not understand. In this way, Isa did not give further information to people who had rejected him. This was both merciful (Allah would not judge them more severely for what they did not understand) and practical (the people who had rejected him could not use his teaching against him).

verse.content: He answered them, "Allah has given knowledge of the secrets of the kingdom of heaven to you. But he has not given it to them.
More will be given to the one who has. But for those who do not have, even what they do have will be taken away.

metadata.item: In other words, those who do not have very much. The reference here is to understanding. Obedience is the key to understanding more.

verse.content: So I speak to them with stories, because they look and do not see. They hear but do not pay attention or understand.
What Allah revealed in the scroll of Shaya is fulfilled in them: 'You will hear but not understand. You will look carefully but not see.

The hearts of this people have become hard. Their ears have become deaf. They have covered their eyes. Otherwise, they would see with their eyes, hear with their ears, understand with their hearts, and turn. Then I would heal them.'

metadata.item: The religious authorities had seen Isa prove he was al-masih, but they willingly chose not to believe him.
This is a quotation from the Tawrat, Shaya 6:9-10.

verse.content: But your seeing eyes and listening ears have a baraka.
I tell you a true saying. Many anbiya and righteous people wanted to see what you see, but they did not see it. They wanted to hear what you hear, but they did not hear it.
Listen to the meaning of the story of the farmer.
Suppose someone hears the word of the kingdom and does not understand it. The evil, cursed one will come and snatch the word sown in his heart. This is the meaning of the seeds sown beside the road.

metadata.item: The evil one and the cursed one are two titles of Al-Shaitan.

verse.content: The seeds that are sown on the rocky ground are people who hear the word and receive it immediately with joy.
But they have no root in themselves. They remain for a time, but as soon as hardship or persecution because of the word touches them, they turn back immediately.
The seeds sown among the weeds are the people who hear the word, but the worries of this life and the deceitful love of riches choke the word, and they produce no fruit.
The seeds sown in the fertile soil are people who hear the word and understand it. Those seeds produce one hundred, sixty, or thirty times as much as was sown."

metadata.item: Each detail in the story has a meaning.

verse.content: Then Isa told them another story, "The kingdom of heaven is like a man who sowed good seeds in his field.
Then his enemy came at night, when everyone was sleeping. He sowed weeds among the wheat and left.
When the seeds grew and the heads of grain appeared, the weeds grew up also.
The slaves went to the owner of the field and asked him: 'Master, did you not sow good seed? Where did these weeds come from?
He told them: 'This is the work of an enemy.' They asked him: 'Do you want us to go and pull up the weeds?'
He said: 'No. If you gather the weeds now, you might pull up the wheat also.
Let the wheat and the weeds grow together. When harvest day comes, I will tell the harvesters: 'Gather the weeds in bundles for the fire. But gather the wheat and put it in my storehouse."

metadata.item: In any group of people who claim to be true followers and believers, there may be some who are not true followers or believers.
Allah knows who the true followers and believers are.

verse.content: He told them another story, "The kingdom of heaven is like a mustard seed. A man took it and sowed it in his field.
It is the smallest seed. Nevertheless, when it grows, it is taller than all plants. It becomes a tree that the birds of the sky make their nests in.

metadata.item: Mustard plants do not usually become trees.

The birds of the air are sometimes a symbol of evil. Some people think that the story means that birds, which sometimes represent evil (see verses 4, 19, Mark 4:4,15, Luke 8: 5,12) will get into the kingdom of heaven. Other people think that it means that the kingdom will grow very large.

verse.content: He told them another story, "The kingdom of heaven is like yeast. A woman took it and hid it in three measures of dough, until all the dough was yeasted."

metadata.item: Yeast was sometimes a symbol of evil. (See Matthew 16:6-12) Some people think this story is a prediction that evil will enter the kingdom of Allah. Other people think this means the kingdom of heaven will expand.

verse.content: Isa spoke to the multitudes with stories about all these matters. He only spoke to them with stories.
This was to fulfill the saying of Allah by the tongue of the nabi: "I will open my mouth with stories and speak secrets hidden since the universe was created."

metadata.item: This is a quotation from the Zabur, Psalms 78:2

verse.content: Then he sent the crowds away and went in to the house. His hawariyun came to him and said, "Explain the story of the weeds of the field to us."
He said, "The one who sows the good seeds is sayyid al-bashar.
The field is the world. The good seeds are the sons of the kingdom. The weeds are the ones who cause corruption in the earth, the sons of the evil, cursed one.

metadata.item: The word sons is not literal here. It means citizens of the kingdom.
The word sons is not literal here. It means followers of the evil one.
Al-Shaitan.

verse.content: The enemy who sowed the weeds is Iblis. The day of harvest is Yawm Al-Din. The harvesters are angels.
The weeds are gathered at the harvest and burned in the fire, and that is the way it will be on Yawm Al-Din.
Sayyid al-bashar will send his angels, and they will gather from his kingdom all the sinful people who cause destruction.
They will throw them in the furnace of fire, where people will cry and grind their teeth.
Then the righteous will shine like the sun in the kingdom of their Most Merciful King. Whoever has ears should listen.

metadata.item: Again, each detail of the story has a meaning. In both this story and the story of the sower and the seeds, Isa explained what each detail meant. This gives us a clue how to understand other stories as well.

verse.content: The kingdom of heaven is like a treasure buried in a field. A man found it by chance and covered it again. He was so happy that he sold everything he had and bought that field.
The kingdom of heaven is like a trader searching for valuable pearls.
When he found a pearl of incredible value, he sold everything he had and bought it.

metadata.item: Both of these people saw the worth of the kingdom of heaven and gave up everything to obtain it.

verse.content: The kingdom of heaven is like a net that was thrown into the lake. All kinds of fish were caught in it.
When it was full, they pulled it to the shore. Then they sat and chose the good fish and kept them. They threw the bad fish away.
This is what will happen on Yawm Al-Din. The angels will come and take the bad people from among the good people.
They will throw them in the furnace of fire, where there will be crying and grinding teeth.
Have you understood all this?" They said, "Yes."

metadata.item: See note on verse 43.

verse.content: He said, "Every faqih who seeks the knowledge of the kingdom of heaven is like a homeowner who brings out treasures containing new and old things from his storehouses."

metadata.item: There are some things in everyone's cultural background that are good and can be retained. Other things must be rejected and replaced with new things.

verse.content: After Isa had finished telling stories, he left that place.

When he returned to his hometown, he started teaching people in the house of salat. They were amazed and asked each other, "Where did he get all this wisdom and these works of power? Is he not the son of the carpenter? Is the name of his mother not Mariam? Are his brothers not Yacoub, Yusif, Simon, and Yahuda?

metadata.item: Yusif, his step-father, whom his mother had married, was a carpenter. These people did not know that he was conceived by Holy Ruh Allah without a human father, and they assumed Yusif was his biological father.

The word brothers includes half-brothers, sons of his mother. But most people assumed that the half-brothers of Isa were full biological brothers. The idea that Yusif had children from a previous marriage is improbable for several reasons. 1) Isa is called the first-born son of Mariam, which implies she had others. 2) Yusif and Mariam went to Bethlehem for the birth of Isa and later fled to Egypt. No other children are mentioned in the whole story. So these brothers and sisters are almost certainly children born to Yusif and Mariam after Mariam gave birth to Isa.

verse.content: Are all of his sisters not with us? From where did he get all this?"

metadata.item: The word sisters includes half-sisters, daughters of his mother.

verse.content: So they doubted him. Isa told them, "A nabi has no honor in his hometown and among his household."
He did not do many works of power there because of their kufr in him.
At that time, the ruler Herod heard about the reputation of Isa.

metadata.item: This is not Archelaus but Antipas, his brother. They and their other brother, Philip, ruled different parts of the kingdom of their father, King Herod the Great.

verse.content: He told his servants, "This is Yahya. He has been resurrected alive. This is why he does these works of power."
Herod had arrested Yahya and put him in prison to give rida to Herodias, the wife of his brother Philip.
Yahya had told Herod, "The wife of your brother is haraam to you."

metadata.item: Herod had married his brother's wife while his brother was still alive.

verse.content: Herod wanted to kill him, but he was afraid of the people. They considered Yahya to be a nabi.
At the birthday party of Herod, the daughter of Herodias danced and he had rida in her.
So he swore a promise to give her whatever she asked.
She asked her mother and then said, "Give me the head of Yahya who does ghusl on a plate."
The king grieved, but because of his promise to her in front of his guests who were there, he ordered that her request be fulfilled.

metadata.item: Or was sad or appalled.
His pride was more important to him than doing what was right.

verse.content: He sent a soldier, who cut off the head of Yahya in prison.
Then he gave it to the girl on a plate, and she gave it to her mother.
The followers of Yahya came and took his body and buried it. Then they went and informed Isa.
When Isa heard that, he withdrew from there in a boat, heading for an isolated place. But the crowds heard about him, and followed him, walking from the cities.
On the shore, Isa got out of the boat and saw the size of the crowd. He had compassion on them and healed their sick people.
When it was evening, his hawariyun came and said, "This place is isolated and the time is late. Send the crowds away to buy food for themselves in the villages."
He told them, "There is no need to send them away. You feed them."
They told him, "We have only five loaves and two fish."
He said, "Bring them to me."

He commanded the crowds to sit down on the grass. Then Isa took the five loaves and the two fish, looked up, prayed in dua' for baraka, broke the loaves, gave them to his followers, and they gave them to the crowds.
They all ate and were full. They gathered twelve hand baskets of leftover pieces.
The number of people who ate was about five thousand men, without counting the women and children.
Immediately, Isa commanded the hawariyun to get in the boat and go to the other shore before him while he sent the crowds away.
After he sent them away, he climbed a mountain by himself to pray in dua'. When evening came, he was there by himself.
The boat was far from the land. The waves were hitting it, because the wind was blowing against them.
Before dawn, Isa came, walking to them on the water of the lake.
When the hawariyun saw him walking on the water of the lake, they were terrified. They shouted in fear, "This is a ghost!"
Immediately he spoke to them, "Be encouraged. It is I. Do not be afraid."
Peter told him, "My mawla, if it is really you, command me to come to you by walking on the water."
Isa told him, "Come." So Peter got out of the boat and walked on the water toward Isa.
But when he saw the wind, he was afraid and started to sink in the water. He shouted, "Rescue me, my mawla!"
Isa stretched out his hand and grabbed him. He said, "You have little trust. Why did you doubt?"
Then they both entered the boat and the wind became calm.
Then those in the boat bowed down to him and said, "You are truly the beloved amir of Allah."
After that, they crossed to the shore by the town of Gennessaret.
The people of the town knew him, sent people to the whole region, and brought all their sick people to him.
They begged him that they could touch at least the edge of his cloak. Everyone who touched it was healed.
Then the Pharisees and the fuqaha came from Al-Quds to Isa and asked him:
"Why do your followers violate the sunna of our elders? They do not wash their hands before eating."

metadata.item: Their traditions were more important to them than the word of Allah.

verse.content: He answered, "And why do you break the commandment of Allah for the sake of your traditions?
Allah commanded in the Tawrat: 'Honor your father and your mother,' and: 'Whoever curses his father and his mother shall be executed.'

metadata.item: This is a quotation from the Tawrat, Exodus 20:12 and Deuteronomy 5:16.
This is a quotation from the Tawrat, Exodus 21:17.

verse.content: But you say: Suppose someone says to his father and his mother: 'What I was going to spend on you I have given to Allah.'
Then you say there is no need for him to honor his father. Thus you make the word of Allah worthless for the sake of your traditions.

metadata.item: Honor includes the idea of giving financial assistance.

verse.content: Hypocrites, you are the ones Allah referred to by the tongue of Shaya:
'This people honors me with their lips but their hearts are far from me.
Their worship is worthless, and their teaching is only commandments invented by people.'"

metadata.item: This is a quotation from the Tawrat, Shaya 29:17. They taught from their traditions, not from the book that Allah had given them.

verse.content: Then he called the crowd to him and said, "Listen and understand.
What enters the mouth does not make a person unclean. It is what comes out of the mouth that makes a person unclean."
The hawariyun came to him and said to him, "Do you know that the Pharisees were offended by your saying?"

metadata.item: They thought certain foods made a person unclean.

verse.content: He answered them, "Every plant that my Most Loving King, the Most High, has not planted will be uprooted.

metadata.item: This refers to the Arabic name Al-Aly, one of the 99 names of Allah.

verse.content: Ignore those blind people who lead other blind people. If a blind person leads another blind person, both of them will fall into a hole."
Peter told him, "Explain the meaning of the story to us."
He answered, "Are you still ignorant?
Do you not understand that what enters the mouth passes through the stomach and then goes out into the drain?
But what comes out of the mouth comes from the heart. That is what makes a person unclean.
Evil thoughts, murder, adultery, sin, stealing, false witness, and lies come out of the heart.
That makes a person unclean, not eating with unwashed hands."
Isa went away and withdrew to the province of Tyre and Sidon.
A Canaanite woman came to him crying, "My master, Ibn Dawood, have mercy on me. A jinni has touched my daughter severely."

metadata.item: By this phrase, this woman who was not from Bani Israil acknowledged that Isa was al-masih, the beloved amir of Allah.

verse.content: But Isa did not say a word in answer. His hawariyun begged him, "Send her away. She is shouting behind us."
He told them, "Allah sent me only to the lost sheep of the people of Bani Israil."

metadata.item: Isa was sent primarily to Bani Israil, but Isa spoke to and healed several other people who were not from Bani Israil, including the daughter of this woman.

verse.content: She came and bowed down in front of him and said, "My mawla, I beg for your help!"
He answered her, "It is not appropriate to throw the bread of the sons to the dogs."

metadata.item: Sons or children here is not literal. It refers to the chosen people, Bani Israil.

Dogs here is not literal. Al-Yahud thought that other people were unclean and they called them dogs. Isa was testing the trust of the woman in him, and to see if she would continue to trust him to heal her daughter despite the view that Al-Yahud had of other people. Isa obviously did not consider the woman and other people who were not Yahud to be dogs, but it was well-known that Al-Yahud in general did so.

verse.content: But she told him, "Yes, my mawla. But even the dogs eat what falls from the tables of their masters." Then Isa said, "Woman, your trust is great. What you want will happen." And her daughter was healed immediately.

metadata.item: The woman passed the test Isa gave her. She affirmed that she did not need the bread of the sons, but even the crumbs that fell from the "table" of Isa would be enough to heal her daughter.

verse.content: He left there and was walking on the shore of Al-Jalil Lake. Then he went up a mountain there and sat down.
Large crowds brought him many people who were lame, blind, disfigured, dumb, or had other diseases. They put them at his feet and he healed them.
The crowds were amazed when the dumb people spoke, the disfigured people were healthy, the lame people walked, and the blind people saw. They praised the glory of Allah, the Rabb of Bani Israil.

Isa called the hawariyun and told them, "I feel compassion for the crowds. They have been with me for three days, and they don't have anything to eat. I do not want to send them away hungry. If I do, they will faint on the way."
The hawariyun said to him, "Where can we find bread enough for all these multitudes in this isolated place?"
Isa asked them, "How many loaves do you have?" They said, "Seven, and a few small fish."
He commanded the crowds to sit down on the ground.
He took the loaves and the fish, praised and thanked Allah, broke them, and gave them to the hawariyun, who gave them to the crowds.
Then they all ate and were full. They gathered the leftover broken pieces, and filled seven large baskets.
There were four thousand men, not including the women and children.
After he sent the crowds away, he got in a boat, going toward the region of Magadan.

metadata.item: One old translation has Magdala, the city of Mariam Magdalene.

verse.content: The Pharisees and the Sadducees came to test him. They asked him to do an ayah from heaven.
He answered them, "At sunset, you predict moderate weather, because the sky is red.
In the morning, you predict rain, because the sky is red and cloudy. You know how to interpret the signs of the sky. Do you not know how to interpret the signs of the times?
A sinful, adulterous generation wants an ayah. But no ayah will be given to them except the ayah of Yunis." Then he left that place.

metadata.item: The meaning here is probably spiritual adultery, unfaithfulness to Allah.
Yunis came out of his grave (the fish) after three days, and then called people to repent. Either of these two things could be the meaning of the sign of Yunis.

verse.content: When the hawariyun arrived to the other shore, they had forgotten to bring their provisions of bread.
Isa told them, "Be careful! Beware of the yeast of the Pharisees and the Sadducees."
They discussed the matter among themselves and said, "That is because we forgot to take bread."
Isa realized that and said to them, "You have little trust. Why are you discussing among yourselves that you do not have bread?
Do you not understand yet? Do you not remember the five loaves for the five thousand people, and how many hand baskets you filled of the leftovers?
Or the seven loaves for the four thousand and how many baskets you filled?
How do you not understand that I was not talking about bread? Beware of the yeast of the Pharisees and the Sadducees!"

metadata.item: Here yeast has an evil meaning, and means evil teaching.

verse.content: Then they understood that he was warning them about the teaching of the Pharisees and the Sadducees, and not about yeast.
Isa entered the region of Caesarea Philippi and asked his hawariyun, "Who do people say sayyid al-bashar is?"

metadata.item: This was the favorite way Isa referred to himself. He meant "Who do people say that I am?" His use of sayyid al-bashar should have reminded them of all the ayat that Isa had done and all his sayings about sayyid al-bashar.

verse.content: They said, "Some people say that you are Yahya who did ghusl. Some people say that you are Ilyas. Some people say that you are Jeremiah or another nabi among the ancient anbiya."
He said to them, "Who do you say that I am?"
Simon Peter answered him, "You are truly al-masih, the beloved amir of Allah, the Living."

metadata.item: This refers to the Arabic name Al-Hayy, one of the 99 names of Allah.

verse.content: Isa answered him, "Simon Bar Yuna, you have a baraka. My secret was not revealed to you by human inspiration, but by inspiration of my Most Loving King who is in heaven.

metadata.item: Yuna seems to be an abbreviation for Yuhana (John 1:42). In Greek, there is no way to write the sound of an h in the middle of a word, so Yuhana in the original language would be written in Greek as Yuna.

verse.content: I tell you that you are Peter, and on this rock I will build my umma of chosen people. The gates of Jahannam will not stand against it.

metadata.item: The word rock is related to the name Peter.
Gates are defensive. Isa was saying that his umma would attack the gates of jahannam and defeat the power of Al-Shaitan.

verse.content: I will give you the keys of the kingdom of heaven. Allah will have tied in heaven what you tie on earth, and Allah will have loosened in heaven what you loosen on earth."

metadata.item: In the original language, this word also means forbidden.
This word also means allowed.

verse.content: He told the hawariyun not to tell anyone that he was the awaited al-masih.

From that time on, Isa began to reveal to his hawariyun that he was destined to go to Al-Quds and suffer many pains from the elders of the people, the leading ahbar and the fuqaha. Then he would be killed and be resurrected alive on the third day.
Peter got alone with him and started to rebuke him, "Allah forbid that you should have that destiny, my mawla!"

metadata.item: Peter was expressing the common view that al-masih was to be a victorious king. The suffering of al-masih was not clearly understood.

verse.content: Isa turned and said to Peter, "Go behind me, Al-Shaitan. You are an obstacle in my sirat. You are not interested in the things of Allah, but in the things of people!"

metadata.item: Peter was not Al-Shaitan, but Al-Shaitan had inspired these thoughts and words to Peter.

verse.content: Then Isa said to his helpers, "If anyone wants to follow me, he must deny himself and sacrifice himself, following the example of my death on the cross.
Whoever wants to save his life will lose it, and whoever loses it in my sirat will protect it.

metadata.item: While following me.

verse.content: What would a person benefit if he gained the whole world and lost his life? What can a person give as a ransom for his life?
Sayyid al-bashar will return in the majesty of the glory of his Most Loving King with his angels, and he will reward each person according to his works.

metadata.item: Isa states that he will be the judge.

verse.content: I tell you a true saying: Some of the people standing here will not taste death until they see sayyid al-bashar coming as king."

metadata.item: Some believe that this means they would not experience spiritual death and that the coming of Isa as king is still future. Others believe that the coming of sayyid al-bashar was his coming in judgment in A.D. 70.

verse.content: After six days, Isa took Peter, Yacoub, and Yahya his brother with him, led them to a high mountain, and was alone with them there.
His appearance changed in front of them, so that his face shined like the sun and his clothing was as white as light.
Suddenly, Musa and Ilyas appeared in front of them and they talked with him.
Peter told Isa, "Our mawla, it is wonderful that we are here. If you want, I will make three tents: for you, for Musa, and for Ilyas."
As he was speaking, a shining cloud came and covered them. A voice shouted out of the cloud, "This is my beloved amir. I have rida with him. Listen to him."
When the three hawariyun heard that, they fell on their faces in awe and terror.
Isa came, touched them, and said, "Stand up. Do not be afraid."
When they looked up, they only saw Isa.
While they were going down the mountain, Isa commanded them, "Do not inform anyone about this vision until sayyid al-bashar has been resurrected alive from death."
His three hawariyun asked him, "Why do the fuqaha say that the coming of Ilyas is before the coming of al-masih?"
He answered them, "Ilyas comes first and restores everything in its correct place.
But I tell you that Ilyas came and they did not know him. They did what they wanted to him. In the same way, sayyid al-bashar will suffer pain from them."
Then they understood that he was talking about Yahya who did ghusl.

metadata.item: When he referred to Ilyas. This is similar to the prophecy of Zakariyya about Yahya. See Luke 1:17.

verse.content: When they reached the crowd, a man came near Isa and kneeled in front of him. He said:
"My master, have mercy on my son. He is crazy and suffers from seizures, so that he often falls in the fire or the water.

metadata.item: Or has a jinni.

verse.content: I brought him to your hawariyun, but they were unable to heal him."
Isa answered, "Disbelieving generation that has gone astray, how long will I remain with you? How long will I put up with you? Bring him to me here."
Isa rebuked the jinni and it went out. The boy was healed instantly.
When the hawariyun were alone with Isa, they asked him, "Why were we unable to cast it out?"
He told them, "Because you have little trust. I tell you a true saying: If the amount of your trust were like a mustard seed, you would say to this mountain:

metadata.item: Either in size or in its capacity to grow.
It is unclear whether Isa was referring to a specific mountain or whether he was referring to a spiritual mountain (kingdom). This may be a reference to the Tawrat, Daniel 2:35.

verse.content: Move from here to there, and it would move. Nothing would be impossible for you."
After they gathered in Al-Jalil, Isa told his hawariyun, "Sayyid al-bashar is destined to be delivered into the hands of people.
They will kill him. Then on the third day, he will be resurrected alive." They were filled with deep sadness because of that.
Then they entered Capernaum, and a collector of taxes for the house of Allah asked Peter, "Does you teacher pay the two-dinar tax?"

metadata.item: These tax collectors were different from the detested tax collectors who worked for the Roman occupiers.

The Tawrat commanded that each person of Bani Israil pay the same amount (equal to two dinars, or two days of the wage of a laborer, in the days of Isa) for the repair and maintenance of the house of Allah every year

verse.content: He said, "Yes." Then he entered the house. Isa first asked him a question. He said, "Simon, what do you think? Do kings of the earth take a jizya from the sons of the country or from foreigners?"

metadata.item: Here and in the next verse, the word sons is not literal; it means citizens.

verse.content: He answered, "From the foreigners." So Isa said, "Then the sons are exempt.

But so that they do not take offense from us, go to the lake and throw in a hook. Open the mouth of the first fish that you catch. You will find a four-dinar coin. Take it and pay the tax for me and for you."
At that time, the hawariyun came to Isa and they asked him, "Who is the greatest person in the kingdom of heaven?"
He called a child to him, had him stand in the middle of them,
and said, "I tell you a true saying: If you are not transformed and do not become like children, you will never enter the kingdom of heaven at all.

metadata.item: Or if you do not turn.

verse.content: Whoever humbles himself like this child is the greatest person in the kingdom of heaven.
Whoever receives a child like this one in my name receives me.
Suppose someone misleads one of these believing children. It would be better for him if a heavy mill stone were attached to his neck, and he would be drowned in the depths of the sea.
Woe to the world for its temptations. Temptations are bound to come, but woe to anyone who causes them!

If your hand or your foot makes you commit a sin, cut if off and throw it away. Entering life in Al-Janna with a limb cut off is better than being thrown in the fire of Jahannam with both feet and hands.
If your eye makes you commit a sin, pull it out and throw it away. Entering life in Al-Janna with one eye is better than being thrown in the fire of Jahannam with both eyes.
Watch out that you do not think lightly of one of these little ones. Their angels in heaven are always in the presence of my Most Loving King in heaven.
What do you think? Suppose someone has a hundred sheep and one sheep goes astray and is lost.
Will he not leave the ninety-nine on the mountain to look for the lost sheep?

metadata.item: He would have made sure the sheep were safe before leaving them. This may have been in a pen with a helper (sheep were counted when entering a pen by the one door). Or this may have been a safe place. A sheep by itself that was away from the shepherd had no safety. He knew that they were exactly ninety-nine sheep and not one hundred. This shows that he had counted them, probably as they entered the sheep pen.

verse.content: I tell you a true saying: When he finds it, he will be happier about it than he is about the ninety-nine which were not lost.
Thus your Most Merciful King in heaven does not will that that any of these little ones be destroyed.
Suppose your brother sins against you. Go to him and rebuke him, between you and him. If he listens to you, you have won your brother.

metadata.item: Brother in this passage is not literal. It refers to a fellow follower of Isa.

verse.content: Suppose he does not listen to you. Then take a brother or two with you. Then every matter will be confirmed by the tongue of two or three witnesses.
Suppose he does not listen to them. Then tell the matter to the umma of chosen people. If he does not listen to the umma either, ostracize him like a kafir or a detested tax collector.
I tell you a true saying: Allah will have tied in heaven whatever you tie on the earth. Allah will have loosened in heaven whatever you loosen on the earth.

metadata.item: Or forbid.
Or permit.

verse.content: I tell you another true saying: If two people among you on earth agree about any matter when they pray in dua', my Most Loving King in heaven will answer them.
Whenever two or three people gather in my name, I will be in the middle of them."
Peter came to him and asked him, "My mawla, how many times must I pardon my brother if he does wrong to me? As many as seven times?"

metadata.item: The Pharisees said three.

verse.content: Isa told him, "I tell you, not seven times, but seventy times seven!
Therefore, the kingdom of heaven is like a king who wanted to settle accounts with his slaves.
He summoned one of them who owed him sixty million silver dinars.

metadata.item: This amount was more than the wealth of anyone on earth at this time. It was the equivalent of the wages of a laborer for 150,000 years. In the original language, it was the largest number (ten thousand) of the largest amount of money (a talent of silver, or about 30 kilograms, equivalent to the amount of money a laborer would make in 15 years.

verse.content: Since he was unable to pay, his master ordered that he, his wife, his children, and everything he owned be sold to pay his debt.
The slave threw himself down, kneeled in front of him, and begged him: Give me more time, and I will pay you the whole amount!

metadata.item: More time would not have helped pay this huge debt.

verse.content: His master had compassion on him, pardoned him, released him from the debt, and let him go.
That slave went out and found another fellow slave, who owed him one hundred dinars. He grabbed him by his neck and said: Pay me what you owe!

metadata.item: 100 dinars was the wage of a laborer for one hundred days.

verse.content: His fellow slave threw himself in front of him and begged him: Give me more time, and I will pay you the amount!

metadata.item: Given enough time, this debt could have been paid.

verse.content: But he refused. He threw him in prison until he paid his debt.

metadata.item: This was a common practice at the time.

verse.content: When his other fellow slaves saw what he did, they were very disturbed and informed their master of everything that had happened.
His master summoned the first slave and told him: You wicked slave! I pardoned you your whole debt because you begged me.
Was it not appropriate for you to have mercy on your fellow slave as I was merciful to you?
So his master was angry with him. He delivered him to torturers until he paid his whole debt.

metadata.item: This is the end of the story. What follows is the comment of Isa about this situation.

verse.content: This is what my Most Loving King, the Most High, will do to every one of you who does not pardon his brother from his heart."
After Isa finished his stories, he left Al-Jalil and went to Yahudia province and the East Bank.
Large crowds followed him, and he healed them.
The Pharisees came to him to test him. They asked him, "Is it halal to divorce a spouse for any reason?"

metadata.item: There were two common views at that time: 1) That a man could divorce his wife for any reason, and 2) That there were very few reasons a man could divorce his wife.

verse.content: He answered them, "Did you not read what Allah revealed in the Tawrat? He created mankind male and female from the beginning.
Allah said: Because of that, a man leaves his father and his mother and is united to his wife. The two become one body.
They are no longer two, but one body. So what Allah has joined, people should not separate."
They asked him, "Then why did Musa command in the Tawrat that a husband should give his wife a certificate of divorce and send her away?"

metadata.item: In the Tawrat, Allah commanded Musa that [if]{.underline} a man divorced his wife, he should give her a certificate of divorce, so she would be free to marry someone else. Allah regulated divorce but did not command it or approve of it. See the Tawrat, Deuteronomy 24:1-4, Malachi 2:16.

verse.content: He told them, "Allah revealed to Musa to allow you to divorce your wives because of the hardness of your hearts. But the matter was not like that from the beginning.
I tell you, whoever divorces his wife except if she was not a virgin, and then marries another, has committed adultery."
The hawariyun said, "If that is the way it is, being single is better than being married."
He answered them, "The people Allah has given this to are the only ones who can accept this.

metadata.item: This ability to be single and still follow Allah obediently.

verse.content: Some people were born incapable of marrying. Some people have been castrated. And some people refrain from marriage in the sirat of the kingdom of heaven. Whoever is able to accept this matter should accept it."
People brought their children to him so that he would touch them and pray in dua' for them. So the hawariyun rebuked them.
But Isa said, "Let the children come to me, and do not forbid them, because the kingdom of heaven belongs to little ones like these."
Then he put his hands on them and left that place.
Someone came to him and asked him, "Teacher, what should I do to inherit a portion in eternal spiritual life?"

metadata.item: This is an unusual question, because a person does not inherit based on what he does, but based on his relationship.

verse.content: He said to him, "Why do you ask me about good deeds? No one is righteous except Allah, the One. If you want to enter the life of Al-Janna, follow the commandments of Allah."

metadata.item: There is no way to become righteous by doing good deeds. A person must trust in Allah.

This refers to the Arabic name Al-Ahad, one of the 99 names of Allah. In a sense, Isa was challenging him, "If I am from Allah, then my teachings are from Allah and you must obey me. If you are just flattering me by calling me good, I do not care about flattery.

verse.content: He asked, "Which commandments?" Isa said, "Do not murder, do not commit adultery, do not steal, do not give false witness,

metadata.item: This is a quotation from the Tawrat, Exodus 20:13 and Deuteronomy 5:17.
This is a quotation from the Tawrat, Exodus 20:14 and Deuteronomy 5:18.
This is a quotation from the Tawrat, Exodus 20:15 and Deuteronomy 5:19.
This is a quotation from the Tawrat, Exodus 20:16 and Deuteronomy 5:20.

verse.content: honor your father and your mother, and love your neighbor as yourself."

metadata.item: This is a quotation from the Tawrat, Exodus 20:12 and Deuteronomy 5:16.
This is a quotation from the Tawrat, Leviticus 19:18.

verse.content: The young man said to him, "I have kept all of these. What else do I lack?"
Isa told him, "If you want to be perfect, go and sell all your possessions and donate them to poor people. You will then have a treasure in Al-Janna. Then come and follow me."
But when he heard this, the young man went away sadly, because he had many possessions.

metadata.item: Isa did not mention all of the commandments of Allah to the young man. It seems that the young man worshipped money in his heart. This was disobedience to the command "Worship Allah only." (The Tawrat, Exodus 20:3)

verse.content: So Isa told his followers, "I tell you a true saying: It is hard for rich people to enter the kingdom of heaven!
I also say that for a camel to enter the eye of a needle is easier than for a rich person to enter the kingdom of heaven."
When his followers heard this, they were greatly amazed and asked him, "Then who can be saved?"

metadata.item: It was commonly thought that riches were a sign of the barakat, acceptance, and favor of Allah.

verse.content: Isa looked at them and answered, "That is impossible for people, but Allah can do everything."
Then Peter told him, "We have left everything and followed you. What will our portion be?"

Isa told them, "I tell you a true saying: Sayyid al-bashar will sit on the throne of the majesty of his glory in the renewal in the next life. Then you, my followers, will sit on twelve thrones. From there, you will judge the twelve tribes of Bani Israil.

Suppose someone leaves houses, brothers, sisters, a father, a mother, children, or lands in the sirat of my name. His reward will be one hundred times as much. And he will inherit eternal spiritual life in Al-Janna.
But many first people will be last. And many last people will be first."
"The kingdom of heaven is like the owner of a vineyard. He went out at sunrise to hire laborers for his vineyard.
He agreed with the laborers to pay them one dinar per day. And he sent them into his vineyard.

metadata.item: This was the standard wage for laborers.

verse.content: Then he went out three hours later. He found other laborers standing in the market.
He told them: Go to my vineyard, and I will pay you what you deserve. So they went.
He went out at noon and midafternoon and did the same thing.
Before sunset, he went out and found other laborers standing. He asked them: Why are you standing here all day without work?
They said: No one has hired us. He told them: You also go to the vineyard.

metadata.item: Maybe none of the people who needed laborers that day had hired them, so their labor was almost worthless, or maybe they were lazy and did not arrive at the workplace until very late.

verse.content: When evening came, the owner of the vineyard told his manager: Call the laborers and pay them their wages, starting with the last laborers and ending with the first laborers.
The last laborers, whom he had hired before sunset, each received a dinar.
When the first laborers came, they expected that they would receive more. But each one of them received a dinar also.
When they received the dinar, they complained to the owner of the vineyard. They said:
These laborers only worked one hour, but you made them equal to us who bore the heat and exhaustion of the whole day.
The owner of the vineyard answered one of them: I did not cheat you, my brother. Did we not agree on a dinar?
Take what you are owed and Allah be with you. I want to give the last one the same wage that I give you.

metadata.item: This is a polite way of saying, "Leave."

verse.content: Am I not free to do what I want with my money? Or is your eye evil because I am generous?

metadata.item: Having an evil eye is similar to being jealous, envious, or greedy.

verse.content: Thus the last ones will be first, and the first ones will be last."
As they were going up to Al-Quds, Isa talked alone with his twelve hawariyun on the road,
"We are going up to Al-Quds, and sayyid al-bashar will be delivered to the leading ahbar and the fuqaha. They will condemn him to be executed.
They will deliver him to the nations of the kuffar, who will mock him, whip him, and crucify him. But on the third day, he will be resurrected alive."

metadata.item: Isa knew hidden things, including the future.

verse.content: Then the mother of the sons of Zebedee and her two sons came to him and bowed in front of him. She asked him for a favor.
He said to her, "What do you want?" She answered, "Command that one son of mine will sit on your right and the other on your left in your kingdom."
Isa answered her sons, "You do not know what you are asking. Are you able to drink the cup that I will drink?" They answered, "We are able."

metadata.item: Isa apparently knew that Yacoub and Yahya had asked their mother to make the request of Isa.

verse.content: He told them, "You will drink the cup of my pains, but the privilege of sitting on my right and my left is not something I grant. My Most Loving King grants that to the people he has chosen."
The rest of the ten hawariyun heard about that, and they were angry at the two brothers.
So Isa called them and told them, "You know that the nations of the kuffar rule over their nations, and their leaders control those nations.
But you should not be that way. If a person wants greatness among you, he should be your servant.
If a person wants to be first, he should be your slave.
This is like sayyid al-bashar. He did not come for people to serve him. He came to serve them, and to sacrifice his life as a ransom for many people."
When they left Jericho, large crowds accompanied them.
Two blind men sitting by the road heard that Isa was passing by them. They shouted, "Our master, Ibn Dawood, have mercy on us!"

metadata.item: Their calling Isa Ibn Dawood showed that they believed he was al-masih, the expected king of Bani Israil, who had authority from Allah.

verse.content: The crowds rebuked them so that they would be quiet. But they shouted even louder, "Our master, Ibn Dawood, have mercy on us!"
Isa stopped and called them. He said, "What do you want from me?"
They told him, "Our master, we want you to open our eyes."
Isa had compassion on them and touched their eyes. Then immediately they could see again. So they followed him.
They approached Al-Quds, and arrived at the village of Bethphage, at the entrance of Jabal Al-Zaytun. He sent two hawariyun
and told them, "Enter the village that is in front of you. Immediately you will find a female donkey tied there, along with a colt. Untie them and bring them both to me.
If anyone tells you anything, say: The master needs them and will return them immediately."
Because of this, what Allah had said by the tongue of the nabi was fulfilled:
"Tell the inhabitants of Al-Quds: Look! Your king is coming to you. He is meek and riding on a female donkey and a donkey's colt."

metadata.item: This is a quotation from the Tawrat, Zakariyya 9:9. Kings of Bani Israil were announced by riding a donkey or mule.

verse.content: The two hawariyun went and did what Isa commanded them.
They brought the female donkey and the colt, his followers put their cloaks on them, and Isa rode.

metadata.item: This is one way of honoring a person.

verse.content: Most of the crowd put their cloaks on the road, and others cut branches and put them on the road.

metadata.item: These are also ways of honoring him.

verse.content: The crowd in front of him and behind him shouted, "Al-hamdu Lillah, the Savior, in the highest place!"

metadata.item: In the original language, this word was Hosanna (Allah, save us!).

verse.content: He entered Al-Quds, and the whole city was stirred. Everyone was asking each other, "Who is this?"
The multitudes were saying, "This is Isa, the nabi of Allah, who is from Al-Nasira in Al-Jalil."
Then Isa entered the house of Allah and cast out the sellers and buyers from it. He turned over the tables of the moneychangers and the chairs of the sellers of pigeons.
He told them, "Allah revealed in his kitab: My house will be called a house of salat, but you are making it a cave for thieves."

metadata.item: This is a quotation from the Tawrat, Shaya 56:7.
This is a reference to the Tawrat, Jeremiah 7:11.

verse.content: There in the house of Allah, blind and lame people came to him and he healed them.

The leading ahbar and fuqaha saw his amazing miracles. They also heard the children shouting in the house of Allah, "Al-hamdu Lillah for Ibn Dawood, the expected king!" This made the ahbar and the fuqaha angry,

and they asked him, "Do you not hear what they are saying?" He told them, "Yes. Have you not read what is in the Zabur? Allah said: I have brought the best praise from the mouths of children and infants."

metadata.item: This is a reference to the Zabur, Psalms 8:2.

verse.content: Then he left them and went from the city to Bethany. He spend that night there.
On his way back to the city in the morning, Isa felt hungry.
He saw a fig tree beside the road and went toward it. But he did not find anything on it except leaves. He told it, "You will never produce fruit again." So the fig tree dried up immediately.

metadata.item: In these verses, the fig tree represents Bani Israil, who should have had the fruits of repentance.
This act may have been a prophecy of what was going to happen to Bani Israil in A.D. 70.

verse.content: The hawariyun were amazed at the sight. So they asked, "How did the fig tree dry up immediately?"

Isa answered them, "I tell you a true saying: If you have trust and no doubt, you will not only do what I have done to the fig tree. If you say to this mountain: 'Move, and be thrown into the sea,' that will happen."

metadata.item: Mountains sometimes represent kingdoms. See the Tawrat, Daniel 2:35.

verse.content: Whatever you pray in dua' with trust will be answered for you."

When he entered the house of Allah and began to teach, the leading ahbar and the elders of the people came toward him. They said to him, "What authority do you have to do these actions? Who gave you this authority?"
Isa answered them, "I will ask you one question. If you answer me, I will answer you about the source of my authority.

What was the source of the ghusl of repentance that Yahya brought? Was is from Allah or from people?" They discussed the matter among themselves. They said, "If we say: 'Allah was the source,' he will say: 'Why did you not believe him?'
But if we say: 'People were the source,' we are afraid of the reaction of the people. Everyone considers Yahya a nabi."
So they answered Isa, "We do not know." So he said to them, "And I will not inform you about the source of my authority.
Now what do you think? A man had two sons. He came to the first and told him: My son, go and work in my vineyard today.
He answered: I don't want to. But later he regretted it and went.
Then the father came to the younger son and told him the same thing. He answered: Yes, sir, I will go. But he did not go.

Which one of them did the will of his father?" They said, "The older one." Isa said, "I tell you a true saying: The detested tax collectors and the prostitutes will enter the kingdom of Allah before you do.
Yahya came on al-sirat al-mustaqim and you did not believe him, but the detested tax collectors and the prostitutes believed him. And even when you saw that, you did not repent and believe him.
Listen to another story: A landowner planted a vineyard, put a hedge around it, dug a winepress, built a watch tower, and then rented it to farmers and traveled.
When the season for grapes approached, he sent a delegation of his slaves to the farmers to bring him his portion of the fruit.
But the farmers grabbed the slaves. They beat some slaves, killed some slaves, and stoned other slaves.
So the owner of the vineyard sent a large delegation of slaves, and the farmers treated them the same way.

metadata.item: The Arabic word used is Rabb, which generally means Allah. In this story, the owner gives a picture of Allah.

verse.content: Finally he sent his son. He said: They will respect my son.
When the farmers saw him, they said: This is the heir. Come! Let us kill him and take his inheritance.
So they grabbed him and threw him out of the vineyard and killed him.
When the owner of the vineyard comes, what do you think he will do to those farmers?"
They answered, "He will torture those wicked people painfully and destroy them. Then he will rent the vineyard to other farmers who will give him his portion every harvest season."

So Isa asked them, "Did you not read what is in the kitab of Allah? 'The stone which the builders rejected has become the pinnacle of the building. This is from Rabb Al-Alamin. In our sight it is wonderful.'

metadata.item: This is a quotation from the Zabur, Psalms 118:22-23

verse.content: For this reason, Allah will withdraw the right to belong to his kingdom from you and give it to an umma that produces fruit for him.

metadata.item: Repentance. See Matthew 3:2,8.

verse.content: Whoever falls on this stone will be smashed. And if the stone falls on anyone, he will be crushed."
The leading ahbar and the Pharisees heard his stories, and they realized his was referring to them.

metadata.item: They were the younger son who said he would obey and did not. They were also the farmers who killed the slaves (anbiya) that Allah sent.

verse.content: So they tried to arrest him. But they were afraid of the crowd, who considered him a nabi.
Again, he told stories to people. He said,
"The kingdom of Allah is like a king who held a banquet on the occasion of the wedding of his son.
He sent his slaves to call those who had accepted his invitation to the banquet, but those people refused to come.

metadata.item: There were two invitations. The initial invitation was sent when the event was planned. The other was sent only to those who had accepted the first invitation when the feast was ready to eat.

verse.content: So he sent other slaves, saying: Tell the people who were invited: I have prepared the dinner. I have slaughtered the bulls and the feed calves. Everything is ready. Come to the banquet.
But they ignored the matter. One went to his farm, and another to his business.
The rest grabbed the slaves of the king, insulted them, and killed them.
The king was angry. He sent his soldiers, who destroyed those murderers and burned their city.
Then he told his slaves: The wedding banquet is ready, but the people who were invited were not worthy of it.
Go to the main roads and invite everyone you find to the banquet.
So they went to the streets and gathered everyone they found in the road, whether they were unrighteous or righteous. Thus the wedding hall was filled with guests.
The king entered to check on the guests. He saw a man who was not wearing a wedding robe.

metadata.item: The host of a banquet provided robes to anyone who did not have one. This person had rejected the provision of the king and decided he wanted to wear his own, regular clothes instead of the king's wedding robe.

verse.content: He asked him: 'Our friend, how did you enter the hall without putting on the wedding robe?' He was silent.
The king ordered his guards: 'Tie his hands and his feet, and throw him into the outer darkness, where people will cry and grind their teeth.'

metadata.item: This is a picture of jahannam.

verse.content: Many people are called, but few of them are chosen."
So the Pharisees went out and conspired to catch him in a word he would say.

So they sent their followers with members of the party of Herod. They said, "Teacher, we know that you are honest. You teach al-sirat al-mustaqim of Allah with truth. The opinions of people do not matter to you, and you do not pay attention to the positions of people.

metadata.item: The Pharisees were against paying the jizya to Caesar, and the party of Herod supported paying it.

verse.content: So tell us your opinion: Is it halal to pay the jizya to Caesar or not?"
Isa understood their malice and said, "You hypocrites, why are you testing me?

metadata.item: One group would have a complaint against him whether he answered yes or no.

verse.content: Show me the coin of the jizya." So they brought him a dinar.
He said to them, "To whom do this picture and this motto belong?"

metadata.item: The dinar used among Al-Yahud in those days in Palestine had no pictures of people or slogans of devotion to them (like Caesar, the emperor) in deference to the monotheistic beliefs of Al-Yahud against idolatry. The enemies of Isa may have hoped to shock Isa and embarrass him. By asking this question, Isa exposed their malice.

verse.content: They said, "To Caesar." So he told them, "Then give to Caesar what he has the right to, and give Allah what Allah has the right to."
When they heard that, they were amazed. They left him and went on their way.

metadata.item: They thought that they had trapped Isa.

verse.content: The Sadducees, who deny Yawm Al-Din, asked him on the same day,
"Teacher, Allah said by the tongue of Musa: 'If a man dies and has no children, his brother must marry his widow to give a descendant to his dead brother.'

metadata.item: Or sons.
This is a reference to the Tawrat, Deuteronomy 24:1.

verse.content: There were seven brothers among us. The oldest one married and died with no descendants. He left his widow to his brother.
The same thing happened with the second, the third, and on to the seventh.
Finally the woman died.
In the next life, at the resurrection, whose wife will she be? All of them married her."
Then Isa answered them, "You have gone astray because you are ignorant of the kitab and the power of Allah.
In the next life, after the resurrection, men do not marry, and women are not given in marriage. Rather, they live forever, like angels in Al-Janna.

metadata.item: So they do not need to marry or propagate.

verse.content: As for the resurrection of the dead, did you not read what Allah told you in the Tawrat?
Allah said: 'I am the Rabb of Ibrahim and the Rabb of Ishaq and the Rabb of Yacoub.' Allah is not the Rabb of dead people. He is the Rabb of living people."

metadata.item: This is a quotation from the Tawrat, Exodus 3:6.
Allah had not said, "I [was]{.underline} the Rabb of Ibrahim..."

verse.content: When the crowds heard this, they were amazed at his teaching.
When the Pharisees heard that he had silenced the Sadducees, they gathered.

metadata.item: This made the Pharisees happy, because the Pharisees disagreed with the Sadducees.

verse.content: One of the scholars of the Tawrat asked him a question to test him,
"Teacher, what is the greatest commandment in the Tawrat?"
He told him, "Love Allah your Mawla with all your heart and with all your soul and with all your mind.

metadata.item: This is a quotation from the Tawrat, Deuteronomy 6:5.

verse.content: This is the first and greatest of the commandments.

metadata.item: Or most important.

verse.content: The second is like it: Love your neighbor as yourself.

metadata.item: This is a quotation from the Tawrat, Leviticus 19:18. Both commandments talk about loving others.

verse.content: These two commandments are the pillars of all the Tawrat and all the scrolls of the anbiya."
Then Isa asked the Pharisees who were gathered,
"What is your opinion about the expected al-masih? Whose son is he?" They answered, "The son of Dawood."

metadata.item: Or Ibn Dawood.

verse.content: He said, "Then how does Dawood call him 'Mawla' by the inspiration of Holy Ruh Allah? He said,
'Al-Mawla said to my mawla: Sit at my right side until I put your enemies under your feet.'

metadata.item: The is a quotation from the Zabur, Psalms 110:1

verse.content: If Dawood calls him 'My mawla', how can he be his son?"

metadata.item: They reasoned that a son was inferior and a mawla was superior.

verse.content: No one was able to answer him with a word. So from that time on, no one had the courage to ask him anything.
Then Isa spoke to the crowds and his followers. He said,
"The fuqaha and the Pharisees are sitting on the seat of Musa to teach you.
So do according to what they say. Be committed to it, but do not imitate their lifestyle, because they say things but do not do them.

metadata.item: Some ancient texts have, "Do whatever he says," referring to what Musa says.

verse.content: They tie heavy burdens and put them on the shoulders of people. But they do not move one finger to help them.
They pretend to be pious so that people will see everything they do. They put turbans on their heads and wear long robes.

metadata.item: They did this to appear religious or pious.

verse.content: They love the seats of honor in the banquets, the first row in the houses of salat,
greetings and respect from people in the markets, and being addressed with the title 'Honored teacher.'

metadata.item: All of these things show that the Pharisees really wanted the rida of people, not the rida of Allah.

verse.content: As for you, do not let people call you 'Honored teacher,' because you have only one teacher, and you are all brothers.

metadata.item: This may refer to Allah, Holy Ruh Allah, or the Tawrat.

verse.content: Do not call anyone on earth a father to you, because you have only one guardian, your Most Merciful King who is in heaven.

metadata.item: Or spiritual father

verse.content: Do not let people call you 'masters', because you have only one master, al-masih.
The greatest among you should be a servant to you.
Allah brings down whoever raises himself up, and raises up whoever humbles himself.

metadata.item: This is an allusion to 1 Samuel 2:7. Al-Rafi (Raiser) and Al-Khafid (Lowerer) are two of the 99 names of Allah.

verse.content: Woe to you, fuqaha and Pharisees, you hypocrites! You close the gates of the kingdom of heaven in the faces of people.
You do not enter, and you do not let anyone else enter.
Woe to you, fuqaha and Pharisees, you hypocrites! You travel on sea and on land to win one follower to yourselves. Then you make him worthy of Jahannam twice as much as you are.
Woe to you, blind guides. You say that it is not a problem if someone swears by the house of Allah. But you say that if someone swears by the gold of the house of Allah, his oath must be kept.
Blind fools, which is greater? Is it the gold or the house of Allah that makes the gold holy?
You say that it is not a problem if someone swears by the altar. But you say that if someone swears by the qurban that is presented on the altar, his oath must be kept.
Blind people, which is greater? Is it the qurban or the altar that makes the qurban holy?
Whoever swears by the altar swears by it and what is on it.
Whoever swears by the house of Allah swears by it and by Allah who lives in it.
Whoever swears by heaven swears by the throne of Allah and the one who sits on it.

Woe to you, fuqaha and Pharisees, you hypocrites! You give zakat on mint, dill and cumin, but you neglect the most important things in the Tawrat: justice, mercy, and honesty. You should have done the first ones without neglecting the others.
Blind guides, you strain water so you do not swallow mosquitos, yet you swallow a camel.

metadata.item: You give zakat on garden spices.
You ignore justice, mercy, and honesty, the main themes of the Tawrat.

verse.content: Woe to you, fuqaha and Pharisees, you hypocrites! You are careful to make sure that cups and plates are tahir from the outside, but inside they are full of forbidden food and greed.

metadata.item: Isa was probably referring to their lives, which looked tahir from the outside, but were actually unclean.

verse.content: Blind Pharisee, first make the cup tahir from the inside, and the outside will be tahir also.
Woe to you, fuqaha and Pharisees, you hypocrites! You are like graves that are beautiful and shining from the outside, but their insides are full of bones of dead people and all kinds of uncleanness.

metadata.item: Your outward appearance is tahir.
Bones of dead people were unclean. See Tawrat, Numbers 19:11.

verse.content: Thus your outsides appear straight to people, but your insides are full of hypocrisy and sin.
Woe to you, fuqaha and Pharisees, you hypocrites! You build the memorials of the anbiya, and decorate the graves of righteous people.
You say, "If we had lived in the ages of our fathers, we would not have participated with them in shedding the blood of the anbiya.

metadata.item: The word fathers is not literal. Here it means ancestors.

verse.content: Thus you testify against yourself that you are children of killers of anbiya.

metadata.item: The word children is not literal. I means either literal descendants or a following generation.

verse.content: Then complete what your fathers began. Let their measure overflow.

metadata.item: The word fathers is not literal. It means either literal ancestors or a previous generation.

verse.content: Serpents, you sons of snakes, how will you be rescued from the punishment of Jahannam?

metadata.item: The word sons is not literal. It means people who have the qualities of a snake: cunning, evil, and malice.

verse.content: Therefore, I send you anbiya, wise men, and fuqaha. You will kill and crucify some of them, whip some of them in your houses of salat, and persecute them from one town to another.

metadata.item: Isa and some of the hawariyun were killed by being crucified.

verse.content: Thus the shedding of the blood of all righteous people will fall upon you, from the blood of Habil to Zakariyya, whom you killed between the house of Allah and the altar of the haram.

metadata.item: Habil son of Adam was the first person murdered. His brother Qabil was angry with him when his qurban was not accepted and the qurban of Habil was accepted, so he killed him. This story is in the Tawrat, Genesis 4.

This Zakariyya was a nabi in the Tawrat, not the father of Yahya. He was the last person recorded in the Tawrat to be murdered. Thus Isa was saying "From the first to the last murder." The last murder (of a man named Zakariyya) recorded in the Tawrat in its original order is in 2 Chronicles 24:20-21.
Note this is the haram (holy place), not haraam (forbidden).

verse.content: I tell you a true saying: Everything they have done will fall upon this generation.

metadata.item: In A.D. 70, this prophecy was fulfilled and Al-Quds was destroyed by the Romans.

verse.content: Al-Quds, Al-Quds, you kill anbiya and stone rusul! How many times I wanted to hug your children as a hen hugs her chicks under her wings, but you refused!

metadata.item: The word you is not literal. Here it refers to the people who lived in Al-Quds.

verse.content: Look, your house is deserted and destroyed!

metadata.item: Isa spoke these words about A.D. 30. This is another prophecy that was fulfilled in A.D. 70.

verse.content: I tell you: You will not see me any more until you give shahada: The one who comes in the name of Rabb Al-Alamin has a baraka!"

metadata.item: This was a greeting given to the person acknowledged as al-masih. It is a reference to the Zabur, Psalms 118:26.

verse.content: When Isa was leaving the house of Allah, his hawariyun came to him and pointed out the buildings of the house of Allah to him.
He said to them, "Do you see these buildings? I tell you a true saying: No stone will be left on another stone. They will all be destroyed."
When Isa was sitting on Jabal Al-Zaytun, the hawariyun came to him alone and said, "Tell us when these things will happen. And what will be the sign of your coming and of the end?"

metadata.item: Some people understand 'end' to mean the end of the world at Yawm Al-Din. Others think it is a reference to the end of Bani Israil as a nation, which happened in A.D. 70.

verse.content: Isa answered them, "Beware! Do not let anyone mislead you!
Many will come and claim in my name: I am the expected al-masih! They will mislead many people.
Be careful that you are not afraid when you hear about wars and about rumors of wars. These things must happen, but the end will not be yet.
One umma will rise up against another umma, and one kingdom will rise up against another kingdom. There will be earthquakes and famines in many countries.
But these are only the beginning of the birth pangs.
Then they will deliver you to be tortured and executed. All nations will hate you because of my name.
Many will fall away and betray and hate each other.
Many dujjals will prophesy and mislead many people.
Because of all the evil that will happen, the love of most people will become cold.
But whoever is patient and firm until the end will be saved.
Then the good news of the kingdom of Allah will be announced as a shahada to all the nations of the inhabited world. After that the end will come.
Suppose you see the disgusting destruction that Allah spoke about by the tongue of nabi Daniel standing in the haram of the house of Allah. (Reader, make sure you understand.)

metadata.item: See note at 23:35.

verse.content: Then whoever is in Yahudia should flee to the mountains.
Whoever is on the roof should not go down to his house to take anything.

metadata.item: Roofs were flat and were sometimes used as extra rooms or for sleeping.

verse.content: Whoever is in the field should not return to take his cloak.

metadata.item: The emphasis in both examples is that people should flee as soon as possible.

verse.content: Woe to the pregnant and nursing women in those days!

metadata.item: Women who were pregnant or nursing would not be able to flee quickly.

verse.content: Pray in dua' to Allah that the trial of that fleeing would not be in the winter or on Al-Sabt.

metadata.item: In winter, travel was more difficult and sometimes roads were washed out.
On Al-Sabt, long distance travel was prohibited. Public transportation may not have been available either.

verse.content: Great trials will happen that have never happened since the beginning of the universe until now. And nothing similar will happen in the future.
If the period of those days had not been shortened, no one would have been saved. But for the sake of the people Allah has chosen, those days will be shortened.
Then suppose someone tells you: Al-masih is here! Or: He is there! Do not believe him.
Dajjals who claim to be al-masih and dajjals who prophesy will do ayat and amazing, lying miracles to mislead even the chosen people (if they could).
I have told you in advance. So be careful.
Suppose they tell you: 'He is in the wilderness!' Do not go out. Suppose they say: 'He is in the inner rooms.' Do not believe them.
The coming of sayyid al-bashar will be like lightning, which shines from the east to the west.
Birds of prey gather around a corpse.
Then, immediately after the trials of those days, the sun will be darkened and the light of the moon will be hidden. The stars will fall, and the powers of heaven will be shaken.

At that time, the ayah of sayyid al-bashar will appear in the sky. And all the tribes of the earth will mourn. You will see sayyid al-bashar coming on the clouds of the sky. He will be mighty, glorious, and majestic.

metadata.item: This is a reference to the Tawrat, Daniel 7:13-14

verse.content: He will send his angels blowing the trumpet. They will gather the chosen people from every part of this world, from the end of the earth to the end of heaven.
Learn this lesson from the story of the fig tree. When this tree has buds and leaves, you know that summer is near.

metadata.item: This happened in spring.

verse.content: So when you see all these ayat happening, know that sayyid al-bashar is near, at the door.
I tell you a true saying: This generation will not disappear until all these things happen.

metadata.item: Isa spoke these things in about A.D. 30 and they happened in the period A.D. 67-70.

verse.content: The heavens and the earth will disappear but my words will never disappear.
But no one knows the day or the hour that it will happen. The angels do not know, and even the beloved amir does not know. The Most Merciful King alone knows everything.
The coming of sayyid al-bashar will be like it was in the days of Nuh.
In the days before the flood, people kept eating, drinking, getting married, and being given in marriage.

metadata.item: The men.
The women.

verse.content: But on the day Nuh entered the ark, people were ignorant until the flood came and took them all. The coming of sayyid al-bashar will be this way.

metadata.item: The large boat that nabi Nuh prepared. By it he rescued his family and the animals. This is recorded in the Tawrat, Genesis 6-8.
Here and in the rest of this passage, the word "take" or "took" means destroy or destroyed.

verse.content: There will be two men in a field. One of them will be taken and the other will be left.
Two women will be grinding wheat at a mill. One of them will be taken and the other will be left.
Remain alert, because you do not know the timing of the coming of your mawla.

metadata.item: The coming of Isa is compared to the destruction that happened in the days of Nuh. Some people believe that the "coming" of Isa referred to when Al-Quds was destroyed in 70 A.D.

verse.content: Be certain: Suppose the owner of a house knew what hour of the night the thief was coming to him. He would have made preparations and would not have allowed him to break into his house.
So be prepared. Sayyid al-bashar will come to you at an hour you do not expect.
A master appoints a wise, faithful slave to be responsible for the servants in the house, to feed them on time.
When his master comes and finds him doing his work, he will get a baraka.
I tell you a true saying: His master will appoint him to be responsible for all his possessions.
However, suppose the slave is wicked and says to himself: 'My master will be delayed in returning.'
Then he starts to beat the other slaves, eat, drink, and get drunk.
His master will return on a day he does not expect, and at an hour he does not know.
His master will tear him in pieces and throw him into the fire with the hypocrites, and people will cry and grind their teeth."
"At that time, the kingdom of Allah will be like ten girls that carried their lamps and went out to meet the groom.

metadata.item: The Arabic word for girls implies that they were virgins.
All the attendees of a wedding would go out to meet the groom when he came for the bride. These girls were attendees, not brides. The groom sometimes came at night, when lamps were necessary.

verse.content: Five of them were ignorant. The other five were wise.
The ignorant girls carried their lamps, but did not bring oil for fuel.

metadata.item: The oil may symbolized Holy Ruh Allah.

verse.content: The wise girls brought their lamps and oil in a container.
The groom came late, and the girls all became drowsy and slept.
At midnight someone called: The groom has come! Come out to meet him!
The girls awakened and prepared their lamps.
The ignorant girls told the wise girls: Give us some of your oil. Our lamps are being extinguished.
But the wise girls answered: No. Maybe the oil we have will not be enough for us and you together. You go to the traders and buy oil for yourselves.
So they went to buy oil. While they went, the groom came, the girls who were prepared went in to the wedding banquet, and the door was closed.
Later, the other girls came and called: Our master, our master, open the door for us!
He answered them: I tell you a true saying: 'I do not know you.'
Be awake, because you do not know the day or the hour.
That is like a man who wanted to travel. He summoned his slaves and gave them responsibility for his money.

He gave one slave responsibility over thirty thousand silver dinars. He gave the second responsibility over twelve thousand. He gave the third responsibility over six thousand. He gave each slave an amount according to his ability. Then he traveled.

metadata.item: All the sums in this passage are expressed in the original language in terms of the largest money unit used then, the talent, which was worth six thousand silver dinars, or about 20 years wages of a laborer. In the original language, the terms used were one talent, two talents, five talents, etc.

verse.content: The first went immediately, traded with the thirty thousand, and gained thirty thousand more.

metadata.item: In modern words, he opened a business.

verse.content: The second gained twelve thousand more.
But the third took the six thousand, dug a hole in the ground, and buried the money of his master.
After a long time, the owner of the slaves came and checked their accounts.

metadata.item: Or judged them.

verse.content: The first slave came and brought the thirty thousand plus what that had gained. He said: Master, you entrusted thirty thousand dinars to me and I have gained thirty thousand more dinars.

metadata.item: The first two slaves worked in their businesses and added the value of their labor to the value of the money and thus increased it.

verse.content: His master said: You are a good, faithful slave! You were faithful in a little matter. I will entrust many matters to you. Enter into the joy of your master.

metadata.item: Or rida. This may mean Al-Janna.

verse.content: The second, who had been entrusted with twelve thousand, came forward. He said: Master, you entrusted twelve thousand dinars to me and I have gained twelve thousand more dinars.
His master said: You are a good, faithful slave! You were faithful in a little matter. I will entrust many matters to you. Enter into the joy of your master.

The third, who had been entrusted with six thousand dinars, came forward. He said: 'My master, I know that you are a hard man. You harvest where you have not planted. You gather what you have not sown.
So I was afraid. I went quickly and hid the six thousand dinars in the ground. Please be honored to take your money.'

metadata.item: It is unclear what the slave was doing while his master was away. Probably nothing, since the master calls him lazy.

verse.content: His master answered him: 'You are an evil, lazy slave! Did you know that I harvest where I have not planted and gather where I have not sown?
Then you should have deposited my money at the bank, so that I would get it back when I return plus interest!'
'Take the six thousand dinars from him and give it to the one who has sixty thousand dinars.
Everyone who has will be given more and will overflow. But if someone does not have, even what he does have will be taken from him.
And take this worthless slave and throw him into the outer darkness, where people will cry and grind their teeth.'
When sayyid al-bashar comes in the majesty of his glory with all his angels, he will sit on the throne of the majesty of his glory.
All nations will be gathered in front of him. He will separate them as the sheep herder separates the sheep from the goats.
He will put the sheep on his right side, and the goats on his left side.

Then the king, al-masih, will tell those who are on the right: 'Come, you people who have a baraka from my Most Loving King. Enter into the kingdom prepared for you since the creation of the universe. I was hungry and you gave me food. I was thirsty and you gave me a drink. I was a stranger and you gave me shelter.

metadata.item: Or, the owners of the right. The meaning is those who are righteous and will be admitted to Al-Janna.

verse.content: I was naked and you gave me clothes. I was sick and you cared for me. I was in prison, and you visited me.'
The righteous asked him: 'Our mawla, when did we see that you were hungry and feed you? When did we see that you were thirsty and give you a drink?
When did we see that you were sick or in prison and visit you?'
The king will answer them: 'I tell you a true saying: Since you did these things to the least of my brothers, you did it to me.'

metadata.item: The word brothers here and in verse 45 is not literal. Here it probably means the followers of Isa. Some people think it means Al-Yahud.

verse.content: Then he will tell those who are on the left: 'Get away from me, you cursed people. Enter the eternal fire prepared for Al-Shaitan and his evil spirits!

metadata.item: Or, the owners of the left. The meaning is those who are not righteous, who will go to jahannam.

verse.content: I was hungry, and you did not give me food. I was thirsty and you did not give me a drink.
I was a stranger and you did not give me shelter. I was naked and you did not give me clothes. I was sick and in prison, and you did not visit me.'
They also will answer him: 'Our mawla, when did we see you hungry, thirsty, naked, a stranger, sick, or in prison and we did not serve you?'
He will answer them: 'I tell you a true saying: Since you did not do that to the least of my brothers, you did not do it to me.'
They will enter eternal torture, and the righteous will enter eternal life."
After he finished talking, Isa told his hawariyun,
"You know that the Eid of Passover is in two days. During it, sayyid al-bashar will be delivered to be crucified."
The leading ahbar and elders of the people were meeting in the courtyard of the house of Caiaphas, the chief habr.
They discussed how to arrest Isa deceptively and kill him.
