But they said, "It is better for this not to be during the eid. Otherwise, there may be a riot among the people."
While Isa was in the house of Simon, who had had leprosy,
a woman came to him with a marble jar filled with very expensive perfume. She poured it on the head of Isa while he was reclining at the table.
The hawariyun were angry at what the woman did. They said, "What is this waste?
It would have been better if the perfume were sold for a huge sum of money and the money was given as alms to poor people!"

metadata.item: This refers to freely given offerings that were not required. In Arabic, sadaqat.

verse.content: Isa knew what they said, so he said to them, "Why are you bothering her? She did a good work to me and it was beautiful.
Poor people are always with you, but I am not always with you!
The woman poured the perfume on my body to prepare my body for burial.
I tell you a true saying: Wherever the good news is proclaimed in this whole world, the act of this woman will be mentioned."
Then Yahuda Iscariot, one of the twelve hawariyun, went to the leading ahbar.
He asked them, "How much will you give me if I deliver him to you?" They paid him thirty silver coins.

metadata.item: Each coin was worth the wages of a laborer for four days.

verse.content: From that time on, he started to look for a good opportunity to betray him.
On the first day of the Eid of Unleavened Bread, the hawariyun came to Isa. They said, "Where shall we prepare the Passover dinner for you?"

metadata.item: Made without yeast.

verse.content: He said, "Enter the city and go to a certain person and tell him: The teacher says: My time has come. I will eat the Passover dinner in your house with my followers, the hawariyun."
The hawariyun did as Isa had ordered them and prepared the Passover dinner."
When evening came, Isa sat at the table with his twelve hawariyun.
As they were eating, he said, "I tell you a true saying: One of you will betray me."
They started asking him very sadly, one after the other, "Is it I, my mawla?"
He answered them, "Someone who dips his hand in the dish with me will betray me.

Sayyid al-bashar will die as Allah revealed concerning him, but woe to his betrayer! It would have been better if he had not been born!" Then Yahuda, the betrayer, asked him, "Is it I, honored teacher?" Isa told him, "You said it."
As they were eating dinner, he took a loaf, praised Allah, broke it, and gave it to the hawariyun. He said, "Take! Eat! This is my body."

metadata.item: Isa is not speaking literally, that the bread was his body, but that it represented his body. This was a major departure from the normal ritual of the Passover Eid traditions.

verse.content: Then he took a cup, praised and thanked Allah, and gave it to them. He said, "All of you, drink some of this.
This is my blood to seal the covenant of Allah. It is poured out to forgive the sins of many people.

metadata.item: Isa is not speaking literally, that what the cup contained was his blood, but that it represented his blood. This was also a major departure from the normal ritual of the Passover Eid traditions.

verse.content: I tell you that I will not drink again from the fruit of the vineyard until the day I drink it new with you in the kingdom of my Most Loving King."
After they praised Allah with an anthem of praise, they went out to Jabal Al-Zaytun.
Then Isa told them, "You will all turn away from me tonight, fulfilling what Allah said: I will strike the sheep herder and the sheep of the flock will be scattered.

metadata.item: This is a quotation from the Tawrat, Zakariyya 13:7. Isa compared himself to a sheep herder and his hawariyun to sheep.

verse.content: But after I am resurrected alive, I will go before you to Al-Jalil."
Peter said, "Even if everyone else turns away from you, I will never turn away from you!"
Isa told him, "I tell you a true saying: This night, before the rooster calls, you will deny me three times."
Peter said, "I will not deny you even if they kill me with you!" All the hawariyun said the same words.
He led them to a place called Gethsemane, and told his hawariyun, "Sit here while I go over there and pray in dua'."
He took Peter and the two sons of Zebedee with him. He became very sad and troubled.
He told them, "My soul is sad enough to die. Stay here and remain awake with me."

He went forward a little distance and threw himself down prostrate. He prayed in dua' to Allah, saying, "Most Loving King, if possible, take this cup away from me. But let it be what you will, not what I will."

metadata.item: Most probably the dua' of Isa was that Allah would keep him from dying before he died on the cross. Some people think it referred to the spiritual separation between Isa and Allah when Isa was on the cross. See 27:46. Since Isa was the word of Allah, this was a horrible thought to him.

verse.content: Then he returned to the hawariyun and found them sleeping. He said to Peter, "Were you all not able to remain awake with me for one hour?
Remain awake and ask Allah for help so that you will not fall into trial. The ruh is ready, but the body is weak."
He went again and prayed in dua' to Allah, "My Most Loving King, if there is no other way except for me to drink it, let your will be done."
Then he came again and found them sleeping. Drowsiness had made their eyes heavy.
He left them, went, and prayed the same thing in dua' a third time.
He came to the hawariyun and said to them, "Is it time for sleeping and rest? The time has approached. Sayyid al-bashar will be delivered to the hands of unjust men.
Come! Look! My betrayer has almost arrived."
As he was speaking, Yahuda, one of the twelve hawariyun came with a large gang armed with swords and sticks. The leading ahbar and elders of the people had sent them.
The betrayer had given the gang a sign. He said, "Grab the one I kiss."

metadata.item: Kissing in public was a common way of greeting between a man and a man or between a woman and a woman, but not between a man and a woman in public. The place a person was kissed showed the relative position of that person.

verse.content: Immediately, he went forward to Isa and said, "Assalamu Alaykum, honored teacher!" Then he kissed him.
So Isa told him, "My friend, do what you came to do." Then the gang came forward and arrested Isa.
One of the followers of Isa drew his sword, attacked the slave of the chief habr, and cut off his ear.

metadata.item: Peter. See the Injil, Yahya 18:10.

verse.content: But Isa told him, "Put your sword in its sheath! Everyone who grabs a sword will be destroyed by a sword.
Do you think I am unable to ask my Most Loving King to send me more than twelve armies of angels?

metadata.item: This word for army usually meant a force of 6000 soldiers.

verse.content: But then, how will what Allah revealed in the kitab be fulfilled? This all must happen."

At that instant, Isa said to the gang, "Have you come out against me armed with swords and sticks, as if I were a thief? I was sitting with you teaching every day in the house of Allah. Why did you not arrest me there?
But this has happened to fulfill what Allah revealed in the scrolls of the anbiya." Then all the hawariyun left him and fled away.

metadata.item: This may be an allusion to the Zabur, Psalms 41:9

verse.content: The gang led Isa to Caiaphas, the chief habr. The fuqaha and elders of the people had met at his house.
Peter followed them from far away to the courtyard of the house of the chief habr. Then he entered and sat with the guards to see the fate of Isa.
All the leading ahbar and members of the highest council, the elders of the people, were searching for false testimony so they could execute him.
Many false witnesses testified, but they did not find anything. Finally, two witnesses came.
They said, "We heard him say that he is able to destroy the house of Allah and build it in three days."
The chief habr stood up and said to him, "Do you not have an answer for what these two testify against you?"
But Isa was silent. The chief habr told him, "I call you to swear by Allah, the Living. Tell us: Are you al-masih, the beloved amir of Allah?"

metadata.item: It was illegal for Al-Yahud to ask a person who was accused to give shahada against himself.

verse.content: Isa told him, "You said it. But I tell you all: From now on, you will see sayyid al-bashar sitting on the right side of Almighty Allah, and coming on the clouds of the sky."

metadata.item: This was the position of authority for the regent of a king.
This refers to the Arabic name Al-Qadir, one of the 99 names of Allah.
This is a reference to the Tawrat, Daniel 7:13-14, which talks about someone coming on the clouds to Almighty Allah and becoming king over the whole earth forever. Isa claimed to be that person.

verse.content: The chief habr tore his robe and said, "He has committed shirk against Allah! Why do we need more witnesses? You have heard his shirk!

metadata.item: This was an expression of horror.
Isa had claimed to be the one whom Allah had appointed as regent over the earth forever. See the Tawrat, Daniel 7:13-14.

verse.content: What is your sentence?" They said, "He deserves death!"

metadata.item: It was illegal for Al-Yahud to ask all the highest council for a verdict. Their procedure required voting one by one, starting with the youngest.

verse.content: Then they spit in his face, beat him, and some people slapped him.
They said, "Prophesy, al-masih! You hit you?"

metadata.item: The concept of al-masih was one person who held the offices of king, habr, and nabi. The ahbar did not believe that Isa was al-masih. They were mocking him. Mocking a person at a trial was illegal.

verse.content: Peter was sitting in the courtyard, and a maid approached him. She told him, "You were also with Isa, the one from Al-Jalil."
But he denied that in front of everyone. He said, "I do not know what you are talking about!"
Then he went to the gate, and another maid saw him. She told the people around her, "This man was with Isa Al-Nasiri."
He denied it a second time with an oath. He said, "I do not know that man!"
After a little while, the people standing there approached him and said, "It is certain that you are one of them. Your dialect has made it clear."

metadata.item: Isa and most of his hawariyun were from Al-Jalil and spoke that dialect. It was a distinctive dialect.

verse.content: Then he started to curse and swear, "I do not know this man!" Immediately, the rooster called.
Peter remembered the saying of Isa, "Before the rooster calls, you will deny me three times." So he went out and cried bitterly.
After dawn, all the leading ahbar and all the elders of the people conspired to execute Isa.

metadata.item: It was illegal for Al-Yahud to conduct a trial at night, but all the previous events happened at night.

verse.content: So they chained him, led him to the Roman governor, Pilate, and delivered him to him.
When Yahuda the betrayer saw the sentence that had been given to Isa, he regretted his actions and returned the thirty silver coins to the leading ahbar and elders of the people.

metadata.item: Or the results of his actions. Some people think Yahuda wanted to push Isa to show his power and become a king on earth.

verse.content: He told them, "I have sinned. I betrayed the blood of an innocent person." They answered, "What do we have to do with that? That is your issue!"
He threw the coins in the house of Allah in front of them, went out, and hanged himself.
The leading ahbar took the silver and said, "It is haraam to put it in the treasury of the house of Allah. It is the price of blood."

metadata.item: It is ironic that they considered this haraam but did not consider killing Isa, who was innocent, to be haraam.

verse.content: They discussed the matter, and then bought the field of the potter with it, to use as a cemetery for foreigners.
That is why is was named, "The field of blood." It is still called that today.
That fulfilled what Allah said by the tongue of the nabi Jeremiah, "Take the thirty silver pieces, the price that Bani Israil specified that he was worth.

metadata.item: This was less than the price of a male slave between 20 and 60 years old. See the Tawrat, Leviticus 27:1-7.

verse.content: Pay for the field of the potter with it, as Rabb Al-Alamin commanded."

metadata.item: This is an allusion to the Tawrat, Jeremiah 32:7-9 and a quotation from Zakariyya 11:12.

verse.content: Isa stood in front of the governor, and the governor questioned him, "Are you the king of Al-Yahud?" Isa said, "You said it."
The leading ahbar and elders of the people accused him, but he did not answer.
Then Pilate asked him, "Do you not hear what they are testifying against you?"
Isa did not answer him a word. The governor was very amazed.
The governor had a custom to release one prisoner the crowd chose at the eid.
Barabbas, a well-known murderer and rioter, was in prison at that time.
When they were gathered with him, Pilate asked, "Who do you want me to release for you? Barabbas or Isa who is called al-masih?"
He knew that their jealousy and zeal were the reasons they had delivered him.

When Pilate was sitting on his seat as the judge, his wife sent him a warning. She said, "That man is righteous and just. Be careful not to do anything to him. I had a very disturbing dream today because of him."

metadata.item: About Isa.

verse.content: But the leading ahbar and elders of the people convinced the crowd to ask for Barabbas to be released and for to Isa be executed.
The governor asked them, "Which of the two men do you want me to release for you?" They said, "Barabbas!"
Pilate asked them again, "What shall I do with Isa, who is called al-masih?" Everyone said, "Crucify him!"

metadata.item: This was an especially painful form of execution invented by the Romans. The hands and feet of the person who was crucified were nailed to wooden beams, and he was hung there to die of thirst and suffocation. Often the shoulders were dislocated from the weight of the body pulling on them.

verse.content: He asked, "Why? What crime has he committed?" They shouted louder, "Crucify him!"

Pilate saw that speaking with them was no use. He also saw signs of the beginning of a riot. So he took some water, washed his hands in front of everyone, and said, "I am innocent of the blood of this man. It is your responsibility!"

metadata.item: His intent seems to have been to declare that it was not his responsibility.

verse.content: The whole nation said, "May his blood be upon us and on our children!"

metadata.item: This acceptance of the guilt for killing Isa may be the reason the nation of Al-Yahud was destroyed about 40 years later in A.D. 70.

verse.content: So he released Barabbas to them. He whipped Isa and delivered him to be crucified.

metadata.item: Roman whippings were very severe and some people died from them. A person who was whipped would lose a lot of blood from the whippings.

verse.content: The soldiers took Isa to the house of the governor. The whole battalion gathered around him.
Then they took off his clothes and put a robe of kingly scarlet color on him.

metadata.item: The blood of Isa would have dried onto the robe.

verse.content: They also made a crown of thorns and crowned him with it. They gave him a reed in his right hand, mocked him by bowing down to him, and saying, "Long live the king of Al-Yahud!"

metadata.item: All this was done in sarcasm.

verse.content: They also spit on him. Then they ripped the reed from his hand and started hitting him on the head with it.
When they were tired of making fun of him, they took off the scarlet robe and put his own clothes on him. Then they led him to be crucified.

metadata.item: The removal of the robe would have made the wounds from the whipping bleed again.

verse.content: While they were going out with him, they found a man from Cyrene, named Simon. They forced him to carry the cross of Isa.
They arrived to the place called Golgotha. (This name means the place of the skull.)
There they offered him a drink of wine mixed with myrrh as a drug. He tasted it and then refused to drink it.
Then the soldiers crucified him. They divided his clothes among them by lot.
Then they sat and guarded him.
Above his head they put a notice of the charge against him. The notice read, "This is Isa, king of Al-Yahud."
Then they crucified two thieves with him. One of them was on his right and the other was on his left.
The people passing by cursed him. They shook their heads and said,

metadata.item: In mocking or insulting him.

verse.content: "He saved other people, and he is unable to save himself! He is king of Bani Israil! Let him come down now from the cross, and we will believe in him!
He trusts in Allah. Let Allah now save him, if he has rida with him. He said: I am the beloved amir of Allah."
Even the two thieves crucified with him spoke dishonorably to him.
Darkness covered everything like a tent from noon to midafternoon.
About three o clock, Isa shouted loudly, "Ily, Ily, lima sabakhthani?" This means, "My god, my god, why did you leave me?"

metadata.item: This is a quotation from the Zabur, Psalms 22:1.

verse.content: Some people standing there heard his shout and said, "This man is calling Ilyas."

metadata.item: They misunderstood him. Most people spoke Aramaic, which was different from the Hebrew language of the Zabur.

verse.content: One of them immediately went quickly and took a sponge. He filled it with vinegar, attached it to a reed, and offered it to him to drink.
Other people said, "Let him alone! Let us see if Ilyas will come to rescue him."
Then Isa shouted loudly again and delivered his ruh to Allah."
Right then, the curtain of the haram of the house of Allah was torn into two pieces from top to bottom, there was an earthquake, rocks were split,
graves were opened, and many holy people were resurrected from death to life.
They came out of their graves after Isa was resurrected alive. Then they entered the holy city and appeared to many people.
The Roman officer and the guards around Isa were very afraid when they saw the earthquake and everything else that happened. They said, "He was truly from Allah!"
Many women had followed him from Al-Jalil and served him. They were watching from a far distance.
These included Mariam Magdalene, Mariam mother of Yacoub and Yusif, and the mother of the two sons of Zebedee.
At sunset, a rich man from the town of Arimathea named Yusif came. He was also a follower of Isa.
He went to Pilate and asked for the body of Isa. Pilate ordered it to be delivered to him.
Yusif took the body, wrapped it in a clean, linen grave cloth,
put it in his own tomb he had just dug from the rock, rolled a large stone at the entrance of the grave to close it, and went away.
Mariam Magdalene and the other Mariam sat there opposite the grave.
The next day was the first day of the eid. The leading ahbar and the Pharisees met in front of Pilate.
They said, "Governor sir, we remember the saying what that dujjal said: I will be resurrected alive on the third day.

So issue an order that the tomb be sealed and guarded until the third day. That way, his followers cannot come, steal his body, and announce to the people: He was resurrected alive. That final deception would be worse than the first."
Pilate told them, "You have soldiers. Go guard it as well as you can."
So they went, sealed the stone at the entrance of the grave, and set up a guard.
After Al-Sabt, on Sunday at dawn, Mariam Magdalene and the other Mariam came to the grave to see it.
Suddenly there was a strong earthquake, because an angel came down from Rabb Al-Alamin, rolled the stone away from the entrance of the grave, and sat on it.
He looked like lightning and his robe was white like snow.
The guards shook in terror and were paralyzed like dead people.
But the angel told the two women, "Do not be afraid! I know you are seeking Isa who was crucified.
He is not here. He was resurrected alive according to his saying. Come see the place where he was put.
Then go quickly and tell his hawariyun that he was resurrected alive from death. He will go before you to Al-Jalil. You will see him there. I have told you the message."
They went quickly from the grave. They were afraid and very happy. They ran to announce the news to his hawariyun.
Then Isa met them and told them, "Assalamu Alaykum!" They approached him and bowed down to him, holding his feet.
Then Isa told them, "Do not be afraid! Go and announce to my brothers that they should travel to Al-Jalil. They will see me there."
While they were on the way, some of the guards went and told the leading ahbar everything that happened.
They met with the elders of the people and discussed the matter among themselves. They gave the soldiers a large bribe.
They told them, "Tell people: His helpers came at night and stole his body while we were asleep.
If the governor hears about this, we will satisfy him, and take any blame from you."

metadata.item: Soldiers who failed in their duty could be executed.

verse.content: The soldiers took the bribe and did what they ordered them. This lie is still spread among Al-Yahud today.
The eleven hawariyun went to the mountain in Al-Jalil according to the command of Isa.
When they saw him, they bowed to him. But some of them doubted.
Isa approached them and told them, "Allah has given me all authority in heaven and on earth.
So go and make followers from all nations. Do ghusl for them into the name of the Most Merciful King, the beloved amir, and Holy Ruh Allah.

metadata.item: Other translations translate this word differently, using the word son. However, those translations miss important meanings that this translation conveys clearly: the idea that the amir has the authority of the king, and that he is in submission to the king.

verse.content: Train them to keep everything I have commanded you. I am with you every day forever."
The beginning of the good news of Isa al-masih, 1 as it is written in the scroll of nabi Shaya: "I am sending my rasul before you. He will prepare your way.

metadata.item: Al-masih is a title, not a name. As such, it is not capitalized. Al-masih means the one anointed with oil to show his appointment by Allah as king, habr, and nabi.
The numbers of the verses come after the verses themselves.

Very few anbiya were predicted in the Tawrat (Isa and Yahya). Other people who were predicted but who were not anbiya were Josiah, a king of Bani Israil, Cyrus, king of Persia, and Mariam, the mother of Isa.
A quotation from the Tawrat, Malachi 3:1. See following footnote.

verse.content: A voice is shouting in the wilderness, 'Prepare the way for Al-Mawla! Make al-sirat al-mustaqim for him!'"

metadata.item: A quotation the Tawrat, Shaya 40:3. Since Shaya is more famous than Malachi, only his name was mentioned.

verse.content: And Yahya who did ghusl was in the wilderness. He proclaimed a ghusl of repentance for forgiveness of sins.

metadata.item: Yahya was a common name. This Yahya is called Yahya who did (or does) ghusl to distinguish him from others of the same name.

verse.content: All the inhabitants of Al-Quds and Yahudia came out to him. They acknowledged their sins to him, and he did ghusl for them in the Jordan River.
Yahya wore a robe made from camel hair and a leather belt, and he ate locusts and wild honey.
He proclaimed, saying: "The one who is coming after me is more powerful than I am---I am not worthy to untie the straps of his sandals.

metadata.item: Isa.
This job was the job of a slave, who would have to bend down to do it. Yahya was saying that his position was like a slave compared to Isa.

verse.content: I have done ghusl for you into water, but he will do ghusl for you into Holy Ruh Allah!"
In those days, Isa came from the town of Al-Nasira in Al-Jalil, and Yahya did ghusl for him into the Jordan River.
When Isa came up out of the water, he immediately saw the heavens torn open and Ruh Allah descending and remaining on him like a dove.
And a voice came from heaven, "You are my beloved amir, and I have rida toward you. "

metadata.item: Other translations translate this word differently, using the word son. However, those translations miss important meanings that this translation conveys clearly: the idea that the amir has the authority of the king, and that he is in submission to the king.

verse.content: Ruh Allah immediately drove Isa out into the wilderness.
He stayed there for forty days and during that time, Al-Shaitan tempted him. He was out among wild animals, and angels served him.
After Yahya was arrested, Isa went out into Al-Jalil, where he proclaimed good news from Allah, saying,
"The time has come, and the kingdom of Allah is near! Repent and trust the good news!"
And as Isa was walking along the shore of Al-Jalil Lake, he saw Simon and his brother Andrew throwing their net into the lake, for they were fishermen.
And he told them, "Follow me, and I will make you gather people instead of fish!"
And immediately they left their nets and followed him.
And as Isa walked further, he saw Yacoub son of Zebedee and Yahya his brother and those in the boat repairing nets.
And immediately he called them, and they left their father, Zebedee, with the hired men in the boat, and followed him.
And they went to the town of Capernaum. And Isa immediately began to teach in the house of salat on Al-Sabt.

metadata.item: Al-Yahud met on Al-Sabt for reading of the Tawrat and for salat.

verse.content: They were amazed at his teaching, because he taught as one who had authority. This was not like the teaching of the fuqaha.

metadata.item: The fuqaha generally quoted other scholars rather than stating their own opinions.

verse.content: And immediately, there was a man in the house of salat who had been touched by an unclean spirit. He shouted,
"Leave us alone, Isa Al-Nasiri. Have you come to destroy us? We know who you are. You are the holy rasul of Allah!"
And Isa rebuked the jinni, "Be quiet and come out of him."
And the unclean spirit threw the man into a convulsion, shouted loudly, and came out of him.
And they were all amazed, and they asked each other: "What is this?! He commands even the unclean spirits with authority, and they obey him!"
And the reputation of Isa immediately spread through the surrounding region of Al-Jalil.
And immediately, they left the house of salat and went to the house of Simon and Andrew with Yacoub and Yahya.
Now the mother-in-law of Simon was lying down because she had a fever. They told Isa about her immediately.
And he went to her and raised her by holding her hand. And the fever left her, and she served them.
After sunset, people brought him everyone who was sick or touched by jinn.
The whole town gathered around the door.
He healed many people who had various diseases. He also cast out many evil jinn, but he did not allow the jinn to speak because they knew him.

metadata.item: It was not the time for the identity of Isa to be made public. In addition, people who heard the jinn giving shahada may have thought that Isa was in cooperation with the jinn.

verse.content: Isa got up the next morning before dawn and went out to the wilderness. He began to pray in dua\' there.
Then Simon and his companions followed him.
When they found him, they said, "Everyone is looking for you."
But he told them, "Let us go to the surrounding villages, so that I can proclaim the message there, too. For that is why I came out."
And he went around to all Al-Jalil, proclaiming it in the houses of salat and casting out jinn.
A man with leprosy came and knelt in front of him, pleading. "If you are willing, you can make me tahir."

metadata.item: Leprosy was a skin disease that caused a person to be considered unclean. Those who had this disease were isolated socially.

verse.content: Isa showed compassion to him, and stretched out his hand and touched him. He said, "I am willing. Be tahir!"

metadata.item: Al-Yahud did not touch people who had leprosy, but rather kept far away from them. They were afraid of the person with leprosy making them unclean. Isa touched the man and the holiness of Isa made the unclean person tahir.

verse.content: Immediately the leprosy left him, and he was made tahir.
Isa sent him away immediately with a strong warning.

He said: "Make sure that you do not say anything to anyone. Instead, go and show yourself to the habr. Offer what Allah commanded Musa because you have been made tahir. This will be a shahada to them."

metadata.item: This was probably because Isa was interested in people following Allah, not in people who were only seeking physical healing and did not want to follow Allah.
This qurban was mentioned in the Tawrat, Leviticus 14:7. The Tawrat never records that a person of Bani Israil had ever been healed of leprosy, so this verse had never been used before.
Al-Yahud believed that healing a leper of Bani Israil was a miracle only al-masih was able to do.

verse.content: But the man went away and began to proclaim many things. He spread the news, so that Isa could not publicly enter any town. But Isa was outside in the wilderness, and people were coming to him from everywhere.
And when Isa returned to Capernaum again, people heard that he was at home.

metadata.item: He had moved from Al-Nasira, where he grew up, to Capernaum.

verse.content: And many gathered together, so that the place was crowded, both inside the house and around the door. And he was speaking the word to them.
Some people brought a paralyzed man to him carried by four men.
They could not get near Isa because of the crowd, so they removed the roof above the place where Isa was. And when they had dug through, they lowered the mat on which the paralyzed man lay.

metadata.item: This was a flat roof and opening up a hole would have involved moving branches or other material.

verse.content: When Isa saw their trust, he said to the paralyzed man, "My child, your sins are forgiven."

metadata.item: The word child is not literal. Here it is a term of compassion, not relationship. Isa was never married and had no children.

verse.content: But some of the fuqaha were sitting there and thinking in their hearts,
"Why is this man speaking shirk? Who can forgive sins except Allah alone?"
Isa immediately knew within his ruh exactly what they were thinking about in themselves. Isa said to them, "Why do you think about these things in your hearts?
Which is easier: To say to the paralyzed man, 'Your sins are forgiven,' or to tell him, 'Stand up, pick up your mat, and go?

metadata.item: No one could check to see if the sins of a person had been forgiven. But it was very easy to check if a paralyzed person had been healed or not. By healing the man, Isa showed that he had the authority for both.

verse.content: I want you to know that sayyid al-bashar has the authority on earth to forgive sins." Then Isa said to the paralyzed man, "I tell you: Stand up, pick up your mat, and go home!"

metadata.item: Sayyid al-bashar is the most common title Isa used for himself. It had three primary meanings in the Tawrat. 1) Sometimes, it meant a human being, as in Numbers 23:19. 2) Many times, it was used to mean a nabi or rasul (93 times in the scroll of Ezekiel alone). 3) The one prophesied in the Tawrah, Daniel 7:14, who was coming to Allah on the clouds of the sky and whom Allah was going to give rule, kingship, and glory over all peoples, nations, and language groups forever in an eternal kingdom. When Isa used this title with the religious authorities, they understood this meaning. See chapter 14:61-62.

verse.content: And the man got up, picked up his mat immediately, and walked out in front of everyone. They were amazed and praised the glory of Allah, saying, "Nothing like this has ever appeared to Bani Israil!"
Isa went out again to the lake. Crowds gathered around him there, and he taught them.
As he went along, he saw Levi son of Alphaeus in the office for collecting taxes. Isa said, "Follow me," So Levi got up and followed him.
Isa was eating at the house of Levi with his hawariyun, along with many tax collectors and other detested sinners. For many of them followed him.
But when the Pharisee fuqaha saw him eating with detested tax collectors and sinners, they said to his hawariyun, "Why does the teacher eat with detestable tax collectors and sinners?"

metadata.item: The Pharisees avoided social relationships with people they thought were not tahir enough for them.

verse.content: When Isa heard this, he told them, "Healthy people do not need a physician\-- sick people do. I have not come to call righteous people, but sinners."

The followers of Yahya and the Pharisees were practicing sawm, and they came and asked him, "Why do the followers of Yahya and the followers of the Pharisees practice sawm, while your hawariyun do not practice sawm?"18 Isa replied, "Do guests of the groom practice sawm while the groom is with them? Of course not. They will not practice sawm as long as the groom is with them.
But the days will come when the groom will be taken from them, and they will practice sawm on that day.
No one patches an old robe with new cloth. If he did, the patch would shrink and tear the robe. The new would separate from the old, and the tear would become worse.
No one puts new wine into an old wineskin. If he did, the wine would tear the wineskin, and the wine and the wineskin would both be lost. New wine is put in a new wineskin."

metadata.item: New wine (grape juice) expands as it ferments. When it is put into a new leather container, the leather stretches. But when it is put into an old container that has already been stretched, it will stretch it further and break it.

verse.content: Isa was walking through some fields of wheat on Al-Sabt. His hawariyun began to make a path as they were picking grain.

metadata.item: This was allowed in occasional instances.

verse.content: The Pharisees said to him, "Look, why are they doing what is forbidden to do on Al-Sabt?"

metadata.item: There is a command in the Tawrat (Exodus 20:10) prohibiting all kinds work on Al-Sabt, including harvesting. It did not prohibit eating when hungry. The Pharisees had made their own sunan which said that picking heads of grain to eat was a kind of harvesting. Isa affirmed the commands of the Tawrat but rejected the rules of men.

verse.content: He said to them, "Have you not read in the kitab what Dawood did when he was in need, when he and those who were with him were hungry?
He went into the house of Allah during the days when Abiathar was chief habr. He ate the bread given as a qurban to Allah. Only the ahbar may to eat it. He gave some to his companions, too."

metadata.item: This story is in the Tawrat, 1 Samuel 21:1-6.

verse.content: Then Isa told them, "Al-Sabt was made for the people, and not people for Al-Sabt.
So sayyid al-bashar is also master of Al-Sabt!"
Isa went into the house of salat again. A man with a dried-up hand was there.
And they watched Isa closely to see if he would heal the man on Al-Sabt. (They wanted to accuse him.)
Isa said to the man with the dried-up hand, "Stand up in the center of the room."
He said to them, "Is it halal on Al-Sabt to do good or to do evil, to save life or to kill?" But they were silent.

metadata.item: It is always halal to do good, and it is never halal to do evil. It is always halal to save a life. It is never halal to take a life (murder).

verse.content: He looked around at them in anger and was sad because of the hardness of their hearts. Isa said to the man, "Stretch out your hand." So he stretched out his hand, and it was restored!
Immediately, the Pharisees went out and conspired with the party of Herod to destroy him.

metadata.item: Normally these two groups were enemies

verse.content: Isa withdrew with his hawariyun to the lake. Large crowds followed him. They came from Al-Jalil, Yahudia, Al-Quds, the East Bank, Tyre, Sidon, and the surrounding areas. They came to him because they heard about what he did.
Isa told his hawariyun to prepare a boat for him so that the crowds would not crush him.
For he had healed many people, so they came to him eagerly so that those who suffered could touch him.
And when the unclean spirits saw him, they fell down in front of him and shouted, "You are the beloved amir of Allah!"
But Isa strongly commanded them not to make him known.

metadata.item: See note at 1:34.

verse.content: And Isa went up a mountain, called the people he wanted, and they came to him.
And he chose twelve men, whom he called hawariyun, to be with him. He would send them out to proclaim,
and to have authority to cast out jinn.
These are the twelve hawariyun: Simon, (whom he named Peter), Yacoub son of Zebedee and Yahya his brother (Isa called them 'Boanerges,' which means sons of thunder),

metadata.item: Of course the word son is not literal.

verse.content: Andrew, Philip, Bartholomew, Matthew, Thomas, Yacoub son of Alphaeus, Thaddeus, Simon the zealot,

metadata.item: This name means son of Talmai. He is also known as Nathaniel. See Yahya 1:45-51.
In 2:14, Levi (Matthew) the son of Alphaeus is mentioned, so it seems there were at least three pairs of brothers among the hawariyun.

verse.content: and Yahuda Iscariot, who betrayed him.
Then Isa entered a house. A crowd gathered again so that they were not even able to eat.
When his relatives heard about it, they came to restrain him. (They said he was crazy.)
But the fuqaha from Al-Quds said, "He has been touched by Iblis. He casts out jinn by the power of the ruler of jinn."

metadata.item: Al-Shaitan or Beelzebul. The fuqaha had witnessed Isa doing an ayah that Al-Yahud believed only al-masih could do. They did not want to acknowledge that Isa was al-masih, so they had to give another explanation why Isa could do his ayat.

verse.content: He called them to himself and told them a story. "How can Al-Shaitan cast out Al-Shaitan?
A divided kingdom that fights against itself will not stand.
And a divided household that fights against itself will not stand.
If Al-Shaitan has risen up against himself and is divided, he will not stand, but his end has come.
No one can enter the house of a strong man to plunder his possessions unless he first binds the strong man. Then he can plunder his house.

metadata.item: or ties up. The word also means to forbid. Isa had authority over Al-Shaitan and was able to forbid him from doing things.

verse.content: I tell you a true saying: All sins of the sons of Adam will be forgiven, even the kufr that they say.

metadata.item: The word sons is not literal. Here 'sons of Adam' means human beings.
It is implied that they repent.

verse.content: But whoever speaks kufr against Holy Ruh Allah will never be forgiven. He is guilty of an eternal sin."
That is because they said, "An unclean spirit has touched him."

metadata.item: Some people believe that kufr against Holy Ruh Allah means attributing the work of Holy Ruh Allah to an unclean spirit or jinni and that that is the eternal sin which never can have forgiveness. Others think that it means a final rejection of the work of Holy Ruh Allah in drawing a person to repent and trust in Isa.

verse.content: His mother and his brothers came. They were standing outside and asking for him to come.

metadata.item: The word brothers includes half-brothers, which in this case referred to the sons of Mariam and Yusif the carpenter. Most people did not know that Isa was conceived by Holy Ruh Allah without a human father, so they assumed that they were his full blood brothers.

verse.content: There was a crowd around him. They told him, "Your mother and your brothers are outside, and they want you to come out."
He answered them, "Who are my mother and brothers?"
Then he looked around at those who were sitting around him and said, "These are my mother and brothers!
Whoever does the will of Allah is my brother and sister and mother."

metadata.item: Of course, mother, brother and sister here are not literal. Isa used these terms to mean that those who obey him have a closer relationship to him than his blood relatives.

verse.content: Again he began teaching by the lake. A large crowd gathered around him, so he got into a boat. He sat in the boat teaching the crowds.
There he taught them many things using stories. He said,
"Listen! See, a farmer went out to sow some seed.

metadata.item: The farmer would take a handful of seeds and throw it toward the good soil. Unfortunately, some of the seeds would fall in other places.

verse.content: As he was sowing, some seed fell on the path, and the birds attacked it and ate it.
Some of it fell on rocky ground with shallow soil. It sprouted immediately because it did not have much soil.
When the sun came up, it was burned. Since it did not have any roots, it dried up.
Some of it fell among thorns that sprouted and choked it, and it produced no fruit.
Some of it fell on good soil, and it sprouted, grew, and it produced thirty, sixty, and even a hundred times as much!"

metadata.item: Normal grain does not produce this much. This is an ayah showing only Allah could do this.

verse.content: Then he said, "Anyone with ears that hear, listen!"
And when he was alone, the people who were around him with hawariyun asked him about the stories.
He replied, "You have been given the secret of the kingdom of Allah. But for those outside, everything is in stories.

metadata.item: Outside your group, or outside the kingdom of Allah.
Stories mean something to those who understand, but seem just like stories to those who refuse to listen and obey.

verse.content: This is so that as they look, they will look and not see, and when they listen, they will hear but not understand, so that they will not repent and be forgiven."

metadata.item: This is a reference to the Tawrat, Shaya 6:9-10.

verse.content: Then Isa said to them, "Did you not understand this story? Then how will you understand all the stories?

metadata.item: This story is a model of how all stories work.

verse.content: The farmer sows the word.
These are the ones along the path where the word is sown: When they hear, Al-Shaitan immediately takes away the word sown in them.

metadata.item: The birds represent Al-Shaitan.

verse.content: Similarly, these are the ones sown among the rocks: When they hear the word, they accept it immediately with joy.
They have no root in themselves, but they last only a little time. Then when they face difficulties or persecution because of the word, immediately they fall away.
And others are the ones that are sown among thorns: They hear the word,
but the worries of this world, the love of riches, and other desires come along. They choke the word, and it does not produce fruit.
And these are the ones that are sown in good soil: Everyone who hears the word and accepts it. They produce thirty, sixty, or one hundred times as much."
Then he said to them, "Is a lamp brought inside to be put under a basket or a bed? No. It is brought in to be put on a lamp stand.
Nothing is hidden that will not be revealed. And nothing is secret that will not be made clear.
Anyone with ears that hear, listen!"
He told them, "Take care what you hear! With the measure you use, it will be measured to you - and more.
For whoever has will be given more. Whoever does not have, even what he does have will be taken from him."

metadata.item: The meaning here may be, whoever obeys what he hears will be given more truth.
In other words, whoever does not have very much.

verse.content: He said, "The kingdom of Allah is like a man who sows seed on the ground.
He sleeps at night and gets up in the morning, and the seeds sprout and grow. He does not know how.

metadata.item: This does not imply that the farmer does not do anything. Farmers do a lot of work, but Allah makes the plants grow.

verse.content: By itself, the earth bears fruit -- first the stalk, then the head, then the fully ripened grain in the head.
When the crop is ripe, the man takes his sickle immediately. For the harvest has come."

metadata.item: A sickle had a long curved blade and was used for harvesting.

verse.content: He said, "To what shall we compare the kingdom of Allah, and with what story would we present it?

metadata.item: Here Isa speaks in the plural, like a king.

verse.content: It is like a mustard seed planted in the ground. It is the smallest of seeds on earth.
But when it has been planted, it grows taller than all the garden herbs. Its branches get so big that birds of the sky can live in its shade."

metadata.item: Birds sometimes represent evil. See verses 4, 15.

The mustard plant is a large bush, not a tree with branches. This kind of growth is abnormal. Some people think that this just refers to the great expansion of the kingdom of Allah. Others think that the birds of the sky are a symbol of evil, and that this story means that evil will enter the kingdom of Allah as it expands.

verse.content: He spoke the word to them with many such stories as they were able to hear.
He spoke to them only in stories, but he explained everything to his hawariyun in private.
After sunset that day, he told them, "Let us go to the other shore."
So they left the crowd, and the hawariyun took him in the boat just as he was. And other boats were with them.
Then there was a strong wind, and the waves beat on the boat.
Isa was sleeping on a pillow in the back of the boat, and they woke him, saying, "Teacher, do you not care if we die?"
He got up, rebuked the wind, and said to the sea, "Peace! Be still!" The wind stopped and there was a great calm.
Isa said to them, "Why were you afraid? Do you still have no trust?"
They were terrified and said to each other, "Who is this? Even the wind and the sea obey him!"
They reached the other side. That is where the people of Jerash live.

metadata.item: The province of Jerash extended to the sea.

verse.content: When Isa got out of the boat, immediately a man with an unclean spirit came out of the tombs to meet him.
He lived there among the tombs. No one was able to bind him any longer, even with chains.
Many times, they had tied him up with shackles and chains, but he tore the chains apart and broke the shackles. No one was strong enough to subdue him.
Day and night, among the tombs and hills, he shouted constantly and cut his body with stones.
But when he saw Isa from a distance, he ran toward him and bowed down to him.
Then he shouted in a loud voice. He said, "What do you have to do with me, Isa, beloved amir of Allah Most High? I beg you by Allah do not torture me!"

metadata.item: The man was afraid because the amir of Allah has the authority of Allah.

If this was the jinni speaking, this would refer to the Arabic name Al-Aly, one of the 99 names of Allah. It is also possible that the man was speaking, and he did not know about Allah. In this case, he would be referring to the highest god that he believed in.
See the previous footnote.

verse.content: Jesus had told him, "Unclean spirit, come out of the man."
Then Isa asked him, "What is your name?" He answered, "My name is Army because we are many."

metadata.item: An army was a force of six thousand soldiers.

verse.content: He begged Isa loudly not to send him out of the region.
There was a herd of pigs feeding nearby.

metadata.item: Pigs were unclean animals, and the Tawrat prohibited Al-Yahud from eating them. See Leviticus 11:7, Deuteronomy 14:8.

verse.content: The jinn begged Isa, "Send us to the pigs, so that we may enter them."
He gave them permission, and the unclean spirits went out and entered the pigs. The herd, about two thousand, hurried down the cliff to the lake, and they drowned in the sea.

metadata.item: Or steep hill.

verse.content: The herders fled and told the people of the town and in the countryside. So people went out to see what had happened.

metadata.item: They may have wanted to demonstrate that the loss of the pigs was not their fault.

verse.content: They flocked to Isa, and they saw the one who had been touched by the Army of jinn sitting down, wearing clothing, and in his right mind. And they were afraid.
The witnesses told them what happened to the one who had been touched by jinn and to the pigs.
So they began to beg Isa to leave their region.

metadata.item: This was possibly because the economic disaster was more important to them than the healing of the man.

verse.content: As Isa was getting in the boat, the one who had been touched by the jinn begged to be with him.

metadata.item: If he had followed Isa, who was a Yahudi teacher, in Al-Jalil or Yahudia, he would have had to convert to the Yahudi religion.

verse.content: Isa refused, but said to him, "Go to your household and relatives. Tell them everything al-mawla has done for you and how he has had mercy on you."
The man went away to proclaim in the Decapolis what Isa has done for him. Everyone was amazed.
After Isa crossed over to the other side again in the boat, a large crowd gathered around him on the shore of the lake.
And a ruler of the house of salat came to him. His name was Jairus. When he saw Isa, he fell down at his feet.
He begged him earnestly, "My little daughter is at the point of death. Come and put your hands on her. Then she will be healed and live."
Isa went with him. A large crowd followed Isa, and they were pressing upon him.
There was a woman there who had been bleeding for twelve years.
She had suffered many things at the hands of many physicians. She had spent everything she had, but she did not get better. Instead, she became worse.
She heard the news about Isa, came to him from behind, and touched his robe.
For she said, "Even if I touch his robe, I will be healed."
Immediately, her bleeding stopped and she felt in her body that she was healed from her suffering.
And Isa sensed in himself immediately that baraka had gone out of him, so he turned in the crowd and said, "Who touched my robe?"

metadata.item: Or power.

verse.content: His hawariyun said, "You see the crowd pressing on you, and you say, 'Who touched me?'"
But Isa was looking around him to see who had done this.
The woman knew what had happened to her. She came to him, and she was trembling with fear. She fell down in front of him and told him the whole truth.
He said to her, "Daughter, your trust has healed you. Go in peace. Be healed from your suffering."

metadata.item: The word daughter is not literal. Here Isa uses it as a term of compassion, not relationship. Isa was never married and had no children.

verse.content: While he was still speaking, people came from the house of the ruler of the house of salat. They said, "Your daughter has died. Why bother the teacher anymore?"
But when Isa overheard what they said, he told the ruler of the house of salat, "Do not fear - only trust."
He let no one come with him except Peter, Yacoub, and Yahya the brother of Yacoub.
So they came to the house of the ruler of the house of salat. Isa saw the confusion and the people crying and wailing loudly.
He went in to the house and said to them, "Why are you troubled and crying? The girl is not dead, but sleeping."

metadata.item: Isa was going to make her alive again, so she was not permanently dead. Isa sometimes used the term 'sleep' to describe someone who had died and who would be resurrected. See Yahya 11:11-14.

verse.content: And when they laughed at him, he made them all go out. He took with him the father of the girl, her mother, and those that were with him. He went in to where the girl was.
And as he took the hand of the child, he said, "Talitha, cumi!" (That means "Girl, I say to you, get up!")
Immediately, the girl got up. She even walked around, for she was twelve years old. And they were completely amazed.
And Isa gave strong orders that nobody should know about this. He also told them to give her something to eat.

He went away from there and returned to his hometown, and his hawariyun followed him.1 On Al-Sabt, he began to teach in the house of salat. Many of the hearers were amazed and said, "Where did he get all this? What is this wisdom he has been given? What are these works of power that are done through his hands?
Is this not the carpenter, Ibn Mariam, and his brothers are Yacoub, Yusif, Yahuda, and Simon? Are all his sisters not here with us?" They were offended by him.

metadata.item: Isa\'s stepfather Yusif was a carpenter, and Isa learned to be a carpenter also.

The word brothers here is not limited to full brothers. Here it means half-brothers (sons of Isa\'s mother Mariam and her husband, whom she married after she gave birth to Isa). Isa had no human father so he had no full brothers. The idea that these were children of Yusif from a previous marriage is not from the Injil. Such boys would not have any relationship to Isa. Isa had no human father and so had no full brothers.

The word sisters here is also not limited to full sisters. Here it means means half-sisters (sons of Mariam and her husband Yusif, whom she married after she gave birth to Isa.) Isa had no human father and so had no full sisters.

verse.content: Isa told them, "A nabi has no honor in his hometown and in his household."
He was unable to do any work of power except that he put his hands on some sick people and healed them.
And he was amazed at their disbelief. Then he went around teaching in the villages nearby.
After that, he called his twelve hawariyun and began to send them out two by two.
He commanded them not to take anything with them on the way except a walking stick only---no bread, no bag, and no money in their belts.
He told them to wear sandals and not to wear two shirts.
He told them, "Whenever you enter a house, stay there until you leave the area.
And wherever a place does not receive you or listen to you, shake off the dust of your feet as a shahada against them."

metadata.item: This may have had the meaning, "I am not taking anything from you, so I do not owe you anything. You had your opportunity."

verse.content: So as they went out, they proclaimed that people should repent.
They cast out many jinn, anointed many sick people with oil, and healed them.

metadata.item: Anointing involved putting or pouring oil on the head.

verse.content: King Herod heard about Isa because his name had become known. And he said, "Yahya who did ghusl has been resurrected alive from death. That is why these powers are at work in him."
But others were saying, "He is Ilyas." Still others were saying, "He is a nabi, like one of the ancient anbiya."
But when Herod heard about him, he said, "He is Yahya, whose head I cut off. He has been resurrected alive from death."
Herod had sent and arrested Yahya and bound him in prison because of Herodias, the wife of his brother Philip, whom Herod had married.

metadata.item: Philip was still alive.

verse.content: For Yahya had been telling Herod, "It is haraam for you to have the wife of your brother."

metadata.item: i.e. marry.

verse.content: And Herodias hated Yahya and wanted to kill him. But she found no way to do so.
For Herod feared Yahya because he knew Yahya was a righteous and holy man. Herod protected him and listened to him often, although he was disturbed by his words.
The opportune time came at the celebration Herod gave for his court officials, military officers, and the leading citizens of Al-Jalil on his birthday.

metadata.item: For Herodias to take revenge.

verse.content: When the daughter of Herodias came in and danced, it Herod and his guests had rida with her. So the king told her, "Ask for whatever you want, and I will give it to you."
He swore an oath to her, "Whatever you ask, I will give it to you, even half my kingdom!"
She went out and asked her mother, "What shall I ask for?" She said, "The head of Yahya who did ghusl."
She immediately returned quickly to the king and said, "I want you to give me the head of Yahya who did ghusl on a plate right now."
The king was very sad, because he did not want to retract his word. He had given his oath to her and his guests were present.

metadata.item: Honor was very important in that culture.
His pride was more important to him that dong what was right.

verse.content: But immediately, he sent an executioner and commanded him to bring him the head of Yahya.
The executioner came carrying his head on a plate, gave it to the girl, and she gave it to her mother.
His followers heard about this, and they came, took his body, and put it in a grave.
Then the hawariyun returned to Isa and told him all they had done and taught.
He told them, "Come by yourselves to an isolated place and rest for a little time." For many people were coming and going, and they did not have time to eat.
They left in a boat by themselves and headed for an isolated place.
But many people saw them going and knew who they were. So they ran on foot from all the cities and arrived there before them.
As Isa got out of the boat, he saw the great crowd. He had compassion on them because they were like sheep without a shepherd. He began to teach them many things.
Since it was already late in the day, the hawariyun came to him and said, "This place is isolated, and the hour is already late.
Send the people away to go to the farms and surrounding villages to buy for themselves something to eat."
He answered them, "You give them something to eat." They asked, "Shall we go and spend two hundred silver dinars for bread to feed them?"
He said to them, "How many loaves do you have? Go and see." When they came back, they said, "Five, and two fish."

metadata.item: They did not know how many loaves they had. For a different crowd in the Injil, Mark 8:5, they already knew.

verse.content: He commanded them to sit down in groups on the green grass.

metadata.item: In chapter 8:6 they sit on the ground.

verse.content: And they sat down in groups of fifty or one hundred.

When Isa took the five loaves and the two fish, he looked up. He prayed in dua\' for baraka, then broke the loaves and gave them to his hawariyun to present them to the people. He divided the two fish among everyone.

metadata.item: Or, he praised Allah, the one who gives baraka.

verse.content: They all ate and were satisfied.
And they picked up the leftovers: twelve hand baskets full of bread and fish.
The number of people who ate was five thousand men.
Immediately, Isa commanded his hawariyun to get into the boat and go to the other side by Bethsaida while he dismissed the crowds.
After he sent them away, he went up the mountain to pray in dua\'.
When evening came, the boat was in the middle of the lake and Isa was alone on the land.
He saw the hawariyun struggling to row because the wind was blowing against them. He came to them walking on the water of the lake before dawn. He intended to pass by them.
When the hawariyun saw him walking on the water of the lake, they thought he was a ghost. And they shouted.
They all saw him, and they were terrified. Immediately he spoke to them. He said, "Courage! I am he. Do not be afraid."
Then he got into the boat with them, and the wind stopped. They were completely amazed.
For they did not understand about the loaves, but their hearts were hardened.
When they crossed to the other side, they landed at the town of Gennasaret, and they dropped the anchor of the boat.
When they got out of the boat, the people knew Isa immediately.
They ran around the whole region and began to bring their sick people on mats to wherever they heard that he was.

Wherever he went in villages, cities, or rural areas, they lay their sick people down in the markets for him. They appealed to him to touch even the edge of his robe. Everyone who touched him was healed.
The Pharisees and some of the fuqaha who had come from Al-Quds gathered around him.

metadata.item: They had already decided to reject Isa, and they were looking for reasons to accuse him.

verse.content: They saw that some of his followers were eating with unclean hands. (In other words, they did not wash them.)
The Pharisees, and all the rest of Al-Yahud, do not eat until they wash their hands thoroughly. This is to keep the sunan of their elders.
And when they return from the market, they only eat after washing. And there are many other sunan which they keep. (For instance, washing cups, containers, and copper pots.)
The Pharisees and the fuqaha asked him, "Why do your hawariyun not follow the sunnah of our elders? They eat with unclean hands."
But Isa told them, "You hypocrites! You are the ones Allah spoke of when he said in the scroll of Shaya: 'These people honor me with their lips, but their hearts are far from me.'
They worship me in vain, and their teaching is only sunan invented by men.
You have left the commandments Allah revealed but you hold firmly to sunan invented by men."

Then he told them, "You cleverly reject the commandment of Allah to confirm your sunan. For Allah said by the tongue of Musa, 'Honor your father and your mother' and 'Anyone who curses his father or mother must be executed.'

metadata.item: This includes financial support.
This is a quotation from the Tawrat, Exodus 20:12.
This is a quotation from the Tawrat, Exodus 21:17.

verse.content: But you say: Suppose someone tells his father and his mother, 'What you might have received from me is a qurban to Allah.'
Then you no longer permit him to do anything for his father and his mother.
In this way, you make the word of Allah worthless by your sunan which you have passed down. And you do many things like this."
He called the crowd together again and said, "All of you, listen and understand.
Nothing that goes into a person from outside makes him unclean.
What comes out of a person is what makes him unclean."
After he left the crowds outside and entered the house, his hawariyun asked him about the story.
He said to them, "So are you also foolish? Do you not understand? Nothing that goes into a person from outside makes him unclean.
It does not go into his heart, but his stomach. Then it passes out into the drain." Thus he cleansed all foods.

metadata.item: Or purged or made them halal and tahir. Literally, thus cleansing all foods.

verse.content: But he said, "What comes out of a person is what makes him unclean.
For from inside, from the heart of people, these come out: evil thoughts, sexual immorality, stealing, murder,
adultery, greed, wickedness, deceit, immoral behavior, an evil eye, kufr, pride, and foolishness.
All these evil things come from inside and they make a person unclean."
Then he got up and went to the province of Tyre and Sidon. He entered a house and did not want anyone to know about him. But he could not be hidden.
Immediately, a woman heard about him. Her daughter had been touched by an unclean spirit. When she came, she fell down at his feet.
She was a Phoenician with Greek citizenship from the province of Syria. She asked him to cast out that jinni from her daughter.
He told her, "Let the children first be satisfied. It is not good to take the bread of the children and cast it to the dogs."

metadata.item: Children is not literal here. It refers to Al-Yahud and their special relationship with Allah.
This is not an insult but a test. It was known that Al-Yahud considered other people as dogs. Isa used this to test the woman\'s trust, since he was primarily sent to Bani Israil.

verse.content: The woman answered, "Yes, my mawla. But even the dogs under the table eat from the crumbs of the children."

metadata.item: She passed the test. She believed that even the crumbs that were left over from Isa and which fell to the floor were enough to heal her daughter.

verse.content: He told her, "Because of this word, go. The jinni has left your daughter."
She returned home and found her daughter lying on a bed. The jinni had left her.
Isa went out again from the province of Tyre, passing through Sidon. He returned to Al-Jalil Lake, passing through the Decapolis.
And they brought him a deaf man with a speech impediment. They urged Isa to lay his hands on him.
After he took him apart from the crowd privately, Isa put a finger into each of his ears. Then Isa spat and touched the tongue of the deaf man.
He looked up, sighed, and said, "Ifatha!" (This means "Be opened.")
His ears were opened, his tongue was released immediately, and he spoke clearly.
He commanded them not to tell anyone. But the more he commanded them, the more they proclaimed it.

metadata.item: Isa was not interested in fame. Having a crowd around him would hinder him from going where he needed to go.

verse.content: They were amazed beyond all measure. They said, "Isa has done all things well! He even makes the deaf man hear and the dumb man speak."
In those days, when another large crowd gathered, and they had nothing to eat. Isa called the hawariyun to him and told them,

metadata.item: It seems this is a different crowd than in chapter 6:35-44, and it included people who were not Yahud. There are hints of this in verses 2, 3, 5, 6, and 8.

verse.content: "I feel compassion for the crowd. They have stayed with me three days now, and they have nothing to eat.

metadata.item: In chapter 6, the hawariyun take the initiative.

verse.content: If I send them away to their homes hungry, they will faint on the way. Some of them have come from distant places."
The hawariyun answered him, "Who can provide bread enough to feed these in this isolated place?"
He asked them, "How many loaves do you have?" They said, "Seven."

metadata.item: In chapter 6, the hawariyun did not know how many they had.

verse.content: At that, he commanded the crowd to sit on the ground. He took the seven loaves, prayed in dua' for baraka and thanked Allah, and broke them. He gave them to his followers to distribute. And they set it before the crowd.

metadata.item: Compare the Injil, Mark 6:39, where they sit on green grass.

verse.content: They also had some small fish, and he prayed in dua\' for baraka on them and presented them also.

metadata.item: Or, he praised Allah, the one who gives baraka.

verse.content: They all ate and were satisfied. They gathered the leftover pieces and filled seven large baskets.

metadata.item: This is a different word than the hand baskets mentioned in the Injil, Mark 6:43. It is a larger basket not used by Al-Yahud.

verse.content: There were about four thousand people, and he sent them away.
Immediately, he got into a boat with his hawariyun. They went to the region of Dalmanutha.

metadata.item: Another name for Magadan. This is a city on the west shore of Al-Jalil lake.

verse.content: The Pharisees came to him and started arguing with him. They asked him to show them an ayah from the heavens to test him.
He sighed in his ruh. He said, "Why does this generation ask for an ayah? I tell you a true saying: No ayah will be given to this generation."
He left them, got into a boat, and headed for the other side.
They had forgotten to take bring bread, and they did not have any, except for one loaf in the boat with them.
He commanded them, "Watch out! Beware of the yeast of the Pharisees and the yeast of Herod."

metadata.item: Yeast is often a symbol of evil. Here it means evil teaching.

verse.content: They discussed the matter among themselves. They said, "We have no bread."
Isa knew what was happening and said, "Why are you discussing that you do not have bread? Do you not know yet? Do you not understand yet? Are your hearts hard?
Though you have eyes, do you not see? Though you have ears, do you not hear? Do you not even remember?
When I broke the five loaves for the five thousand, how many hand baskets did you gather of leftover pieces?" They told him, "Twelve."
When I broke the seven loaves for the four thousand, how many large baskets of leftover pieces did you gather?" They said, "Seven."
He said to them, "Do you still not understand?"
And he came to the village of Bethsaida. They brought him a blind man, asking Isa to touch him.
He took the blind man by the hand and led him outside the village. Then Isa spat into his eyes, put his hands on him, and asked him, "Do you see anything?"
The blind man looked up and said, "I see people but they look like trees walking."
Then he put his hands on the eyes of the blind man again, the man looked intently, and he was restored and saw everything clearly.
Isa sent him to his home, saying, "Do not go into the village."
Isa and his hawariyun departed for the village of Caesarea Philippi. On the way, he asked them, "Who do people say I am?"
They told him, "Yahya who did ghusl. Others, Ilyas. Still others, one of the ancient anbiya."
And Isa asked them, "Who do you say I am?" Peter answered him, "You are al-masih al-mustafa."
He ordered them not to tell anyone about him.

He began to teach them that sayyid al-bashar must suffer greatly, be rejected by the elders of the people, the leading ahbar, and the fuqaha, be killed, and after three days be resurrected alive from death.
He said this plainly. And Peter took him aside and began to rebuke him.
But Isa turned and looked at his hawariyun. Then he rebuked Peter, saying, "Go behind me, al-shaitan. You have not set your mind on matters of Allah but on matters of people!"

metadata.item: Peter was not Al-Shaitan, but he expressed thoughts that came from Al-Shaitan.

verse.content: He then called the crowd and his hawariyun and said, "If anyone wants to come after me, he must deny himself, sacrifice himself following the example of my death on the cross, and follow me.
Whoever wants to save his life will lose it. Whoever loses it for my sake and for the sake of the good news will save it.
What does a person benefit if he were to gain the whole of this world and lose his life?
Or what would a person give in exchange for his life?

For suppose someone is ashamed of me and my words in this adulterous, sinful generation. Sayyid al-bashar will be ashamed of him when he comes in the majesty of the glory of his Most Loving King with the holy angels.

metadata.item: This refers to the Arabic names Al-Malik and Al-Wadud, two of the 99 names of Allah. Isa used this title to describe his unique relationship with Allah. Isa called him his Most Loving King, with Isa as his amir. See glossary for more information.

verse.content: He told them, "I tell you a true saying: Indeed some of the ones standing here will not taste death before they see the kingdom of Allah come with power."

metadata.item: Some people think this meant the following story. Others think that it meant the events connected with the destruction of Al-Quds forty years later. Still others think the death referred to is spiritual death, not physical death, and that the establishment of the kingdom of Allah is still future.

verse.content: Six days later, Isa took Peter, Yacoub, and Yahya, and led them by themselves to a high mountain. His appearance in form was changed in front of them.
His clothing turned shining, bright white, whiter than any bleaching on earth could make it.
Then Ilyas along with Musa appeared to them. They were speaking with Isa.
Peter answered and told Isa, "Honored teacher, it is good that we are here. Let us set up three tents: for you, for Musa, and for Ilyas."
(He did not know what to say because he was terrified.)
Then a cloud covered them with its shadow and a voice came from the cloud, "This is my beloved amir. Listen to him."

metadata.item: The amir is superior to Musa, who represents the law of the Tawrat, and to Ilyas, who represents the anbiya.

verse.content: Unexpectedly as they looked around them, they did not see anyone except Isa with them.
As they were going down the mountain, Isa commanded them not to tell anyone what they had seen until sayyid al-bashar was resurrected alive from death.
They kept the matter to themselves, discussing what resurrection from death was.
They asked him, "Why do the Pharisees and the fuqaha say that Ilyas must come first?"
He told them, "Ilyas does come first, to restore all things. And how is it written in the kitab about sayyid al-bashar, that he must suffer many pains and be treated with contempt?

metadata.item: This is a possible reference to the Tawrat, Malachi 4:5-6.

verse.content: But I tell you that Ilyas has already come, and they did whatever they wanted to him, as it is written in the kitab about him."

metadata.item: Yahya had come in the spirit and power of Ilyas, and so he was a fulfillment of this prophecy. See Matthew 11:14

verse.content: When they returned to the rest of the hawariyun, he found a large crowd around them and the fuqaha arguing with them.
And immediately, when the crowd saw him, they were greatly amazed and ran up to greet him.

metadata.item: It is possible that they were amazed because they saw some of the shining light from the mountain. Something similar had happened with Musa in the Tawrat, Exodus 34:29, see the Injil, 2 Corinthians 3:13.

verse.content: He asked them, "What are you arguing about with them?"
One of the crowd answered him, "Teacher, I brought you my son who has spirit of dumbness.

metadata.item: The spirit made the boy unable to speak.

verse.content: Whenever it touches him, it seizes him and throws him to the ground. He foams at the mouth, grinds his teeth, and becomes stiff. I asked your hawariyun to cast it out, but they could not."
Isa answered them, "Generation of kuffar, how long must I remain with you? How long must I bear you? Bring him to me."
And so he brought the boy to Isa. As soon as the spirit saw Isa, he immediately convulsed the boy. The boy fell on the ground, writhing and foaming at the mouth.
Isa asked his father, "How long has it touched him?" He answered, "Since childhood.

metadata.item: Isa may have been asking so that the source of the touching would be known. Since it was from the boy's childhood, it may not have been due to anything the child had done.

verse.content: It often throws him into the fire or into water to destroy him. But if you can do anything, help us and have pity on us."
Isa said, "'If you can?' All things are possible to a person who trusts."
Immediately, the father of the boy shouted, "I trust! Help me in my disbelief!"

metadata.item: The disbelief of the father may have been the reason for the jinni touching his son.

verse.content: When Isa saw that the crowd was running toward him, he rebuked the unclean spirit, "Deaf and dumb spirit, I command you to come out of him and not to enter into him anymore."
And as the jinni shouted and convulsed the boy violently, it came out. The boy seemed to be dead. Most of the people said that he was dead.

metadata.item: It is unclear whether the boy was unconscious or dead.

verse.content: But Isa took his hand and raised him, and he stood up.
When Isa entered the house, his hawariyun asked him in private, "Why could we not cast it out?"
He told them, "This kind cannot be cast out except through praying in dua\'."
When they left there, they passed through Al-Jalil. And he did not want anyone to know.

For he was teaching his hawariyun. He said to them, "Sayyid al-bashar must be delivered into the hands of men who will kill him. But after he has been killed, he will be resurrected alive from death after three days."

metadata.item: This is a reference to the Tawrat, Shaya 52:13-53:12, Hosea 6:3, Yunis 1:17, and the Zabur, Psalms 16:10.

verse.content: But they did not understand the saying, and they were afraid to ask him.
Then they came to Capernaum. While Isa was in the house, he asked them, "What were you discussing on the way?"
They were silent, because on the way they had been discussing who was the greatest.
Then Isa sat down and called the hawariyun. He told them, "Suppose someone wants to be the first. Let him be the last of all and servant of all."
And when he had received a child, Isa placed him in the middle of them. As he hugged him, Isa said,
"Whoever receives one of these children in my name receives me. And whoever receives me receives not me, but the One who sent me."
Yahya said, "Teacher, we saw a man casting out jinn in your name. So we prohibited him because he was not following us."
But Isa said, "Do not prohibit him. No one who does a work of power in my name can quickly say something evil about me.
Whoever is not against us is for us.
I tell you a true saying: Whoever gives you a cup of water to drink because you are mine will not lose his reward.
Suppose someone leads one of these little ones who trust in me astray. It would be better for him to have a large stone tied around his neck and to be thrown into the sea.
If your hand makes you stumble, cut it off.
Entering life maimed is better for you than having both hands and going into the unquenchable fire of Jahannam.

metadata.item: In Al-Janna.

verse.content: If your foot makes you stumble, cut it off.
Entering life crippled is better for you than having both feet and being thrown into Jahannam with both feet.
If your eye makes you stumble, pull it out. Entering into the life of the kingdom of Allah with one eye is better than being thrown into Jahannam with two eyes.
There their worm never dies and the fire is unquenchable.
Everyone will be salted with fire.
Salt is good, but if it loses its saltiness, how can it be seasoned? Have salt in yourselves and be at peace with one another."
He went from there to Yahudia and the East Bank. The crowds flocked to him again and he taught them, as was his habit.
Then some Pharisees came to him to test him. They asked him, "Is it halal for a man to divorce his wife?"
He answered them, "What did Musa command you in the Tawrat?"
They said, "Musa permitted a man to write a certificate of divorce and dismiss her."
Isa told them, "He wrote you this command because of the hardness of your heart.
But from the beginning of creation, Allah created people male and female.
Because of this, a man leaves his father and mother.
And the two become one body. So they are no longer two, but they are one body.
Therefore, people must not separate what Allah has joined."
Then in the house again, the hawariyun asked him about the matter.
He told them, "If a man divorces his wife and marries another woman, he commits adultery against her.
And if a woman divorces her husband and marries another man, she commits adultery."

metadata.item: This was legally possible in that time.
See notes at Luke 16:18.

verse.content: And they were bringing their children to him for him to touch them, and the hawariyun rebuked them.
But when Isa saw that, he became angry, and told them, "Let the children come to me. Do not forbid them, because the kingdom of Allah belongs to people like these.
I tell you a true saying: Whoever does not receive the kingdom of Allah like a child will never enter it."
And as he took the children in his arms, he gave them a baraka by laying his hands upon them.
As he was going out, a man ran up, knelt in front of him, and asked him, "Righteous teacher, what must I do to inherit a portion in eternal spiritual life?"
Isa told him, "Why do you call me 'righteous'? Allah alone is righteous.

metadata.item: i.e. If I am from Allah and teach the way of Allah, you must obey me. But if your intent is to flatter me, I am not interested.

verse.content: You know the commandments of the Tawrat: Do not murder, do not steal, do not give false shahada, do not cheat, and honor your father and mother."

metadata.item: This is a quotation from the Tawrat, Exodus 20:13, Deuteronomy 5:17.
This is a quotation from the Tawrat, Exodus 20:15, Deuteronomy 5:19.
This is a quotation from the Tawrat, Exodus 20:16, Deuteronomy 5:20.
This is an allusion to the Tawrat, Amos 8:5.
This is a quotation from the Tawrat, Exodus 20:12, Deuteronomy 5:16.

verse.content: The man told him, "Teacher, I have kept all of these since my youth."
