But as Isa looked at him, he loved him, and told him, "You only lack one thing. Go and sell what you have. Give the money to the poor, and you will have treasure in Al-Janna. Then come follow me."
But the man was shocked at this word. He went away sad, because he had many possessions.
As Isa looked around him, he told his hawariyun, "It is very hard for rich people to enter the kingdom of Allah!"
His followers were amazed at his words. Then Isa said, "Children, it is very hard to enter the kingdom of Allah!

metadata.item: Al-Yahud thought that people were rich because Allah had given them baraka and rida and they would go to Al-Janna. If even they could not enter the kingdom of Allah, then who could enter it?
The word children is not literal. Isa was never married and had no children. He used this word to show tenderness.

verse.content: A camel going through the eye of a needle is easier than a rich man entering the kingdom of Allah."

metadata.item: In other words, impossible for humans. See verse 27.

verse.content: They were very amazed and asked each other, "Then who will be saved?"
Isa looked at them and said, "With people, this is impossible, but not for Allah. Allah can do anything."
Peter began to tell him, "We have left everything and followed you. How shall it be for us?"
Isa said, "I tell you a true saying: Everyone who has left house, brothers, sisters, mother, father, children, or property for the sake of the good news

will be rewarded one hundred times as much in return in this world: houses, brothers, sisters, mothers, children, and property, along with persecution. In the next life, his reward will be eternal spiritual life in Al-Janna.
But many who are first will be last, and the last will be first."

And they were going up on their way to Al-Quds, and Isa was going ahead of them. The hawariyun were amazed, and those who followed them were afraid. Isa got alone with his twelve hawariyun and began to tell them what was going to happen to him,

metadata.item: They may have been amazed and afraid because Isa seemed to be going intentionally into a dangerous situation.

verse.content: "Look. We are going up to Al-Quds. Sayyid al-bashar will be delivered to the leading ahbar. They will condemn him to be executed and deliver him to the nations of the kuffar.

metadata.item: Al-Quds is on a mountain.

verse.content: They will mock him, spit on him, whip him, and kill him. But after three days, he will be resurrected alive from death."
Then Yacoub and Yahya, the two sons of Zebedee, came to him and said, "Teacher, we want you to
let one of us sit on your right
and one of us on your left in the majesty of your glory."
But Isa told them, "You do not know what you are asking. Can you drink the cup that I will drink? Can you do a ghusl like my ghusl when I do ghusl?"

metadata.item: This ghusl was a ghusl into the waters of death.

verse.content: They said, "We can." Isa said, "You will drink the cup which I drink, and you will do a ghusl into the ghusl that I will do ghusl in.

metadata.item: The cup of suffering.

verse.content: But sitting on my right or left is not something for me to give. It is given to the ones my Most Loving King has prepared."

metadata.item: This refers to the Arabic names Al-Malik and Al-Wadud, two of the 99 names of Allah. Isa used this title to describe his unique relationship with Allah. Isa called him his Most Loving King, with Isa as his amir. See glossary for more information.

verse.content: When the other ten hawariyun heard that, they were angry with Yacoub and Yahya.
Isa called them all and told them, "You know that the rulers of the nations of the kuffar dominate them, and their kings are tyrants over them.
But do not let it be this way among you. But whoever wants to be great should be a servant to you.
And whoever wants to be first should be a slave of everyone.
For even sayyid al-bashar did not come to be served. He came to serve and to sacrifice his life as a ransom for many."
Then they came to Jericho. As Isa, his hawariyun, and a large crowd were leaving it, a blind beggar named Bartimaeus, the son of Timaeus, was sitting beside the road.
And when he heard that it was Isa Al-Nasiri, he shouted, "Isa, Ibn Dawood, have mercy on me!"
Many people rebuked him and told him to be quiet. But he shouted even more, "Ibn Dawood, have mercy on me!"
Isa stopped and said, "Call him." So they called him and told him, "Be encouraged. Get up. He is calling you."
He threw off his cloak, jumped up, and came to Isa.
Isa asked him, "What do you want me to do for you?" The blind man said, "Honored teacher, I want to see again."
Isa told him, "Go. Your trust has healed you." Immediately the man was able to see again, and he followed Isa on the way.
When they approached Al-Quds by the villages of Bethphage and Bethany near Jabal Al-Zaytun, he sent two of his hawariyun, and said to them,
\"Go to the village. Immediately after you enter it, you will find a young donkey tied up, which no one has ever ridden. Untie it and bring it here.
Suppose someone says to you, 'What are you doing with it?' Say: The master needs it and will send it back immediately."
They went and found the young donkey tied up by a door on the street and untied it.
Some people standing there asked them, "What are you doing untying the young donkey?"
They answered just as Isa had said, and they let them take it.
They brought the young donkey to Isa. Then his followers threw their cloaks on it, and Isa sat on it.
Many people threw their cloaks on the road for him. Others put branches cut from the fields on it.

metadata.item: These were ways of honoring him.

verse.content: Those who went ahead and those who followed were calling out, "Al-Hamdu Lillah the Savior! The person who is coming in the name of Rabb Al-Alamin has a baraka!

metadata.item: This was a greeting acknowledging that Isa was al-masih. It is a reference to the Zabur, Psalms 118:26.

verse.content: The coming kingdom of our father Dawood has a baraka. Al-Hamdu Lillah the Savior in the highest place!"

metadata.item: The word father is not literal. Here it means ancestor.
The highest place probably means heaven.

verse.content: Isa went into Al-Quds to the house of Allah. And he looked around at everything. Since it was evening, he returned to Bethany with the twelve hawariyun.
The next day, they returned from Bethany.
From a distance, he saw a fig tree with leaves, and he went toward it to see if he could find something on it. But as he came near, he only found leaves, because it was not the season for figs.
He told the fig tree, "May no one ever eat fruit from you again!" His hawariyun heard him say that.

metadata.item: Some people think that the fig tree represented the umma of Bani Israil. They should have had the fruits of repentance and trust, but they did not. Isa proclaimed the judgment of Allah against them.

verse.content: Then they came to Al-Quds. As Isa entered the house of Allah, he began casting out the merchants and the buyers from it. He turned over the tables of the moneychangers and the seats of the sellers of pigeons.

metadata.item: This portion of the house of Allah was for non-Yahudi ummas to pray. The commerce made it too distracting to pray.

verse.content: He did not allow anything to be carried through the house of Allah.
He taught them, "Is it not written in the kitab: 'My house will be called the house of salat for all the nations'? But you have made it into a cave for thieves."

metadata.item: This is a reference to the Tawrat, Shaya 56:7
This is a reference to the Tawrat, Jeremiah 7:11

verse.content: The leading ahbar and fuqaha heard him. So they began to discuss how to destroy him. For they were afraid of him because the crowds were amazed at his teaching.

metadata.item: Since they were responsible for the house of Allah, this meant that Isa was saying they were disobeying the Tawrat.

verse.content: Isa went out of the city in the evening.
In the morning, he passed by and they saw the fig tree. It had dried up from its roots.
Peter remembered and said, "Honored teacher, look! The fig tree that you cursed has dried up."

metadata.item: This may be a prophecy about what would happen to Bani Israil when they finally rejected Isa and were destroyed later by the Romans.

verse.content: Isa answered them, "Trust in Allah.

I tell you a true saying: Suppose someone says to this mountain, 'Be picked up and thrown in the sea.' If doubt does not enter his heart, and he trusts that it will happen, it will be fulfilled for him.

metadata.item: In the Tawrat, mountains are sometimes a symbol of kingdoms. When Isa said, "this mountain," he may have been referring to the kingdom of Bani Israil, which would soon be destroyed.

verse.content: Therefore I tell you: whatever you pray in dua\' and ask for, trust that you will receive it, and it will be done for you.
When you stand up to do salat, if someone has something against anyone,
pardon him so that your Most Gracious King who is in heaven will forgive you your sins."

metadata.item: This refers to the Arabic names Al-Rahman and Al-Malik, two of the 99 names of Allah. See the glossary for a discussion on this term.

verse.content: Then they entered Al-Quds again. While Isa was walking in the house of Allah, the leading ahbar and fuqaha and elders of the people came toward him.
They said to him, "By what authority do you do these things, or who gave you this authority to do them?"

metadata.item: The leading ahbar were in charge of the house of Allah. They were probably asking him on what basis he had cast out the merchants and moneychangers. They may also have had a financial benefit from the traders that worked in the house of Allah.

verse.content: Isa said to them, "I will ask you one question. Answer me and I will tell you by what authority I do these things.
Was the ghusl of repentance that Yahya did from heaven or from people? Answer me."

metadata.item: Al-Yahud were afraid of offending Allah by mispronouncing his name, so sometimes they said "heaven" instead of "Allah."

verse.content: They discussed the matter among themselves, saying, "If we say, 'From heaven,' he will say, 'Why did you not believe him?'
And if we say, 'From people...'" They feared the crowd because everyone considered Yahya to be a nabi.
So as they answered Isa, "We do not know," Isa told them, "So I will not tell you by what authority I do these things."
Then he began to tell them stories: "A man planted a vineyard, and he built a hedge around it, dug a winepress, built a tower to guard it, rented it to tenant farmers, and went away.
At the time of harvest, he sent a slave to the farmers to take his portion from the grapes of the vineyard from them.
But they grabbed the slave, beat him, and sent him away empty-handed.
He sent another slave, and they struck that slave on the head and treated him with shame.
He sent another. They killed him. The same thing happened to many other slaves. They beat some and killed some.
He only had his beloved son left. Finally, the man sent him to them, saying, 'They will respect my son.'

metadata.item: The son had the authority of his father.

verse.content: But the tenants discussed the matter among themselves, saying, 'This one is the heir. Come, let us kill him, and the inheritance will be ours!'

metadata.item: They may have thought that it would be deserted property that they could take over.

verse.content: So they grabbed him and killed him and threw him outside the vineyard.
Therefore what will the owner of the vineyard do? He will come, destroy the tenants, and give the vineyard to others!
Have you not read the kitab? 'The stone that the builders rejected has become the cornerstone of the building.
This is from Rabb Al-Alamin, and it is amazing in our eyes.'"

metadata.item: This is a quotation from the Zabur, Psalms 118:22-23.

verse.content: And they tried to arrest him, but they were afraid of the crowd, They knew that he told the story about them. So they left and went away.

metadata.item: They were the builders who rejected the best stone and they were the tenant farmers who had beaten and killed the slaves.

verse.content: They sent some Pharisees and members of the party of Herod to him to trap him with a word.

So when they came, they said, "Teacher, we know that you are true and you do not care what people think. For you do not seek to please, but you teach the sirat of Allah in truth. Is it halal to pay the jizya to Caesar or not? Should we pay it or not?"

metadata.item: If he said, "Yes," the Pharisees would attack him, and if he said, "No," the party of Herod would attack him.

verse.content: Since he knew their hypocrisy, he said to them, "Why are you testing me? Bring a dinar for me to see."

metadata.item: Isa knew what was hidden.
This dinar was the wage of a laborer for one day.

verse.content: They brought him a dinar, and he said to them, "Whose picture and inscription are these?" They said, "Caesar\'s."

metadata.item: The dinar used in Palestine at that time did not have Caesar\'s picture and motto in deference to the monotheism of Al-Yahud. The Pharisees may have given him one of the dinars with Caesar\'s picture on it to shock him or to emphasize their rejection of paying a jizya to Caesar on the grounds of idolatry. Isa exposes that they had given him this kind of dinar.

verse.content: Isa told them, "Then give to Caesar what belongs to Caesar, and give Allah what belongs to Allah." They were greatly amazed at him.

metadata.item: They thought they had trapped him.

verse.content: Then some Sadducees came to him. They deny the resurrection. They asked him,
"Teacher, Musa wrote for us in the Tawrat: If a brother dies and leaves a wife but has no child, his brother should marry the widow and have children for his brother.

metadata.item: This is a reference to the Tawrat, Deuteronomy 25:5.

verse.content: There were seven brothers. The first married and died and did not have children.
The second married the widow and died without children. The same thing happened with the third,
and none of the seven had children. Last of all, the woman also died.
In the resurrection, whose wife will she be? For all seven brothers had her as wife."

metadata.item: Since they denied the day of resurrection, they thought this hypothetical situation proved their belief. They assumed a woman could not be married to more than one man.

verse.content: Then Isa said to them, "Is this not why you have gone astray? It is because you do not know the kitab nor the power of Allah.
For when dead people are resurrected alive, they do not marry. They are like the angels in Al-Janna.

metadata.item: Since they are eternal, they do not need to reproduce to continue the race, so marriage is not necessary.

verse.content: But as for the resurrection of the dead, have you not read in the Tawrat the verse about the burning bush? Allah spoke to him, 'I am the Rabb of Ibrahim and the Rabb of Ishaq and the Rabb of Yacoub.'

metadata.item: This story is in the Tawrat, Exodus 3:1-14.
Musa.
The point of Isa is that the Tawrat does not say "was" here.
This is a quotation from the Tawrat, Exodus 3:6. When this conversation was happening, Ibrahim, Ishaq and Yacoub had been dead for hundreds of years.

verse.content: Allah is not Rabb of dead people but Rabb of living people. You have been greatly led astray."

metadata.item: So Ibrahim, Ishaq and Yacoub had been resurrected.

verse.content: One of the fuqaha came and heard the argument, and realized that Isa had answered well. He asked Isa, "What is the most important commandment?"

metadata.item: The fuqaha and Pharisees had opposite views from the Sadducees, so they were happy when Isa had proved that the view of the Sadducees about the resurrection wrong.

verse.content: Isa answered, "The first one is: 'Listen, Bani Israil, Allah is our Mawla. There is no god except him.
And you shall love Allah your Mawla with all your heart, with all your soul, with all your mind, and with all your strength.'

metadata.item: This is a quotation from the Tawrat, Deuteronomy 6:4-5.

verse.content: The second is this: 'Love your neighbor as yourself.' No other commandment is greater than these two."

metadata.item: This is a quotation from the Tawrat, Leviticus 19:18.

verse.content: The faqih answered, "Teacher, truly you have spoken well. Allah is One, and there is no god except him.
And loving Allah with all your heart, with all your understanding, and with all your strength, and loving your neighbor as yourself is more than all burnt qarabin and sacrifices."
Isa recognized his wise answer, and he told him, "You are not far from the kingdom of Allah." After that, no one dared to ask him anything.
Isa began to teach in the house of Allah. He asked, "How do the fuqaha say that al-masih is Ibn Dawood?

metadata.item: The son of Dawood.

verse.content: Dawood himself said about him by Holy Ruh Allah in the Zabur: 'Al-Mawla said to my mawla: Sit at my right side until I put your enemies under your feet.'

metadata.item: This is a quotation from the Zabur, Psalms 110:1.

verse.content: If Dawood calls him 'My mawla,' how can he be his son?" A large crowd heard him gladly.

metadata.item: A mawla is superior, so the mawla of Dawood would be superior to Dawood. A son is submissive, or junior, to his father, so Ibn Dawood would be inferior or in submission to Dawood.

verse.content: He said in his teaching, "Beware of the fuqaha. They love walking around with long religious robes, being greeted in the markets,
standing in the front row in the houses of salat, and sitting in the seats of honor in the banquets.
But they devour the houses of widows and make long salat to pretend they are pious. They will receive the greater punishment!"

metadata.item: On Yawm Al-Din.

verse.content: He sat opposite the box of contributions in the house of Allah, watching the crowds contributing money. Many rich people threw in large amounts.
A poor widow came and gave two fils.

metadata.item: This fils was worth less than 1% of the daily wage of a laborer.

verse.content: He called his hawariyun and told them, "I tell you a true saying: This poor widow has contributed more than everyone else has contributed.
They all gave what they could easily afford, but despite her poverty she contributed all she had, her whole living.
As Isa was leaving the house of Allah, one of his hawariyun said to him, "Teacher, teacher, the stones of the house of Allah are wonderful! Its buildings are wonderful!"
Isa said to him, "Do you see these great buildings? No stone will be left on top of another stone. They will all be thrown down."
When Isa was sitting on Jabal Al-Zaytun opposite the house of Allah, Peter, Yacoub, Yahya, and Andrew asked him privately,
"Tell us when these things will happen. What will the ayah be that they are about to be fulfilled?"
Isa began to tell them, "Be on your guard that no one leads you astray!
Many people will come in my name, claiming, 'I am he.' They will mislead many.

metadata.item: The expected al-masih.

verse.content: Do not be afraid when you hear of wars or rumors of wars. These things must happen, but the end is not yet.
One nation will rise up against another nation and one kingdom against another kingdom. There will be earthquakes. These are only the beginning of the birth pangs.
Be on guard for yourselves. They will deliver you to courts and whip you in places of salat. Because of me, they will summon you before governors and kings as a shahada to them.
The good news must first be proclaimed to all nations.
But when they arrest you and deliver you for trial, do not be worried about what you will say. But say whatever is given to you at that time. For you are not the speakers, but Holy Ruh Allah.
A man will deliver his brother to death, and a father will deliver his son. Children will rise up against their parents and have them executed.

metadata.item: He will report him to the police or other authorities and give shahada against him.

verse.content: All people will hate you because of my name. But whoever endures until the end will be saved.
When you see the detestable thing which causes destruction standing where it should not be (let the reader understand), then those who live in Yahudia should flee to the mountains.

metadata.item: This was fulfilled in A.D. 70 when the Romans set up their flag in the house of Allah.

verse.content: Whoever is on the roof should not go down into his house to take anything from it.

metadata.item: The roofs were flat and were used as living and sleeping spaces

verse.content: Whoever is in the field should not return home to get his cloak.

metadata.item: The main point is to flee quickly.

verse.content: Woe to the women who are pregnant or nursing in those days!

metadata.item: Women who were pregnant or who had nursing babies could not flee quickly.

verse.content: Pray to Allah in dua\' that this would not happen in the winter.

metadata.item: Winter was cold and rain was common, making travel difficult.

verse.content: For in those days, there will be the worst suffering since Allah first created the world. It will never happen again, either.
If Rabb Al-Alamin had not shortened the period of those days, no one would be saved. But because of the chosen people whom Allah selected, he shortened those days.
And then, do not believe anyone who tells you, 'Al-masih is here!' Or, 'He is there!'
Dajjals who claim to be al-masih and liars who prophesy will do ayat and miracles to mislead even the chosen people, if possible.
I am telling you everything beforehand, so be on your guard.
But after the distress of those days, the sun will be darkened and the moon will not give its light.
The stars will fall from the heavens, and the powers in the heavens will be shaken.
Then you will see sayyid al-bashar coming in the clouds with great power and glory.
Then he will send out his angels, and he will gather his chosen people from the four winds, from the end of the earth until the end of heaven.
Learn this lesson from the fig tree. When its branch becomes tender and it puts forth leaves, you know that the summer is near.

metadata.item: This happens in the spring.

verse.content: In the same way, when you see these things happen, know that it is near, at the gates themselves.
I tell you a true saying: This generation will not end until all these things happen.

metadata.item: Isa spoke these words about 33 A.D. Al-Quds was destroyed in 70 A.D.

verse.content: The heavens and the earth will end, but my words will never end.
But no one knows about the day or the hour that these things will happen. The angels in heaven do not know, and the beloved amir does not know. Only the Most Gracious King knows.
Be on your guard! Watch out and pray in dua\'! You do not know when the time this come.
It is like a man who travels away from his home. He delegates all the matters of the house to his slaves, and gives each one his responsibility. He orders the doorkeeper to keep watch diligently.
So be ready, because you do not know the time when the master of the house will come, whether it is in the evening, at midnight, when the rooster calls, or in the morning.
Otherwise, he will come suddenly and find you sleeping.
So what I tell you, I tell everyone: Watch!"
Two days before the Passover Eid and the Eid of Unleavened Bread, the leading ahbar and fuqaha were seeking how to arrest him quietly and kill him.

metadata.item: Unleavened bread is made without yeast, and does not rise. It is flat like crackers.

verse.content: For they said, "It is better for us not to do it during the eid. Otherwise, there may be a riot among the people."

metadata.item: The Passover Eid was only one day but it was followed immediately by the Eid of Unleavened Bread, and they were all considered one eid.

verse.content: While Isa was in the house of Simon, who had previously had leprosy, in the village of Bethany, a woman came with an alabaster jar full of pure nard. Then she broke the jar and poured the nard on the head of Isa as he was reclining at the table.

metadata.item: Alabaster is an expensive white stone.
This was an expensive perfumed oil. Women often had their life savings (in the form of perfume) stored in jars.

verse.content: Some of those who were there were angry. They said among themselves, "Why was this perfume wasted?
It would have been better for the nard to be sold for three hundred dinars and be donated to the poor!" And they rebuked her.

metadata.item: This was about the wages of a laborer for one year.

verse.content: But Isa told them, "Leave her alone! Why are you bothering her? She has done a beautiful thing for me.
You will always have poor people with you. Whenever you want, you can give alms to them. But I will not always be with you.

metadata.item: Or, do good.

verse.content: She has done what she could. She has poured the perfume on my body in preparation for my burial.
I tell you a true saying: Wherever the good news is proclaimed in the whole world, what she has done will be told in memory of her."
After that, Yahuda Iscariot, one of the twelve hawariyun, went to the leading ahbar to deliver Isa to them.
They were happy at the news, and they promised to give him money. So he started looking for an opportunity to betray Isa.

metadata.item: The offered to pay him money worth 120 days of the wage of a laborer.

verse.content: On the first day of the Eid of Unleavened Bread, when the Passover Eid lamb was sacrificed, his hawariyun asked him, "Where shall we prepare the Passover Eid dinner?"

metadata.item: The Eid of Unleavened Bread (one week long) followed immediately after the Passover Eid (one day). As a result, the Passover Eid was sometimes considered the first day of the Eid of Unleavened Bread.
People from Al-Jalil celebrated the eid one day earlier than people in Yahudia.

verse.content: He sent two of his hawariyun and told them, "Go to the city, and a man carrying a water jar will meet you. Follow him.
When he enters a house, tell its owner, 'The teacher says to you: Where is my guest room so I can eat the Passover Eid dinner with my hawariyun?'
He will take you up to a large, furnished room on the upper floor. Prepare everything for us there."

metadata.item: Isa knew that Yahuda was looking for an opportunity to betray him, and he knew that the will of Allah was that he should not die before eating the Passover Eid dinner with his hawariyun.

verse.content: So the hawariyun went to the city, and found everything just as Isa had told them. So they prepared the Passover Eid meal.
When it was evening, Isa came with the twelve hawariyun.
While they were reclining and eating, Isa told them, "I tell you a true saying: One of you who is eating with me will betray me."
They began to be distressed. One after another, they asked him, "Am I the one?"
He told them, "It is one of the twelve hawariyun, who is dipping his bread with me.

metadata.item: They had a serving dish in the middle, and each person dipped his bread into the dish.

verse.content: Sayyid al-bashar will go as it is written in the kitab about him, but woe to the person who betrays sayyid al-bashar! It would have been better for that man if he had not been born!"

metadata.item: Be betrayed and die.

verse.content: While they were eating, he took a loaf of bread, praised Allah, broke it, and gave it to them. He said, "Take this! This is my body."

metadata.item: This statement was a major change in the traditional Passover ceremony. The word body is not literal. Isa is saying that the bread represents his body.

verse.content: He took the cup, praised and thanked Allah, and gave it to them, and they all drank from it.
He told them, "This is my blood of the covenant which is poured out as a ransom for many.

metadata.item: This was also a major change in the ceremony. The word blood is not literal. Isa is saying that the contents of the cup represent his blood.
A new covenant between Allah and people. Covenants were ratified by a blood sacrifice.

verse.content: I tell you a true saying: I will not drink from the fruit of the vine until the day when I drink it new in the kingdom of Allah."
After they praised Allah with an anthem, they went out to Jabal Al-Zaytun.
Isa told them, "All of you will turn back from me, as Allah said, 'I will strike the sheep herder, and the sheep will be scattered.'

metadata.item: Isa was the sheep herder and his followers were the sheep. This is a quotation from the Tawrat, Zakariyya 13:7.

verse.content: But after I am resurrected alive, I will go to Al-Jalil before you."
Peter told him, "Even if everyone falls away, I will not!"
Isa told him, "I tell you a true saying: Today, this night, before the rooster calls, you will deny me three times."

metadata.item: Their days began at sunset.
Peter.

verse.content: Peter said strongly, "Even if I must die with you, I will never deny you!" And they all said the same thing.
Then they went to the place named Gethsemane. He told his hawariyun, "Sit here while I pray in dua\'."
He took Peter, Yacoub, and Yahya with him, and he began to be distressed and troubled.
He told them, "My soul is very sad, to the point of death. Remain here and keep watch."
He went on a little way and fell on the ground. He asked Allah in dua' that the hour might pass from him if it were possible.
Then he said, "Loving One! My Beloved King, all things are possible for you. Take this cup away from me. But let it be your will, not my will."

metadata.item: This refers to the Arabic name Al-Wadud, one of the 99 names of Allah. The word in the original language shows a very close, tender relationship with Allah.

verse.content: And he came and found them sleeping. He said to Peter, "Simon, are you sleeping? Could you not watch for one hour?
Watch and pray in dua' that you do not come into temptation. The ruh is willing, but the body is weak."
And he went away again and prayed the same dua\'.
And he came and found them sleeping, for their eyes were heavy. They did not know how to answer him.
And he came to them a third time, and said, "Are you still sleeping and taking your rest? Enough! The hour has come. Sayyid al-bashar will be delivered into the hands of sinners.
Get up. Let us go. Look! My betrayer is near."
And immediately while he was still speaking, Yahuda, one of the twelve hawariyun, arrived with a crowd armed with swords and clubs. They had been sent by the leading ahbar, fuqaha, and the elders.
The betrayer had given them a sign, "He is the one I kiss.Arrest him and take him away under guard."

metadata.item: A kiss in public was a common greeting between men and men and between women and women.

verse.content: Immediately after he arrived, he went forward to Isa and said, "Honored teacher!" and kissed him.
and they laid hands on him and arrested him.
One of the people standing by drew a sword and wounded the slave of the chief habr and cut off his ear.

metadata.item: Peter. See the Injil, Yahya 18:10.

verse.content: Isa said to them, "Did you come out armed with swords and clubs to arrest me like a thief?
I was with you each day in the house of Allah teaching, and you did not arrest me there. But let the kitab be fulfilled."
So they all left him and fled away.
A certain young man followed him, wearing only wearing a linen cloth around his body. They grabbed him,

metadata.item: Some people think that this was Mark, the scribe for this account.

verse.content: but he left the linen cloth behind and ran away naked.
They took Isa to the chief habr, and all the leading ahbar, elders of the people, and fuqaha assembled together.

metadata.item: It was illegal for Al-Yahud to hold a trial at night, but they did it anyway.

verse.content: Peter followed him at a distance into the courtyard of the house of the chief habr. He sat warming himself at the fire with the guards.

metadata.item: It was early spring and it was cold at night.
Probably the temple guards.

verse.content: All the leading ahbar and members of the highest council were looking for shahada against Isa to execute him, but they found nothing.

metadata.item: It was illegal to look for shahada against someone rather than just examine the evidence. They had already decided they wanted to find him guilty.

verse.content: Many testified against him falsely, but their shahada did not agree.
Some of them stood up and gave false shahada against him,
saying, "I will destroy this house of Allah that was made by human hands, and in three days, I will build another not made by human hands."
Even so, their shahada did not agree.
The chief habr stood up in the middle of the assembly and asked Isa, "Do not you have an answer for the shahada they are giving against you?"
But Isa was silent and gave no answer at all. So the chief habr asked him again, "Are you al-masih, the beloved amir of Allah?"

metadata.item: A person who was accused did not have to give shahada about himself.

verse.content: Isa answered him, "I am. And you will see sayyid al-bashar sitting on the right hand of power and coming with the clouds of the sky."

metadata.item: In the original language, this could be understood to refer to the name of Allah.
This is probably a reference to Allah, the Almighty.
This was a reference to the Tawrat, Daniel 7:14.

verse.content: Then the chief habr tore his robe and said, "Why do we need more shahada?

metadata.item: This showed his horror that Isa would claim to be the one Allah made his regent.

verse.content: You have heard his shirk! How does it seem to you?" And they all condemned him as deserving death.

metadata.item: They understood his claim to be the person described in the Tawrat, Daniel 7:13-14, who was appointed by Allah as king over all people forever, to be shirk. See previous footnote.
Asking for a group decision was illegal for Bani Israil. Their laws said that each person should give his opinion individually, starting with the youngest.

verse.content: And some began to spit on him. They covered his face and struck him. They said, "Prophesy!" The guards took him and beat him, too.

metadata.item: Insulting and mocking a person who was accused was illegal for Al-Yahud.
Al-Yahud believed that al-masih would be a nabi and habr and king, all in one person. So since Isa had said he was al-masih, they challenged him as a nabi to prophesy who had hit him.

verse.content: Peter was below in the courtyard, and a maid of the chief habr came by.
She saw Peter warming himself and looked at him. She said, "You also were with Isa Al-Nasiri."
But he denied it. He said, "I do not know or understand what you are saying!" He went out to the forecourt.
When the maid saw him, she began to say again to the people who were standing around, "That man is one of them."
But he denied it again. After a while, the people who were standing told Peter, "You are certainly one of them because you are also from Al-Jalil."

metadata.item: People from Al-Jalil had a distinctive accent.

verse.content: He began to say a curse and swear, "I do not know the man!"
Immediately the rooster called, and Peter remembered the word which Isa spoke to him, "Before the rooster calls, you will deny me three times." And he started crying.

Immediately, very early in the morning, the leading ahbar along with the elders of the people and the fuqaha and all the members of the highest council prepared a plan. They tied Isa and delivered him to the Roman governor Pilate.
Pilate questioned him, "Are you the king of Al-Yahud?" He answered him and said, "You said it."
The leading ahbar accused him of many things.
So Pilate asked him, "Do you not have any answer to make at all? Listen to the many accusations against you!"
But Isa did not answer any more, so that Pilate was amazed.
During the eid, Pilate used to release a prisoner whom the people requested.
There was one man named Barabbas who was arrested with others who had committed murder during the rebellion.
So when the crowd gathered, the people asked Pilate to release a prisoner for them according to his custom.
But Pilate asked them, "Do you want me to release the king of Al-Yahud for you?"
For he realized that the ahbar had arrested Isa because they were jealous of him.
But the ahbar incited the crowd to ask for the release of Barabbas instead.
But Pilate answered them again and said, "What shall I do with the one you call the king of Al-Yahud?"
They shouted again, "Crucify him!"
Pilate asked, "Why? What crime did he commit?" They shouted even more, "Crucify him!"
Pilate wanted to satisfy the crowd, so he released Barabbas for them. After he had whipped Isa severely, he delivered him to be crucified.

metadata.item: Pilate was afraid to offend Al-Yahud and have a bad report about him sent to Caesar.
Many people died from the Roman whipping.

verse.content: The soldiers led Isa into the courtyard of the official residence of the governor, and they gathered the whole squadron.
Then they dressed him in a royal-purple-colored robe and wound thorns into a crown and put it on him.

metadata.item: The bleeding from the whipping would then dry on the robe.
This caused pain and bleeding.

verse.content: They began to greet him, "Hail, king of Al-Yahud!"

metadata.item: Sarcastically.
This was all done in mocking because they did not believe he was a king.

verse.content: And they beat him repeatedly on his head with a reed and spat on him. They kneeled and prostrated themselves in front of him.

metadata.item: They were mocking him.

verse.content: After they had mocked him, they took off the purple robe and put his own clothes back on him. Then they led him out to be crucified.

metadata.item: This would have re-opened the wounds and caused further bleeding.

verse.content: Simon from Cyrene, father of Alexander and Rufus, was coming from the countryside. As he was passing by, the soldiers forced him to carry the cross of Isa.

metadata.item: Isa was weak from loss of blood.

verse.content: Then they brought him to Golgotha (which means 'the place of the skull').
And they offered him wine mixed with myrrh, but he refused it.

metadata.item: This was a painkiller.

verse.content: And as they crucified him, they divided his clothes among them by lot, so each one of them would get his share.
It was the third hour when they crucified him.

metadata.item: 9:00 a.m. according to the Jewish way of counting time.

verse.content: The written notice of the charge against him read "King of Al-Yahud."
They crucified two thieves with him, one on his right and the other on his left.
Those who were passing by mocked him. They shook their heads, saying,

metadata.item: This was an expression of mocking or scorn.

verse.content: "Aha, you who would destroy the house of Allah and build it in three days,
save yourself and come down from the cross!"
Likewise, the leading ahbar and fuqaha mocked him to each other, saying, "He saved others, and now he cannot save himself!
Let al-masih, the king of Bani Israil, come down from the cross now, so that we might see and believe!" Even the two thieves who were crucified with him insulted him.
At the sixth hour, darkness covered all the land until the ninth hour.

metadata.item: Noon.

verse.content: Then, at the ninth hour, Isa shouted loudly: "Eloi, Eloi, lima sabakhthani?" (This means 'My Rabb, my Rabb, why did you desert me?')

metadata.item: In the original language, Elohi, Elohi. Greek does not have a way to represent the sound of h in the middle of a word.

verse.content: Some people standing there heard him and said, "Look! He is calling Ilyas."

metadata.item: These people misunderstood what Isa was saying. In the original language, the name of Allah and Ilyas are similar.

verse.content: One of them ran off to fill a sponge with vinegar, put in on a reed, and offered it to him to drink, saying, "Let us see if Ilyas will come to take him down."

metadata.item: He may have done this because the throat of Isa was dry and he could not speak clearly

verse.content: Isa shouted loudly and breathed his last breath.

metadata.item: For what Isa shouted, see Injil, Luke 23:46.

verse.content: Then the curtain of the house of Allah was torn in two, from top to bottom.

metadata.item: This is the curtain that separated the holy haram and the most holy haram. When this curtain was torn, the way into the most holy haram was opened.
The curtain was about 10 cm thick. For this curtain to be torn at all was a miracle. But since it was torn from the top to the bottom, this was an ayah from Allah.

verse.content: The Roman officer who was standing in front of him saw how he breathed his last breath, and he said, "Truly this man was the beloved amir of Allah!"

metadata.item: The officer was close enough to see how he surrendered his spirit to Allah and died voluntarily and in peace. Another unusual thing about the death of Isa were that he shouted as he died. Most others died quietly. Also, seeing the darkness from noon until when Isa died might have been convincing. History tells us that this officer was named Longinus, and that he became a follower of Isa at this time.

verse.content: Many women were watching from a distance. They included Mariam Magdalene, Mariam Um Yacoub the younger and Yusi, and Salome.
They followed him when he was in Al-Jalil and served him. And many other women went up with him to Al-Quds.
And evening had already come. It was the day of preparation (the day before Al-Sabt).

metadata.item: Al-Yahud considered that their days started at sunset.

verse.content: Yusif of Arimathea, one of the respected members of the highest council, who was waiting for the kingdom of Allah, came before Pilate and asked him for the body of Isa.
Pilate was amazed that he had died so quickly, and summoned the officer to ask if Isa had really already died.

metadata.item: Some people lived for two or three days on the cross before dying. Isa had endured the Roman whipping and lost a lot of blood, so physically he was weaker. He surrendered his life at the same time that the Passover lamb was being sacrificed.

verse.content: When Pilate learned from the officer what had happened, he gave Yusif the body.
Yusif bought a linen cloth, took the body down, wrapped it in the linen cloth, put it in a grave dug out of rock, and rolled a stone against the entrance of the grave.
But Mariam Magdalene and Mariam Um Yacoub and Salome bought spices so they might come and perfume his body.
Very early on the first day of the week, they came to the grave when the sun rose.

metadata.item: Sunday.

verse.content: They said to each other, "Who will roll the stone away from the entrance to the grave for us?"
But they looked and saw that the stone had already been rolled away. For it was very large.
When they entered the grave, they saw a young man in a white robe, sitting on the right side. They were alarmed.

But he told them, "Do not be alarmed! You are seeking Isa, who was crucified. He has been resurrected alive and is not here! Look at the place where they put him. Go and tell his hawariyun, especially Peter, that he is going before you to Al-Jalil. There you will see him as he told you."
And when they came out, they ran away from the grave. For trembling and terror had seized them. And they said nothing to anyone. For they were afraid. 8

metadata.item: Later on, they got over their fear and told the hawariyun. See Luke 24:9-10.

The book of Mark ends here in the most ancient manuscript, on which this translation is based. In various other translations of the Injil that are based on later manuscripts, there is a story inserted here. This translation is from the oldest manuscript of the Injil in the world, (before 350 A.D.), which does not include the story. Thus this translation does not include it. The story is about what Isa told the hawariyun to do after he was resurrected from death to life.

verse.content: Many have written a message about what happened among us. 1 The ones who passed it on to us were eyewitnesses of it and servants of the word since the beginning.

metadata.item: The verse numbers come at the end of the verse.

verse.content: I have followed all these matters carefully from their sources. I thought it was good to record it in order for you, your Excellency Theophilus.

metadata.item: Luke spent a period of time in Palestine (Injil, Acts of the Hawariyun 21:8-27:1). It seems he spent much the of time researching with eyewitnesses who had seen Isa.
Some people think this is a title, meaning "person who loves Allah", rather than a name. He may have been the lawyer for Paul (see also the Injil, Acts of the Hawariyun 1:1)

verse.content: Then your knowledge about what you have learned can be certain.
Zakariyya lived in the reign of Herod the Great, king of Yahudia. Zakariyya was a habr from the group of Abijah, a descendant of Harun. His wife Elizabeth was also descended from Harun.

metadata.item: This was the father of Yahya.
His kingdom also included parts of what is now Lebanon and Syria.

verse.content: They were both righteous. They put into practice everything Rabb Al-Alamin had revealed in the kitab without exception. Allah had rida with them.
However, Elizabeth was barren and they had not been given a son. And they were both old.
The turn of the group of Zakariyya to serve in the house of Allah came. While he was serving,
they chose him to enter the holy haram of Rabb Al-Alamin, burn incense, and intercede. They chose him by casting lots, which was their custom.

metadata.item: This was a great honor, and was given a maximum of once in a lifetime.

verse.content: The crowd of the people was in the courtyard of the haram doing salat at the time to burn incense.
An angel from Rabb Al-Alamin appeared to him. He was standing on the right side of the incense burner.
Zakariyya was disturbed by the vision, and fear overpowered him.
But the angel called to him: "Zakariyya, do not fear. Allah has heard your dua\'. Your wife Elizabeth will give birth to a son. Name him Yahya.
He will make you joyful and glad, and many will rejoice at his birth.
He will have a high position with Rabb Al-Alamin, and he will never drink wine or an intoxicating drink. He will be filled with Holy Ruh Allah, even when he is in the womb of his mother.
He will guide many of Bani Israil to Allah their Mawla.

He will walk before al-masih like Ilyas in ruh and power, to turn the hearts of the fathers back to their children, to turn sinners back to the wisdom of the righteous, and to prepare a repentant people for their Mawla."

metadata.item: This is a reference to the Tawrat, Malachi 4:5-6.

verse.content: Zakariyya asked the angel: "How can I be sure of your word? My wife and I are old."

metadata.item: This shows his doubt and lack of faith.

verse.content: The angel answered him, "I am Jibril, and I am brought near to Allah. I am the rasul of your Rabb to bring you this good news.
I will give you an ayah. You will be silent from now until the promise of Allah is fulfilled in its time. This is because you doubted my true word."
The people were waiting for Zakariyya, and were amazed at his delay in the haram.
When he came out, he was not able to speak. He gestured to them, they understood that he had seen a vision in the haram, and he remained dumb.
When the days of his group in service in the house of Allah finished, Zakariyya returned home.

metadata.item: Each group served for 14 days total.

verse.content: After some days, his wife Elizabeth became pregnant. She isolated herself in their house for five months. She said,
"Rabb Al-Alamin has shown me grace in these days. By his compassion on me, he has removed my shame among people."

metadata.item: It was a great honor to have children and a great shame not to have children.

verse.content: When she reached her sixth month of pregnancy, Allah sent the angel Jibril to the town of Al-Nasira in the province of Al-Jalil.
Allah sent him to a virgin named Mariam, whose fianc Yusif had formally betrothed her. He was one of the descendants of Dawood.

metadata.item: Al-Yahud had three steps to marriage: engagement, betrothal, and marriage. At betrothal, a couple was legally husband and wife, but they had not consummated the marriage. This is the stage of Mariam and Yusif at this point.

verse.content: The angel entered and said to her, "Assalamu Alaykum. May the rida of Allah be with you. Rabb Al-Alamin is with you."
She was disturbed by his word and wondered what this greeting meant.
The angel said to her, "Mariam, do not be afraid. Allah has rida towards you.
I will give you an ayah: you will become pregnant and give birth to a son. You will call him Isa.
He will be highly honored and will be called the beloved amir of Allah, and Allah Al-Mawla will give him the throne of his father Dawood.

metadata.item: Arabic wajih.
The word father is not literal. Here it means descendant. Mariam was descended from Dawood.

verse.content: He will reign as king forever over the family of Yacoub, and his kingdom will not end.
Mariam asked the angel, "How can this be, since no man has had sex with me?"

metadata.item: Mariam did not doubt the words, but she asked how it could happen.

verse.content: The angel answered her, "Holy Ruh Allah will descend on you. The power of the Most High will cover you. Therefore your holy, sinless son will be called the beloved amir of Allah.

metadata.item: This refers to the Arabic name Al-Aly, one of the 99 names of Allah.
Arabic zaki.

verse.content: Your relative Elizabeth is also pregnant with a son, despite her age. She was called barren, but this is the sixth month of her pregnancy.

metadata.item: If Elizabeth was a blood relative, this means that Mariam was also descended from Harun. Some of her ancestors would have been descended from Harun and others from Dawood (see last note on Luke 3:23).

verse.content: Allah can do anything."
Mariam said, "I am a servant of Rabb Al-Alamin. Let what you said happen to me." Then the angel left.
Mariam got up in those days and went quickly to a town in the mountains of Yahudia.
She entered the house of Zakariyya and greeted Elizabeth.
When Elizabeth heard the greeting of Mariam, the baby in her womb jumped. Holy Ruh Allah came down on her and filled her.

metadata.item: Yahya

verse.content: She shouted, "You have more baraka than any other woman in the universe. The fruit in your womb also has baraka.

metadata.item: Isa

verse.content: Has Allah really honored me so much that the mother of my mawla visited me?
The baby in my womb jumped for joy as soon as your greeting came to my ear!
You have baraka because you trusted in the fulfillment of the true promise of your Rabb."
Mariam said, "I praise Rabb Al-Alamin with my whole heart.
My ruh rejoices in Allah my Savior.

metadata.item: This refers to the Arabic name Al-Nasir, considered by some to be one of the 99 names of Allah.

verse.content: The All-seeing One has rida toward his humble servant. From now on, people in all generations will say I have baraka.

metadata.item: This refers to the Arabic name Al-Basir, one of the 99 names of Allah.
Mariam

verse.content: The Mighty, Great One has brought me his greatest ayat. His name is Holy.

metadata.item: This refers to the Arabic names Al-Qadir and Al-Azim, two of the 99 names of Allah.
This refers to the Arabic name Al-Qudus, one of the 99 names of Allah.

verse.content: His mercy is for those who fear him from generation to generation.

metadata.item: This refers to the Arabic name Al-Rahim, one of the 99 names of Allah.

verse.content: His hand is glorious in strength. He scattered those with proud thoughts in their hearts.

metadata.item: This does not mean that Allah has a body. It refers to the power of Allah.
This refers to the Arabic name Al-Majid, one of the 99 names of Allah.
This refers to the Arabic name Al-Qawi, one of the 99 names of Allah.

verse.content: He lowered the kings from their thrones, and raised the humble.

metadata.item: Lowered and raised refer to the Arabic names Al-Khafid and Al-Rafi', two of the 99 names of Allah.
This is a reference to the Tawrat, 1 Samuel 2:6-7.

verse.content: He fed the hungry with his good food. He sent away the rich empty-handed.

metadata.item: This refers to the Arabic name Al-Razzaq, one of the 99 names of Allah.

verse.content: He aided Bani Israil his slaves in faithfulness to his mercy.
This is what he promised forever to our fathers, Ibrahim and his family.\"

metadata.item: The word fathers is not literal. Here it means ancestors.

verse.content: Mariam remained with Elizabeth about three months, and then returned to her house.
Elizabeth went into labor and she gave birth to her son.
Her neighbors and relatives heard that Rabb Al-Alamin had shown much mercy to her, and they rejoiced together.
On the eighth day, they came to circumcise the boy. They wanted to call him the name of his father Zakariyya.

metadata.item: Circumcision was commanded to be done on the eighth day after birth (see the Tawrat, Genesis 17:12), and it became custom to give the baby a name on that day.

verse.content: But his mother objected. She said, "No. He must be named Yahya."
They answered her, "But none of you has this name."

metadata.item: Apparently people usually named their children after a relative.

verse.content: They gestured to the father of the boy to know what he wanted the boy to be named.
He asked for a writing board and wrote, "His name is Yahya." Everyone was amazed.
Immediately his mouth and tongue were loosened, and he praised Allah greatly.
All the neighbors were astounded at what happened. The people talked about these matters in all Yahudia.
Everyone who heard about it meditated in his heart. They asked, "What will the destiny of this boy be? "He is definitely aided by Rabb Al-Alamin.
Then Holy Ruh Allah came down on his father Zakariyya and filled him. He prophesied, "67 Al-hamdu Lillah, the Rabb of Bani Israil, because he aided his people and ransomed them.
He raised up a mighty victor for us from the family of his slave Dawood.

metadata.item: Isa.

verse.content: He said this through the mouth of his holy anbiya from ancient times.
He did it to save us from our enemies, and from the hands of those who hate us.
This shows mercy to our forefathers to fulfill his holy covenant.
He fulfilled his oath to our father Ibrahim.

metadata.item: The word father is not literal. Here it means ancestor.

verse.content: He rescued us from the hand of our enemies. Then we can worship him without fear,
fearing Allah and being righteous before him all our days.
You, my son, will be called nabi of the Most High. You will walk before our mawla to prepare his ways.

metadata.item: Yahya.
This refers to the Arabic name Al-Aly, one of the 99 names of Allah.

verse.content: He gives his umma knowledge of saving mercy through forgiveness of their sins.

metadata.item: Isa.

verse.content: Our Rabb is compassionate and merciful. He will send al-masih to us from above like the rising sun.

metadata.item: This refers to the Arabic names Al- Raouf and Al- Rahim, two of the 99 names of Allah.

verse.content: He will give light to those sitting in the darkness and the shadows of death. He will guide our steps in the sirat of peace.

metadata.item: This may refer to the Arabic name Al-Nur, one of the 99 names of Allah.
This refers to the Arabic name Al-Hadi, one of the 99 names of Allah.
This refers to the Arabic name Al-Salaam, one of the 99 names of Allah.

verse.content: The boy Yahya grew and became strong in ruh. He lived in the wilderness until the time to give his message to Bani Israil.
In those days, Caesar Augustus issued a tax decree to conduct a census of all the residents of the empire.
This was the first census, during the rule of Quirinius, the Roman ruler over Syria.

metadata.item: This was in about 3-2 B.C.
Literally, hegemony, a general word for rule. The word for governor is not used here.
He later became governor.

verse.content: Everyone went to his original home town to be counted.
So Yusif also traveled from the town of Al-Nasira in the province of Al-Jalil to Bait Lahm, the town of Dawood, in Yahudia. This was because he was descended from Dawood.
He went to be counted with his fiance Mariam, who was pregnant.

metadata.item: Or betrothed. They were legally married, but the marriage had not been consummated. Her pregnancy was from Holy Ruh Allah. Al-Yahud had three steps to marriage: engagement, betrothal, and marriage. At betrothal, a couple was legally husband and wife, but they had not consummated the marriage. This was the stage of Mariam and Yusif.

verse.content: While they were there, the time came for her birth pangs.
She gave birth to her first-born son. She wrapped him and laid him down in a feeding trough, because the guest place was full.

metadata.item: She later had other children with Yusif, who became her husband. See the Injil, Mark 6:3..

Some translations say inn or khan, but this is inaccurate. This is the same word used in Luke 22:11, and its proper translation is guest place or guest room. A different word, which does mean inn, is used in Luke 10:34. It seems that Mariam and Yusif were staying in a one-room house. Many houses in those days were one-room houses, with an upper level accessible by stairs where guests would usually stay. Because of the census, this part was apparently already full with other relatives. Animals were usually brought inside at night and stayed in the lower part of the room. Their food was in feeding troughs, and Isa was put in one of these. (see verse 12)

verse.content: There were shepherds staying in the pastures of that town. They were guarding their flocks at night.
An angel from Rabb Al-Alamin appeared. The light of the majesty of Rabb Al-Alamin was shining around them. So they were very afraid.
But the angel said to them, "Do not be afraid. I give you good news of great joy for all people:
Your mawla the savior, the expected al-masih, was born today in the city of Dawood.

metadata.item: Al-masih is a title, not a name. As such, it is not capitalized. Al-masih means the one anointed with oil to show his appointment by Allah as king, habr, and nabi.

verse.content: This is the ayah for you: You will find a newborn boy wrapped and sleeping in a feeding trough.

metadata.item: Or lying down.
The ayah for them was that al-masih, though a king, would be born in a common house and wrapped the way normal children were wrapped.

verse.content: A group of the heavenly army appeared with the angel, and they praised Allah. They said,

metadata.item: This refers to angels, who fight in the path of Allah.

verse.content: "Al-hamdu Lillah in the highest! Peace on the earth be with those Allah has rida!
Then the angels returned to heaven, and the shepherds discussed it among themselves. They said, "Let us go to Bait Lahm and see this matter that Rabb Al-Alamin has given us good news about."

metadata.item: Shepherds were of low social standing.
They would have felt embarrassed to enter a palace where they would have expected a king would be born, but entering a normal house was not a problem to them.

verse.content: They hurried and found Mariam and Yusif. The child was sleeping in the feeding trough.
After they saw him, they informed them about the words of the angel about the child.
Everyone who heard the words of the shepherds was amazed.
Mariam kept all these things in her heart and meditated on their meaning.
Then the shepherds returned. They praised the glory of Allah for all they had heard and seen, which conformed to the words of the angel.
When the baby was eight days old, the age of circumcision, they named him Isa. That is what the angel commanded Mariam before she became pregnant with him.

metadata.item: See note at Luke 1:59.

verse.content: Then the days of their purification were finished, according to the saying of Allah to Musa in the Tawrat. They took the child to the house of Allah in Al-Quds. They presented him before Rabb Al-Alamin.

metadata.item: After the birth of a boy, the mother was considered unclean for seven days, and then purified herself for thirty-three more days. See the Tawrat, Leviticus 12:2-4.

verse.content: This was according to what Al-Mawla revealed in the Tawrat: "Every first-born son is vowed to Rabb Al-Alamin."

metadata.item: A vow is a promise to give something, or in this case, someone, to Allah.
This is a reference to the Tawrat, Exodus 13:2,12.

verse.content: They presented the qurban specified in the Tawrat: "A pair of doves or two pigeon chicks."

metadata.item: This was commanded in the Tawrat, Leviticus 12:1-8. This was the qurban for poor people who could not afford the normal qurban of a lamb. At this time, the majus had not yet come with their valuable gifts. See the Injil, Matthew 2:1-12.

verse.content: A righteous man named Simon who feared Allah lived in Al-Quds. Holy Ruh Allah was on him. He was waiting for the time of the coming of the comforter of Bani Israil.

metadata.item: This was one of the roles of Isa. Comforter or counselor was one of the titles of al-masih in the Tawrat (Shaya 9:6).

verse.content: Holy Ruh Allah had inspired to him that he would not die until he saw al-masih, al-mustafa of Rabb Al-Alamin.
Ruh Allah led him to the house of Allah. Mariam and Yusif brought the child Isa to do what the Tawrat required.
Then, Simon carried him in his arms and praised Allah. He said,
"My Rabb, your promise to your slave was true, so let me die in peace.
I have seen your ransom with my eyes.

metadata.item: Isa was a ransom for people like the ram was a ransom for the son of Ibrahim.

verse.content: You prepared this ransom for all people.
It is light and guidance for the nations of the kuffar. It is glory and honor for your umma, Bani Israil!"
Yusif and his mother were amazed what was said about him.

Then Simon asked for baraka from Allah on them. He said to his mother Mariam: "Allah has made this child the reason for many of Bani Israil to fall and for many others to rise up. He has made him an ayah they disbelieve in and oppose.

metadata.item: Isa himself is an ayah. He is also an ayah according to the Tawrat, Shaya 7:14.

verse.content: This will expose the intentions of the hearts of people. But a sword will pierce your heart, Mariam.
An old woman named Anna daughter of Phanuel was there and she prophesied. She was from the tribe of Asher. She had been married for seven years, and then became a widow.

metadata.item: Asher was one of the twelve sons of Yacoub and his descendants became one of the twelve tribes or asbat.

verse.content: She remained a widow for eighty-four years. She did not leave the house of Allah night or day. She remained devoted to sawm and salat.
She came to them at that instant and praised Allah. She began to speak about Isa to all those who were waiting for the redemption of Al-Quds.
They did all the requirements of Allah mentioned in the Tawrat. Then they returned to Al-Nasira in Al-Jalil.

metadata.item: Yusif and Mariam

verse.content: The boy grew and became strong. He was filled with wisdom and the grace of Allah was on him.
Yusif and the mother did hajj every year to Al-Quds for the Passover Eid.

metadata.item: Mariam. The original language uses the word parents, which includes step-parents.

verse.content: When Isa was twelve years old, they went to Al-Quds as usual.

metadata.item: This was the age of becoming an adult member of the umma of Bani Israil. As a full member of the umma, Isa would have participated in these rituals.

verse.content: After the eid, the boy Isa stayed while Yusif and the mother returned. But they did not know this.

metadata.item: In Al-Quds.

verse.content: They thought he was in the caravan. They walked one day and then looked for him among their relatives and acquaintances.

metadata.item: A group of people traveling together.

verse.content: But they did not find him, so they returned to Al-Quds. They looked for him,
and after three days, they found him in the house of Allah. He was sitting among the fuqaha of the Tawrat, listening to them and asking them questions.

metadata.item: Or, on the third day. Al-Yahud counted part of a day as a full day. The first day they walked toward home, the second day they walked back to Al-Quds, and the third day they found him.

verse.content: Everyone who heard him was amazed at his understanding and his answers.
Both of them were amazed when they saw him. His mother asked him, "My son, why did you do this to us? Your guardian and I having been looking carefully for you."

metadata.item: The word translated guardian here can mean father also. The word father included step-father or legal guardian. Yusif was not the biological father of Isa, but he was the step-father, having married Mariam, and he raised and supported Isa.

verse.content: He answered them, "Why were you looking for me? Did you not know that I must be concerned with the matters of my Most Loving King?"

metadata.item: This refers to the Arabic names Al-Malik and Al-Wadud, two of the 99 names of Allah. Isa used this title to describe his unique relationship with Allah. Isa called him his Most Loving King, with Isa as his amir. See glossary for more information.

verse.content: But they did not understand his saying.
He returned with them to Al-Nasira. He lived in obedience to them and honored them. His mother kept all these things in her heart.

metadata.item: She thought deeply about them.

verse.content: Isa grew in wisdom and height and in the rida of Allah and of people.

In the fifteenth year of the reign of Caesar Tiberius, Pontius Pilate was the Roman governor over Yahudia. Herod was ruler over one-fourth of the kingdom of his father in the province of Al-Jalil. His brother Philip was ruler over one-fourth of the kingdom in Ituraea and Trachonitis, and Lysanius was governor over one-fourth of it near Damascus.

metadata.item: In the rest of the book of Luke, Herod refers to Herod Antipas, a son of King Herod the Great and a ruler of one-fourth of the kingdom of his father, the province of Al-Jalil.
King Herod the Great.
This area today is in the Western Beqaa Valley in Lebanon and southern Syria.
Archelaus (see Matthew 2:22) was ethnarch (ruler of the people) over the rest of the kingdom: Yahudia and Idumea.

verse.content: Annas and Caiaphas were the two leading ahbar. At that time, Allah inspired Yahya the son of Zakariyya in the wilderness.

metadata.item: Yahya was a common name. This Yahya is called Yahya who did (or does) ghusl or Yahya son of Zakariyya to distinguish him from others of the same name.

verse.content: He went to all parts of the Jordan River valley. He called people to a ghusl of repentance for forgiveness of their sins.
This was the fulfillment of the promise of Allah in the book of Shaya in the kitab: "A voice shouting in the wilderness: Prepare the way of Al-Mawla. Make al-sirat al-mustaqim for him.
Every valley will be raised and every mountain and hill will be lowered. Every crooked thing will be straightened and every uneven thing will be leveled.
All people will see the saving mercy of Allah."

metadata.item: This is a quotation from the Tawrat, Shaya 40:3-5.

verse.content: Yahya was telling the crowds who sought him and asked for the ghusl of repentance by him: "Sons of snakes, the anger of Allah will come down on you! Who warned you to flee from it?

metadata.item: The word sons is not literal of course. Here it means those who have the qualities of snakes -- evil and deceit.

verse.content: Be fruitful in a way that is appropriate to repentance. Do not say to yourselves: Our father is Ibrahim. I tell you that Allah is able to make sons of Ibrahim out of these rocks.

metadata.item: The word father here is not literal. Here it means ancestor.
It was commonly thought that because Al-Yahud were descended from Ibrahim, that this saved them from going to Jahannam, even if they were disobedient, and guaranteed them Al-Janna.
The word sons is not literal. Here it means either descendants of Ibrahim or believers.
The message here is that it is not important who you are descended from, but how your heart is before Allah.

verse.content: The hatchet is now ready to cut the roots of the trees. Every tree that does not produce good fruit will be cut down and thrown in the fire!

metadata.item: He compares people to trees.
This would have been shocking to Al-Yahud who were listening to Yahya. See second note on previous verse.

verse.content: The multitudes asked him: "What can we do?"
He answered them: "Whoever has two robes should give one to someone who does not have one. The same applies to anyone who has food."
Detested tax collectors came and asked for the ghusl of repentance. They asked him, "Teacher, what shall we do?"
He said to them, "Do not take more than what is required of you."

metadata.item: Tax collectors were detested because they often took more than was required and so they became rich. They also were detested because they worked for the Romans, who were an occupying force in those days.

verse.content: Some soldiers asked him also: "And us? What shall we do?" He told them: "Do not extort money from anyone. Do not cheat anyone. Be content with your wages."

metadata.item: Even some Roman soldiers wanted to repent.

verse.content: Everyone was expectant, asking themselves if perhaps Yahya were the awaited al-masih.

metadata.item: This is a title, not a name. It means the person appointed by Allah to be a nabi, habr, and king.

verse.content: Yahya answered all of them, "I do ghusl for you in water, but the one who comes after me is stronger than I am. I am not worthy of untying the straps of his sandals. He will do ghusl for you into holy Ruh Allah and into fire.

metadata.item: Isa, the expected al-masih.
This is not referring to physical strength but authority.
This was the job of a slave.
See the Injil, Acts of the Hawariyun 2:4.

verse.content: He holds his winnowing fork in his hand to purify his threshing floor. He will gather his wheat in his storehouse. He will burn the straw with fire that cannot be extinguished.

metadata.item: This was used to separate grain by throwing the grain into the air. The grain would fall back to the ground and the rest of the plant would blow away.
They got rid of the outside coverings of the grain, the stalks, and the other inedible parts of the grain so that the pure kernel of grain could be eaten.

verse.content: With many other sermons like this, Yahya told good news to the people.
Yahya rebuked the ruler Herod for his marriage to Herodias, the wife of his brother, and for all the other evil he did.

metadata.item: His brother was still alive.

verse.content: But Herod later became even more unjust than he had been before. He imprisoned Yahya.
But while Yahya was still doing ghusl for everyone, Isa received ghusl also. As Isa was praising Allah, the sky was opened.
Holy Ruh Allah came down on him like a dove. A voice called from the sky. It said: "You are my beloved amir. I have rida with you."
Isa was about thirty years old when he began bringing his message. People considered him the son of Yusif Ibn Eli

metadata.item: This is Yusif the husband of Mariam. Most people did not know that Isa was conceived by Holy Ruh Allah, and they thought he was the biological son of Yusif.

This genealogy is probably that of Mariam, but sometimes, women are not mentioned in genealogies. Yusif the carpenter was probably the son-in-law of Eli. Since this is not a father-son relationship, the Arabic word Ibn is used, rather than Bin.

verse.content: Bin Matthat Bin Levi Bin Melchi Bin Jannai Bin Yusif
Bin Mattathias Bin Amos Bin Nahum Bin Hesli Bin Naggai
Bin Maath Bin Mattathias Bin Semein Bin Josech, Bin Yahuda
Bin Yahya Bin Rhesa Bin Zerubbabel Ibn Shealtiel Bin Neri

metadata.item: The word Ibn here is used to convey a son who is not biological. In this case, it seems Shealtiel died with no children and his brother Pedaiah married his widow in obedience to the Tawrat (Deuteronomy 25:5-10) to have a child to inherit Shealtiel's property and his right to be king. See the Tawrat, 1 Chronicles 3:17-19, Ezra 3:2.

verse.content: Bin Melchi Bin Addi Bin Cosam Bin Elmadam Bin Er
Bin Joshua Bin Eliezer Bin Jorim Bin Matthat Bin Levi
Bin Simon Bin Yahuda Bin Yusif Bin Jonam Bin Eliakim
Bin Melea Bin Menna Bin Mattatha Bin Nathan Bin Dawood

metadata.item: This is Dawood the nabi and king.

verse.content: Bin Jesse Bin Obed Bin Boaz Bin Salmon Bin Nahshon
Bin Amminadab Bin Admin Bin Ram Bin Hezron Bin Perez Bin Yahuda
Bin Yacoub Bin Ishaq Bin Ibrahim Bin Terah Bin Nahor
Bin Serug Bin Reu Bin Peleg Bin Heber Bin Shelah

metadata.item: Some people think this is the same as Hud.
Some people think this is the same as Salih. Others think Salih is Methusaleh.

verse.content: Bin Cainan Bin Arphaxad Bin Sam Bin Nuh Bin Lamik
Bin Salih Bin Idris Bin Jared Bin Mahalaleel Bin Cainan

metadata.item: Or Methusaleh.

verse.content: Bin Enosh Bin Seth Bin Adam, Regent of Allah.

metadata.item: The word construction here is the same as with the other ancestors in the original language, but the meaning is obviously different. Adam was formed from clay or dirt and Allah breathed into him the breath of life. (See the Tawrat, Genesis 2:7) All the other ancestors were conceived through sexual intercourse between a human father and mother. The Tawrat refers to the regent of Allah as his son, which of course is not literal. Adam was a regent for Allah (a person appointed by a king, in this case Allah, to act for him). In addition to Adam, Dawood is also referred to in the same way as regent in the Zabur, Psalms 2:7.

verse.content: Isa returned from the Jordan River filled with Holy Ruh Allah, and Ruh Allah led him into the wilderness.

metadata.item: Ruh Allah and Holy Ruh Allah refer to the same Ruh. This is not a title for Isa in the Injil.

verse.content: Iblis tempted him there for forty days. Isa was doing sawm night and day all that time. When that time finished, he was very hungry.

metadata.item: See note at Matthew 4:2.

verse.content: Then Iblis told him: "If you are the beloved amir of Allah, command this stone to become bread."

metadata.item: One of the primary meanings of this phrase amir of Allah is that the amir has the authority of Allah.

verse.content: Isa answered him: "The Tawrat says: People live not only with bread."

metadata.item: This is a quotation from the Tawrat, Deuteronomy 8:3.

verse.content: Then Iblis took him and in an instant, showed him all the kingdoms of the earth.

metadata.item: This was in a vision, because there is no place from which all the kingdoms of the earth can be seen in an instant.

verse.content: Iblis told him: "I will give you authority over all these kingdoms and all the glory in them. They have all been delivered to me, and I can give them to anyone I want.

metadata.item: Adam was given authority over the earth as the regent of Allah, and Adam delivered this authority to Iblis by listening to Iblis and disobeying Allah.

verse.content: If you bow down to me, they will be yours."
Isa answered him: "The Tawrat says: Bow down to Allah your Mawla. Worship only him."

metadata.item: This is a quotation from the Tawrat, Deuteronomy 6:13.

verse.content: Then Al-Shaitan took Isa to Al-Quds, and had him stand on the roof of the top of the house of Allah. He said to him: "If you are the beloved amir of Allah, throw yourself from here.
The Zabur says: He will command his angels about you. They will protect you.
On their hands they will carry you so you will not hit your foot on a stone."

metadata.item: This was not the complete quotation from the Zabur, Psalms 91:11-12. Iblis omitted \"to guard you in all your ways.\" Omitting this phrase changes the meaning of the verses from trusting Allah to testing Allah. The meaning of the verses is to trust Allah as we obey him, not to test Allah.

verse.content: Isa answered him: "Allah said in the Tawrat: Do not test Allah your Mawla."

metadata.item: This is a quotation from the Tawrat, Deuteronomy 6:16. Here Isa shows that taking a part of a verse without looking at the rest of what is revealed is wrong.

verse.content: After all these temptations, Iblis went away from him for a time.
Then Isa went back to Al-Jalil. He was aided by the power of Ruh Allah. News about him spread in all surrounding regions.
He was teaching in the houses of salat of Al-Jalil. Everyone honored him.
Then he came to Al-Nasira, where he was raised. He went to the house of salat on Al-Sabt, as was his habit. He stood up to read from the kitab of Allah.
They gave him the scroll of the nabi Shaya. He opened the scroll, and found the portion where it is written:

'The Ruh of Rabb Al-Alamin is on me. He chose me to bring good news to the poor. He sent me to call for release of the prisoners. I will heal the blind so they see, and free those who are unjustly treated.

metadata.item: The same as Holy Ruh Allah.

verse.content: I will announce the rida of Rabb Al-Alamin to them.'

metadata.item: This is a quotation from the Tawrat, Shaya 61:1-2.

verse.content: Then he rolled up the scroll and returned it to the attendant and sat down. All those who came for salat stared at him.

metadata.item: It was the custom of teachers to stand when reading the Tawrat or Zabur and to sit when teaching.

verse.content: He told them: "Today this promise of Allah has been fulfilled as you heard it."
Everyone spoke well of him. They were amazed at the words of baraka coming out of his mouth. They started to say, \"Is this not the son of Yusif?"

metadata.item: Yusif was the step-father of Isa and raised Isa. He had married Mariam, the mother of Isa, after Isa was conceived. Most people thought that Yusif was the biological father of Isa. They did not know that he had been conceived by Holy Ruh Allah. In addition, the word "son" is often not literal. It includes other meanings like stepson, descendant, having similar qualities, etc.

verse.content: He said to them: "No doubt you will tell me the proverb: Physician, heal yourself. We have heard of your ayat in the town of Capernaum. Do similar ones here in your home town, too.
Then he said: "I tell you a true saying: No nabi is acceptable in his home town.
I tell you a true saying: In the time of Ilyas, there were many widows among Bani Israil. Allah had stopped the rain for three years and six months, and there was a great famine.

metadata.item: This story is in the Tawrat, 1 Kings, 17-18.

verse.content: But Allah did not send Ilyas to help any of them. He sent him to a widow from Zarephath in the province of Sidon.

metadata.item: Reminding Al-Yahud of this preference of other ummas over Bani Israil would have made them upset.
Arabic Sarfand in southern Lebanon today.
This story is in the Tawrat, 1 Kings 17:8-16.

verse.content: In the time of the nabi Alyasa, there were many of Bani Israil afflicted with leprosy. But Allah did not make any of them tahir, but he made Naaman the Syrian tahir!

metadata.item: He was the commanding general of the army of Syria, an enemy of Bani Israil at that time.
This story is in the Tawrat, 2 Kings 5. Reminding them of this story would have made them even madder.

verse.content: When those who were praying heard these words, they exploded with anger.

metadata.item: Al-Yahud did not like the idea of Allah showing mercy to anyone who was not from Bani Israil.

verse.content: They stood up and threw him out of the town. Then they led him to the edge of the mountain that their town was built on. They wanted to throw him down.
But he passed in between them and immediately went on his way.
