Then he went down to his town Capernaum in Al-Jalil. He began to teach people on Al-Sabt.

metadata.item: Isa had moved and stayed with Simon, who lived in Capernaum.

verse.content: They were amazed at his teachings, since his word was authoritative.

metadata.item: The teachers of Al-Yahud quoted other teachers, but Isa gave the meaning himself.

verse.content: In the house of salat, there was a man touched by the spirit of an unclean jinni. He had been shouting with a loud voice:
"Leave us alone, Isa al-Nasiri! Did you come to destroy us? I know you! You are the holy one who comes from Allah!"

metadata.item: This either refers to several jinn in a person or region or a feeling of the jinn that all the jinn were under attack by Isa.
The jinn seemed to know that Isa had authority over them.

verse.content: Isa rebuked him. He said, "Be silent and come out of him." Then the jinni threw the man on the ground in front of them, and went out of him without harming him.

metadata.item: Isa did not need or want the shahada from jinn. He wanted it to be clear that he had nothing to do with jinn.

verse.content: Everyone was totally amazed, and they started to say to each other, "How powerful his word is! He commands the unclean spirits with authority and power and they go out!"
So his reputation spread all throughout the region.
Then he left the house of salat and entered the house of Simon. The mother of the wife of Simon was sick with a high fever, so they urged Isa to heal her.
He stood next to her and rebuked the fever. So it left her and she got up immediately and served them.
At sunset, people who had various diseases came to Isa. He put his hands on each one of them and healed them all.

metadata.item: Sunset was the beginning of the new day. Bani Israil were forbidden from working on Al-Sabt, and Al-Yahud considered that Al-Sabt finished at sunset.

verse.content: The jinn left many people and shouted: "You are the beloved amir of Allah!" But he rebuked them and forbade them from speaking, because they knew that he was the awaited al-masih.
Then Isa went out at dawn to an isolated place. The crowds were searching for him. They came to him and held on to him so he would not leave them.
But he said to them: "I must also give good news of the kingdom of Allah to people in the other towns. This is my message."
He went on preaching in the houses of salat in Yahudia.

metadata.item: This verse implies a trip of several days of walking to the south from Al-Jalil.

verse.content: Isa was standing on the shore of Al-Jalil Lake. The multitudes crowded around him to hear the word of Allah.
He saw two boats on the shore. (The fishermen had left them to wash the nets.)
Isa got into one of the boats, which belonged to Simon. He asked him move it a little from the shore. Then he sat down and taught the crowds from the boat.
When he finished speaking, he said to Simon: "Go out to the deep water and throw your nets in to catch fish."
Simon answered him: "Master, we worked hard all night and did not catch anything. But according to your command I will throw the nets."

metadata.item: Fishermen often caught most of their fish at night.

verse.content: When they did that, the nets were filled with fish. The nets started to break because there were so many fish.
He motioned to his partners in the other boat to help them. So they came and filled both boats. The boats were almost sinking.
When Simon Peter saw this, he bowed down at the knees of Isa. He said, "Mawla, leave me alone. I am a sinful man!"
He and everyone with him were totally amazed by the amount of fish they had caught.
The two partners of Simon, Yacoub and Yahya sons of Zebedee, were also totally amazed. Then Isa told Simon: "Do not fear. From now on, you will gather people.\"
Then they pulled the boats to shore and they left everything behind them and followed him.

Isa was in a village, and a man covered with leprosy saw Isa and fell down on his face. He begged Isa, "Master, if you will, you are able to make me tahir."12 Isa stretched out his hand and touched where he was unclean. He said, "I will it. Be healed and tahir." Immediately the leprosy left him.
He commanded him not to tell anyone. He said, "Go and show yourself to the habr. Present the qurban for your becoming tahir as Allah commanded Musa as a proof to them."

metadata.item: Isa may have said this because he was interested in people following Allah, not just people who were curious or those who were sick.
This is a reference to the Tawrat, Leviticus 13:49, 14:2ff.

Al-Yahud believed that making a leper from Bani Israil tahir was an ayah that only al-masih could do. By showing the result of this ayah to the ahbar, it was a declaration and proof that Isa was al-masih.

verse.content: But the news about Isa spread more. The crowds came to him to hear him and be healed of his diseases.
But Isa went to an isolated place in the wilderness and prayed in dua\'.

One day, Isa was teaching people. Pharisees and teachers of the Tawrat from all villages of Al-Jalil and Al-Quds and Yahudia were sitting there. The power from Rabb Al-Alamin was on him to heal the sick.

metadata.item: It seems they were testing Isa, to get an official judgment about him.

verse.content: Men carrying a paralyzed man on a mat came and tried to bring him in to put him in front of Isa.
They could not find a way to take him in because of the crowd. So they took him to the roof. They lowered him through an opening in the tiles in the middle, in front of Isa.

metadata.item: The roofs of houses were flat.

verse.content: When Isa saw their trust, he said, "Man, your sins are forgiven."
The fuqaha and Pharisees were thinking: "Who is this? He speaks shirk! Only Allah can forgive sins. "
Isa realized their thoughts. He answered them: "Why do you hide these thoughts in your hearts?

metadata.item: Isa was able to know hidden things.

verse.content: Which is easier? To say: 'Your sins are forgiven,' or to say: 'Stand up and walk'?
But so you can know that sayyid al-bashar has authority on earth to forgive sins," he said to the paralyzed man: "I tell you, stand up and carry your mat and go home."

metadata.item: Sayyid al-bashar is the most common title Isa used for himself. It had three primary meanings in the Tawrat. 1) Sometimes, it meant a human being, as in Numbers 23:19. 2) Many times, it was used to mean a nabi or rasul (93 times in the scroll of Ezekiel alone). 3) The one prophesied in, Daniel 7:14, who was coming to Allah on the clouds of the sky and to whom Allah was going to give rule, kingship, and glory over all peoples, nations, and language groups forever in an eternal kingdom. When Isa used this title with the religious authorities, they understood this meaning.

No one could check to see if the sins of a person had been forgiven. But it was very easy to check if a paralyzed person had been healed or not. By healing the man, Isa showed that he had the authority of Allah for both.

verse.content: Immediately the man stood up in front of those present there, and carried his mat and went home. He praised the glory of Allah.
All were amazed and praised the glory of Allah, and they were filled with fear. They said, "Today we have seen strange things!"
Later Isa went out and saw a detested tax collector named Levi sitting in his office. Isa told him, "Follow me."

metadata.item: They were detested because they collaborated with the Roman occupiers and because they took extra for themselves.
His other name was Matthew.

verse.content: He stood up, left everything and became one of his followers.
Then Levi held a large banquet in his house in honor of Isa. A large group of detested tax collectors and others ate dinner with them.
The Pharisees and fuqaha complained to his followers. They said, "Why do you eat and drink with detested tax collectors and sinners?"
Isa answered: "The healthy, not the sick, need a physician.
I did not come to righteous people. I came to call sinners to repentance."
They also said to him, "The followers of Yahya and the Pharisees do much sawm and salat. Your followers eat and drink all the time."
Isa said to them: "Can you tell wedding guests to do sawm when the groom is still with them?
Days will come when the groom will be taken away from them. Then they will do sawm."
Then he told them a story: "No one cuts a piece from a new robe to make a patch for an old robe. If he does, he will ruin the new robe and the new patch will not be suitable for the old.

metadata.item: New patches shrink after washing, and would make the tear in the garment worse.

verse.content: No one puts new wine in an old leather container. If he does, the new wine will tear the container, the wine will be spilled, and the container will be ruined.

metadata.item: New wine (grape juice) expands. When put in a new leather container, they both expand together. But an old leather container has already expanded and will tear if expanded again.

verse.content: New wine is put in a new container.
Whoever drinks old wine will not want the new. He will say: The old is good enough."
Isa passed through the wheat fields, and it was Al-Sabt. His followers started picking the heads of grain, rubbing them in their hands, and eating.

metadata.item: To separate the edible grain from its skin (chaff).

verse.content: Some Pharisees said to them: "Why do you do wrong things on Al-Sabt?"

metadata.item: There is a command that Allah gave Musa in the Tawrat (Exodus 20:10) for Bani Israil prohibiting all kinds work on Al-Sabt, including harvesting. It did not prohibit eating when hungry. The Pharisees had made their own sunan which said that picking heads of grain to eat was a kind of harvesting. Isa affirmed the commands of the Tawrat but rejected the rules of men.

verse.content: Isa answered: "Did you not read in the kitab what Dawood did? He and his soldiers were hungry.
He entered the house of Allah and took the bread that had been a qurban to Allah and ate it. It was forbidden to anyone except the ahbar. He also gave it to his companions."
Then he told them: "Sayyid al-bashar is master of Al-Sabt!"
On another Sabt, Isa entered the house of salat and started to talk. There was a man with a dried-up right hand.
The fuqaha and the Pharisees watched Isa to see if he would heal him on Al-Sabt. They were looking for an excuse to accuse him.
Isa knew their thoughts. He said to the man with the dried-up hand: "Stand up here in the middle." So he got up and stood in front of them.
Isa said to them: "I ask you a question. Is it halal on Al-Sabt to do good or to do evil? Is it halal to save a life or to destroy it?"

metadata.item: The fuqaha and Pharisees.
Of course, the answer was that it is always halal to do good and it is never halal to do evil.

verse.content: He looked around at them all. He said to the man, "Stretch your hand out." He did it and his hand was made straight.

metadata.item: No one answered Isa because they could not justify their position, which was based on the traditions of men and contradicted the Tawrah.

verse.content: This made them crazy with anger and they conspired against Isa.
In those days, Isa went to an isolated place on a mountain to pray in dua\' to Allah. He spent all night praying in dua\'.
When morning came, he called his followers to come to him. He chose twelve of them and called them hawariyun.
Their names were: Simon, whom he called Peter, his brother Andrew, Yacoub, Yahya, Philip, Bartholomew,

metadata.item: This Yahya was the son of Zebedee, not the nabi Yahya. Yahya was a common name.

verse.content: Matthew, Thomas, Yacoub son of Alphaeus, Simon the zealot,
Yahuda son of Yacoub, and Yahuda Iscariot who later became a traitor.
Then he went down with them, and he stood in an open place. A multitude of followers and a large crowd from Yahudia, Al-Quds, and the coast of Tyre and Sidon gathered around him.
They came to hear him and to be healed from their diseases. People who were tormented from a touch by unclean spirits came and were healed.
The whole multitude tried to touch him, because power came out from him and healed them all.
He looked up to his hawariyun and said to them: "You poor have a baraka, because you have a share in the kingdom of Allah.

metadata.item: This was the opposite of what people thought. Al-Yahud thought that you were poor was because Allah had cursed you and you were rich was because Allah had given you a baraka.

verse.content: You who are hungry now have a baraka, because you will be filled. You who cry now have a baraka, because you will laugh.
Suppose people hate you, reject you, curse you, and insult you because you are followers of sayyid al-bashar.
Rejoice on that day. Dance joyfully. Your reward with your Rabb is great. That is what your fathers did to the anbiya.

metadata.item: The word fathers is not literal. Here it means ancestors.

verse.content: But woe to you rich people. You are only rich in this world.
Woe to you who are full now. You will be hungry. Woe to you who laugh now. You will grieve and cry.
Woe to you when all people speak well of you. That is what your ancestors did to the dajjals.

metadata.item: Who pretended to be anbiya.

verse.content: I tell you who hear: Love your enemies. Do good to those who hate you.

metadata.item: This was the opposite of what the teachers of Bani Israil taught. They taught people to hate their enemies.

verse.content: Pray in dua\' for baraka to those who curse you. Pray in dua\' for good for those you dishonor you.
If someone hits you on the cheek, offer him the other cheek to hit. If someone takes your cloak, do not withhold even your robe.
Give to everyone who asks you. If anyone takes something from you, do not demand that he return it to you.
Treat people as you want them to treat you.
If you love people who love you, what benefit is that? Even sinners love people who love them.
If you do good to people who do good to you, what benefit is that? Sinners also do that.
Suppose you give a loan to people and you expect that they will pay you back. What benefit is that?

Love your enemies and do good to them. Give loans without expecting anything back. Your reward will be great. In this way you will be umara to Allah the Most High and Generous. He is gracious even to the ungrateful and evil.

metadata.item: Isa may have repeated this because it is so different from the natural reaction.
This refers to the Arabic names Al-Ali and Al-Karim, two of the 99 names of Allah.
This refers to the Arabic name Al-Munim, one of the 99 names of Allah.

verse.content: Show mercy to people as your Most Gracious King is compassionate and merciful.

metadata.item: This refers to the Arabic names Al-Rahman and Al-Malik, two of the 99 names of Allah.
This refers to the Arabic names Al-Rauf and Al-Rahim, two of the 99 names of Allah.

verse.content: Do not judge anyone, and you will not be judged. Do not condemn and you will not be condemned. Pardon them and Allah will forgive you.
Give and your Rabb will give to you his great baraka. He will give you a full measure, pressed down, shaken and overflowing. It will be measured to you with the same measure you measure out."

metadata.item: Totally full to the maximum.

verse.content: He told them a story: "Can one blind man lead another blind man? Will both of them not fall together into a pit?
The follower is not higher than his teacher. Whoever completes his learning has been mentored by his teacher.
Why do you look at the straw in the eye of your brother, when there is a board in your eye that you do not notice?

How do you dare say to your brother: "Brother, let me take the straw from your eye, when you do not see the board in your eye? You hypocrite, first take the board out of your eye. Then you will see clearly to take the straw from the eye of your brother!
The good tree does not produce bad fruit, and the bad tree does not produce good fruit.
Every tree is known by its fruit. People do not harvest figs from thorn bushes. They do not pick grapes from a thistle bush.
The good person brings out good from the treasure of good in his heart. The bad person brings out bad from the bad that is in him, since his tongue speaks from the overflow of his heart.
Why do you call me: 'Our master, our master,' while you do not do my word?

metadata.item: In Arabic, sayyidna.

verse.content: Whoever comes to me and hears my word and does it
is like a man, building a house, who dug deep to make a foundation on the rock. When the river overflowed and struck that house, it was not shaken because it was built well.

The one who hears my word and does not do it is like a man who built a house on the sand without a foundation. When the river overflowed and struck that house, it fell down immediately, and destroyed the whole house."
He finished his speech to the people and entered Capernaum.
A Roman officer lived there. A dear slave of his was sick and near to death.
The officer heard the news of Isa, so he sent some elders of Al-Yahud to ask him to come and heal his slave.
The delegation came to Isa and pleaded with him urgently. They said: "He deserves for you to respond to him,
for he loves our umma and built us a house of salat."
Isa went with them, and when he approached the house, the officer sent his friends to him to tell him: "Master, do not bother yourself. I am not worthy for you to come under the shade in my house.
This is why I did not consider myself worthy to appear in front of you. It is enough for you to command it, and my slave will be healed.
I have a commander above me, and soldiers under my command. I tell one, 'Go,' and he goes, and I tell another, 'Come,' and he comes. I tell my slave, 'Do this,' and he does it."

metadata.item: In other words, when a person has authority, a command is sufficient.

verse.content: Isa heard this, and he was amazed at the officer. He turned and said to the crowd that was following him: "I tell you that I have not found this kind of great trust even among Bani Israil." The delegation returned to the house, and found the slave well.
The next day, Isa went to the town of Nain with his followers and a large crowd.
When he approached the gate of the town, people were carrying out a dead man. He was the only son of his mother, who was a widow. Many people from the town accompanied her.
Our mawla saw her and had compassion on her. He said to her, "Do not cry." He went, touched the bier, and the people who were carrying it stopped. Then he said, "Young man, I tell you, get up!"

metadata.item: The thing that held the body of the dead man.

verse.content: The dead man sat up and started to speak, and Isa gave him back to his mother.
Fear gripped everyone. They praised the glory of Allah and said, "Allah has sent us a great nabi," and "Allah has aided his umma."
This news about Isa spread through Yahudia and all the surrounding areas.
Yahya heard about these events from his followers, so he called two of his followers.

metadata.item: He was in prison. See the Injil, Matthew 11:2.

verse.content: He sent them to Isa to ask him, "Are you the promised one who is coming, or should we wait for someone else?"

metadata.item: Allah had promised in the Tawrat to send al-masih, but Yahya was no longer sure that Isa was al-masih. He may have become discouraged in prison. Or he might have expected Isa to come and release him from prison.

verse.content: The two men came to Isa and told him, "Yahya who did ghusl sent us to you. He asks you: Are you the promised one who is coming, or should we wait for someone else?"
Isa healed many who were sick, ill, in pain, and touched by evil spirits in that hour. He also gave sight to many blind people.
Then he answered them: "Go and tell Yahya what you saw and heard: The blind see, the lame walk, lepers are healed, the deaf hear, the dead are resurrected, and the poor receive good news.
And the person who does not doubt me has a baraka!"
When the two rusul of Yahya went away, Isa began to talk to the crowds about Yahya: "Why did you go out to the wilderness? To see a reed shaken by the wind?
Why did you go out? To see a man wearing fine clothes? People who have fine clothes and rich people live in palaces.

metadata.item: The expected answer to both of these questions was, "Of course not."

verse.content: So why did you go out? To see a nabi? Yes, I tell you. He is even more than a nabi.
He is the one Allah spoke about in the kitab: I am sending my rasul before you to prepare the way in front of you.

metadata.item: Very few anbiya were predicted in the Tawrat (only Isa and Yahya). Other people who were predicted but who were not anbiya were Josiah (a king of Bani Israil), Cyrus (king of Persia), and Mariam (the mother of Isa).

verse.content: I tell you that among the sons born of women, none is greater than Yahya. But the least person in the kingdom of Allah is greater than he is."

metadata.item: Here the phrase 'sons born of women' means humans or people.

verse.content: When they heard this, all the people who had received the ghusl of repentance from Yahya affirmed the justice of Allah, including the detested tax collectors.

metadata.item: This refers to the Arabic name Al-Adl, one of the 99 names of Allah.

verse.content: But the Pharisees and scholars of the Tawrat rejected the will of Allah for them. They had not received the ghusl of repentance from Yahya.

metadata.item: They thought they did not need to repent.

verse.content: "What can I compare this generation to? What are they like?
They are like children sitting in the market calling one another: We played the flute and you did not dance. We mourned for you, and you did not cry.

metadata.item: Playing the flute and dancing happened at weddings.
Mourning and crying happened at funerals.
In other words, nothing gives you rida. You reject the truth however it is presented.

verse.content: Yahya who did ghusl came as an ascetic. He did not eat bread and wine, and you rejected him. You said: A jinni has touched him!
Then sayyid al-bashar came eating and drinking and you rejected him. You said: He is a glutton and a drunkard, and a friend of detestable tax collectors and sinners!
But the truth of wisdom is proven in everyone who is committed to it."
One of the Pharisees invited him for dinner, and Isa entered his house. Isa was reclining at the table.

metadata.item: The tables for eating were either very low or on the ground, and people leaned on their left side to eat.

verse.content: A sinful woman from that town knew that Isa was at the house of the Pharisee. She came with an alabaster jar containing expensive perfumed oil.

metadata.item: Women often saved their money by buying perfumed oil and putting it in a special jar. This could have been the woman's life savings.

verse.content: She stood behind Isa crying near his feet, wetting them with her tears. Then she wiped his feet with the hair of her head. She kissed them and put her oil on them.

metadata.item: Possibly because of the dishonors given to Isa by Simon. See what she did compared to Simon in verses 44-46.
Women did not uncover and unbraid their hair in public. For her to do this showed deep devotion to Isa.

verse.content: When the Pharisee who hosted Isa saw this, he said to himself: "If he were a nabi, he would know that this woman who is touching him is unclean. She is a sinner!
Isa answered: "Simon, I have something to say to you." He said, "Speak, teacher."
"There were two men who owed money to a moneylender. One of them owed five hundred silver dinars. The other owed fifty.
Both were unable to pay, so he pardoned them and released them from their debts out of his grace. Which of them will love the moneylender more?"
Simon said, "I think the one who was pardoned from the greater debt." Isa said to him: "You have judged correctly."

Then he turned to the woman and said to Simon: "Do you see this woman? I entered your house as a guest and you did not give me water to wash my feet. But she has wetted my feet with her tears and wiped them with her hair.

metadata.item: He focused on the woman's honoring him as he spoke to Simon.
This was a minimum courtesy given to guests. Simon had insulted Isa by not giving him this. Normally a slave would wash the feet of a guest.
Yahya 11:2 says that this was Mariam, the sister of Martha.

verse.content: You did not kiss me when I came in. But since I came in, she has not stopped kissing my feet.

metadata.item: This was a basic courtesy given to guests. Simon had insulted Isa by not giving him this.

A kiss on the head showed that the person kissed was inferior. A kiss on the cheek showed that the person kissed was an equal. A kiss on the hand showed the person kissed was superior. A kiss on the feet was rarely done and showed the great superiority of the person kissed. Simon may have avoided kissing Isa because he did not want to acknowledge the superiority of Isa.

verse.content: You did not put oil on my head, but she has put expensive perfumed oil on my feet.

metadata.item: This was a courtesy given to honored guests. It was refreshing, like a shower is today.

verse.content: So I tell you, her many sins are forgiven for her, so she loved much. But the one who is forgiven little, loves little."

metadata.item: Love is the result of being forgiven.

verse.content: Then he said to the woman: "Your sins are forgiven for you."
Those who were reclining started to ask each other: "Who is this who forgives sins?"
Isa said to the woman: "Your trust has made you inherit Al-Janna, so go in the peace of Allah.

metadata.item: Literally, an owner of the right. In Matthew 25:31-46, Isa referred to those on his right as inheriting the kingdom of Allah.
This refers to the Arabic name Al-Salam, one of the 99 names of Allah.

verse.content: After that, Isa went around in the towns and villages preaching and giving good news of the Kingdom of Allah. He was accompanied by the twelve hawariyun
and some women whom he had healed from a touch by evil spirits and from sicknesses. The names of the women were Mariam Magdalene, from whom he had cast out seven jinn,
Joanna the wife of Chuza, the steward of Herod, Susanna, and many others who spent their money in the sirat of Isa.
When great multitudes gathered around him from all the villages of the region, he told them a story:
"A farmer went out to sow seeds. While he was sowing, some of the seeds fell beside the road, and people stepped on them. Then the birds of the sky flew down on the seeds and ate them.

metadata.item: Farmers took handfuls of grain and threw them on the good ground. Some grains would unfortunately fall where the farmer did not intend.

verse.content: Some of the seeds fell on the rock, sprouted, and dried up since they lacked moisture.
Some of them fell among thorns, which sprouted with them and choked them.
But some of them fell on the fertile ground, and they sprouted and produced one hundred times as much." Then Isa called out: "Everyone with two ears to hear should listen."

metadata.item: Seeds normally do not produce this much. See note at Mark 4:8.

verse.content: His hawariyun asked him about the meaning of the story.
He said: "Allah has given you knowledge of the secrets of the kingdom of Allah. But I tell other people stories, so that when they look, they do not see, and when they listen, they do not understand.

metadata.item: Isa revealed the meaning of the stories to his hawariyin and those who would obey it. Those who rejected it were not told the meaning. This is a reference to the Tawrat, Shaya 6:9-10.

verse.content: This is the meaning of the story: The seeds are the word of Allah.
The seeds that fell beside the road are people who hear, and Iblis comes and takes away the word from their hearts. So they do not believe and are not saved from destruction.
The seeds that fell on the rock are people who hear the word and accept it joyfully. But they have no root. They believe for a while, and turn back when there is a trial.
The seeds that fell among thorns are people who hear, and as time passes, the worries, riches, and concerns of this life choke them. So their fruit does not mature.
But the seeds in the fertile soil are those who hear the word in good, sound hearts. They hold on to it and are patient and produce fruit.
No one lights a lamp and hides it under a basket, nor does he put it under a bed. He puts it on a lamp stand so that those who come in can be guided by its light.
Everything that is hidden will be made public. Everything covered will be known and exposed in the light.
Be alert as you listen! Whoever has will be given more. But suppose a person does not have. Even what he thinks he has will be taken away from him.

metadata.item: I.e. has understanding.
Those who obey what they understand will understand more. Those who disobey what they understand will have their understanding taken away.

verse.content: The mother and brothers of Isa came to him, but they could not reach him because of the crowd.
Someone told him: "Your mother and brothers are standing outside and they want to see you."

metadata.item: Here mother is used physically.
These are his half-brothers, the sons of his mother Mariam and Yusif the carpenter.

verse.content: He answered them: "My mother and brothers are the ones who hear the word of Allah and do it."

metadata.item: Here mother and brothers is not literal. It refers to followers who listen and obey.

verse.content: One day, Isa and his hawariyun got in a boat. He said to them: "Let us go over to the other shore of the lake." So they left.
As they were sailing, Isa went to sleep. Then the winds on the lake became stormy, the boat became almost full of water, and they were in danger of drowning.
They came to him, woke him, and said, "Our master, our master, we are going to die." So he got up and rebuked the winds and the waves. And the waves were still and there was total calm.
Then he asked them: "Where is your trust?" They were awestruck and amazed. They asked: "Who is this? He commands even the winds and the waves, and they obey him!"
Then they sailed to the land of the people of Jerash, east of Al-Jalil.
Isa got out on the shore. A man from the town who was touched by jinn met him there. He had not worn clothing for a long time. He did not live in a house, but among the tombs.
When he saw Isa, he bowed down in front of him and shouted as loud as he could: "What do you have to do with me, Isa, beloved amir of Allah Most High? Please do not torture me!"

This was because Isa had been commanding the unclean spirit to leave the man. The jinni often took control of the man. People tied him with chains and bonds and guarded him. But he would break them and the jinni would lead him into the wilderness.
Isa asked him: "What is your name?" He said: "I am Army." An army of jinn had taken up residence in the man.

metadata.item: An army was a force of six thousand soldiers in war. In peacetime, it was sometimes reduced to 2000-3000.

verse.content: The jinn begged him not to judge them by sending them out into the Abyss.
There was a large herd of pigs grazing on the mountain. The jinn begged Isa to give them permission to enter the pigs, and he gave them permission.

metadata.item: The Tawrat taught that pigs are unclean animals (Leviticus 11:7). Bani Israil were forbidden to eat them or to touch their dead bodies.

verse.content: So the jinn left the man and entered the pigs. Then the whole herd rushed from the mountain cliff to the lake and drowned.
When the herders saw what happened, they fled and told the people of the town and the rural residents.
So the people went out to see what happened and came to Isa. They saw the man sitting by the feet of Isa. The jinn had left him. He was wearing clothes and his mind was sound. So they were afraid.
The eyewitnesses told them how Isa had saved the man who had been touched by jinn, and had healed him.
The people of Jerash and its region asked him to go away from them, because they had become very afraid. So Isa got in the boat and went away from there.

metadata.item: They also had suffered financially from loss of the pigs. Money was more important to them than the healed man.

verse.content: The man the jinn had left begged him to go along with him. But Isa sent him away:
"Go back to your household and tell them all that Allah has done for you." So he went and told the whole town what Isa had done for him.
When Isa returned, the multitudes welcomed him, because they were all waiting for him.
One of the rulers of the house of salat named Jairus came to him. He fell down at his feet and begged him to come to his house.
His only daughter was dying. She was about twelve years old. Isa started going to the house of the ruler, but there was a crowd around him.

metadata.item: Probably his only child.

verse.content: There was a woman who had been suffering from bleeding for twelve years. She had spent all her money on physicians. But none of them were able to heal her.

metadata.item: Menstrual bleeding made a woman unclean, and if it continued longer than normal, the woman remained unclean until it stopped. (The Tawrat, Leviticus 15:19ff).

verse.content: She approached Isa from behind, touched the edge of his robe, and her bleeding stopped immediately.
Isa said: "Who touched me?" But they all denied it. Peter told him: "Our master, the crowd is crowding around you and is pressing on you."
Isa said: "Someone touched me intentionally, because I felt power going out of me."

The woman saw that her story was going to be exposed. So she came trembling and threw herself down in front of him. She told him, in front of the crowd, the reason she had touched him and that she had been healed immediately.
He said to her: "My daughter, your trust has healed you. Go in peace."

metadata.item: This is a term of compassion, and not literal. Isa was never married and had no children.

verse.content: He was still speaking, and someone came from the house of the ruler of the house of salat. He told him: "Your daughter has died. Do not bother the teacher any longer."
Isa heard this and told the ruler: "Do not be afraid. Only have trust and the girl will be well."
Then Isa came to the house. He did not allow anyone to enter with him except Peter, Yahya, Yacoub, and the father and mother of the girl.

metadata.item: One of the hawariyun, not Yahya son of Zakariyya.

verse.content: Everyone was crying and mourning for her. He said, "Do not cry. She did not die. She is sleeping."

metadata.item: Isa seems to be using the word "sleeping" to refer to someone who died but would not remain dead. He does something similar in the Injil, Yahya 11.

verse.content: They laughed at him, because they knew that she was really dead.
But Isa took hold of the hand of the girl and called her, "Girl, get up!"
Her ruh returned to her and she got up immediately. Then he told them to give her some food.
Her parents were amazed, but he told them not to tell anyone what had happened.
After that, he called his twelve hawariyun, and gave them power and clear authority to cast out jinn and to heal sick people.
He sent them to announce the kingdom of Allah and to heal the sick.
He told them: "Do not take anything for your trip: No walking stick, no bag, no bread, no money and no extra robe.
Wherever you enter a house, stay there until you leave the region.
Suppose people do not welcome you. Then leave their town and shake off the dust from your feet as a shahada against them."

metadata.item: The message would be: We are not taking anything from you, and we do not owe you anything.

verse.content: The hawariyun went out proclaiming good news in all the villages, and healing everywhere.
The ruler Herod heard the news of everything that was happening, and he was puzzled, because some people were saying that Yahya had been resurrected alive from death.

metadata.item: This is Yahya the son of Zakariyya who did ghusl, not Yahya the son of Zebedee, who was one of the hawariyun. None of the hawariyun died before the time of the death of Isa.

verse.content: Some were saying: "Ilyas has appeared,\" and some of them were saying that one of the old anbiya has been resurrected alive.
But Herod said: "I cut off the head of Yahya. Who is the one I hear these things about?" So he tried to see him.
Then the hawariyun returned and told Isa everything they had done. So he took them with him by themselves to the town of Bethsaida.
But the crowd knew it, and they followed him. He welcomed them and spoke to them about the kingdom of Allah. He healed all their sick.

Before sunset, the twelve hawariyun came and told him: "Send the crowd away so they can go to the villages and the surrounding rural areas, stay there, and find food for themselves. We are in an isolated place."
But Isa told them: "You feed them." They said: "We only have five loaves and two fish, unless we go and buy food for all these people."
There were about five thousand men. Isa told his hawariyun: "Make them sit down in groups of fifty per group."
They told the people and everyone sat down.
Then Isa took the five loaves and two fish, looked up, and prayed in dua\' for baraka. Then he broke them and gave them to his followers to present to the crowds.
So they all ate and were full. Then they gathered twelve baskets of broken pieces that were left over.
Later, Isa was praying in dua\' alone with his hawariyun. Then he asked them: "Who do people say I am?"
They answered him: "Some people say that you are Yahya who did ghusl. Other people say you are Ilyas. Some people say you are one of the ancient anbiya who has been resurrected."
Isa said to them: "What about you? Who do you say I am?" Peter answered: "You are al-masih, al-mustafa of Allah."

metadata.item: These are both titles, not names. See glossary.

verse.content: He commanded them strongly not to reveal this to anyone.

metadata.item: One reason may have been that there were misconceptions about what those titles meant.

verse.content: He told them: "It is written that sayyid al-bashar must suffer many pains. The elders of the people and the leading ahbar and fuqaha must reject him. He must be killed and on the third day he must be resurrected alive."
Then he said to everyone: "If anyone wants to follow me, he must deny himself, sacrifice himself daily, (following the example of my death on the cross), and follow me.
Whoever wants to rescue his life will lose it. Whoever loses it in my sirat will rescue it.
What will a person benefit if he gains the whole world and loses or destroys his soul?

If anyone is embarrassed to mention me and my words, sayyid al-bashar will be embarrassed of him when he comes in the majesty of his glory, the glory of the Most Gracious King, and the glory of the holy angels.

metadata.item: This refers to the Arabic names Al-Rahman and Al-Malik, two of the 99 names of Allah. See the glossary for a discussion on this term.

verse.content: But I tell you a true saying: Some of the ones standing here will not die before they see the kingdom of Allah."

metadata.item: This probably refers to the event that follows next. Other people think it refers to the destruction of Al-Quds or some event that is still future.

verse.content: After about eight days, Isa took Peter and Yahya and Yacoub and went up on a mountain so he could pray in dua\'.
As he was praying in dua\', the appearance of his face changed and his clothes became white and shining, like lightning.
Suddenly, two men were talking with him: Musa and Ilyas.
They appeared in majesty, and started talking with him about his departure, which would happen soon in Al-Quds.
But Peter and his two companions were drowsy. When they woke up, they saw the majesty of the glory of Isa and the two men standing with him.

Before the two rusul departed, Peter said to Isa: "Our master, how wonderful it is that we are here. Let us build three tents: one for you, one for Musa, and one for Ilyas." He did not know what he was saying.

metadata.item: Musa and Ilyas.

verse.content: Then a voice shouted from the cloud. It said: "This is my beloved amir, al-mustafa. Listen to him."
After the voice, they saw only Isa. They were silent and did not tell anyone in those days what they had seen.
The next day they went down from the mountain, and a huge crowd welcomed him.
A man in the crowd shouted: "Teacher, please have compassion on my son. He is my only son!

A spirit takes control of him and suddenly makes him scream. He makes him shake, throws him on the ground, and makes him foam at the mouth. He does not leave him except after a great struggle and violent torture.
I begged your hawariyun to make him go out, but they could not."
Isa answered him: "You are a generation of kuffar who go astray! How long will I remain with you and bear you? Bring your son here."
As he brought him close, the jinni threw him to the ground and shook him. Isa rebuked the unclean spirit, healed the boy, made him well, and returned him to his father.
Everyone was amazed at the greatness of Allah. While they were marveling at everything Isa did, he said to his hawariyun:

metadata.item: This refers to the Arabic name Al-Azim, one of the 99 names of Allah.

verse.content: "Listen carefully to this saying: Sayyid al-bashar must be delivered to the hands of people."
But they did not understand his saying. It was unclear to them. They did not realize what it meant, but they were afraid to ask him about it.
Later, there was an argument among the hawariyun about who was the greatest of them.
Since Isa saw the thoughts of their hearts, he took a child beside him.
He told them: "Whoever receives this child in my name receives me. Whoever receives me receives Allah who sent me. The least of you is the greatest."
Yahya answered: "Our master, we saw a man casting out jinn in your name. We prohibited him, because he is not in our group."
Isa told him: "Do not prohibit him, because the person who is not against you is for you."
When the time approached for Isa to go up to heaven, he determined to head toward Al-Quds.
He sent rusul ahead of him, and they entered a village of Samaritans to prepare things for him.

metadata.item: Or messengers. Probably the hawariyun.

verse.content: But the people of the town did not accept him, because he was determined to head toward Al-Quds.

metadata.item: Samaritans disagreed with Al-Yahud about the proper place for worship. See the story in the Injil, Yahya 4.

verse.content: When the hawariyun Yacoub and Yahya saw this, they said: "Our mawla, do you want us to command fire to come down from the sky on them and destroy them?"

metadata.item: Ilyas had done this ayah. See the Tawrat, 2 Kings 1:9-16.

verse.content: Isa turned and rebuked them both.
Then they went to another village.
As they were walking on the way, a man said to him: "I will follow you wherever you go."
Isa told him: "Foxes have holes, and birds have nests, but sayyid al-bashar has no place to rest his head."
Isa told another person, "Follow me." But he answered him: "My master, let me go and bury my father first."
Isa said, "Let the dead bury their dead. You, go and announce the good news of the kingdom of Allah."
Another person said, "My master, I will follow you, but let me first say goodbye to my household."
Isa told him: "Everyone who puts his hand on the plow and then looks backward is not good enough for the kingdom of Allah."
Then our mawla appointed seventy others, and sent them two by two so they would go before him to all the cities and villages that he was going to visit.
He told them: "The harvest is plenteous and the laborers are few. Pray in dua\' to the Rabb of the harvest to send laborers to his harvest.
Go. Know that I have sent you as sheep among wolves.
Do not carry money, a bag, or shoes. Do not waste time with greetings on the way.

metadata.item: The intent of Isa may have been, "Do not waste time talking to people I have not sent you to."

verse.content: Whenever you enter a house, say, Assalamu alaykum to the people of that house!
If there is a son of peace in it, your peace will come upon him. If not, it will return to you.

metadata.item: The word son is obviously not literal. "Son of peace" means a peaceful person who received them, their peace, and their message.
Arabic salam, the same word as in the greeting assalamu alaykum.
The peace in your greeting assalamu alaykum.

verse.content: Stay at that house, and consume the food and drink what they offer you. The laborer deserves his wage. Do not move from one house to another house.
If you enter a town and its people receive you, eat the food they offer you.
Heal their sick people and tell them: the kingdom of Allah has approached you.
But whenever you enter a town and its people do not receive you, go out into its streets and say:
'We shake off even the dust of your town from our feet as a shahada against you. Know certainly that the kingdom of Allah has approached.'

metadata.item: In other words, we will not take anything from you so we do not owe you anything.

verse.content: I tell you that on Yawm Al-Din, the torture of the people of Lut, the inhabitants of Sodom, will be lighter than the torture of that town.

Woe to you, town of Chorazin! Woe to you, town of Bethsaida! If Tyre and Sidon had witnessed the works of power that you have witnessed, their people would have repented sincerely a long time ago, wearing sackcloth and sitting in ashes.

metadata.item: These towns were near Tabariyya Lake, and Isa did many ayat there.
These were towns of kuffar, to the north of Al-Jalil in what is modern-day Lebanon, on the coast of the Mediterranean Sea. In the Injil, it is only recorded that Isa went there once.
These are ways of showing sorrow for sin and repentance to Allah.

verse.content: But the torture of Tyre and Sidon will be lighter than your torture on Yawm Al-Din!
Capernaum, will Allah raise you up to the heights of Al-Janna? No. He will bring you down to Jahannam!
Whoever listens to you has listened to me. Whoever rejects you has rejected me. Whoever rejects me has rejected Allah who sent me."
When the seventy messengers returned, they said joyfully: "Our mawla, even the jinn are subject to us in your name!"

metadata.item: Because Isa had given them authority.

verse.content: Isa told them: "I saw Al-Shaitan defeated and falling from the heavens like lightning!
I have given you authority over all the power of the enemy, and you will even walk on serpents and scorpions. Nothing will harm you at all.

metadata.item: Al-Shaitan.

verse.content: But do not rejoice because the spirits submit to you, but rejoice that your names have been written in the register of Al-Janna."

In that hour, Isa rejoiced in Holy Ruh Allah and said: "Praise be to you, Most Loving King, Rabb of heaven and earth. You have hidden these secrets from wise and clever people and shown them to simple people! Yes, Most Loving King, everything has happened according to your rida.

My Most Loving King has delegated all things to me. No one knows who the beloved amir is except the Most Loving King. No one knows who the Most Loving King is except the beloved amir and whoever the beloved amir wills to reveal him."

metadata.item: This refers to the Arabic names Al-Malik and Al-Wadud, two of the 99 names of Allah. Isa used this title to describe his unique relationship with Allah. Isa called him his Most Loving King, with Isa as his amir. See glossary for more information.

verse.content: He turned to his hawariyun and told them in private: "The eyes that see what you see have a baraka.
I tell you that many anbiya and kings wanted to see what you see, but they did not see it. They wanted to hear what you hear, but did not hear it."
One of the scholars of the Tawrat stood up to test Isa. He said: "Teacher, what should I do to inherit a portion in eternal spiritual life?"

metadata.item: This question is unusual, because normally a person does not do anything to receive an inheritance. The inheritance received is based on a relationship.

verse.content: Isa told him: "What did Allah reveal in the Tawrat about that? How do you understand it?"
The scholar said: "Love Allah your Mawla with all your heart with all your soul and with all your strength and with all your mind. And love your neighbor like yourself."
Isa told him: "Good answer. If you do this, you will live."
But the scholar wanted to justify himself, and asked Isa: "And who is my neighbor?"

metadata.item: He would have thought that his fellow Yahud were his neighbors.

verse.content: Isa answered him: "A traveler was going down from Al-Quds to Jericho. Robbers grabbed him, stripped him naked, beat him, and left him half dead.

metadata.item: Al-Quds is on a mountain.

verse.content: It happened that a habr passed by on that road. He saw him, avoided him, and continued his journey.

metadata.item: The habr might not have known that the man was not dead. Touching a dead body made a person unclean. The habr had probably just finished his service at the house of Allah in Al-Quds, and was going home. If he became unclean, becoming tahir again after touching a dead body would require seven days of purification (See the Tawrat, Numbers 19:11-22). He probably thought that the chance of his becoming unclean would not be worth waiting seven more days before he became tahir again.

verse.content: A Levite also passed by and saw him. He avoided him and continued his journey.

metadata.item: The Levite probably thought the same way as the habr.

verse.content: Then a Samaritan passed by on his journey and saw him. He had compassion on him.

metadata.item: Al-Yahud hated the Samaritans and thought they were inferior. The listeners would have expected Isa to mention a Yahudi as the third person of the story.

verse.content: He came close to him, bandaged his wounds, and poured oil and wine on them. Then he loaded him on his beast and took him to a khan and cared for him.
The next day, the Samaritan gave two silver dinars to the owner of the khan. He told him: "Take care of him and when I return I will pay you back for everything extra you have spent.
Which of the three was truly a neighbor to the one who fell into the hands of robbers?"
The scholar said, "The one who treated him with mercy." Isa told him: "Go and do like him."

metadata.item: The scholar could not force himself to say the word Samaritan.

verse.content: During his journey, they entered a village and a woman named Martha hosted Isa.
Her sister Mariam sat at the feet of our mawla, listening to his words.

metadata.item: Mariam was a common name. This is not the mother of Isa.

verse.content: But Martha was busy with much serving. Then she came and told him: "My mawla, do you not notice that my sister has left me to work alone? Tell her to help me."
Our mawla answered her: "Martha, Martha, you are anxious and troubled with many things.
One matter is needed. Mariam has chosen the best portion. It will never be taken from her."
One day, Isa was praying in dua\' to Allah in a certain place, and when he stopped, one of his hawariyun told him: "Our mawla, teach us to do salat as Yahya taught his followers."

metadata.item: Or dua'.

verse.content: Isa told them: "If you do salat, say, "Allahumma, our Most Gracious King, may your holy name be praised. May your kingdom appear.
Provide bread for us every day for that day.
Forgive us our sins, for we pardon all who are in debt to us. Do not make us enter trials."
Then he spoke to them: "Suppose one of you goes to the house of his friend at midnight and tells him: Friend, loan me three loaves of bread.

metadata.item: Bread was the main staple that everyone had. To have no bread meant to have nothing.

verse.content: A guest from out of town has come to me, and I have nothing to offer him.
Your friend would never say from inside: Do not bother me! I have locked the door and my children are sleeping with me in the bed. I cannot get up to give you what you are asking for!
I tell you: even though he would not get up and give it to him because of affection between them, he will give him whatever he needs because of his honor.

metadata.item: Or shamelessness. If he refused, all the neighbors would consider him a dishonorable person. Bread was the cheapest food and asking for bread showed that the host had nothing at all to serve.

verse.content: So I tell you: pray in dua\' and you will receive. Seek and you will find. Knock and it will be opened to you.

metadata.item: Allah will act honorably.

verse.content: Everyone who asks receives, and he who seeks finds, and the door will be opened to the one who knocks.
What father among you will give his son a rock if he asks for bread? Will you give him a water snake if he asks for a fish?

metadata.item: Many rocks in that area were flat and round, like their bread.
Water snakes (eels) and fish both come from the water and have scales. Some water snakes are poisonous.

verse.content: If he asks for an egg, will you give him a scorpion?

metadata.item: When a scorpion is curled up, it is in the shape of an egg. The sting of a scorpion is poisonous.

verse.content: If even you evil people know how to give your children good gifts, how much more will your Most Gracious King in the heavens give his Holy Ruh Allah to the one who asks him?"

metadata.item: Ruh Allah refers to Allah's spirit. It does not refer to an angel. It is not used in the Injil as a title of Isa.

verse.content: Isa was casting out a dumb jinni, and when the jinni went out, the dumb man spoke, and the crowds were amazed.

metadata.item: This was a miracle Al-Yahud believed that only al-masih could do. Al-Yahud would ask the jinni for its name and use its name to cast it out, but person with a dumb jinni could not speak. Thus they were not able to cast it out.

verse.content: But some of them said, "He casts out jinn with the power of Iblis, king of the jinn!"

metadata.item: The miracle of casting out a dumb jinni forced the leaders of Bani Israil to acknowledge that Isa was al-masih or not. Since they decided not to acknowledge this, they had to invent an explanation for why he could do this miracle.

verse.content: A group of them asked him to bring them an ayah from heaven, in order to test him.

metadata.item: Isa had just done an ayah and they did not believe.

verse.content: He knew their intentions, and told them: "Every divided kingdom will be destroyed. Every divided house will fall down.
If Al-Shaitan is divided, how can he remain? You said that I cast out jinn with the power of Iblis.

metadata.item: He referred to the ayah that he had just done.

verse.content: If I cast out jinn with the power of Iblis, by whose power do your sons cast them out? Thus they will judge you.

metadata.item: The word sons is not literal. Here it means followers.
They cast out the jinn by asking the jinn for their names. When a jinni made a person unable to speak, they could not get an answer and could not cast him out.

verse.content: But if I cast out jinn by the finger of Allah, the kingdom of Allah has been established among you.

metadata.item: The word finger is not literal. It does not mean that Allah has a body. It refers to the power of Allah.

verse.content: When a strong, armed man guards his palace, his possessions are safe.
But suppose someone stronger than he attacks him and defeats him. He will strip him of his armor in which he trusted and distribute the spoils.
He who is not with me is against me. He who does not gather with me is scattered.
If an unclean spirit leaves a man, it wanders about in desolate places seeking rest in vain. Then it says: I will go to my residence that I left.

metadata.item: The person the jinni had been in.

verse.content: It comes to the man and finds that he is like a house that has been swept, clean and neat.
So it goes and brings seven spirits more evil than it as companions, and they enter him and live in him. The final situation of that man is worse than his first situation."

metadata.item: When a jinni is cast out of a person, it is important to have Holy Ruh Allah fill the person or his situation will become worse.

verse.content: As he was speaking, a woman in the crowd shouted: "The mother who gave birth to you and nursed you has a baraka!"
Isa said, "Those who hear the word of Allah and do it have a greater baraka."
People were crowding around him, so Isa started saying: "This generation is an unjust generation. It seeks an ayah, but it will not be given an ayah except for the ayah of Yunis.
Yunis was an ayah for the people of the city of Ninevah. Sayyid al-bashar will similarly be an ayah for this generation.

metadata.item: Allah raised him out of his grave (the fish) on the third day and he was a warner to the people of Ninevah.
Yunis would have remained in the fish unless Allah had brought him out after three days. Isa would have remained in his grave unless Allah had brought him out after three days.

verse.content: The queen of Sheba will be resurrected on the Yawm Al-Din along with the men of this generation and condemn them. She came from the ends of the earth to hear the wisdom of Sulayman. But here there is someone greater than Sulayman!

metadata.item: A kingdom of Yemen. In Arabic, Saba'.
This story is in the Tawrat, 1 Kings 10.
Isa is the one who is greater than Sulaiman.

verse.content: No one lights a lamp and then puts it in a hiding place or under a basket. He puts it on a lamp stand so those who enter will be guided by its light.
The lamp of your body is your eye. When your eye is healthy, your whole body will be full of light. When your eye is evil, your body will be filled with darkness.

metadata.item: An evil eye often means jealousy and envy.

verse.content: Beware! Do not let the light in you be darkness.
But if your whole body is full of light, with no darkness in it, it will all shine, just as you see from the light of a shining lamp."
He was speaking, and one of the Pharisees invited him to eat with him. So Isa went into his house and reclined at the table.

metadata.item: People ate around a low table by leaning on their left side on the ground.

verse.content: The Pharisee was amazed when he saw that Isa did not wash his hands before the food.
Our mawla said to him: "You Pharisees are careful that your glasses and plates are tahir on the outside, but you are full of greed and evil inside.

metadata.item: It seems Isa knew what the host was thinking.

verse.content: You are fools. Isn't the creator of the outward form the creator of the inside also?
Give zakat for what is inside you, and then everything will be tahir for you.
Woe to you Pharisees! You give zakat on mint, thyme, and other herbs, and neglect justice and the love of Allah! Doing the first things is necessary, but you should not neglect the other things.

metadata.item: Justice and the love of Allah are more important than the zakat on herbs.

verse.content: Woe to you Pharisees! You love the front row in the houses of salat, greetings from people, and respect in the markets.
Woe to you! You are like unseen graves. People walk over them by accident and become unclean."

metadata.item: By contact with a dead body.

verse.content: A scholar of the Tawrat answered him: "Teacher, by this saying, you insult us, too."
Isa said, "Woe to you also, scholars of the Tawrat! You load people with difficult burdens and do not move even a finger to touch them.
Woe to you! You decorate the graves of the anbiya whom your ancestors murdered.
By that, you give shahada that you approve of what your ancestors did. They killed the anbiya and you completed their work by building their graves.
This is what Allah, the Wise said: I will send them anbiya and rusul. They will kill some of them and persecute some of them.

metadata.item: This refers to the Arabic name Al-Hakim, one of the 99 names of Allah.

verse.content: Therefore Allah will hold this generation responsible for shedding the blood of all the anbiya murdered since the beginning of the worlds,

metadata.item: The anbiya and the rusul predicted the coming of al-masih and Al-Yahud killed them. When al-masih came, that generation of Al-Yahud rejected him and later killed him.

verse.content: starting with the blood of Habil until the blood of Zakariyya, who was murdered between the altar of the haram and the house of Allah. Yes, I tell you that Allah will hold this generation responsible for all this blood.

metadata.item: Habil son of Adam was killed by his brother Qabil. Qabil was angry that Allah did not accept his qurban of food. Allah accepted the sacrifice of a sheep by his brother Habil. This was the first murder in the Tawrat.
Zakariyya was a common name. This does not refer to the father of Yahya.
The murder of this Zakariyya was the last murder recorded in the Tawrat.

verse.content: Woe to you, scholars of the Tawrat! You have taken away the key to the door of knowledge. You have not entered the door, and you have prevented those who want to enter from entering."
When Isa left there, the fuqaha and the Pharisees were more furious. They asked many more questions.
They wanted to catch him in a word he would say.

Meanwhile, the multitudes of ten thousands gathered. There were so many that some of them were stepping on others. Isa began to teach his hawariyun: "Beware of the yeast of the Pharisees, which is hypocrisy.

metadata.item: They all wanted to be close enough to hear Isa.
Yeast is usually a symbol of evil. Yeast spreads to affect all the dough. Hypocrisy similarly spread to affect all the lives of the Pharisees.

verse.content: Everything covered will be shown, and everything hidden will be made known.
What you said in the dark will be heard in the light, and what you whispered in small rooms will be announced from the roofs.
I tell you, loved ones, do not fear those who kill the body. They have no further power for anything else.
But I warn you whom to fear: Fear Allah who kills and has authority to throw you into Jahannam. Yes, I tell you. Fear him!
Are five sparrows not sold for only two dirhams? And Allah is not unaware of one of them.

metadata.item: This dirham was equal to one-sixteenth of the daily wage of a laborer.

verse.content: But even the hair on your heads is all counted. So do not fear. You are more valuable than many sparrows.

metadata.item: So Allah will take care of you.

verse.content: Suppose someone supports me in front of men. I tell you that sayyid al-bashar will support him in front of the angels of Allah.
But if someone denies me in front of men, I will deny him in front of the angels of Allah.
Whoever says a word against sayyid al-bashar can be forgiven, but he who disbelieves in Holy Ruh Allah will never be forgiven for that.

metadata.item: Some people believe this refers to attributing the work of Holy Ruh Allah to Al-Shaitan. Others believe it means a final rejection of the shahada of Holy Ruh Allah about Isa and rejecting him.

verse.content: If they bring you in front of houses of salat and authorities and governors, do not worry how to answer them or what to say.
Holy Ruh Allah will reveal to you what you should say in that hour."
Someone in the multitude said: "Teacher, tell my brother to divide the inheritance with me."
But Isa told him: "Man, who set me up over you as a judge or a divider?"

metadata.item: Although Isa actually is a judge and a divider. See the Injil, Matthew 25:31-46.

verse.content: Then he said to people: "Beware of greediness! Beware of all of its varieties! Life is not merely an abundance of possessions."
He told them a story: "The land of a rich man had a harvest.
He told himself: What shall I do? My storehouses are already full of crops.
Then he said: I will do this: I will tear down my storehouses and then build bigger storehouses, and store all my crops and yield in it.
Then I will tell my soul: 'Soul, rest, eat, drink, and rejoice. You have bounteous provision prepared in my storehouses for years!'
But Allah told him: 'Fool, I will make you die tonight. Then who will inherit what you prepared?'
This is the destiny of everyone who stores treasure for himself and is not rich with Allah."
Then Isa told his hawariyun: "Therefore I tell you: Do not worry about your lives (what you eat) or about your bodies (what you wear).
Life is more than food, and the body more than clothing.
Think about the ravens. They do not plant seeds or harvest crops. They have no storehouses, but Allah, the Provider, feeds them. Are you not more important that they are?

metadata.item: This refers to the Arabic name Al-Razzaq, one of the 99 names of Allah.

verse.content: Who among you can lengthen his life by one second by worrying?
If you cannot do something easy, why do you worry about anything hard?
Think about the lilies and how they grow. They do not spin thread or get tired. But I tell you: Even Sulayman in the height of his majesty never wore clothes like one of them.

metadata.item: See the Tawrat, 1 Kings 3:13, for example.

verse.content: Allah gives glorious clothing to the grass that remains for one day in the field. The next day it is thrown in the oven. How much more will he give clothing to you people who have little faith? Do not be concerned or worried about what you eat and drink.
People in all nations of the world seek these things. But your Most Gracious King knows well your needs.
But seek his kingdom, and Allah will provide your needs.
Do not fear, little group! Your Most Gracious King has rida to give you a share in the kingdom!
Sell what you own. Give its value to the poor. You will get eternal bags with Allah with imperishable treasure in them. No robber will come near it, and no moth will eat it.
Your hearts will be wherever your treasures are.
Be ready and dressed for service, with your lamps lit.
Be like slaves who are waiting for their master to return from a wedding feast. As soon as he arrives and knocks, they will open the door for him.
When their master comes and finds them awake, they will have a baraka. I tell you the truth: Their master will roll up his sleeves, gather them at the table, and serve them!
They will have a baraka when he finds them staying up at midnight or just before dawn!
Be sure of this: If the owner of the house knew what time the robber was coming, he would not have let his house be robbed.
Be ready, because sayyid al-bashar will come to you at a time that you do not expect."
Peter told him: "Our mawla, are you telling this story for us only, or also for all people?"
Al-mawla said: "Who is a wise, faithful manager? His master will give him responsibility over his servants, to feed them at the right times.
When his master finds that slave doing his work, the slave has a baraka.
I tell you a true saying: His master will give him responsibility over all his property.
But suppose that slave says to himself: My master will be late coming back. Suppose he starts to beat the male and female slaves, to eat, drink, and get drunk.
The master of that slave will return on a day he does not expect, at an hour he does not know. He will tear him in pieces and throw him in Jahannam along with the disbelievers destined for Jahannam!

metadata.item: The master referred to here represents Allah. Only Allah can throw people into jahannam.

verse.content: That slave will be beaten severely, because he knew the will of his master and was lazy or disobedient.

But the slave who does not know his will and does what deserves a beating will be beaten lightly. If someone has been given much, much will be required from him. Whoever has responsibility for much will be asked for more.
I came to cast down fire on the earth. I wish very much that it was burning now!
But I must do a ghusl into pain. How it constrains me until it is accomplished!

metadata.item: Ghusl was done by immersing into water. Here Isa says he will be immersed in pain.

verse.content: Do you imagine that I came to cast peace on earth? No, but division!
From now on, if there are five in a home, they will be divided three against two and two against three.
The father will be divided against his son, the mother against her daughter, the daughter against her mother, and the daughter-in-law against her mother-in-law.

metadata.item: This division may come when some people of the family follow Isa and others do not. This is not a command but a prediction.

verse.content: Then he told the multitude: "When you see a cloud come up in the west, you predict that it will rain, and it rains.

metadata.item: Their weather generally came from the west.

verse.content: If a south wind blows, you predict that it will be hot, and the heat comes.

metadata.item: From the desert. When weather came from the desert, it was hot and dry.

verse.content: You are hypocrites! You know how to explain the ayat of the sky and the earth. So how can you be ignorant how to explain the ayat of this time?

metadata.item: Isa had done many ayat that proved that he was al-masih.

verse.content: Why can you not judge rightly by yourselves?

If you go to court with your opponent, try to reconcile with him while you are on the way. Otherwise, he may drag you to the judge, the judge may turn you over to the policeman, and he may throw you in prison.

metadata.item: Putting debtors in prison was a common practice.

verse.content: I tell you, you will not get out until after you have paid the last fils you owe.

metadata.item: This fils was worth less than one percent of the daily wage of a laborer.

verse.content: At that time, some people there told him that the governor Pilate had killed some people of Al-Jalil. Their blood was mixed with the blood of their sacrifices.

metadata.item: When Pilate felt strong, he was very cruel.
They were killed while presenting their sacrifices to Allah.

verse.content: Isa answered them: "Do you think that those people from Al-Jalil were greater sinners than the rest of the people of Al-Jalil because they died this way?
I tell you: No. But if you do not repent, you will all die like they died!
Do you think those eighteen people who died when the tower near Siloam pool fell on them were greater debtors than the rest of the inhabitants of Al-Quds?
I tell you: No. But if you do not repent, you will all die like they died.

metadata.item: People do not necessarily die because of their own sins. But everyone needs to repent.

verse.content: He told them this story: "The owner of a vineyard planted a fig tree in his vineyard. He came to it many times, wanting figs, but did not find any.
He said to the orchard keeper: For three years, I have been coming to this fig tree looking for fruit. I have not found any. Cut it down! Why should we let it waste the ground?

metadata.item: Grapes could have been planted there.

verse.content: But the orchard keeper answered him: Master, give it another year. I will plow the soil and fertilize it.
Maybe it will produce fruit in the future. If not, I will cut it down."

metadata.item: Isa had been giving the message to Bani Israil to repent for three years. Within one more year, Isa would die and Bani Israil would be judged by Allah.

verse.content: Isa was teaching in a house of salat on Al-Sabt.
A woman came who was touched by a spirit of illness. It had made her back bent for eighteen years. All that time, she could not stand up straight.
When Isa saw her, he called her to come to him and told her: "Woman, you are free from your illness."
Then he put his hands on her and immediately she stood up straight. She started praising the glory of Allah.

The ruler of the house of salat was angry at him, because Isa had healed on Al-Sabt. He said to the crowd: "You have six days for work. Come on those days seeking healing. Do not break the boundaries of Al-Sabt."

metadata.item: He was referring to the Tawrat, Exodus 20:9.

The ruler of the house of salat was referring to man-made boundaries - definitions about what not working on Al-Sabt meant. Allah never prohibited showing mercy by healing people on Al-Sabt in the Tawrat.

verse.content: Our mawla said to him in response: "Hypocrites, does not every one of you on Al-Sabt untie the bonds of his bull or his donkey and lead it from the feeding trough to give it water?
This woman, who is a daughter of Ibrahim, was tied up by Al-Shaitan for eighteen years. Was it not necessary that she be freed from these bonds on Al-Sabt?"

metadata.item: The word daughter is not literal. Ibrahim had been dead for about 2000 years, and any daughters would have been dead for almost that long. Being called a child of Ibrahim meant the person had true faith and trust in Allah, like Ibrahim did.
By her being hunch-backed.

verse.content: All his opponents were embarrassed by his words, but the crowds rejoiced at all the glorious ayat that he did.
Isa said: "What is the kingdom of Allah like? What shall I compare it to?
It is like a mustard seed. A man took it and threw it in his garden. It grew and became a tree. Even birds of the sky made their nests in its branches."

metadata.item: Mustard plants are bushes and do not naturally become trees. Some people believe this refers to the unexpected growth of the kingdom of Allah. Others think that the birds of the air represent evil (see chapter 8:5,12) and that this story refers to the spread of evil within the kingdom of Allah. See Matthew 13:24-30 for another story with that meaning.

verse.content: He also said: "To what shall I compare the kingdom of Allah?
It is like yeast that a woman took and hid in three measures of dough. Then the yeast made all the dough rise."

metadata.item: Some people believe this refers to the expansion of the kingdom of Allah. Others think that yeast represents evil (see for example Mark 8:15) and that the yeast in this story refers to the spread of evil within the kingdom of Allah.

verse.content: Isa passed by the towns and villages, teaching on his way and headed to Al-Quds.
A man asked him: "Our mawla, will those who will be given life be few?" He told him,

metadata.item: The reference is to a portion of life in Al-Janna.

verse.content: "Struggle to enter by the narrow door. I tell you that many will try to enter and will not be able to.

As soon as the master of the house gets up and closes the door, you will find yourselves outside, knocking on the door. You will plead with him: Our master, open to us! He will answer you from inside: I do not know where you come from.

metadata.item: By changing the pronoun from "they" to "you," Isa shows that he was talking about Al-Yahud. They thought they were all going to Al-Janna just because they were from Bani Israil.

verse.content: Then you will begin to say: We ate and drank in front of you, and you taught in our streets!
He will tell you: I do not know where you come from. Get away from me, you unjust people!

metadata.item: Being near Isa is not enough. A person must have a relationship with him. Hearing his teaching without being righteous is not enough.

verse.content: There people will cry and grind their teeth. You will see Ibrahim and Ishaq and Yacoub and the rest of the anbiya in the kingdom of Allah. But you will be thrown outside.

metadata.item: In jahannam.

verse.content: People will come from east, west, north and south. They will recline at the feast of the kingdom of Allah.

metadata.item: This is where other ummas lived. Isa told this to Al-Yahud who thought that they would be the only umma who would be allowed into Al-Janna.

verse.content: Then the last ones will be first and the first will be last."
At that time, some Pharisees approached him and told him: "Flee from here, because Herod wants to kill you."

metadata.item: Herod Antipas. See glossary.
They wanted Isa to run away and hide, which would have brought shame on him and his message.

verse.content: But he told them: "Go and tell that fox: Today and tomorrow I will cast out jinn and heal the sick. On the third day I will finish my sirat.
But I must continue my travel today, tomorrow, and the day after tomorrow until I get to Al-Quds. It is impossible that the murder of a nabi would happen outside Al-Quds.

metadata.item: Three days, in other words. Isa also predicted that he would remain dead for three days.

verse.content: Al-Quds, Al-Quds, you kill anbiya and stone rusul! How often I wanted to gather your sons as a hen gathers her chicks under her wings, but you refused!

metadata.item: The word sons is not literal. Here it means citizens.

verse.content: Look! Your house will be deserted! I tell you: you will not see me any more until you say in shahada: The person who comes in the name of Rabb Al-Alamin has a baraka."

metadata.item: This statement is an acknowledgement that Isa truly is al-masih. It is a reference to the Zabur, Psalms 118:26.

verse.content: On Al-Sabt, Isa went to the house of one of the leading Pharisees to eat there. They were trying to trap him.
A man with edema came in front of him.

metadata.item: A disease of swelling, because the body retains excess fluid.

verse.content: Isa asked the scholars of the Tawrat and the Pharisees: "Is healing on Al-Sabt halal or haraam?"

metadata.item: It is always halal to do good, and it is always haraam to do evil.

verse.content: They were silent. Isa took the hand of the sick man, healed him and sent him off.

metadata.item: They had no good answer. They saw that their sunan were wrong but they did not want to admit it.

verse.content: Then he told them: "If one of you has a son or an ox that has fallen into a well, he quickly goes to pull him or it out on Al-Sabt."

metadata.item: Even they did not keep all their man-made laws.

verse.content: They were unable to answer him in this matter.
Isa saw how the guests chose seats of honor, and he told them a story. He said:
"If someone invites you to a wedding feast, do not sit in the most honored seat. He may have invited someone more important than you.
Your host may come and tell you: Give your seat to him! You will be very embarrassed when you go to sit in the lowest seat.

Rather, when you are invited, sit in the lowest seat. Then the host will come and tell you: My friend, go up to a more honorable place! Your position will be greater in the sight of everyone seated there.
Allah lowers people who lift themselves up and raises up people who are humble."

metadata.item: This refers to the Arabic names Al-Khafid and Al-Rafi', two of the 99 names of Allah.

verse.content: Then Isa said to the host: "If you give a lunch or dinner, do not invite your friends or your brothers or relatives or rich neighbors. They may invite you in return. Then you will receive a reward for your good deed.
If you give a feast, invite people who are poor, disfigured, lame, and blind.
Allah will give you a baraka, because they cannot repay you. You will receive your reward from your Rabb on the day of resurrection along with the righteous.\"
One of those sitting heard the words of Isa. He said to him: "The person who will eat bread in the kingdom of Allah has a baraka!"

metadata.item: The word bread here is not literal. Here it means food.

verse.content: Isa told him: "A man gave a big feast and invited many people.
He sent his slave at the time of the dinner to tell those who had accepted the invitation: Come now. Everything is totally ready.

metadata.item: There were two invitations. The first one was about the future event, and its exact timing was not yet fixed. The second invitation went to those who had accepted the invitation when everything was ready. The people in this story had already accepted the first invitation. To refuse to come when everything was ready was a great insult.
