verse.content: All those invited started to make excuses. The first said: I have bought a farm, and I must go now and see it. Please excuse me.

metadata.item: No one would have bought a farm without seeing it. This man was insulting the host by giving a ridiculous excuse.

verse.content: Another said: I have bought five pairs of oxen, and I am going now to try them out. Please excuse me.

metadata.item: No one would have bought five pair of oxen without making sure they pulled well together. This man was insulting the host by giving a ridiculous excuse.

verse.content: Another said: I have a bride and I cannot come.

metadata.item: Women were not valued very much in the days of Isa. This man was insulting his host by saying that he would be spending time with a woman rather than coming to the feast.

verse.content: The slave returned and told his master what happened. The master of the house told his slave: Go quickly to the streets and alleys of the city. Bring us people who are poor, disfigured, blind, and lame.

metadata.item: It would be a shame for the master of the house to have a feast and the room not be filled. In addition, his animals had already been slaughtered and the food was all cooked. It would be wasted if someone did not eat it.

verse.content: The slave returned later and said: Master, I have executed your orders, and there is still more room in the place.
The master said to the slave: Go to the roads and paths, and force people to attend, so my home will be filled with guests.

metadata.item: Or convince.

verse.content: I tell you: No one who was invited will taste a bite of my feast!"

metadata.item: Al-Yahud had been prepared by the anbiya for al-masih, but when he came, most of them rejected him. So Allah invited everyone else in the world.

verse.content: Large crowds accompanied Isa. He turned to them and said:
"Suppose someone comes to me and does not hate his father and mother, wife and children, brothers and sisters, and even his own life. He cannot be one of my followers.

metadata.item: The word 'hate' is not literal. It has two meanings. The first meaning is that Isa is saying that those people who follow Isa must love him more than they love their family, so that by comparison their love for their family is like hate. The second meaning of 'hate' is 'not choose'. This meaning is found in the Tawrat, Malachi 1:3. According to this meaning, those people who follow Isa must choose him over their family.

verse.content: Whoever does not sacrifice himself, following the example of my death on the cross, cannot be one of my disciples.
Suppose one of you wants to build a tower. Does he not first sit and calculate the expenses to see if he can finish it?
Otherwise, he will lay a foundation and not be able to finish it. Everyone who sees the tower will mock him and say:
'This man began to build and was not able to finish it!'

Suppose a king wants to go to war against another king who is coming against him with twenty thousand soldiers. Will he not sit down first and take counsel if he is able to face him with his army of ten thousand?

metadata.item: Some military analysts believe that a force of defenders which number half the number of attackers is enough to resist the attack.

verse.content: Otherwise, he will send a delegation to his enemy while he is still far away. He will ask for conditions of peace.
So none of you can be my follower unless he renounces everything he owns.
Salt is good, but if the salt is spoiled, how can its salty flavor be restored?
It is useless for the ground and for fertilizer. It is thrown outside. Everyone who has ears should listen."
All the tax collectors and sinners came close to Isa and listened to him.
But the Pharisees and fuqaha grumbled, "He receives sinners and eats with them!"
Isa told them this story:
"Suppose one of you has one hundred sheep, and one sheep is lost. Does he not leave the ninety-nine in the wilderness to look for the lost sheep until he finds it?

metadata.item: Pharisees despised shepherds and thought that it was a shame to own sheep.

Inside an enclosure for sheep in the care of a helper, or otherwise safe from harm. The shepherd knew that there were exactly 99 sheep and not 100, which implies that he counted them, probably as they came into a sheep fold. Others have suggested that when sheep are together in a group, a predatory animal will not attack them. In any case, a lone sheep would be the most vulnerable.

verse.content: When he finds it, he will carry it on his shoulders.
He will bring it back to the house and gather his friends and neighbors. He will say to them: "Rejoice with me. I found my lost sheep!
I tell you that there will be more joy in heaven when someone repents after going astray than from ninety-nine righteous people who do not need repentance.
If a woman loses one of her ten dinars, will she not light a lamp and sweep the house and look for it eagerly until she finds it?

metadata.item: These ten dinars (drachmas in the original language) may have been the dirhams on a necklace that was given as the bride price or part of it. Having them complete would show that she is still married. This dinar was worth about the daily wage of a laborer.
Women in those days would rarely go outside their houses. The woman must have known that the lost dinar must be somewhere in the house.

verse.content: When she does find it, she will gather her friends and neighbors and tell them: Rejoice with me, because I found the lost dinar!
So I tell you that there will be joy in the presence of the angels when one person repents from going astray."
Then Isa said: "A man had two sons.
The younger son said to his father: Father, give me my share of the inheritance now. So the father divided all his possessions between them.

metadata.item: In a sense, he was wishing that his father would die so he could get his inheritance immediately. This was extremely rude and insulting.

The expected response would have been to punish the younger son. Giving away a part of the lands and cattle would have caused the rest of the family to have less to live on. The response of the father would have been shocking to the audience.

verse.content: In a few days, the younger son gathered all his inheritance and traveled to a far country. There he wasted his money in expensive living.

metadata.item: To gather an inheritance which would be mostly property and livestock and selling it quickly would probably have involved not getting good prices for the sales. Bargaining over a long period of time was common.

verse.content: After he had spent all his money, that country had a severe famine, so he was needy.
So he went and attached himself to a man of that country. The man sent him into his fields to be a pig herder.

metadata.item: Al-Yahud listening to Isa considered pigs to be unclean animals based on the teaching of the Tawrat in Leviticus 11:7. For a Yahudi to feed pigs was the worst humiliation possible.

verse.content: He was so hungry that he wished he could fill his stomach with the carob that the pigs were eating. No one gave him anything.
Then he came to his senses and said: My father has many workers who have more than enough food. I am dying here from hunger!
I will get up and return to my father. I will tell him: 'Father, I have sinned against Allah and against you.
I am not worthy to be called your son. Hire me as one of your workers.'
So he got up and returned to his father. His father saw him coming from far away and had compassion on him. He ran to his son and hugged him and kissed him.

metadata.item: This implies the father was waiting and watching for him. It also implies that the house of the father was higher in elevation, so he could see far. This probably means that the father was relatively wealthy.

Men in the Middle East never ran or walked quickly as it was seen as not dignified. However, to protect his son, he took this shame on himself and met his son before the son had to pass down through the village and endure their abuse.

verse.content: His son told him: 'Father, I have sinned against Allah and against you. I am not worthy to be called your son any more.'
But the father commanded his slaves: Go quickly and bring the most elegant robe and put it on him. Put a ring on his finger and shoes on his feet!

metadata.item: Fathers had a special robe, and to receive this robe was the highest honor. It was a sign that the younger son had been fully accepted and restored.
A ring and shoes were signs that he was a son. Slaves did not wear them.

verse.content: Bring the feed calf and slaughter it so we can eat and celebrate.
This son of mine was dead and he lives. He was lost and is found! They started celebrating.
The older son was in the field. When he came near the house, he heard singing and dancing.
He called one of the servants and asked him what was happening.
He told him: Your brother came and your father slaughtered the feed calf because he returned safely.
He became angry and did not want to enter. So his father went out and begged him.

metadata.item: The older son was expected to act as a host to the party. Not entering was a huge insult to the father.
The expected response would have been to punish the older son. The response of the father would have been shocking to the audience.

verse.content: But he answered his father: "Listen! Like a slave I have served you for a long time. I did not disobey one of your orders. But you did not give me even a young goat to celebrate with my friends.

metadata.item: This statement was very disrespectful also.
This shows that the older son also wanted the possessions of the father, and not a relationship with the father.

verse.content: But this son of yours wasted his possessions with prostitutes. Then he came and you slaughtered the feed calf!

metadata.item: This accusation is not supported by the story.

verse.content: He said, Son, you are with me always. All I have is yours.

metadata.item: The younger son had spent his portion of the inheritance. The usual response of the father would have been to punish him. The gracious response of the father would have been shocking to the audience.

verse.content: But we must celebrate and rejoice, because your brother was dead and is alive. He went astray and is found."

metadata.item: The response of the Pharisees and the fuqaha is not mentioned. The reason may be that the reader is expected to respond.

verse.content: He also told his hawariyun: "A rich man heard that his manager was wasting his money.
So he called him and asked him: What is this I hear about you? Give me the accounts of your management position. You are not worthy to remain as my manager.
The manager said to himself: What can I do, when my master takes away my management position? I am not strong enough to work on a farm, and I am ashamed to beg.
I know what I will do when my position as manager is taken away from me. People will receive me into their homes!
He called each person who was in debt to his master, one by one. He asked the first: How much do you owe my master?

metadata.item: The manager may have communicated that he was the one responsible for arranging the discount with the rich man.

verse.content: He said: One hundred barrels of oil. The manager told him: Take your note, sit down quickly, and change it to fifty.
Then he asked another: How about you? How much do you owe? He said: One hundred measures of wheat. The manager told him: Take your note and change it to eighty.

metadata.item: The values of the discounts each received were approximately equal.

verse.content: His master commended the cleverness of the sneaky steward when he heard what he had done. Sons of this world are smarter than sons of light in their dealings with their generation.

metadata.item: The rich man was forced by his honor as a generous man to acknowledge that he had agreed to the reductions of the debts.
The word sons is obviously not literal. Here it means inhabitants.
The word sons here is also not literal. Here it means those whose lives are characterized by light.

verse.content: I tell you: Make friendships using the money of injustice so that you will be welcomed in the eternal dwellings when money passes away.

metadata.item: Al-Janna
Some people think Isa was being sarcastic here. Other people think that he meant that people should use money (which can be used for evil purposes) for purposes that serve Allah.

verse.content: A person who is faithful in little is faithful in much, also. A person who betrays in little will betray in much.

metadata.item: Or is unfaithful.

verse.content: If you betray in money of injustice which passes away, who will entrust you with truth which is lasting?
If you betray in what belongs to someone else, who will entrust you with what is yours?

A slave cannot serve two masters. Either he will love one of them and hate the other or he will be devoted to one of them and despise the other. You cannot worship Allah and the god of money together."

metadata.item: In the original language, Mammon.

verse.content: The Pharisees heard what he said and they mocked him, because they loved money.
Isa told them: "You justify yourselves in front of people, but Allah knows what is in your hearts. What people consider honorable is detested by Allah.
The era of the Tawrat and the scrolls of the anbiya lasted until the time of Yahya. Since that time, the good news of the kingdom of Allah is proclaimed. Many are struggling to enter it.
But making heaven and the earth disappear would be easier than making one dot from the kitab disappear.
Whoever divorces his wife and marries another wife commits adultery. Whoever marries a divorced woman commits adultery.

metadata.item: Isa gives no exceptions here. In the Injil, Matthew 5 and 19, there is an exception because of the difference in marriage customs. Al-Yahud had three steps to marriage: engagement, betrothal, and marriage. At betrothal, a couple was legally husband and wife, but they had not consummated the marriage. In Matthew, Isa allows divorce if it is discovered during the betrothal stage that the wife was not a virgin.

The word adultery (twice in this verse) means sexual relations with a married person who is not the spouse. This means divorce is not valid to Isa. Marrying a divorced person is adultery because that person is still the spouse of the first husband or wife.

verse.content: A rich man wore fancy purple robes and soft linen. He enjoyed rich feasts every day.
There was a poor beggar at his door named Lazarus. His skin was covered with sores.

metadata.item: This is the same name as a friend of Isa, who later died and Isa resurrected him alive from death. See the Injil, Yahya 11.

verse.content: He wanted desperately to eat the crumbs that fell from the table of the rich man. The dogs licked his wounds.
Lazarus died, and the angels carried him to the lap of Ibrahim. Then the rich man died and was buried.
He was undergoing the torture of the grave and he looked up. He saw Ibrahim with Lazarus in his lap.
He called, "Father Ibrahim, have mercy on me. Send Lazarus to moisten the end of his finger in water and cool my tongue. I am being tortured in this flame.

metadata.item: The word father in this story is not literal. Here it means either an ancestor or the father of people who are believers.
He was used to giving orders and having his desires fulfilled.

verse.content: Ibrahim said: Son, remember that you received barakat in your earthly life. Lazarus received evil and misfortunes. Now he is comforted and you are being tortured.

metadata.item: The word son is not literal. Here it is an expression of the compassion and kindness of Ibrahim.

verse.content: In addition, Allah has placed between us and you a great barrier. Those who want to cross from here to you cannot, nor can they cross from there to us.
The rich man said: Father, then please send him to the household of my father.
I have five brothers, and he can warn them so they will not come to this place of torture.
But Ibrahim told him: They have the book of Musa and the scrolls of the anbiya. Let them listen to them.
He answered them: No, Father Ibrahim. But if someone is resurrected from the dead and goes to them, they will repent!
But Ibrahim told him: If they do not listen to the words of Musa and the anbiya, they will not be convinced even if someone among them is resurrected from the dead."

metadata.item: Here the revelations to Bani Israil are divided into two parts. In other places, they are considered all one part (for example the Injil, Matthew 5:18), or three parts (the Injil, Luke 24:44).
Isa was resurrected from death to life and Al-Yahud still did not believe.

verse.content: Isa told his followers: "Temptations must come, but woe to the one who is the source of them.
Suppose someone misleads one of these little ones. It would be better for him for a grindstone to be tied to his neck and for him to be thrown in the sea.

metadata.item: Grindstones were used to grind grain and were very heavy.

verse.content: Pay attention to yourselves! If your brother does something bad to you, rebuke him. If he repents, pardon him.

metadata.item: This word refers to a physical brother as well as a brother in faith.

verse.content: Suppose he does something bad to you seven times every day and returns to you seven times and says: 'I have sinned against you and I repent.' Then you must pardon him."
Then the hawariyun said to their mawla: "Please increase our trust!"
Their mawla said: "If the amount of your trust was like a mustard seed, you would tell a berry tree: be uprooted and be planted in the sea. And it would obey you.
If one of your slaves returns from his work plowing or herding sheep, would you tell him as soon as he arrives: Please have a seat at the table?
No. You will order him: Prepare my dinner and serve me while I eat and drink. Then you may eat and drink.
Must the master thank his slave for obeying his orders?
So if you do everything you were ordered to, say: Slaves deserve no thanks for doing what they have to do. We only did what we had to do."
Then Isa passed between Samaria and Al-Jalil on his way to Al-Quds.

metadata.item: The normal path between Al-Jalil and Al-Quds did not pass through Samaria, but went around it on the East Bank of the Jordan River.

verse.content: He entered a village in front of him and ten people suffering from leprosy met him. They were standing far away.

metadata.item: Lepers were supposed to stay far away from other people so they would not make them unclean.

verse.content: Then they cried out for help: "Isa, our master, have mercy on us!"
Isa looked at them and told them: "Go and show yourselves to the ahbar of the house of Allah." So they went. As they were on the way, they were all healed and cleansed.

metadata.item: See the Tawrat, Leviticus 13:49, 14:2ff.

verse.content: One of them returned as soon as he saw that he had been healed. He loudly praised the glory of Allah.
He threw himself on his face at the feet of Isa, giving thanks. He was a Samaritan.
Isa answered him: "Did not ten people get healed and cleansed? Where are the other nine people?
Did no one among them return and praise Allah for his grace except this foreigner?"

metadata.item: Al-Yahud considered Samaritans as foreigners because they were not pure blooded people of Al-Yahud.

verse.content: Then he told him: "Get up, and go on your way. Your trust has healed you."
The Pharisees asked him one day when the kingdom of Allah would appear. He answered: "The kingdom of Allah will not come with visible ayat.
People will not say: 'Here it is!' or 'There it is!' Truly the kingdom of Allah is in your midst."

metadata.item: The king, Isa, was standing right there in the midst of the Pharisees.

verse.content: He said to his followers: "Days will come when you will want to see one day of the days of sayyid al-bashar. But you will not see it.
People will say: 'He is here!' or 'He is there!' But do not go out and follow them.
Sayyid al-bashar in his day will appear like the lightning that shines. Its light reaches the horizons of the earth.
But he must first suffer many pains and be rejected by this generation.
The way it was in the days of Nuh is the way it will it be in the days of sayyid al-bashar:
People kept eating and drinking, marrying and getting married, until the day Nuh entered the ark. Then the flood came and destroyed them all.

metadata.item: The men.
The women.

verse.content: It was the same in the days of Lut. They were eating and drinking, buying and selling, planting and building.
But on the day Lut went out of the city of Sodom, Allah sent down fire and sulfur on them and destroyed them all.
It will be the same on the day sayyid al-bashar appears.

metadata.item: The appearance of sayyid al-bashar is connected with destruction, as was the situation with Nuh and Lut. See also the Injil, Luke 21:21.

verse.content: On that day, anyone on the roof should not go down to get his things from the house. Anyone in the field should not return.

metadata.item: The roofs were flat and sometimes used like an extra room. See the Tawrat, 2 Kings 4:10-11.
The emphasis is to flee quickly.

verse.content: Remember the wife of Lut!

metadata.item: She did not flee as Allah commanded, but looked back and was turned into a pillar of salt. The story is in the Tawrat, Genesis 19.

verse.content: Whoever tries to save his life will lose it. Whoever loses his life will keep it.
I tell you that in that night, two people will be sleeping on one bed. One of them will be taken and the other one will be left.

metadata.item: From the context, this probably means taken in judgment.

verse.content: Two women will meet at the wheat mill.

metadata.item: This was a morning activity. At some places on earth it will be night and at other places it will be daytime. When it happens, some people will be destroyed and others will not.

verse.content: One of them will be taken and the other one will be left."
They answered him: "Where is that, our mawla?" He said to them: "Birds of prey gather around a corpse."

metadata.item: Probably vultures or eagles. Some people think this is a reference to a Roman flagstaff with an eagle on it. The Roman army destroyed Al-Quds in A.D. 70 and put their flag in the house of Allah.

verse.content: He told them a story about the need to continue to pray in dua\' without being disappointed.
He said: "There was a judge in a city that did not fear Allah and did not respect men.
A widow in that city came to him and insisted: Please give me justice from my unjust opponent!
He refused for a while, but finally said to himself: Even though I do not fear Allah and I do not respect men,
this woman bothers me. Therefore I will give her justice or she will keep coming and make me exhausted."
Our mawla said: "Listen to what the unjust judge says!
Will Allah not give justice to his chosen people who cry out to him day and night? Will he be slow to answer?
I tell you that he will give them justice quickly. But when sayyid al-bashar returns, will he find people who trust on earth?"
Then Isa told a story to people who thought that they were righteous and who hated others.
He said, "Two men went into the house of Allah to do salat. One of them was a Pharisee and the other was a detested tax collector.
The Pharisee stood and prayed a dua\' about himself. He said: Allah, I praise you that I am not like other people - robbers, unjust people, and adulterers - nor like this detestable tax collector.
I have vowed to practice sawm two days a week, and I always give a zakat of a tenth of all my income.
But the detested tax collector stood in the last row. He did not raise his eyes to heaven. He prayed in dua\' and beat his breast. He said: Allah, expiate my sins. I am the worst of sinners!

I tell you that Allah had rida toward this tax collector, who went down to his house accepted by Allah. This was not the case for the Pharisee. Allah brings down the one who raises himself up and raises the one who humbles himself."

metadata.item: This refers to the Arabic names Al- Khafid and Al- Rafi', two of the 99 names of Allah.
This is an allusion to the Tawrat, 1 Samuel 2:6.

verse.content: People brought their children to him so that he would touch them. When the hawariyun saw them, they started to rebuke them.
But Isa called the children to him. He said: "Let the children come to me and do not forbid them. The kingdom of Allah belongs to these little ones.
I tell you a true saying: Whoever does not receive the kingdom of Allah like a child will not enter it at all."

metadata.item: This could mean gratefully, enthusiastically, trustingly, and immediately.

verse.content: A leader of Al-Yahud asked him, "Righteous teacher, what shall I do to inherit a share in eternal spiritual life?"

metadata.item: People do not inherit things because of what they do, but because of their relationship with someone.

verse.content: Isa said to him, "Why do you call me righteous? No one is righteous except Allah alone.

metadata.item: In other words, if I am from Allah and I teach the message of Allah, you must obey it. If you are saying that to flatter me, I am not interested in flattery.

verse.content: You know the commandments of the Tawrat: Do not commit adultery, do not murder, do not steal, do not say false shahada, honor your father and mother."

metadata.item: This is a quotation from the Tawrat, Exodus 20:14, Deuteronomy 5:18.
This is a quotation from the Tawrat, Exodus 20:13, Deuteronomy 5:17.
This is a quotation from the Tawrat, Exodus 20:15, Deuteronomy 5:19.
This is a quotation from the Tawrat, Exodus 20:16, Deuteronomy 5:20.
This is a quotation from the Tawrat, Exodus 20:12, Deuteronomy 5:16.

verse.content: He answered, "I have kept all these since I was young."
When he heard that, Isa told him, "You only need one thing: Sell everything you have and give alms with the money to the poor. You will have a treasure in Al-Janna. Then come and follow me."
But when he heard that, he was very sad, because he was very rich.

metadata.item: The wealth of the rich man may have become his idol, and Allah said not to have any other gods before him or to make any idols (The Tawrat, Exodus 20: 3-5).

verse.content: Isa saw it and said, "It is very hard for rich people to enter the kingdom of Allah!
A camel going through the eye of a needle is easier than a rich man entering the kingdom of Allah."
Those listening said, "So who can be saved?"

metadata.item: Al-Yahud thought that people were rich because Allah had rida toward them, and that Allah would admit them into Al-Janna. So they thought that if the rich people could not get into Al-Janna, no one could.

verse.content: He answered them: "What is impossible for man is easy to Allah, the Most High."

metadata.item: This refers to the Arabic name Al-Aly, one of the 99 names of Allah.

verse.content: Peter said: "We have left everything we had and followed you."
He told him, "I tell you a true saying: Suppose someone has left a house, wife, brothers, parents, or children for the sake of the kingdom of Allah.
He will be rewarded with many times more in this world. In the next life, his reward will be eternal spiritual life in Al-Janna."
Isa got alone with his twelve hawariyun and told them: "We are going to Al-Quds. Allah will fulfill everything that is written in the scrolls of the anbiya about sayyid al-bashar.
He will be delivered to the nations of the kuffar and they will mock him, dishonor him, spit on him,
whip him, and kill him. Then on the third day he will be resurrected alive."
But the hawariyun did not understand any of these things. The meaning was hidden from them, and they did not realize what he said.
When Isa came close to Jericho, a blind man was sitting next to the road and begging.
When he heard the multitude passing, he asked about the reason.
They told him that Isa Al-Nasiri was passing by.
He started to shout: "Isa, Ibn Dawood, have mercy on me!"

metadata.item: By calling him Ibn Dawood, he was acknowledging that Isa was al-masih, the king of Bani Israil.

verse.content: Those walking by in the front rebuked him so that he would be silent. But he screamed even louder: "Ibn Dawood, have mercy on me!"

metadata.item: This woman was acknowledging that Isa was al-masih.

verse.content: Isa stopped and told them to bring him to him. When he approached him, Isa asked him,
"What do you want me to do for you?" He said, "Master, I want to see again."
Isa told him, "See again. Your trust in me has healed you."
Immediately he could see and he followed him, praising the glory of Allah. All the people praised Allah when they saw this.
Isa entered Jericho and was passing through.
The detested chief tax collector was there. His name was Zacchaeus. He was rich.

metadata.item: Tax collectors got rich by collecting more than they were authorized to collect.

verse.content: He tried to see Isa, but he could not see him because he was short and there was a crowd.
He ran to a sycamore tree by the way Isa was coming and climbed it to see him.

metadata.item: These trees had low branches.

verse.content: When Isa reached the tree, he looked up to him and told him: "Zacchaeus, come down quickly. I must stay as a guest with you in your house today."
So he came down quickly and received him gladly.
Everyone murmured at what they saw: "He has gone to be a guest with a sinful man!"
Zacchaeus got up and said to our mawla: "My mawla, I will give half of what I own to the poor. I will repay the money I have gotten unjustly four times as much!"

metadata.item: These decisions show his repentance.

verse.content: Isa told him: "Today saving mercy has come down to this household, because he is a son of Ibrahim also!

metadata.item: The word son is not literal. Here it means either that he is descended from Ibrahim and/or that he is a true believer.

verse.content: Sayyid al-bashar came to search for the lost and to save them."
The crowds were listening to these matters. So he told them a story because they were approaching Al-Quds. They thought that the kingdom of Allah would appear immediately.

metadata.item: They thought Isa was coming to Al-Quds to become king and defeat the Roman occupiers.

verse.content: He said: "A prince traveled to a far country to be crowned king, and then he would return back.

metadata.item: The prince would be crowned king by the emperor, who was king over all.

verse.content: Before he left, he summoned ten of his slaves. He delivered a gold dinar to each one of them and told them: Trade with this money for me until I return.

metadata.item: This gold dinar was worth three months wages for a laborer.
I.e. go into business.

verse.content: But his people hated him. They sent a delegation after him, saying: We do not want this man to be king over us!
He returned after being crowned king, and he ordered the slaves who were entrusted with the money to be summoned. He wanted to see how much each one had gained by his trading.
The first one came and said, 'Master, your dinar has earned ten times as much.'
He told him, 'What a good slave you are! You were faithful in a little. So you will be a governor over ten cities.'
The second came and said, 'Master, your dinar has earned five dinars.'
He said to him also, 'You will be a governor over five cities.'
The third said, 'Master, this is your dinar. I hid it for you in a cloth to protect it.
I was afraid of you, because you are a harsh man. You take what you did not invest, and you harvest what you did not plant.'
The king told him, 'You evil slave, by your own words I will condemn you. Did you know me as harsh, taking what I did not invest and harvesting what I did not plant?
Then why did you not put my money in the bank? Then I could have gotten it back with interest when I returned?'
Then he ordered his guards, 'Take the dinar from him and give it to the one who has ten dinars.'
But they told him: 'Our master, he has ten gold dinars!'
He answered, 'I tell you: whoever has will be given more. But whoever does not have, even what he has will be taken from him.

metadata.item: The reference here is probably to obedience or faithfulness.

verse.content: And bring me my enemies, who did not want me as king over them. Then kill them in front of me!'"
After those words, Isa went forward, going up toward Al-Quds.
He approached the two villages of Bethphage and Bethany near Jabal Al-Zaytun. Then he sent two of his hawariyun.
He told them, "Go to the village that is in front of you. There you will find a donkey that is tied up. No one has ever ridden it. Untie it and bring it here.
Suppose someone asks you: Why are you untying it? Answer him: Our mawla needs it."
The two hawariyun went and found the donkey, just as Isa had told them.
When they were untying the donkey, its owners said to them, "Why are you untying the donkey?"
They answered, "Our mawla needs it."
They brought it to Isa, and his followers threw their coats on the donkey and seated Isa on it.

metadata.item: This is a way of showing honor to Isa. Kings rode on donkeys or mules when they were newly appointed. See the Tawrat, 1 Kings 1:44. This is an allusion to the Tawrat, Zakariyya 9:9.

verse.content: As he was riding, his followers put their coats on the road to honor him.

metadata.item: A similar way of honoring a king is mentioned in the Tawrat, 2 Kings 9:13.

verse.content: Then he approached the slope of Jabal Al-Zaytun. The whole crowd of his followers started shouting praises to Allah with gladness because of the works of power they had seen.
They said, "The King who comes in the name of Rabb Al-Alamin has baraka! Peace in heaven and glory to Allah in the highest!"

metadata.item: This was their shahada that Isa was al-masih. This is a reference to the Zabur, Psalms 118:26.

verse.content: Some of the Pharisees in the crowd told him, "Teacher, rebuke your followers for these words."
Isa answered them, "I tell you, if these followers were silent, the stones would shout!"
When he came near the city and saw it, he cried about it.
He said, "I wish you knew the way to peace, even in this day of yours! But it is hidden from your eyes.

metadata.item: The city of Al-Quds.

verse.content: Days will come when your enemies will surround you. They will surround you and press you in from every side.

metadata.item: This happened about forty years later, in A.D. 67-70.

verse.content: They will crush you and your children. They will not leave one stone on top of another stone. This is because you did not know the time when the helper was coming to you!

metadata.item: The reference is to Isa.

verse.content: Then Isa entered the house of Allah. He started casting out the traders from it.

metadata.item: This place was the outer court of the house of Allah, where people of other ummas could come. The traders prevented them from focusing on worshiping Allah.

verse.content: He told them: "Allah revealed in his kitab: My house will be a house of salat. But you made it a cave of thieves!"

metadata.item: This is a reference to the Tawrat, Shaya 56:7, which says that it was a house of salat for all ummas.
This is a reference to the Tawrat, Jeremiah 7:11.

verse.content: He was teaching the people daily in the house of Allah. The leading ahbar and fuqaha and the leaders of Al-Yahud tried to assassinate him.
But they could not find a way, because the multitude of Al-Yahud loved to listen to him.

metadata.item: The common people loved Isa, but the religious leaders rejected him.

verse.content: One day, Isa was teaching the people in the house of Allah and telling them good news. The leading ahbar and fuqaha and the elders of the people confronted him.
They told him, "Answer us! What authority do you use to do these things? Who gave you this authority?"
He said in reply, "I will ask you a question, too. Answer me:
Was the ghusl of repentance that Yahya did from Allah or from humans?"
They consulted among themselves, saying, "If we say: 'From Allah,' he will say, 'Why did you not believe him?'
And if we say, 'From humans,' all the people will stone us, because they are convinced that Yahya is a nabi."
So they answered him that they did not know where it was from.
So Isa told them, "I will not inform you about the source of my authority either."
Isa told this story to the people, "A man planted a vineyard. Then he rented it to farmers and traveled for a long time.
When it was time to pick the grapes, he sent a slave to the farmers to give him his share of the fruit. But the farmers beat him and sent him back empty-handed.
Then he sent another slave. They beat him, dishonored him, and sent him back empty-handed.
Then he sent a third slave. They wounded him and threw him out.
Then the owner of the vineyard said: What shall I do? I will send my beloved son. Maybe they will respect him.
But when the farmers saw him, they discussed the matter among themselves, saying: This is the heir. Let us kill him so that we can possess the inheritance!

metadata.item: Their thoughts may have been that it would become deserted property which they could take.

verse.content: So they threw him out of the vineyard and murdered him. What do you think the owner of the vineyard will do to them?
He will come and destroy the farmers and give the vineyard to others!" The listeners said: "May Allah not permit it!"

metadata.item: In the Tawrat, Bani Israil is compared to the vineyard of Allah. Al-Yahud understood that they were the unjust farmers, Allah was the owner of the vineyard, the anbiya and rusul were the slaves, the beloved son was Isa, and that Allah would take their special position in the kingdom of Allah away from them.

verse.content: But he looked at them and said: "Then what does the Zabur mean? 'The stone that the builders rejected became the top of the building.'

metadata.item: This is a quotation from the Zabur, Psalms 118:22.

verse.content: Everyone who falls on this stone will be crushed. The stone will crush anyone it falls on."

metadata.item: This is an allusion to the Tawrat, Shaya 8:14, 28:16, and Daniel 2:44-45

verse.content: The fuqaha and the leading ahbar tried to arrest him at that time, because they perceived that he was talking about them them in the story he had told. But they were afraid of the people.

metadata.item: They were the murderous farmers and they were the builders who had rejected the chosen stone.

verse.content: So they watched him and sent him spies who pretended to be righteous. They wanted to catch him with a word and turn him over to the authority of the Roman governor for his sentence.
The spies said to him, "Teacher, we know that you teach us the truth. You do not show partiality. You teach al-sirat al-mustaqim of Allah in truth.
Is it halal for us to pay the jizya to Caesar or not?"
He realized their cunning and told them:
"Show me a dinar." Then he asked them: "Whose are this picture and slogan?" They said, "Caesar's."

metadata.item: Dinars used in Palestine did not have pictures of people on them, or offensive slogans in deference to Al-Yahud, who were monotheistic. They may have showed him this dinar, which was used elsewhere in the Roman empire, to provoke him.

verse.content: So he told them, "Then give Caesar what Caesar is due, and give Allah what Allah is due."
They were not able to catch him with a single word in front of the people. They were amazed at his answers and were silent.
The Sadducees deny the day of resurrection. Some of came to him and asked him,
"Teacher, Musa made a regulation for us in the Tawrat: Suppose a man is married but has no children. If he dies, his brother must marry the widow to produce children for his dead brother.

metadata.item: This is a quotation from the Tawrat, Deuteronomy 25:5. Its purpose was to preserve inheritance rights. The word brother is used literally here.

verse.content: There were seven brothers. The oldest one got married and died without children.
The second married her.
Then the third, and so on. All seven died and had no children.
Finally the woman died, too.
In the next life at the resurrection, whose wife will she be? All seven married her."

metadata.item: They did not believe in the resurrection, and were telling this hypothetical story because they thought it showed that belief in the resurrection would create impossible scenarios.
It was their assumption that a woman could not have multiple husbands at one time.

verse.content: Isa told them, "Marriage is for the sons of this world.

metadata.item: The word sons is obviously not literal. It means inhabitants.

verse.content: But there is no marriage for those who have a portion in the next life after they have been resurrected from the dead.
They cannot die any more after that. They will live forever like angels, for they are umara of Allah, because they have been resurrected alive.

metadata.item: Since they will not die, there is no need to have children to continue the race, so there is no need for marriage.

verse.content: As for the resurrection of the dead, Musa showed it clearly in the verse of the fire in the bush. Rabb Al-Alamin is the Rabb of Ibrahim and the Rabb of Ishaq and the Rabb of Yacoub.

metadata.item: This story is in the Tawrat, Exodus 3:1-14.

verse.content: Allah is not the Rabb of dead people. He is the Rabb of living people. All people are alive with him."

metadata.item: So Ibrahim, Ishaq, and Yacoub were alive with Allah several centuries after their death. This shows that Allah had resurrected them.

verse.content: Some of the fuqaha said: "Teacher, your words were well said!"

metadata.item: They were opponents of the Sadducees, and they were happy that Isa had just proven that the Sadducees were wrong about the resurrection.

verse.content: After that, no one dared to ask him anything.
So Isa asked them: "How can people say that the awaited al-masih is Ibn Dawood?

metadata.item: The word Ibn is used to express descent but not immediate descent from a father. Isa was more than 30 generations removed from Dawood.

verse.content: For Dawood himself, by inspiration of Allah, said about him in the Zabur: 'Al-Mawla said to my mawla, sit at my right hand
until I place your enemies under your feet.'

metadata.item: This is a quotation from the Zabur, Psalms 110:1

verse.content: If Dawood calls him 'My mawla,' how can he be his son?"

metadata.item: The mawla was a master, and a son was submissive to his father.

verse.content: He told his followers in the hearing of the multitude,

"Beware of the fuqaha, because they love to walk around with long religious robes, to receive greetings and respect from people in the markets, to stand in the first row in the houses of salat, and to sit in the seats of honor in the feasts.
But they devour houses of widows and make long salat for the sake of appearance. Their punishment will be harsh on Yawm Al-Din!"
Then he looked and saw the rich people putting their donations into the treasury of the house of Allah.
He also saw a poor widow give two fils.

metadata.item: This coin was worth less than one percent of the daily wage of a laborer.

verse.content: He said, "I tell you a true saying: This poor widow has donated more than everyone else.
Everyone threw in a small portion of their excess. But she gave all her livelihood, despite her poverty."
Some people began to speak of how the house of Allah was decorated with beautiful stones and gifts dedicated to Allah. Isa said,
"Days will come when nothing you see will be left with one stone on top of another, but all of them will be destroyed. "
They asked him: "Teacher, when will these ayat happen? What is the ayah that precedes their coming?"
He spoke to them, "Beware that you are not led astray! Many will come claiming in my name: "I am he! The hour has come close!" Do not follow them.
Do not be afraid when you hear of wars and disturbances. These are things that must happen first, but the end will not follow immediately."
Then he told them, "One nation will attack another nation, and one kingdom will attack another kingdom.
Severe earthquakes, famines, and plagues will happen in many countries on earth. Terrifying sights and great ayat will appear in the sky.
Before all these events, they will arrest you, persecute you, turn you over for trial at houses of salat, send you to prisons, and accuse you in front of kings and governors because of my name.
These will be your opportunities to give a shahada about me.
Be calm in your hearts and do not prepare a defense for yourselves beforehand.
I will give you words and wisdom your adversaries will not be to resist or contradict.
Your parents, brothers, relatives, and friends will betray you, and they will execute some of you.
All people will hate you because of my name.
But not one hair from your heads will be destroyed.
Gain your souls by your firm patience.
But when you see Al-Quds surrounded by armies, know that its destruction is near.

metadata.item: This happened in 67 A.D.
Al-Quds was destroyed in 70 A.D.

verse.content: On that day, whoever is in Yahudia should flee to the mountains. Whoever is in the city should leave it. Whoever is in a rural area should not go into the city.

metadata.item: Al-Quds.

verse.content: These are days of revenge. Allah will fulfill everything that he wrote about it.

metadata.item: There are many ayat in the Tawrat concerning this, including Leviticus 26:14-33, Deuteronomy 28:15-68, 29:19-28, Shaya 63:4, 65:12-16, Daniel 9:24-27; Hosea 9:7, Zakariyya 14:1-2, Malachi 4:1.

verse.content: Woe to women who are pregnant and nursing in those days. Harsh disaster will be on all this land. The anger of Allah will be on this people!

metadata.item: They would be unable to flee quickly.
Al-Yahud.

verse.content: Some of them will be killed with the sword. Others will be taken as captives to all nations of the kuffar.

metadata.item: This happened in 70 A.D.

verse.content: Ayat will appear in the sun, moon and stars. Nations will be astounded and puzzled at the sounds and raging of the seas.
People will faint in fear and terror at what is happening to the world. The powers of heaven will be shaken.
At that time, they will see sayyid al-bashar coming in the clouds, mighty, glorious, and majestic.

metadata.item: This was prophesied in the Tawrat, Daniel 7:13-14.

verse.content: When these ayat begin to happen, stand up and lift your heads. Your redemption is near!"

metadata.item: Look up to the sky.
Or deliverance.

verse.content: Then he told them a story, "Look at the fig tree, and all trees.
When their leaves appear, it is an obvious ayah to you that summer is near.
When you see all these ayat happen, know that the kingdom of Allah is near.
I tell you a true saying: This generation will not disappear until all these things happen.

metadata.item: These words were spoken about 30 A.D.

verse.content: Heaven and earth will disappear, but my words will never disappear.
Watch out for yourselves. Do not let your hearts be exhausted with cares, drunkenness, and worries of this world. If you do, that day may surprise you.
It will come as a trap for all inhabitants of the world.
Watch always. Beg Allah that you can flee from everything that happens and stand, accepted in front of sayyid al-bashar."

metadata.item: Sayyid al-bashar will be the judge.

verse.content: Isa was teaching in the house of Allah during the day. At night, he would leave Al-Quds and stay on Jabal Al-Zaytun.
All the people would come to him in the house of Allah early in the morning to hear him.
The Eid of Unleavened Bread, called Passover Eid, was near.

metadata.item: This bread was made without leaven (yeast) so it did not rise and was flat. This was in memory of when Allah delivered Bani Israil from Egypt and they left quickly, without time for their bread to rise.

verse.content: The leading ahbar and the fuqaha were trying to find a way to kill Isa. They were afraid of the positive response of the people to him.
Al-Shaitan entered Yahuda Iscariot, one of the twelve hawariyun.
So Yahuda went to the leading ahbar and officers of the house of Allah, and spoke to them about his delivering Isa to them.
They were happy and agreed to pay him money.

metadata.item: They offered to pay him money worth 120 days of the wage of a laborer. See the Tawrah, Zakariyya 11:12.

verse.content: He agreed and started to look for an opportunity to betray him in the absence of the crowds.
It was the first day of the Eid of Unleavened Bread, when the Passover lamb was sacrificed.

metadata.item: The Passover Eid happened immediately before the Eid of Unleavened Bread, so they were considered one eid.

verse.content: Isa sent Peter and Yahya and said, "Go and prepare the Passover dinner so we can eat."
They said to him, "Where do you want us to prepare it?"
He told them: "Enter the city. You will meet a man carrying a jar of water. Follow him to the house he enters.
Tell the owner of the house: The teacher says: Where is the guest room where I can eat the Passover dinner with my followers, the hawariyun?
He will take you up to a large, furnished room. Prepare our dinner there."

metadata.item: Isa may have told Peter and Yahya this so that Yahuda would not know where they would be and thus could not betray Isa until the time was right according to the will of Allah.

verse.content: They went and found everything as Isa had told them, so they prepared the Passover dinner.
When the hour came, Isa reclined at the table with the hawariyun.
He told them: "I have really wanted to eat this Passover dinner with you before I suffer my pains.
I tell you, I will not eat it again until its reality is fulfilled in the kingdom of Allah."

metadata.item: Passover was a symbol of Allah delivering Bani Israil from Egypt, and it was also a symbol of Allah delivering all people through Isa.

verse.content: Then he took a cup and praised Allah. He said: "Take this and divide it among yourselves.
I tell you that I will not drink from the fruit of the vineyard from now until the kingdom of Allah comes."
Then he took a loaf and praised Allah. He broke it and gave it to them. He said: "This is my body which I will sacrifice as a ransom for you. Do this in my remembrance."

metadata.item: Since Isa going to return to Allah. This was shocking to the hawariyun and it was a major departure from the rituals usually spoken at the Passover dinner.

verse.content: In the same way, he took the cup after dinner and said: "This cup is the new covenant of Allah confirmed with my blood that is shed as a ransom for you.

metadata.item: This was also a significant and shocking departure from the rituals usually spoken at the Passover dinner.

verse.content: But the hand of my betrayer is with me on this table.
The death of sayyid al-bashar is a predestined matter, but woe to my betrayer!"
The hawariyun asked each other which one of them would do that.
Then they argued about who of them was the greatest.
He told them: "Kings of the nations of kuffar rule over their nations. Those in power are called benefactors.
But do not imitate them. Let the greatest one of you take the lowest position. Let the leader among you be a servant to you.
Is the person who reclines at the table greater, or the one who serves? Is it not the one who reclines at the table? But I am among you like one who serves.

metadata.item: Though Isa was their leader, he did not use his privilege as a leader, but served his followers.

verse.content: You are those who have stood by me in my trials.
The Most Loving King has given me a kingdom. I will also give you a kingdom.
You will eat and drink at my table in my kingdom. You will sit on thrones to judge the twelve tribes of Bani Israil."
Then our mawla said, "Simon, Simon, Al-Shaitan demanded to beat you like a farmer beats wheat.

metadata.item: To separate the wheat from the stalks.

verse.content: But I have prayed for you all, so that your trust would not die. Peter, when you return to me again, make your brothers firm."

metadata.item: Isa predicted Peter's unfaithfulness and repentance.

verse.content: Simon answered him: "My mawla, I am ready to go with you to prison and to death!"
Isa said: "Peter, I tell you that before the rooster calls at dawn, you will deny three times that you know me."
Isa told him: "When I sent you without money, a bag, or sandals, did you lack anything?" They said: "No."
He told them: "But now, whoever has money should take it. Whoever has a bag should carry it. Whoever does not have a sword should sell his coat and buy one.
I tell you that what Allah revealed in the kitab will be fulfilled: 'They considered him one of the disobedient.' Everything about me must be fulfilled in truth."

metadata.item: This is a quotation from the Tawrat, Shaya 53:12. It refers to the trial of Isa, who was convicted and executed as a criminal though he had never done anything wrong and had never sinned.

verse.content: They said: "Our mawla, look! Here are two swords. He told them: "Enough!"
Then Isa went out, as was his custom, to Jabal Al-Zaytun. The hawariyun followed him.
When he arrived to the place, he told them: "Ask Allah for help so you will not fall into temptation."
Then he went a short distance away from them and knelt, praying in dua':
"Most Loving King, if it is your will, take this cup from me. But let your will happen, not my will."
Allah aided him by an angel that appeared to him and strengthened him.
Then he struggled while praying in dua\' and was hard-pressed. His sweat was like drops of blood dripping from him on the ground.

metadata.item: Some people think that his sweat was as big as drops of blood. Others think that this refers to hematidrosis, where a person under extreme stress has blood come out of his skin.

verse.content: When he got up from praying in dua\', he returned to the hawariyun and found them sleeping because they were extremely sad.
He said to them: "Why are you sleeping? Get up and ask Allah for help, so you will not fall into temptation."
While he was speaking, Yahuda, one of the twelve hawariyun, appeared. He was leading a gang. He came near Isa to kiss him.
Isa said to him: "Yahuda, will you betray sayyid al-bashar with a kiss?"
The rest of his followers saw what was happening. They asked him: "Our mawla, shall we strike them with the sword?"
One of them attacked the slave of the chief habr and cut off his right ear.

metadata.item: Peter. See the Injil, Yahya 18:10.

verse.content: Isa said: "Enough!" He touched the ear of the slave and healed him.

metadata.item: This probably saved the life of Peter.

verse.content: Then Isa said to the leading ahbar, officers of the guards of the house of Allah and the elders of the people who came toward him: "Have you come out armed with swords and sticks to arrest me like a thief?
I was with you daily in the house of Allah, and you did not arrest me there. But this is your hour, when the power of darkness reigns."
They arrested Isa and led him to the house of the chief habr. Peter followed from far away.
The guards lit a fire in the middle of the courtyard and sat together. Peter sat among them.
A slave girl saw him as he was sitting in front of the fire. She looked carefully at him and said, "This man was also with Isa."
But he denied it, "I do not know him, woman!"
After a little while, another person saw him and said, "You are also one of them." Peter said, "No, man!"
After an hour, another person insisted: "Certainly this man was with him, because he is also from Al-Jalil."

metadata.item: People from Al-Jalil had a distinctive accent.

verse.content: But Peter said, "Man, I do not know what you are talking about." As he was speaking, the rooster called.
Then Isa turned and looked at Peter. Then Peter remembered the word of his mawla when he told him, "Before the rooster calls at dawn, you will deny me three times!"
So he went out and cried bitterly.
The guards started to mock Isa and beat him.
Then they blindfolded his eyes and started to say to him, "Nabi, prophesy to us! Who hit you?"
They insulted him with many other curses.
At dawn, the elders of the people met. These were the leading ahbar and the fuqaha, and they led him to their highest council.

metadata.item: This was their religious high court.

verse.content: They said to him: "If you are the expected al-masih, tell us!" He told them: "If I tell you, you will not believe me.
If I ask you, you will not answer me.
But from now on, sayyid al-bashar will sit at the right hand of Almighty Allah!"

metadata.item: This refers to the Arabic name Al-Qadir, one of the 99 names of Allah.
Isa was saying that he was the person who fulfilled this prophesy in the Zabur, Psalms 110:1. He was also saying that he was the person who fulfilled the prophecy in the Tawrat, Daniel 7:13-14.

verse.content: They all said: "So you are the beloved amir of Allah?" He told them: "You said it. I am he."

metadata.item: In the original language, "I am" could have been understood as the name of Allah.

verse.content: They said: "Why do we need other witnesses? All of us have heard the words of his mouth!"

metadata.item: Making a group judgment was illegal. They had to vote one by one, starting from the youngest.

verse.content: Then all the highest council stood up and took him to the Roman governor, Pilate.
They began to accuse Isa. They said: "We found that this man corrupts our people and stirs them up to stop paying the jizya to Caesar. He claims that he is the expected al-masih, the King!"
Pilate interrogated him. He asked: "Are you the king of Al-Yahud?" He told him in answer: "You said it."
Pilate said to the leading ahbar and the crowds: "I do not find any reason for accusing this man."
But they insisted. They said: "He stirs up the people by what he teaches in Yahudia, starting from the province of Al-Jalil to here."
When Pilate heard that, he asked if he was from Al-Jalil.
After he realized that he was from the province of Herod, Pilate sent him to Herod, who was in Al-Quds in those days.

metadata.item: Herod (Antipas) was ruler of Al-Jalil.

verse.content: Herod was so happy when he saw Isa that he was shaking. He had heard about him previously. For a long time, he had wanted to see him perform an ayah.
He asked him about many things. But Isa did not answer him at all.
Meanwhile, the leading ahbar and fuqaha were standing and accusing him harshly.
Then Herod and his soldiers started mocking him and making fun of him. After that, to mock him, they put an ornate robe on him and returned him to Pilate.
Herod and Pilate had been enemies, but they became friends that day.
Then Pilate told the leading ahbar and leaders of the people,
"You brought me this man and accused him of misleading the people. I interrogated him in front of you and did not find this man guilty of any of your accusations!
Herod also issued the same verdict and returned him to us. He did not do anything that deserves execution!
I will whip him and let him go."
But the crowd shouted with one voice:
"Away with this man! Release Barabbas for us!"
Barabbas was imprisoned for starting a riot in Al-Quds and for murder.
But Pilate wanted to let Isa go free. So he spoke to them a second time.
But they shouted: "Crucify him! Crucify him!"
He asked them a third time: "Why? What crime has he committed? I did not find a reason to condemn him to execution. So I will whip him and release him."
But they shouted as loud as they could, insisting on their demand to have him crucified. Their shouting succeeded in the end.
Pilate gave sentence to execute him as they had demanded.

metadata.item: Pilate may have followed their wishes at this time since his supporter in Rome was no longer able to support him. In chapter 13, Pilate is described as ruthless and not concerned about the opinion of the Yahudi people.

verse.content: He released the one they asked for, the prisoner who was a murderer and rioter. He delivered Isa to their will.
As they were taking Isa outside for execution, they grabbed Simon from Cyrene coming from the countryside. They put the cross on his back to carry it behind Isa.

metadata.item: Arabic Qairawan, a city in Libya today.

Usually the person to be executed carried his own cross, but Isa had been whipped and had lost a lot of blood, so he was too weak to carry it. What was carried was usually the horizontal crossbar, which weighed about 50 kg (150 Roman pounds). The whole cross weighed about 150 kg.

verse.content: A huge multitude of the people followed him, including sad women mourning and crying for him.
Isa turned to them and told them, "Daughters of Al-Quds, do not cry for me. Cry for yourselves and your children.

metadata.item: The word daughters is not literal, of course. It means women inhabitants.
The women and children would probably suffer most when Al-Quds was destroyed.

verse.content: The days are coming when they will say: The barren woman, who has not been pregnant and has not nursed, has a baraka.

metadata.item: They would not see the death of their children.

verse.content: Then people will say to the mountains: Fall on us! And to the hills: Cover us!
If they do this to the green branch, what will happen when it is dry?"
They led two criminals to be executed with him, one on his right and the other on his left.
Isa prayed in dua\': "Most Loving King, forgive them, because they are ignorant of what they are doing!" The soldiers divided his clothes by choosing lots.
The people stood looking. Their leaders were mocking him, "He saved others. Let him save himself, if he is really the expected al-masih, al-mustafa of Allah!"

metadata.item: Al-Yahud.

verse.content: Then the soldiers came to him and mocked him also. They offered him vinegar.
They said, "If you are really the king of Al-Yahud, save yourself!"
Above him, a sign said, "This is the king of Al-Yahud."
One of the criminals hanging next to him started to curse him: "Aren't you expected al-masih? Save yourself and us!"
The second rebuked him, "Do you not fear Allah? You are condemned with the same punishment.
We deserve our punishment for our crimes. But this man has no guilt!"
Then he said, "Isa, remember me when you come in your kingdom!"
He told him, "I tell you a true saying: Today you will be with me in Firdaus."
The time was about noon, and darkness covered the whole earth until mid-afternoon.

metadata.item: Or land.

This was an ayah from Allah, not a solar eclipse. The moon was on the exact opposite side of the earth from what would have been necessary for a solar eclipse. In fact there was a lunar eclipse that evening.

verse.content: The sun was darkened. Then the curtain of the haram of the house of Allah was torn in two pieces.
Isa shouted loudly: "My Most Loving King, I place my ruh into your hands!" Then he breathed his last breath.
The Roman officer saw what happened, and he praised Allah. He said, "This man was really innocent and righteous!"

metadata.item: Isa surrendered his life to Allah. People did not murder him against the will of Allah.

verse.content: The multitudes crowded to watch the scene. When they saw what happened, they all returned, beating their chests.

metadata.item: This was an expression of sorrow.

verse.content: But the acquaintances of Isa and the women who followed him from Al-Jalil stood looking from afar.

metadata.item: They were not close enough to see that Isa had surrendered his life - only that he was now dead..

verse.content: One of the members of the highest council was a good, righteous man named Yusif.
Yusif was from the town of Arimathea in Yahudia. He did not agree to what they had done. He was expecting the kingdom of Allah.

metadata.item: The highest council.

verse.content: He went to Pilate and asked for the body of Isa.
Then he took the body down from the cross, wrapped it in a linen grave cloth, and put it into a grave dug in the rock. No one had been put in it before.

metadata.item: This was his own grave he had dug. See the Injil, Matthew 27:60.

verse.content: That Friday was the day of preparation for the eid. Al-Sabt was almost beginning.

metadata.item: Al-Yahud considered that days began at sunset.

verse.content: The women who went out with him from Al-Jalil followed Yusif and saw the grave and how the body was placed.
Then they returned and prepared spices and perfumes. All day they did not work on Al-Sabt, as Allah commanded.

metadata.item: This is a reference to the Tawrat, Exodus 20:8-11.

verse.content: The women came to the grave Sunday at dawn. They brought the spices they had prepared.
They found that the stone that had sealed the entrance was rolled away from the tomb.
They entered, but they did not find the body of our mawla Isa.
While they were wondering about this matter, two men suddenly stood beside them. They were wearing shining clothing.

metadata.item: These were probably angels in the form of men. See verse 22.

verse.content: The women were terrified and they bowed their heads to the ground. The two men told them, "Why do you look for the living one among dead people?

metadata.item: This refers to the Arabic name Al-Hayy, one of the 99 names of Allah.

verse.content: He is not here, but he has been resurrected alive! Remember his words to you when you were in Al-Jalil.
He said that sayyid al-bashar was destined to be given to evil people and be crucified and be resurrected alive on the third day."
They remembered his words.
They returned from the tomb and announced all these things to the eleven hawariyun and the rest of the followers.
The women who told the hawariyun were: Mariam Magdalene, Joanna, and Mariam Um Yacoub and others.
But their words seemed empty, and the hawariyun did not believe them.
But Peter got up and ran to the tomb. He bent down and saw the empty grave clothes. He returned, wondering about what had happened.

metadata.item: It seems that the grave clothes were in the same place, but the body of Isa was no longer inside them.

verse.content: The same day, two of the followers were walking to the village of Emmaus, which is about seven miles from Al-Quds.

metadata.item: This is approximately the mile used by Arab geographers. In the original, sixty stadia, which would be about 11.5 km.

verse.content: They were speaking about these events.
They were talking and discussing when Isa came near them and walked with them.
But Allah did not let them recognize him.
Then he said to them, "What were you discussing as you were walking?" They stood sadly.
Then one of them, named Cleopas, answered him, "Are you the only stranger in Al-Quds who does not know what has happened these days?"
He asked them: "What has happened?" They answered: "Isa Al-Nasiri was mighty in sayings and in works. He was a nabi highly exalted with Allah and all the people.

metadata.item: Arabic wajih.

verse.content: But the leading ahbar and our leaders turned him over for the sentence of execution and he was crucified.
We hoped that he would be the redeemer of Bani Israil. Today is the third day after these events.

metadata.item: Or liberator or deliverer.

verse.content: Some women of our group amazed us. They went to the tomb at dawn today.
They did not find his body. When they returned, they told us that they had seen a vision of two angels, who said he was alive.
Some men from our group went to the tomb, and found everything as the women said. But they did not see Isa."
Isa told them, "You are so stupid. Your hearts are so slow to believe everything that Allah revealed through the anbiya!
Was it not the destiny of the expected al-masih to suffer these pains and enter into his majesty?"
And Isa began to explain to them everything that was written about him in the Tawrat and all the scrolls of the anbiya.

metadata.item: Sometimes the word Tawrat referred to whole kitab that Allah gave to Bani Israil, and sometimes it referred to only the kitab of Musa. When that second meaning was used, the rest of the Tawrat was sometimes called the scrolls of the anbiya, and sometimes called the Zabur and the scrolls of the anbiya (see verse 44). In this case, it is similar to the modern usage of Al-Yahud, who refer to the Tanakh (Law -- scrolls of Musa, scrolls of the anbiya, and writings (including the Zabur).

verse.content: When they approached the village that they were intending to go to, Isa pretended that he was going to continue walking.
But they urged him, "Stay tonight with us, for the sun will set soon." So he entered to spend the night with them.
He reclined at the table with them and took a loaf. He praised Allah and broke it and gave it to them.
At that time, Allah opened their eyes and they recognized him. Then he disappeared and was hidden from them.
One of them said to the other: "Did our hearts not burn with desire as he spoke to us on the way and he explained the kitab to us?"
Then they left that same hour and returned to Al-Quds. They found the eleven hawariyun and the others who were with them gathered.
They were saying, "Our mawla really has been resurrected alive and he appeared to Simon!"
The two related what happened with them on the way, and how they knew him when he broke the bread.
While they were speaking of this, Isa himself stood in the middle of them. He said, "Assalamu alaykum!"
But they were terrified and greatly afraid. They thought they were seeing a spirit.
He asked them, "Why are you disturbed? Why are your hearts doubting?
Look at my hands and feet. It really is me. Touch me and make sure, for a spirit does not have flesh and bones as you see I do!"
After saying this, he showed them his hands and feet.
But they remained in doubt, because they were so happy and amazed. He asked them, "Do you have any food here?"
They gave him a piece of roasted fish.
He took it and ate it in front of them.

They he said to them, "I spoke these words to you while I was with you: Everything that was predicted about me in the Tawrat and the scrolls of the anbiya and the Zabur was a true promise that must be fulfilled."

metadata.item: The revelation to Bani Israil is sometimes divided into three parts, which today is called the Tanakh (Tawrah, prophets, writings).

verse.content: Then he opened their minds to understand the kitab.
He told them: "It is written in the kitab that the expected al-masih would suffer pains and be resurrected alive from death on the third day.
Repentance and forgiveness of sins in his name should be preached in all nations, starting from Al-Quds.
You are witnesses of these things.
I will send you what the Most Loving King promised. So stay in the city until power from on high comes on you."

metadata.item: Isa had told them of the promise of Allah to send Holy Ruh Allah to live in them.
From Allah.

verse.content: Then Isa led them outside Al-Quds to Bethany. He raised his hands and gave them a baraka.
During the baraka, he departed from them and Allah raised him to himself.
They bowed down prostate to him. Then they returned to Al-Quds with great joy.
They continued to be devoted to worship in the house of Allah, praising Allah.
The Word was in eternity past. The Word was with Allah, and the Word is the essence of Allah. 1 He was in eternity past with Allah.

metadata.item: In the original language, this can also mean speech or communication.
This does not mean there are two gods. Allah is One. This the word of Allah, his communication to people.
Or has the same nature as Allah. Allah could never be separated from his word, or else he could not speak. The essence of Allah, or his nature, is expressed in his word.
The verse numbers come at the end of the verse.

verse.content: Everything was created through the Word. Everything that Allah created was created through him.

metadata.item: When Allah created, he spoke a word. That speech was done by his word.

verse.content: In the Word was life, and that life was the light of the universe.

metadata.item: Or, of all people.

verse.content: The light dawns in the darkness, and the darkness did not overcome it.

metadata.item: Or shines.

verse.content: Yahya was a rasul from Allah.
His message was to give shahada to the light, so that everyone would believe through his shahada.

metadata.item: This word includes trust in and dependence on, and does not only refer to acknowledging the existence of something.

verse.content: Yahya himself was not the light. But Allah sent him to give shahada about the light.
The true light which enlightens every person entered this world.

metadata.item: This refers to Al-Nur and Al-Haqq, two of the 99 names of Allah that refer to Isa.

verse.content: The light was in this world, and everything that was in the world was created through him, but the people of this world did not know him.
He came to his people, and his people did not welcome him.
But he gave everyone who welcomed him, trusting in his name, the right to become part of the family of Allah.

metadata.item: The word family is not literal. Allah does not father children or have sexual relations. (Far be it from him!) Here the meaning is those who are dependent on Allah, trust him, and who are obedient to him.

verse.content: This was not by bloodlines, nor by the will of the flesh. It was not by the will of a man, but of Allah.

metadata.item: Literally, bloods. This may refer to circumcision. The meaning in either case is that a person does not become part of the family of Allah (those who are admitted to heaven) because of his/her ancestry.
This probably refers to the desire of a man and a woman to have sexual relations. The meaning here is that it is not normal, natural birth that makes a person part of the family of Allah, either.
In other words, the initiative is not from a man, but from Allah.

verse.content: The Word became a person and lived among us. We saw the majesty of his glory. It was the majesty of the only unique one of the Glorious, Most Gracious King. He was full of grace and truth.

metadata.item: This refers to the Arabic names Al-Majid, Al-Rahman, and Al-Malik, three of the 99 names of Allah. See the glossary for a discussion on the Most Gracious King.

verse.content: Yahya gave shahada about him. He shouted, "This is the one I told you about: The person who comes after me is greater than I am, because he was before me."

metadata.item: The Word existed from eternity past. When the Word became a human being by Holy Ruh Allah, that person is called Isa.

verse.content: He gave us all many barakat from his perfection.
Allah revealed the Tawrat to Musa. He revealed grace and truth to us through Isa al-masih.

metadata.item: Al-masih is a title, not a name. As such, it is not capitalized. Al-masih means the one anointed with oil (oil was put or poured on his head) to show his appointment by Allah as king, habr, and nabi.

verse.content: No one has seen Allah except the only near one, the secret of the Most Gracious King. He alone caused us to know about Allah.

metadata.item: This refers to the Arabic name Al-Qarib, one of the 99 names of Allah.

verse.content: This is the shahada of Yahya, when the Yahudi leaders sent a delegation of ahbar and Levites to Yahya: They asked him, "Who are you?"
He gave shahada to them in truth when he confirmed and did not deny, "I am not the expected al-masih."

metadata.item: Al-Yahud were expecting al-masih, but they did not know who he was. They thought maybe Yahya was al-masih.

verse.content: Then they asked him, "So who are you? Are you Ilyas?" He said, "I am not." They asked him, "Are you our nabi?" He said, "No."

metadata.item: There was a prophecy in the Tawrat that Ilyas would return. See Tawrat, Malachi 4:5. Yahya was not literally Ilyas, though he came with the spirit and power of Ilyas.
There was a prophecy in the Tawrat that a nabi from Bani Israil who would be like Musa would come, and they should obey him. See Tawrat, Deuteronomy 18:15. This was another title of al-masih.

verse.content: Then they asked him, "So who are you? Answer us so we can tell the people who sent us. What is your shahada about yourself?"
He said, "I am a voice shouting in the wilderness: make al-sirat al-mustaqim for Al-Mawla, as Allah revealed by the tongue of the nabi Shaya."
The Pharisees had sent them.
They asked him, "Why are you doing the ghusl of repentance for people, since you are not al-masih, nor Ilyas, nor the nabi?"

metadata.item: Isa said that Yahya came in the spirit of Ilyas. (See the Injil, Matthew 11:14)
The nabi we expect. See the footnote above on ayah 21.

verse.content: Yahya answered them, "I do ghusl for people into water, but there is someone you do not know among you.
He comes after me, and I am not good enough to untie the straps of his shoes."

metadata.item: This was the job of a slave.

verse.content: This happened in the village of Bethany on the East Bank, where Yahya was doing ghusl for people.

metadata.item: The East Bank of the Jordan River.

verse.content: The next day, Yahya saw Isa coming close to him, and said, "Look! This is the lamb that is from Allah. By his sacrifice, Allah will ransom all people from their sins!

metadata.item: Just as Allah provided a ransom for the son of Ibrahim, and the ransom died so that his son would not have to die, so Isa would be a ransom for all people.

verse.content: This is the person I gave shahada about when I said: The person who comes after me is greater than I am, because he was before me.

metadata.item: Yahya was six months older than Isa, but see footnote on verse 15, which explains this comment.

verse.content: I did not know him, but I do ghusl for people into water so that he will be shown to Bani Israil."
Yahya gave shahada, "I saw Ruh Allah coming down on him from the sky like a dove, and he remained on him.

I did not know him, but Allah, who sent me with the message of the ghusl of repentance, told me: When you see Ruh Allah coming down and staying on a person, that person will do ghusl for you all into Holy Ruh Allah!
I saw him and I gave shahada that he is al-mustafa of Allah!"

metadata.item: This was a title of Isa, which mean the person Allah had chosen.

verse.content: The next day, Yahya was standing with two of his followers.
He saw Isa passing him and said, "This is the lamb of ransom from Allah!"

metadata.item: This probably reminded people of the lamb that Allah had provided for Ibrahim to sacrifice instead of his son.

verse.content: Those two followers heard him, and they followed Isa.
Isa turned and saw them following him. He asked them, "What do you want?" They said, "Honored teacher, where do you live?"
He said, "Come and you will see." They went and saw where he lived, and they stayed with him that day, because it was late afternoon.
One of the two people who heard the shahada of Yahya and followed Isa was Andrew, the brother of Simon.
He found his brother Simon first, and told him, "We have found al-masih." (Al-masih means the expected king.)

metadata.item: The scroll of Yahya was written to people who did not know some Hebrew or Aramaic terms.

verse.content: He came, Isa looked at him, and said, "You are Simon, son of Yuhana. You will be called Cephas. (Cephas means Peter).

metadata.item: Yuna (used in Matthew 16:18) seems to be an abbreviation for Yuhana (John 1:42). In the Greek language, there is no way to write the sound of an h in the middle of a word, so Yuhana in the original language would be written in Greek as Yuna. Other people think he was known by two names, as several of the hawariyun were (Nathaniel/Bartholomew, Thaddeus/Judas, Matthew/Levi, etc.). Some people had a Greek name and a Hebrew/Aramaic name.
Cephas is the Aramaic word for rock.
Peter is the English name meaning rock.
