verse.content: The next day, Isa wanted to go to the province of Al-Jalil. He found Philip and said to him, "Follow me."
Philip was from the village of Bethsaida, the town of Andrew and Peter.
Philip found Nathaniel and told him, "We have found the nabi that Musa and the anbiya told about in the kitab by the inspiration of Allah. His name is Isa, known as the son of Yusif, from Al-Nasira."

metadata.item: The verse that is probably referred to here is the Tawrat, Deuteronomy 18:15. This verse is a prophecy of Isa, as is shown in Acts of the Hawariyun 3:22 and 7:37.
One of the verses that Philip may have been thinking of is the Tawrat, Shaya 9:6,7.
Most people did not know that Isa was conceived by Holy Ruh Allah, and they thought that his step-father, Yusif the carpenter, was his biological father. The word father includes step-fathers.

verse.content: Nathaniel said, "Does anything good come from Al-Nasira?" Philip answered, "Come, and you will see."
When Isa saw Nathaniel coming, he said about him, "This person of Bani Israil is pure and has no guile in him."
Nathaniel asked him, "How do you know me?" Isa answered him, "I saw you under the fig tree before Philip called you."
Nathaniel answered him, "Honored teacher, you are the beloved amir of Allah! You are the king of Bani Israil!"
The Isa answered him, "Did you believe in me because I told you: I saw you under the fig tree? You will see greater ayat."
Isa said, "I tell you a true, true saying: you will see the sky opened in front of you and the angels of Allah coming down and going up on sayyid al-bashar."

metadata.item: Al-Yahud has a custom that [after]{.underline} a teacher said something they especially agreed with, or something especially clear or true, they would respond with /amin/, which meant faithful, safe or true. Isa was the only teacher who ever said /amin/ himself, or who said it [before]{.underline} his statement. By this, he was claiming higher authority than the opinions of people. In the book of Yahya, Isa often said, /amin amin/ before his statements to emphasize his authority. This also was a unique thing that only Isa did.

Sayyid al-bashar is the most common title Isa used for himself. It had three primary meanings in the Tawrat. 1) Sometimes, it meant a human being, as in Numbers 23:19. 2) Many times, it was used to mean a nabi or rasul (93 times in the scroll of Ezekiel alone). 3) The one prophesied in the Tawrah, Daniel 7:14, who was coming to Allah on the clouds of the sky and whom Allah was going to give rule, kingship, and glory over all peoples, nations, and language groups forever in an eternal kingdom. When Isa used this title with the religious authorities, they understood this meaning.

verse.content: On the third day, there was a wedding celebration in the village of Cana in Al-Jalil. Um Isa attended.
Isa and the hawariyun were also invited.
When the wine was finished, Um Isa informed him: "They do not have any more wine."

metadata.item: Isa.
To run out of wine at a wedding was a great shame.

verse.content: He told her, "What do your concerns have to do with me, honored woman? It is not my time yet."
Um Isa told the servants, "Obey what he says, whatever it is."

metadata.item: Mariam knew of the ayah of the birth of Isa so she trusted that he could do other ayat.

verse.content: There were six stone containers that Al-Yahud used for wudu'. Each one held two or three barrels.

metadata.item: Each barrel was about 34 liters. The total amount he made was between 400 and 600 liters of wine.

verse.content: Isa told the servants, "Fill the containers with water." So they filled them completely.
Then he told them, "Now take some of it to the host of the wedding celebration." And they did.
When the host tasted the wine that had been transformed from water, he did not know its source. But the servants knew. The host called the groom
and said to him, "Everyone serves the good wine first, and then later serves the normal wine to the people who are drunk. But you have kept the good wine until now."
This was the first ayah Isa did. He did it in the village of Cana in Al-Jalil. He showed the majesty of his glory and his hawariyun believed in him.
Then he went with his mother and his brothers to the town of Capernaum to stay there a few days.
It was the time of the Passover Eid, and Isa went up to Al-Quds.

metadata.item: Al-Quds is on a mountain.

verse.content: In the house of Allah, he found sellers of sheep, cows, and doves, and the money changers were sitting at their tables.

metadata.item: These were all animals that were used in sacrifice at the house of Allah.

Some people came from other countries and could not bring their sacrificial animals with them. So they had to bring money issued in other countries to pay for them. They needed to pay for the animals in local currency, and so moneychangers changed their money for local currency, at a profit, of course.

verse.content: Isa took a rope, made a whip from it, and cast them all out from the house of Allah, along with the sheep and the cows. He scattered the coins of the money changers and turned their tables over.
He told the sellers of doves, "Take these away from here, and do not make the house of my Most Loving King a house of commerce."

metadata.item: The leaders of Al-Yahud responsible for the house of Allah, the Sadducees, may have been making a profit from rent charged to the sellers of animals. They were responsible for assuring that the animals were acceptable for sacrifice (not blind, lame, sick, etc.) and might have had an agreement with the animal sellers that only animals sold by the sellers would be acceptable. Thus the foreigners who came to worship Allah at the house of Allah might have been cheated in changing money and in paying extra for the sacrificial animals. Isa disapproved of cheating people who were sincerely trying to worship Allah. In addition, people from other ummas could only come into this court, and not the inner courts. All the commerce made the atmosphere not conducive for them to worship Allah.

verse.content: His hawariyun remembered what Allah had said, "Jealousy for your house will consume me."

metadata.item: This is a quotation from the Zabur, Psalms 69:9.

verse.content: Then the leaders of Al-Yahud asked him, "What is the ayah of your authority to do this?"
Isa answered them, "Destroy this house, and in three days I will raise it up."

metadata.item: See verse 21 for the meaning of this.

verse.content: Al-Yahud said, "Building this house has taken forty-six years. Will you raise it up in three days?"

metadata.item: The house of Allah.

verse.content: But Isa meant his body when he said 'house.'
When Isa was resurrected alive from death, his hawariyun remembered what he had said, and they believed the kitab of Allah and the word of Isa.

metadata.item: Isa had been dead for three days when he was resurrected alive.
In the Tawrat, Hosea 6:3 and Yunis 1:17 mentioned being raised after three days (which was another way of saying on the third day). Al-Yahud considered any part of a day as a full day.

verse.content: Many people believed in his name during his stay in Al-Quds during the days of Passover Eid when they saw his ayat.

metadata.item: Passover Eid was only one day, but it was immediately followed by the Eid of Unleavened Bread, which was seven days long. They were considered one eid, and were sometimes collectively known as the Passover Eid, since that was the most important one. People who came for the Passover Eid stayed for the Eid of Unleavened Bread.

verse.content: But he did not entrust himself to them, because he knew all people.
He did not need the shahada of anyone, because he knew their hearts.
Nicodemus was a religious man, a Pharisee, and a leader of Al-Yahud.

metadata.item: He was a member of the highest council.

verse.content: He went to Isa at night, and said, "Honored teacher, we realize that Allah has sent you as a teacher, since no one can do miracles unless Allah aids him."

metadata.item: Coming at night shows that Nicodemus was not public about his coming to Isa.

verse.content: Isa answered him, "I tell you a true, true saying: Only the person who has been born a second time from the Most High can see the kingdom of Allah."

metadata.item: This refers to the Arabic name Al-Aly, one of the 99 names of Allah.

verse.content: Nicodemus said, "How can a person be born when he is old? Can he enter the womb of his mother a second time and be born?"

metadata.item: Al-Yahud use the phrase "be born again" to describe a boy becoming a man, a man getting married, a man becoming a teacher, and a teacher founding a school of teaching, (Nicodemus had done all these things.), a descendant of Dawood becoming king, and a person from another umma becoming part of Al-Yahud. In addition, doing ghusl and repentance were considered by some to be ways of being born again. Nicodemus has done all the possible ways for him to be "born again" already.

verse.content: Isa answered, "I tell you a true, true saying: Only people who have been born of water and Al-Ruh can enter the kingdom of Allah.
A body gives birth to a body, and Al-Ruh gives birth to a ruh.
Do not be amazed at my saying: You all must be born again."
People who are born from Al-Ruh are like the wind. The wind blows as it wills. You hear its sound, but you do not know from where it comes or where it goes."

metadata.item: The words for wind and ruh (spirit) are the same in the original language.

verse.content: Nicodemus said again, "How can this be?"
Isa answered, "Are you the teacher of Bani Israil, and you do not know?

metadata.item: Nicodemus was the chief teacher of Al-Yahud.

verse.content: I tell you a true, true saying: We speak about what we know, and give shahada about what we have seen. But you do not receive our shahada.

metadata.item: Here Isa uses the plural to speak, like a king.
In this verse and the next verse, "you" is plural, referring to the Yahudi leaders as a whole.

verse.content: If I tell you stories about the earth and you do not believe, how will you believe if I tell you stories about heaven?
Only sayyid al-bashar has ascended to heaven. He is the one who descended from heaven.

metadata.item: Sayyid al-bashar existed before his birth, just like the word of Allah which was sent to Mariam.

verse.content: Musa raised the serpent on the piece of wood in the wilderness. In the same way, sayyid al-bashar must be raised up.

metadata.item: This story is in the Tawrat, Numbers 21:4-9.

verse.content: Then everyone who believes and trusts in him will be given eternal spiritual life.
Allah loved all the people of the universe with a great love. So he sacrificed his unique, beloved amir to ransom everyone who trusts in him from the death of eternity and give him life of eternity.
Allah did not send the beloved amir to all people of the world to condemn them, but to rescue them through him.
No one who trusts in him will be condemned. But everyone who does not trust in him has already been condemned. That is because he has not believed in the name of the unique, beloved amir of Allah.
The judgment is that the light came into this world, but people preferred darkness rather than light because of the evil of their works.

metadata.item: "The light" may mean Isa himself. See Yahya 1:4. This may have been a challenge to Nicodemus, who had not come in the light.

verse.content: Everyone who does evil works hates the light. He does not approach the light, or his works would be exposed.
But whoever does true things comes to the light, so that it will be obvious that his works have been done by the power of Allah."
After that, Isa and his hawariyun came to Yahudia. He remained there with them and did ghusl for people.
Yahya was also doing ghusl in Eynon, near Salem because there was a lot of water there. People came and received ghusl,
because Yahya had not been put in prison yet.
A discussion arose between some followers of Yahya and a Yahudi man about purification.

metadata.item: Ghusl is connected with purification.

verse.content: They came to Yahya and asked him, "Teacher, the person who was with you, the one you gave shahada to on the East Bank, is doing ghusl for people. Everyone is going to him!"

metadata.item: Isa.

verse.content: Yahya answered them, "No one can receive anything unless if it is from Allah.
You all can give shahada that I said: I am not al-masih. I am a rasul sent before him.
The bride belongs to the groom. The best man waits for his voice when he comes. He is happy to hear him. Therefore my happiness is completed.

metadata.item: Yahya is using a picture, and is not speaking literally. The bride represents the people of Bani Israil, the groom represents Isa, and the best man, his attendant, represents Yahya.

verse.content: He will certainly be lifted up, and I will be lowered.

metadata.item: This refers to the Arabic names Al-Khafid and Al-Rafi', two of the 99 names of Allah.

verse.content: He who comes from the highest place is above everyone. The person who is from this world is of this world, and he speaks the words of this world.

metadata.item: Isa, the word of Allah, who was sent from Allah through Holy Ruh Allah into the body of Mariam.
Yahya is referring to himself.

verse.content: The person who comes from heaven gives shahada about what he saw and heard. But no one receives his shahada.
But anyone who receives his shahada is certain that Allah is true.

metadata.item: This refers to the Arabic name Al-Haqq, one of the 99 names of Allah.

verse.content: The rasul of Allah speaks the words of Allah, because Allah gives his Ruh without limit.

metadata.item: Isa.

verse.content: The Most Loving King loves the beloved amir, and delegated everything to him.

metadata.item: This clearly shows that one meaning of the beloved amir is the one who has the authority of Allah.

verse.content: The person who trusts the beloved amir has eternal spiritual life. The person who disobeys the beloved amir will never see life. Rather, the anger of Allah remains on him."

metadata.item: The beloved amir is the only way of entering Al-Janna and the only way of escaping from jahannam.

verse.content: Isa knew that the Pharisees had heard that he was attracting followers and doing ghusl for them more than Yahya was.
(Actually, Isa did not do ghusl for them. His hawariyun did.)
So he left Yahudia and headed for Al-Jalil again.
He had to pass through Samaria.
He reached a Samaritan town named Sochar, near the field Yacoub gave to his son Yusif.
He sat there at the well of Yacoub and rested from his tiring journey. It was noon.
A Samaritan woman came to get water from the well. So Isa asked her, "Would you give me a drink of water?"

metadata.item: Coming at noon to get water, when it was hot, was unusual. Many people think this woman did this because she had been rejected by her society.

verse.content: (The hawariyun had entered Sochar to buy food.)
The Samaritan woman asked him, "How can you ask me for water? You are a Yahudi and I am a Samaritan." (Al-Yahud and Samaritans have no dealings with each other.)

Isa answered her, "If you only knew what the gift of Allah was, and who the person who asked you for a drink of water is! You would have asked him for water, and he would have given you life-giving water."

metadata.item: Life-giving water, or living water, was a familiar concept to Samaritans. It may have referred to water from a spring or river.

verse.content: She told him, "Sir, you have no bucket and the well is deep. Where did you get life-giving water?"
Are you greater than our father Yacoub? He is the one who gave us the well. He and his sons and his cattle drank from it."

metadata.item: The word father is not literal. Here it means ancestor. The Samaritans traced their ancestry back to Yacoub Bin Ishaq.

verse.content: Isa answered her, "Everyone who drinks from this water will be thirsty again.
But the person who drinks from the water that I give him will never be thirsty. The water that I give him will become a spring inside of him. It will overflow with eternal spiritual life."
The woman said, "Sir, give me that water. Then I will never be thirsty. So I will not come here any more to get water."
Isa told her, "Go, call your husband, and come back."
She answered him, "I do not have a husband." Isa told her, "You spoke the truth when you said, 'I have no husband.'
You have been married five times, and now you are living with a man who is not your husband. Your statement was true."
She told him, "I think you are a nabi.

metadata.item: Isa knew hidden things.

verse.content: Our fathers chose this mountain as a place of worship. But you Yahud say that the correct place of worship is in Al-Quds."

metadata.item: The word fathers is not literal. Here it means ancestors.

Mount Gerazim. They based this on the Tawrat, Deuteronomy 11:29 and other verses from their scriptures. Al-Yahud based their claim on the Tawrat, 1 Kings 9:3, and on the fact that David and his descendants who were king after him
Al-Yahud based their claim on the Tawrat, 1 Kings 9:3, and on the fact that David and his descendants who were king after him were kings in Al-Quds.

verse.content: Isa told her, "Woman, believe me. The hour is coming when you will neither worship the Most Gracious King here, nor in Al-Quds.
You worship him ignorantly. We worship him with knowledge. For saving mercy comes from Al-Yahud.

metadata.item: Isa probably meant that al-masih came from Al-Yahud, and al-masih provided saving mercy from Allah.

verse.content: A time is coming - actually, it is already here - when the true worshippers of the Most Gracious King will worship him in Ruh and truth. Those are the worshippers who have the rida of the Most Gracious King.
Allah is Ruh. Worshippers must worship him in Ruh and truth."

metadata.item: He does not have a body.
Or in their inner beings. True worship is not just what the body does.

verse.content: The woman said, "I know that the expected al-masih will come. When he comes, he will clarify everything to us."

metadata.item: She may have been referring to the prophecy in Al-Tawrat, Daniel 9:25 or the one in Deuteronomy 18:15,18.
She was obviously confused.

verse.content: Isa told her, "I who speak to you am he."

metadata.item: Isa rarely acknowledged the title of al-masih because of common misconceptions of al-masih as a political deliverer. Here understanding was that al-masih was the explainer of mysteries and Isa affirmed that.

verse.content: When his hawariyun returned, they were amazed that he was talking with a woman. But no one asked him, "What do you want from her?" Or, "Why are you talking with her?"

metadata.item: Men and women did not usually talk together in public.

verse.content: The woman left her jar and went and told the people of the town,
"Come and see a man who told me everything I have ever done! Is he the expected al-masih?"
So they went out of the town to him.
Meanwhile, the hawariyun urged Isa, "Honored teacher, eat."
He told them, "I have food you do not know about."
The hawariyun started asking, "Did anyone bring him food?"
Isa told them, "My food is to do the will of the One who sent me and to finish his work.

metadata.item: Allah.

verse.content: Do you not say: The harvest will come in four months? I tell you: Look and see the fields. You will find them white and ready for harvest.

metadata.item: The harvest of grain was not yet ready, but the harvest of the Samaritan people was ready.

verse.content: The harvester will receive his reward. He will gather fruit for eternal spiritual life. Then the sower and the harvester will rejoice together.

metadata.item: Rewards.
This is an allusion to the Tawrat, Proverbs 11:18.

verse.content: Then the saying will be fulfilled: One person sows and another person harvests.

metadata.item: This was a proverb, not a direct quotation from the Tawrat.

verse.content: I sent you to harvest a harvest that you did not work for. Other people worked, and you have become their partners in their work."
Many inhabitants of Sochar believed in him because of the shahada of the Samaritan woman, when she said, "He told me everything I have ever done."

metadata.item: This is the beginning of the "harvest."

verse.content: So the Samaritans came to Isa and asked him to stay among them. And he stayed there two days.
Many more Samaritans became believers because of his word.

metadata.item: This is more of the "harvest."

verse.content: They told the woman, "We no longer believe in him because of your word only. We have heard and known that he is indeed the savior of all the universe."
After two days, Isa went to Al-Jalil.
Isa himself had given shahada that a nabi has no honor in his home town.
So he came to Al-Jalil, and the people there welcomed him. They had done hajj to Al-Quds and had seen his ayat during the eid.
He went to Cana in Al-Jalil. That was where he had changed the water into wine. In Capernaum, the son of an official of the king became sick.

metadata.item: These two cities were over 30 km apart.

verse.content: When the official heard that Isa had returned from Yahudia to Al-Jalil, he went to him. He begged him to come and heal his son, because he was dying.

metadata.item: In this story, the word "son" is literal.

verse.content: Isa told him, "None of you will believe unless you see ayat and miracles."
The official begged him, "Sir, please come before my son dies."
Isa told him, "Return home. Your son is alive." The man trusted the word of Isa and returned home.
When he was on the way, his slaves met him. They told him that his son was well.
He asked them when he began to improve. They told him, "Yesterday at noon the fever left him."

metadata.item: He assumed that his son got better gradually.
Literally, the seventh hour. This was around noon (time of Al-Yahud) or possibly at sunset (Roman time).
Isa had healed the son immediately.

verse.content: The father knew that that was the time that Isa told him, "Your son is alive." So he and all his family believed.
Isa did this second ayah in Al-Jalil after he came from Yahudia.
After that there was an eid of Al-Yahud, so Isa went up to Al-Quds.

metadata.item: There were three eids per year that Al-Yahud celebrated. When they could, Al-Yahud did hajj to Al-Quds for them.

verse.content: Near the sheep gate in Al-Quds is a pool of water. In Hebrew, its name is Bethzatha. It has five corridors.
A large number of people who were sick, blind, lame, and paralyzed were lying there.
There was a man there who had been sick for thirty-eight years.
Isa saw him lying there, and he knew how long he had been sick.
So he asked him, "Do you want to be healed?"
The sick man answered him, "Sir, I have no one to lower me into the water when it moves. Whenever I have tried, another person always enters first."

metadata.item: They thought that an angel had moved the water, and that the water would have a baraka of healing the disease of the first person who got into it.

verse.content: Isa commanded him, "Get up, carry your mat, and walk!"
He was healed at once, carried his mat, and walked. It was Al-Sabt.
The Yahudi leaders told the man who had been healed, "Today is Al-Sabt. Carrying your mat is haraam."

metadata.item: The Tawrat prohibited work, but it did not specify exactly what work was. Al-Yahud made many sunan to describe what they thought should be included as work, and carrying a mat was one of them.

verse.content: He answered them, "The person who healed me commanded me: 'Carry your mat and walk.'"
So they asked him, "Who told you: 'Carry your mat and walk'?"
He did not know who had healed him, because Isa had withdrawn in the middle of the crowds.
After that, Isa found him in the house of Allah. He told him, "You are well. Do not return to your sins, or something more evil will happen to you."

metadata.item: This shows that some sickness is caused by disobedience to Allah or sins.

verse.content: So the man went and informed the Yahudi leaders that the man who healed him was Isa.
So the Yahudi leaders persecuted Isa for what he did on Al-Sabt.
But Isa answered them, "My Most Loving King works all the time, and I work, too."

metadata.item: This refers to the Arabic names Al-Malik and Al-Wadud, two of the 99 names of Allah. Isa used this title to describe his unique relationship with Allah. Isa called him his Most Loving King, with Isa as his amir. See glossary for more information.

verse.content: So the Yahudi leaders tried harder to kill him. This was because they considered that he not only broke their sunan for Al-Sabt, and he also committed shirk when he said that Allah was his Most Loving King and his Guardian.

Isa said in his answer, "I tell you a true, true saying: The beloved amir cannot do anything by himself. He can only do something if he sees the Most Loving King doing it. The amir does what the King does.

metadata.item: The answer Isa gives continues to the end of this chapter (verse 47).
Isa answered the accusation of shirk by saying he was in submission to Allah, just as an amir is in submission to the king.

verse.content: The Most Loving King loves the beloved amir, and he shows him everything he does. He will show him greater ayat that will amaze you.
The Most Loving King is the Resurrector and the Life-Giver. So also, the beloved amir gives life to whomever he wants.

metadata.item: This refers to the Arabic names Al-Baith and Al-Muhyi, two of the 99 names of Allah.

verse.content: The King does not condemn anyone. He has delegated judgment on Yawm Al-Din to the amir.
This is so that everyone will honor the amir as they honor the King. Whoever does not honor the beloved amir does not honor the Most Loving King who sent him.

metadata.item: Not honoring the amir is an insult to the king who sent him.

verse.content: I tell you a true, true saying: Whoever responds to my words and trusts the One who sent me has eternal spiritual life. He will not be condemned on Yawm Al-Din, because he has moved from death to life.

metadata.item: Allah.

verse.content: I tell you a true, true saying: The time is coming, and it has arrived, when dead people will hear the voice of the beloved amir of Allah, and whoever hears his voice will live.
The Living King is the source of life in himself. In the same way, he has made the beloved amir the source of life in himself.

metadata.item: This refers to the Arabic names Al-Malik and Al-Hayy, two of the 99 names of Allah.

verse.content: And he has delegated judgment on Yawm Al-Din to the beloved amir, because he is sayyid al-bashar.
Do not be amazed at this matter. An hour is coming when everyone who is in a grave will hear his voice and come out.

metadata.item: Out of the grave.

verse.content: The people who have done righteously will be resurrected to life. And the people who have done evil will be resurrected for judgment.

metadata.item: This is an allusion to the Tawrat, Daniel 12:2.

verse.content: I cannot do anything by myself. As I hear, I judge, and my judgment is just. That is because I do not seek my will but the will of the One who sent me.
If I were the only one who gave shahada to myself, my shahada would not be accepted.

metadata.item: As legal testimony, shahada from at least two different people was required.

verse.content: Someone else has given shahada for me, and I know that his shahada is true.
You sent a delegation to Yahya, and he gave shahada to the truth.

metadata.item: Yahya gave the second shahada.
This shahada is in the Injil, Yahya 1:19-28.

verse.content: I do not accept the shahada of people, but I say this so that you can be saved.
Yahya was a bright, shining lamp, and you joyfully sought his light for a while.

But I have a shahada that is greater than the shahada of Yahya. This is the shahada of the miracles that the Most Loving King has authorized me to do. They give shahada that I am the rasul of the Most Loving King.

metadata.item: The miracles gave the third shahada.

verse.content: The Most Loving King who sent me has also given shahada for me. But you have not heard his voice and you have never seen his appearance.

metadata.item: Allah gave the fourth shahada.

verse.content: Nor has his word remained in you, because you have not believed his rasul.
You study the kitab in depth, imagining that it is al-sirat for you to eternal spiritual life. And this kitab gives shahada to me.

metadata.item: The kitab gave the fifth shahada.

verse.content: Yet you refuse to come to me so that I can give life to you.

metadata.item: This refers to the Arabic name Al-Muhyi, one of the 99 names of Allah.

verse.content: I do not accept commendation from people.
But I know you, and I know that you have no trace of love for Allah in you.

metadata.item: They were very religious, and were religious leaders, but they did not love Allah.

verse.content: I have come to you in the name of my Most Loving King and you did not receive me. If someone else came in his own name, you would have received him.
How can you believe? You receive commendation from each other and you do not seek the rida of Allah, the One and Only.

metadata.item: This refers to the Arabic names Al-Wahid and Al-Ahad, two of the 99 names of Allah.

verse.content: Do not think that I will accuse you to the Most Loving King. You have put your hope in Musa, but he will accuse you.
If you had believed Musa, you would have believed me, because he was a nabi who prophesied about me.

metadata.item: See the Tawrat, Deuteronomy 18:18.

verse.content: But since you have not believed the message of the rasul Musa, how can you believe my words?"

metadata.item: The message of Isa came to Bani Israil as a fulfillment of the message of Musa.

verse.content: After that Isa crossed Al-Jalil Lake (also know as Tabaria Lake).
Huge crowds followed him, since they had seen his miracles of healing sick people.
Isa went up a mountain and sat with his hawariyun.
It was time for the Passover Eid of Al-Yahud.
Isa looked and saw the huge crowd coming. And Isa asked Philip the hawari, "Where can we buy bread for them to eat?"
He asked him this to test him, because Isa had already decided to do an ayah.
Philip answered him, "Two hundred silver dinars is not enough for a bite for each of them."
But Andrew, the hawari, the brother of Simon, told Isa,
"Here is a boy who has five loaves of barley bread and two fish. But what good is that for these crowds?"
Isa told them, "Make the people sit down." There was much grass, and the men sat down. They were about five thousand.
Then Isa took the bread, gave thanks and praise to Allah, and distributed it to the people who were sitting. He did the same thing with the fish, as much as they wanted.
When they were full, he commanded his hawariyun, "Gather the leftover pieces of bread, so that nothing will be wasted."
They gathered it, and they filled twelve hand baskets with leftover pieces of the five barley loaves that remained from the people who were full.
The people saw the ayah and gave shahada, "Isa is really the nabi that was promised to come to the world."

metadata.item: See note at 5:46.

verse.content: Isa realized that the people wanted him to be king over them, to free them from the occupation forces, whether or not he wanted that. So he isolated himself on the mountain.
His hawariyun went down at sunset to the lake.
They got in a boat and sailed toward Capernaum. It was dark, and Isa had not come to them yet.
The waves became rough because of the strong wind.
They had rowed for about three miles. Then they saw Isa approaching them, walking on the water of the lake. They were terrified,

metadata.item: These are approximately the miles used by Arab geographers. In the original, twenty five or thirty stadia, which would be about 5 km.

verse.content: but he told them, "I am he. Do not be afraid!"
They wanted him to get on the boat, and immediately they reached the shore they wanted to go to.
The next day, the crowds across the lake realized that there had only been one boat on the shore, and Isa did not get into it with his hawariyun. The hawariyun had sailed in it by themselves.
Then, other boats arrived from Tabaria, near the place where they ate the bread after our mawla had given thanks to Allah.
The crowds noticed that Isa and his hawariyun were not there. So they got on boats and sailed to Capernaum, seeking Isa.
When they found him across the lake, they asked him, "Honored teacher, when did you come?"
Isa answered them, "I tell you a true, true saying: You do not seek me because of the ayat you saw. You seek me because you were full of bread.

metadata.item: All you want is free food.

verse.content: Do not seek food that passes away. Seek the food that lasts to eternal spiritual life. This is what sayyid al-bashar gives you, because Allah, the Most Loving King has sealed him."

metadata.item: This is an allusion to the Tawrat, Shaya 55:2.
This refers to the Arabic word khatam. It means to confirm as correct.

verse.content: They asked him, "What should we do to do the requirements that give rida to Allah?"
Isa answered them, "This is the work that Allah requires of you: Believe and trust in his rasul."

metadata.item: In Isa.

verse.content: They said to him, "What is your ayah so that we can see it and believe you? What will you do?
Our fathers ate manna in the wilderness, as the kitab of Allah says: He sent bread from heaven down to them to eat."

metadata.item: The word fathers is not literal. Here it means ancestors.
This story is in the Tawrat, Exodus 16:4-35

verse.content: Isa told them, "I tell you a true, true saying: It was not Musa who sent bread from heaven down on you. It is my Most Loving King who sends you the true bread from heaven."
They told him, "Our master, give us this bread always."
Isa told them, "I am the bread of life. The person who comes to me will no longer be hungry. The person who trusts in me will never be thirsty.
But I told you that you have seen me and you have not believed in me.
Everyone whom the Most Loving King has given to me will come to me. I will never cast outside anyone who comes to me.
I have not come down from heaven to do my will, but to do the will of the One who sent me.

metadata.item: Allah.

verse.content: That will is that I not lose anyone of the people he gave me. Rather, I will resurrect them on the last day.

metadata.item: This refers to the Arabic name Al-Baith, one of the 99 names of Allah.

verse.content: The will of my Most Loving King is that everyone who sees the beloved amir and trusts in him will have eternal spiritual life, and I will resurrect him on the last day."
The Yahudi leaders began to grumble about what Isa said, "I am the bread that was sent down from heaven."
They said, "He is only Isa son of Yusif. We know his father and his mother. How can he claim now: I came down from heaven?"

metadata.item: Here the word son is intended literally, but the information the people had about Isa was not correct. They assumed that his step-father Yusif was his biological father. They did not know that Isa had been conceived by Mariam through Holy Ruh Allah (see the Injil, Luke 1:35) and that he was the word of Allah sent down to Mariam (see the Injil, Yahya 1:1,14)

verse.content: Isa answered them, "Do not grumble among yourselves.
No one can come to me unless the Most Gracious King who sent me attracts him. I will resurrect that person on the last day.
Allah has revealed in the kitab to the anbiya: 'Allah teaches them all.' If anyone hears the Most Gracious King and learns from him, he comes to me.

metadata.item: This is a quotation from the Tawrat, Shaya 54:13.

verse.content: No one has seen the Most Loving King except the one who is from Allah. He is the one who has seen the Most Loving King.

metadata.item: Isa.

verse.content: I tell you a true, true saying: Whoever believes and trusts in me has eternal spiritual life.
I am the bread of life.

metadata.item: Bread of life is not literal. Here it means the source of life.

verse.content: Your fathers ate the manna in the wilderness and they died.

metadata.item: Fathers here is not literal but refers to ancestors.
They died normal deaths, not as a result of eating the manna.

verse.content: But whoever eats this bread that was sent down from heaven will never die.

metadata.item: Most people think this refers to spiritual death, or separation from Allah. Such a person would die physically, but Allah would reward him with life forever in the presence of Allah.

verse.content: I am the living bread that was sent down from heaven. If anyone eats this bread, he will live forever. The bread that I will give for the life of all people is my body."
Al-Yahud argued among themselves and asked themselves, "How can this man give us his body to eat?"
Isa told them, "I tell you a true, true saying: If you do not eat the body of sayyid al-bashar and drink his blood, you have no life in you.
Whoever eats my body and drinks my blood has eternal spiritual life, and I will resurrect him on the last day.

metadata.item: Eating the body and drinking the blood are not literal. Drinking the blood of a person has the meaning of participating in the death of that person, as in the Tawrat, 2 Samuel 23:17.

verse.content: My body is true food, and my blood is true drink.
Whoever eats my body and drinks my blood remains firmly in me, and I remain in him.
The Most Loving, Living King sent me, and I live through the Most Loving King. In the same way, the person who eats me will live through me.

metadata.item: This refers to the Arabic names Al-Hayy, Al-Wadud, and Al-Malik, three of the 99 names of Allah.

verse.content: This is the bread that was sent down from heaven. It is not like the manna that your fathers ate and eventually died. Whoever eats this bread will live forever."
This was the speech of Isa in the house of salat in Capernaum.
Many of his supporters heard this speech and said, "These words are difficult. Who can bear to hear them?"

metadata.item: Arabic ansar.

verse.content: Isa perceived the grumbling of his supporters and asked them, "Do you want to turn back and doubt?
How will it be for you when you see sayyid al-bashar ascending to Allah, where he was previously?

metadata.item: Allah sent down his word, who was with him from eternity, to Mariam, and Isa was born. See chapter 1:1, 14. Here Isa speaks about sayyid al-bashar in a similar way.

verse.content: Ruh Allah is the giver of life. The body does not benefit. My words to you are ruh and life.

metadata.item: This refers to the spirit of Allah. It is not a title of Isa in the Injil.

verse.content: But there are some of you who do not truly trust in me." Isa knew who would not believe in him since the time he began delivering his message. He also knew who would betray him.

metadata.item: Isa knew hidden things and future things.

verse.content: He said, "This is why I told you that no one comes to me unless the Most Gracious King gives him that privilege."
Starting at that time, many of his supporters turned away from him and did not accompany him anymore.
Isa said to the hawariyun, "Do you want to go away also?"
Simon Peter answered him: "Our mawla, to whom can we go? You have the words of eternal spiritual life.
We have believed in you and totally trust that you are the holy one from Allah."

metadata.item: This refers to the Arabic name Al-Qudus, one of the 99 names of Allah.

verse.content: Isa answered them, "I have chosen you twelve hawariyun. But one of you is a shaytan."

metadata.item: Not Al-Shaitan, but a person who has characteristics of Al-Shaitan: treachery and evil.

verse.content: He meant Yahuda, son of Simon Iscariot. He was the hawari who would later betray him.
After that, Isa walked around Al-Jalil and avoided Yahudia, because the Yahudi leaders were trying to kill him.
The Yahudi eid of tents was coming soon.
His brothers advised him, "Leave this place and go to Yahudia so that your supporters can see your miracles.

metadata.item: The word brothers included half-brothers. Isa had no full brothers, of course, since he had no human father.

verse.content: No one works in secret if he wants to become famous. Since you have been aided with these miracles, show yourself to all people."

metadata.item: By Allah.

verse.content: Even his brothers did not believe in him.

metadata.item: After the resurrection of Isa, at least two of his brothers became followers of Isa: Yacoub and Yahuda.

verse.content: Isa told them, "My time has not come yet. But you are ready at any time.
It is impossible for you to arouse the hatred of the people of this world, but I arouse their hatred because of my shahada about the evil of their works.
Do hajj yourselves for the eid. I am not going to this eid, because my time has not yet come."

metadata.item: The eid called the day of atonement was five days before the eid of tents, and some of Al-Yahud went to Al-Quds for that. Isa did not go to Al-Quds for that eid, possibly because the time for him to die for the sins of Al-Yahud had not come yet.

verse.content: Then he stayed in Al-Jalil as he said.
But after his brothers had gone to the eid, he also went. He went secretly, not publicly.
The Yahudi leaders were looking for him at the eid. They asked, "Where is he?"

metadata.item: The eid of tents.

verse.content: The people were grumbling about him. Some said, "He is righteous." Others said, "No, he leads our people astray."

metadata.item: Al-Yahud.

verse.content: No one spoke about him publicly because they were afraid of the Yahudi leaders.
In the middle of the eid, Isa went to the house of Allah and taught the people.

metadata.item: The eid was seven days long.

verse.content: The Yahudi leaders were amazed. They said, "Where did this man get his knowledge of the kitab of Allah, when he has not studied?"

metadata.item: Isa had not gone to the schools of Al-Yahud that taught their traditions and interpretations. He had obviously learned the Tawrat on his own.

verse.content: Isa answered them, "My teaching is not from myself. It is from the One who sent me.

metadata.item: Allah.

verse.content: If anyone wants to do the will of Allah, he will know if my teaching is from Allah or from myself.
A person who speaks from himself seeks his own glory. The person who seeks the glory of the one who sent him is true. There is no lie in him.
Allah revealed the Tawrat to Musa for you. But none of you keeps it! Why do you seek to kill me?"
The crowds answered him, "You have a jinni! Who is seeking to kill you?"

metadata.item: Or, you are crazy.

verse.content: Isa answered them, "I did one ayah, and you were all amazed.

metadata.item: Isa had done many ayat, but they had only seen one of them.

verse.content: Allah revealed to Musa the law about circumcision, as our fathers did before him. That is why you practice circumcision on Al-Sabt.

metadata.item: The word fathers is not literal. Here it means ancestors. Circumcision was first commanded to Ibrahim in the Tawrat, Genesis 17:10ff, hundreds of years before Musa.
Circumcision had to be done on the eighth day (one week after birth.) If a boy was born on Al-Sabt, he had to be circumcised on the next Al-Sabt. See the Tawrat, Leviticus 12:3.

verse.content: If you say that the work of circumcision is halal on Al-Sabt in honor of the Tawrat of Musa, why are you angry with me because I healed a man's whole body on Al-Sabt?

metadata.item: Circumcision involved taking a body that was whole and cutting off a part of it. Isa took a body that was not whole and he made it whole.

verse.content: Do not judge by external appearance. Judge with truth."

metadata.item: This is a quotation from the Tawrat, Leviticus 19:15.

verse.content: Some of the inhabitants of Al-Quds said, "Is not this man the person they are seeking to kill?
Here he is, speaking publicly, and they are not saying anything to him. Have the leaders decided that he is the expected al-masih?
When al-masih appears, no one will know where he comes from. But we know where Isa came from."

metadata.item: This was a common belief, but not supported by the Tawrat. In the Tawrat, Micah 5:2, it states that he would be born in Bethlehem. See also The Injil, Matthew 2:5.
They thought he was from Al-Nasira because he grew up there. But he was born in Bethlehem. See previous note.

verse.content: Isa raised his voice as he was teaching in the house of Allah, "Do you know me? Do you know where I come from? I have not come by myself. The one who sent me is true, and you do not know him.
I know him, because I came from him and he sent me."
So the Yahudi leaders tried to arrest him. But no one could grab him, because his time had not come yet.
Many people from the crowds believed in him. They said, "When the expected al-masih appears, will he do more ayat that the ayat of Isa?"

metadata.item: To those who assumed that Isa was not al-masih.

verse.content: The Pharisees heard what the crowds were whispering about Isa. So the leading ahbar and the Pharisees sent the guards to arrest him.
Isa told them, "I will remain with you for a little while. Then I will go to the One who sent me.

metadata.item: Allah

verse.content: You will seek for me, and you will not find me. You cannot come to me where I will be."
The Yahudi leaders asked each other, "Where will he go that we will not find him? Will he go our people who are scattered among the Greeks to teach the Greeks?

metadata.item: Al-Yahud
Or Greek-speaking Yahud.

verse.content: What does he mean by: You will seek for me, and you will not find me? And: You cannot come to me where I will be?"
On the last day of the eid, the greatest day, Isa stood and announced with a loud voice, "If anyone is thirsty, let him come to me and drink.

metadata.item: Al-Yahud were forbidden from doing hard work on that day. See the Tawrat, Leviticus 23:36.

verse.content: As Allah revealed in the kitab, Rivers of water that give life will flow from the heart of everyone who trusts in me."

metadata.item: This is an allusion to several verses from the Tawrat: Proverbs 4:23 (file:///C:UsersOwnerDesktopEnglish%20Bible%20for%20MuslimsBwRefEE('Pro%204:23')), 5:15 (file:///C:UsersOwnerDesktopEnglish%20Bible%20for%20MuslimsBwRefEE('Pro%205:15')); Shaya 44:3 (file:///C:UsersOwnerDesktopEnglish%20Bible%20for%20MuslimsBwRefEE('Isa%2044:3')), 55:1 (file:///C:UsersOwnerDesktopEnglish%20Bible%20for%20MuslimsBwRefEE('Isa%2055:1')), 58:11; Ezekiel 47:1 (file:///C:UsersOwnerDesktopEnglish%20Bible%20for%20MuslimsBwRefEE('Eze%2047:1')) ff.; Joel 3:18 (file:///C:UsersOwnerDesktopEnglish%20Bible%20for%20MuslimsBwRefEE('Joe%203:18')); and Zakariyya 13:1 (file:///C:UsersOwnerDesktopEnglish%20Bible%20for%20MuslimsBwRefEE('Zec%2013:1')),14:8 (file:///C:UsersOwnerDesktopEnglish%20Bible%20for%20MuslimsBwRefEE('Zec%2014:8')).

verse.content: He meant Ruh Allah, which Allah would send down on trusting believers. The time for that had not come, since Allah had not raised Isa in the majesty of his glory yet.
The crowds hear this word and some of them said, "This is truly the nabi."

metadata.item: This is the nabi that Musa talked about in the Tawrat, Deuteronomy 18:15. See also the Injil, Yahya 1:21. The nabi was another title for al-masih. See also, the Injil, Acts of the Hawariyun 3:22 and 7:37.

verse.content: Other people said, "He is the expected king, al-masih." But others said, "Does the king al-masih come from Al-Jalil?
Did Allah not reveal in the kitab that the king al-masih comes from the seed of king Dawood, from Bait Lahm, the village of Dawood?"

metadata.item: Or descendants. Arabic dhuriyya.

Isa was born in the village of Bait Lahm, and was descended from king Dawood, but this was not widely known. He grew up in Al-Jalil, and people assumed he had been born there. The prophecy about al al-masih being born in Bait Lahm is in the Tawrat, Micah 5:2. The prophecy about al-masih being of the seed of Dawood is in the Zabur, Psalms 89:3-4.

verse.content: So people differed in their view of him.
Some people wanted to arrest him, but no one was able to catch him.
The guards returned to the leading ahbar and Pharisees, who asked them, "Why did you not bring him?"
The guards answered, "No one has ever spoken words like that man!"
The Pharisees answered them, "Have you also gone astray?
Has anyone of the religious leaders or the Pharisees believed in him? 48 But these people who are ignorant of the Tawrat have been cursed by Allah."

metadata.item: They thought that because the religious establishment had rejected Isa as al-masih, that this showed that he was not. The religious establishment was wrong.

verse.content: Nicodemus, the Pharisee leader who previously visited Isa, said to them, "Does our law judge anyone before investigating him and knowing what he does?"

metadata.item: See note at 3:21.

verse.content: They answered him, "Are you also from Al-Jalil? Study, and you will find that no nabi comes from Al-Jalil!"

metadata.item: The Pharisees hated people from Al-Jalil, but they were wrong that no nabi would grow up there or have a message for the people there. The Tawrat, Shaya 9:1 is one example.

verse.content: Isa spoke to them again, "I am the light of the universe. Whoever follows me will never walk in darkness. He will have the light of life." 1 The Pharisees objected, "You are giving shahada to yourself. Your shahada is not true."

metadata.item: In some other translations of the Injil that were made from later manuscripts, there is a story inserted here. This translation is from the oldest complete manuscript of the Injil in the world, from before 350 A.D., and this ancient manuscript does not include the story. Thus this translation, being before any changes to the Injil, does not include it. The story is about a woman who was caught committing adultery. She only (and not the man) was brought to Isa by leaders of Al-Yahud, and they asked Isa to condemn her. Isa answered that the person who had no sin could begin the process of killing her, so everyone left. Then Isa told her that he did not condemn her, and to stop sinning.

Because this translation does not include anything that was added to the Injil later, the numbers of the verses in this chapter are different. Verse 1 in this translation is verse 12 in most other translations, and the rest of the verses in this chapter are 11 less than in other translations.
Not legally acceptable in court.

verse.content: Isa answered them, "Even if I give shahada to myself, my shahada is true. I know where I came from and where I will go. But you do not know where I came from and where I will go.

metadata.item: Accurate.

verse.content: You judge with human judgment. I do not condemn anyone.
Even if I judge, my judgment is true, because I am not alone in my judgment. I judge together with the Most Loving King who sent me.
In the Tawrat, it says that the shahada of two witnesses is true.

metadata.item: Or legally admissible in court. See the Tawrat, Numbers 35:30, Deuteronomy 17:6.

verse.content: I give shahada to myself, and the second one who gives shahada is the Most Loving King who sent me."
They asked him, "Where is your father?" Isa answered them, "You do not know me, and you do not know my Most Loving King. If you knew me, you would know my Most Loving King also."

metadata.item: This saying has two meanings. The first is an insult to Isa. Isa had no human father. Almost no one of Al-Yahud knew that Isa was conceived by Holy Ruh Allah, and so they thought he was illegitimate. The second meaning is the one used by Isa. Allah is the Most Loving, Most Gracious King, and Isa is his amir, or prince, who has his authority. Of course, Allah did not have sexual relations with the mother of Isa (far be it from Allah!), but his relationship with Isa is as the relation of a loving king to his beloved prince: The prince and the king work together, the prince has the authority of the king, the king and the prince are inseparable in purpose and will, the king and the prince have the same nature or character (Isa had a nature from Ruh Allah as well as a human nature from his mother Mariam), and this relationship is unique (no other person was conceived by Holy Ruh Allah.

verse.content: Isa gave this speech by the box of donations while he taught in the house of Allah. But no one arrested him, because his time had not come yet.
Then he spoke to them again, "I will go away, and you will search for me. But you will die as kuffar, because you cannot come to me where I will go."
Al-Yahud said, "Will he kill himself? He said: You cannot come to me where I will go."
He answered them, "You are from below. But I am from above. You are from this world. I am not from it.

metadata.item: Isa was the word of Allah sent down to Mariam.

verse.content: I said that you will die as kuffar. If you do not believe that I am he, you will die as kuffar."

metadata.item: I.e. al-masih or the beloved amir.

verse.content: They asked him, "Who are you?" He told them, "I told you from the beginning.
I have many things to tell you. I will condemn you for them. The one who sent me is true, and I announce to everyone what I have heard from him."
They did not understand that he was talking about the Most Gracious King.

metadata.item: This refers to the Arabic names Al-Malik and Al-Rahman, two of the 99 names of Allah.

verse.content: Isa said, "When you lift up sayyid al-bashar, you will realize that I am he, because I do nothing by myself. I speak as the Most Loving King taught me.

metadata.item: Here Isa refers to the way he would die.

verse.content: The One who sent me is with me. He has not left me alone. I always do what gives him rida."
Many people believed in him while he was speaking.
He said to those of Al-Yahud who believed in him, "If you are firmly rooted, trusting in my word, you are truly my followers.
You will know the truth, and the truth will make you free."
They answered him, "We are from the seed of Ibrahim. We have never been in slavery to anyone! What do you mean that we will be made free?"

metadata.item: They trusted in their ancestry, not their obedience.

Their statement was not true. Bani Israil who were of the seed of Ibrahim had been slaves in Egypt for four hundred years. Furthermore, Bani Israil lived under the occupation of the Romans during the days of Isa.

verse.content: Isa answered them, "I tell you a true, true saying: Every sinner is a slave to sin.
A slave does not have the right to remain in the house of his master forever. But the son of the master remains forever.
If the son makes you free, you will be truly free.
I know that you are from the seed of Ibrahim. But you are seeking to kill me because you reject my word.
I speak about what I saw with the Most Loving King. You do what you saw your father doing.
They answered him, "Ibrahim is our father!" Isa told them, "If you were sons of Ibrahim, you would do the works that Ibrahim did.

metadata.item: The word father here is not literal. It means either ancestor, ancestor in faith, or model in faith.
The word sons here is not literal. It has the idea of someone who follows the example of Ibrahim.

verse.content: But now you seek to kill me. And I have told you the truth that I heard from Allah. That is not what Ibrahim did!
You do the works of your father!" They answered him, "We are not illegitimate children! We have one father: Allah!"

metadata.item: There is another insult to Isa here. They are implying that Isa was an illegitimate son of Mariam, being conceived before Mariam was married to Yusif. Almost no one of Al-Yahud knew that Isa was conceived by Holy Ruh Allah, and so they thought he was illegitimate.
The word father here is not literal. Here it refers to someone who is followed or obeyed.

verse.content: Isa told them, "If Allah were your father, you would love me, because I am rasul Allah and came here. I did not come by myself, but he sent me.
Why do you not understand my words? Because you are unable to listen to my word.

You are of your father Al-Shaitan. You want to follow his desires. He was a murderer since the beginning. He has no foundation on the truth, since there is no truth in him. When he lies, he speaks from his inner nature. He is a liar and the father of lies.

metadata.item: The word father here is not literal. Here it refers to someone who is followed or obeyed.
The phrase 'father of lies' here is not literal. Here it means someone who produces lies.

verse.content: I tell you the truth. That is why you do not believe me.
Who among you can say anything I have done wrong? If I tell you the truth, why do you reject me?

metadata.item: No one could answer this, because Isa was sinless and had never done anything wrong.
Or "call me a liar." Arabic yukadhdhib.

verse.content: A person who is from Allah responds to the words of Allah. This is why you do not respond to him: You are not from Allah."
Al-Yahud answered him, "Are we lying when we say that you are a Samaritan kafir, and that you have a jinni in you?"

metadata.item: The Samaritans were partly Yahud and partly from other nations in their ancestry. This was another insult to Isa. It implies that his father was not Yahudi, possibly a Roman soldier, though his mother was Yahudi.

verse.content: Isa answered them, "I do not have a jinni, but I honor my Most Loving King, and you insult me.
I do not seek my own glory. Seeking and judgment are by Allah.
I tell you a true, true saying: Whoever keeps my word will never see death."
Al-Yahud said to him, "You truly have a jinni. Ibrahim and the anbiya died, and you claim that whoever keeps your word will never taste death.

metadata.item: Or are crazy.

verse.content: Are you greater than our father Ibrahim and the anbiya? They all died. Who do you think you are?"

metadata.item: The word father is not literal. Here it means ancestor and spiritual model.

verse.content: Isa answered them, "If I give glory to myself, my glory is nothing. My Most Loving King glorifies me. He is the one you claim is your Rabb.
You do not know him, but I know him. If I said I do not know him, I would be a liar like you. But I know him and keep his word.
Ibrahim your father rejoiced to see my day. He saw it and was happy."
The Yahudi leaders said, "You are not even fifty years old. How could you have seen Ibrahim?"

metadata.item: Isa was probably about 32 years old at this time.

verse.content: Isa told them, "I tell you a true, true saying: Before Ibrahim was, I am he!"

metadata.item: "I am he" could be understood as the name of Allah in the original language.

verse.content: They picked up stones to stone him, but he hid and left the house of Allah."

metadata.item: They wanted to kill Isa for shirk, because they thought that he was a normal man claiming to be Allah. They did not know that he was word of Allah, which had been sent down to Mariam, who conceived him. The word of Allah has always existed, since before creation, since if Allah was ever without his word, he would be dumb and thus imperfect. This is impossible, since Allah is perfect.

verse.content: On his way, he saw a man who had been blind since birth.
His hawariyun asked him, "Honored teacher, what made him blind? Was it his sins or the sins of his parents?"
Isa answered them, "Neither his nor theirs. He was born blind so that the ayat of Allah would be shown in him.
We must do the works of the One who sent me as long as it is day. When night comes, work is impossible.
I am the light of the world as long as I am in the world."
After that, he spat in the dust, made clay, and rubbed it on the eyes of the man born blind.
He commanded him, "Go and wash in the Siloam Pool." (Siloam means sent.) So he went and washed. When he returned, he could see.

metadata.item: Al-Yahud believed that healing of a man born blind was a miracle that only al-masih could do.

verse.content: His neighbors and other people who knew him previously asked each other, "Is this the person who sat and begged?"
Some of them said, "It is he." Other people said, "No, but he looks similar to him." But he said continually, "I am he!"
The Yahudi leaders asked him, "How were your eyes opened?"
He answered them, "The man named Isa made clay, put it on my eyes, and commanded me to wash in Siloam Pool. So I went and washed and I could see."
They asked him, "Where is he?" He answered, "I do not know."
They brought the man who had been blind to the Pharisees.
The day that Isa made clay and healed the man born blind was Al-Sabt.
The Pharisees asked him again how he could see. He told them, "Isa rubbed clay on my eyes, I washed them, and I could see."

Some of the Pharisees said, "This Isa is not from Allah. He does not keep the sunnah of Al-Sabt." Another group said, "How could a disobedient person do such miracles?" There was a disagreement among them.

metadata.item: They had raised their sunnah to the level of their book.

verse.content: They asked the man born blind again, "What do you think about him? He opened your eyes." He said, "He is a nabi."
The leaders of Al-Yahud did not believe that he had been blind and could see, until they summoned his parents.
They asked them, "Is this your son, whom you claim was born blind? How can he see now?"
His parents answered, "We know that this is our son, and that he was born blind.
But we do not know how he can see now. We do not know who opened his eyes. Ask him. He is legally an adult. He can give shahada for himself."
His parents said this because they were afraid of the Yahudi leaders. The Yahudi leaders had threatened that anyone who gave shahada that Isa was al-masih would be excluded from the house of salat.
That is why they said that he was legally an adult, and to ask him.
They called the man who had been born blind again and made him swear to tell the truth. They said, "Swear by Allah! We know that this man is disobedient."
He answered, "I do not know if he is disobedient. But I do know one thing. I was blind and now I can see."
They asked him again, "What did he do to you? How did he open your eyes?"
He answered them, "I already told you and you did not listen. Do you want to hear it again so you can become his followers, too?"
They cursed him, "You are one of his followers, but we are followers of Musa. We know Allah spoke to Musa. But we do not know where this man came from."
The man said, "This is amazing! He opened my eyes and you do not know where he came from!

metadata.item: Opening the eyes of a person born blind was a miracle that the leaders of Al-Yahud believed that only al-masih could do. Isa had just done that , yet they refused to believe.

verse.content: We know that Allah does not respond to disobedient people. But Allah will respond to a god-fearing person who does the will of Allah.
Healing a man born blind has never been heard of since the days of Adam.
If he were not from Allah, he could not do anything."
They answered him, "Your whole body was born in sin. Are you teaching us?" Then they cast him out.

metadata.item: They assumed that sin was the cause of his former blindness.

verse.content: Isa heard that he had been cast out, so he found him. He asked him, "Do you believe in sayyid al-bashar?"
He answered him, "Master, who is he, so I can believe in him?"
Isa told him, "You have seen him, and he is speaking with you.
I came into this world for judgment, so that the blind could see and people who see would become blind."

metadata.item: Both people who were physically blind and people who were spiritually blind.
Physically but not spiritually.
Spiritually. See note for the Injil, Matthew 13:11.

verse.content: Some of the Pharisees around him heard what he said, and asked him,
"Are we blind, too?"
Isa told them, "If you were blind, you would not be guilty, but since you claim that you see, your guilt remains."

metadata.item: Physically.
Spiritually.

verse.content: "I tell you a true, true saying: Anyone who does not enter the sheep pen through the door, but instead goes in from another place, is a thief and a plunderer.
Whoever enters through the door is the sheep herder.
The doorkeeper opens the door to him, and the sheep hear his voice. He calls his sheep by their names and leads them outside.

metadata.item: In this passage, the word sheep is not literal. It refers to people who follow Allah. In the Zabur (Psalms 23:1, 28:9, 80:1) and in the Tawrat, (Genesis 48:15, Shaya 40:11, Jeremiah 31:10, Ezekiel 34:12. Micah 7:14), Allah is called the sheep herder of Bani Israil.
Sheep herders would give names to their sheep and talk to them. So the sheep would recognize their voices and follower the sheep herder.

verse.content: After the sheep go out, he walks in front of them. They follow him because they know his voice.
They do not follow a stranger, but they turn away from him and flee. That is because they do not know the voice of a stranger."
Isa told them this story, but they did not understand what he meant.
Isa told them, "I tell you a true, true saying: I am the door of the sheep.

metadata.item: Obviously, the word door is not literal. Here Isa meant that he was the sirat into the sheep pen, which was the place of safety for the sheep.

verse.content: Everyone who came before me were thieves and robbers. But the sheep did not listen to them.

metadata.item: This may refer to the leaders of Bani Israil in the days of Isa.

verse.content: I am the door. Whoever enters through me will be safe. He will come in and go out and find pasture.

metadata.item: Or saved.
This is a reference to the Zabur, Psalms 23:1-2.

verse.content: The thief comes only to plunder, kill, and destroy. I came to give them life, abundant life.
I am the good sheep herder, who sacrifices his life as a ransom for the sheep.
The paid worker, who is not the sheep herder or the owner of the sheep, abandons the sheep and flees as soon as he sees the wolf coming. So the wolf snatches them and scatters them.
That happens because he is a paid worker, and he does not care for the sheep.
I am the good sheep herder. I know my flock, and my flock knows me.
The Most Loving King knows me and I know the Most Loving King, too. And I sacrifice my life as a ransom for the sheep.
I have other sheep that are not in this sheep pen. I must bring them, and they will listen to my voice. Then the sheep will all be one flock belonging to one sheep herder.

metadata.item: Probably people who were not Yahud.

verse.content: This is why the Most Loving King loves me, because I sacrifice my life so I can recover it.

No one will kill me. I will sacrifice my life completely of my own will. I have the authority to sacrifice it, and I have the authority to regain it. This is a command sent down on me from my Most Loving King."

metadata.item: Some of Al-Yahud would later claim that they had killed Isa. But Isa, who had power over death (to resurrect others from the dead and to be resurrected himself) from Holy Ruh Allah who had caused him to be conceived could not be killed. Rather, he voluntarily surrendered his life on behalf of those who followed him.

verse.content: The Yahudi leaders again differed about these words.
A group of them said, "He is crazy, and he has been touched by jinn. Why do you listen to him?"
However, another group said, "These words are not from the touch of a jinni. Can a jinni open the eyes of a man born blind?"
Then it was time for the eid of dedication of the house of Allah in Al-Quds. It was winter.
Isa was walking around in the house of Allah, in the corridor of Sulayman.
The Yahudi leaders surrounded him and said to him, "How long will you keep us in suspense? If you are the expected al-masih, tell us clearly."
Isa answered, "I told you, and you did not believe me, even though the miracles that I did in the name of my Most Loving King are a shahada to me.
But you do not believe me, because you are not my sheep.

metadata.item: The word sheep is not literal. Here it means followers.

verse.content: My sheep listen to my voice, I know them, and they follow me.
I gave them eternal spiritual life, and they will never be destroyed. No one can grab them from my hand.
My Most Loving King, who gave them to me, is greater than all. No one can grab them from the hand of the Most Gracious King.

metadata.item: Arabic Akbar.
This refers to the Arabic names Al-Malik and Al-Rahman, two of the 99 names of Allah. Allah does not have a body, so he does not have a physical hand. Here the word hand refers to his protection.

verse.content: I and the Most Loving King are one.

metadata.item: Some translations have "one in purpose" or "in complete agreement." In addition, however, Isa was conceived by Holy Ruh Allah in Mariam, so he has a human nature from Mariam and a nature from Holy Ruh Allah as well. No one else was conceived in this way, so no one else had a divine, spiritual nature, and no one else could claim this. Isa did not claim to be a god in addition to Allah, (see verse 33), but affirmed that Allah is one, and the divine nature Isa had did not contradict the oneness of Allah.

verse.content: The Yahudi leaders again picked up stones to stone him.

metadata.item: Al-Yahud did not know or believe that Isa was conceived by Holy Ruh Allah, so they did not know or believe that Isa had a divine, spiritual nature from Holy Ruh Allah. So they thought that Isa was a normal man claiming to be Allah. The penalty for that was death by stoning the person.

verse.content: Isa answered them, "I have shown you great ayat and miracles of the Most Gracious King. Which ayah do you want to kill me for?"
The Yahudi leaders answered him, "We will not kill you for miracles and ayat, but for shirk. You are a man, and you make yourself a Rabb."
Isa said to them, "Did Allah not reveal in the Zabur: I named you all arbab?

metadata.item: This is a quotation from the Zabur, Psalms 82:6

verse.content: Allah called those to whom his word was revealed arbab, and there is no substituting the words of the kitab.

metadata.item: Allah is all-powerful to protect his words. To say that his words could have been changed is to say that man is more powerful than Allah.

verse.content: So how can you accuse the one whom the Most Loving King has chosen and sent to all people of shirk because I said: I am the beloved amir of Allah?
If I do not do the ayat and miracles of my Most Loving King, do not believe me.
But if I do them, believe me because of them, even if you will not believe me. Then you will understand and believe that the Most Loving King is in me and I am in the Most Loving King."
They tried to arrest him, but he went out from among them.
Then he crossed the Jordan River again and remained in the place where Yahya had done ghusl at first.
Many people gathered around him and said, "Yahya did no ayah, but his shahada about Isa was completely true."
Many people believed in him there.
A man named Lazarus, brother of Mariam and Martha, from the village of Bethany, was sick.

metadata.item: Mariam was a common name. This does not refer to the mother of Isa.

verse.content: This is the Mariam, the sister of the sick man, who had put expensive, perfumed oil on our mawla and wiped his feet with her hair.

metadata.item: This story is in the Injil, Luke 7:36-49.

verse.content: The two sisters sent news to Isa, "Master, your beloved friend is sick."

When Isa heard this news, he said, "The purpose of this sickness is not death. It is for the majesty of the glory of Allah, so that the majesty of the glory of the beloved amir of Allah will be shown."

metadata.item: Sometimes Allah allows sickness for his glory to be shown.

verse.content: Isa loved Martha, her sister, and Lazarus.
So when Isa heard the news of the sickness of Lazarus, he remained where he was for two more days.
Then he said to the hawariyun, "Let us go to Yahudia."
They answered him, "Honored teacher, will you return there? The Yahudi leaders tried to kill you recently."
Isa answered, "Are there not twelve hours in a day? The person who walks in the day will not stumble, because he sees the light of this world.
But if someone walks in the night, he stumbles, because there is no light in him."
Then he said, "Our beloved Lazarus is asleep, and I will go and awaken him."

metadata.item: Isa is using the word sleep here to mean death that is not final. He later resurrected Lazarus from death to life.

verse.content: The hawariyun said, "Our mawla, if he is asleep, he will awaken."
Isa had meant the sleep of death, but the hawariyun thought he meant normal sleep.
So Isa told them clearly, "Lazarus has died.
I am happy that I was not there. It is for your benefit, so that you can truly trust in me. Let us go to him."
Thomas, called Twin, said to the rest of the hawariyun, "Let us go and die with him."

metadata.item: He anticipated that Isa would be killed by the Yahudi leaders.

verse.content: When he arrived, Isa found that Lazarus had been in the grave for four days.

metadata.item: When people died, they were usually put in the grave very quickly.

verse.content: Since Bethany was only two miles from Al-Quds,

metadata.item: This is approximately the mile used by Arab geographers. In the original, fifteen stadia, which would be about 3 km.

verse.content: many people of Al-Yahud had come to comfort Martha and Mariam.
Martha heard that Isa had come, so she went out to meet him. Mariam remained sitting at home.
Martha said to Isa, "My mawla, if you had been here, my brother would not have died.
And I know for certain that even now, Allah will answer what you ask him."
Isa told her, "Your brother will be resurrected alive."
Martha said, "I know that he will be resurrected on the last day."
Isa told her, "I am the resurrection and the life. Whoever trusts in me will live, even if he dies.

metadata.item: In Al-Janna with Allah.

verse.content: And whoever lives and believes in me will never be destroyed. Do you believe this?"
She said, "Yes, my mawla, I believe that you are al-masih, the beloved amir of Allah who comes into the world.
After that, Martha went and whispered to her sister, "The teacher has come and he is calling you."
She got up as soon as she heard this, and went quickly to him.
Isa was still outside the village, in the place where Martha met him.
The Yahudi comforters in the house saw that Mariam left quickly, and they followed her. They thought she was going to the grave to cry there.
Mariam came to Isa, and she prostrated herself at his feet. She said, "My mawla, if you had been here, my brother would not have died."
Isa saw her crying and the crying of Al-Yahud who were with her. So he was sad from the bottom of his ruh and very troubled.
He asked, "Where have you buried him?" They said, "Come and see, our master."
And Isa cried.
The Yahudi people said, "Look how much of a friend he was to him."
But a group of them said, "He healed the man born blind. Could he not have protected him from death?"

metadata.item: Lazarus.

verse.content: Then Isa came to the grave, and again was sad from the bottom of his ruh. The grave was a cave, closed with a stone.
Isa ordered, "Lift the stone away." Martha, the sister of the dead man, said, "My mawla, he has been dead for four days. There will be a bad smell from him."
Isa said to her, "Did I not tell you that you would see the majesty of the glory of Allah if you would trust?"
So they lifted the stone away. Then Isa lifted his eyes up and prayed in dua', "Most Loving King, Answerer, I praise and thank you that you have answered me.

metadata.item: This refers to the Arabic name Al-Mujib, one of the 99 names of Allah.

verse.content: I know that you always answer me. But I said this so that these people here would believe that you sent me."
After that, he shouted, "Lazarus, come out!"
The dead man came out. His hands and feet were wrapped up. His face was wrapped with a cloth. Isa ordered them, "Untie him and let him go."

metadata.item: Al-Yahud believed that only al-masih could resurrect a person who had been dead more than three days.
This was the typical way of burial.

verse.content: Many of Al-Yahud who came with Mariam believed in him when they saw this miracle.
But some of them went to the Pharisees and told them what Isa had done.
The leading ahbar and the Pharisees met in the highest council. They said, "What shall we do? This man does many miracles.
If we let him continue like this, everyone will believe in him. Then the Romans will come and destroy our place and our umma."
Caiaphas, who was chief habr that year, said, "You do not understand anything.
You do not realize that it is better for you if one man dies as a ransom for the people. That way, the whole umma will not be destroyed."
He did not say this of himself. But since he was chief habr, he prophesied that Isa would die as a ransom for the umma.
Not only for the umma, but also for all the scattered family of Allah, to make them one.

metadata.item: The word family is not literal. Allah did not get married or have children. (Far be it from him!). This phrase means those who are followers of Allah in all places on earth.

verse.content: So they began conspiring that day to kill him.

metadata.item: The highest council of Al-Yahud.

verse.content: So Isa no longer walked in public among Al-Yahud. Instead, he traveled to a town called Ephraim, on the edge of the wilderness. He stayed there with the hawariyun.
The time for the Passover Eid of Al-Yahud came, and many did hajj from the villages to Al-Quds to purify themselves before the eid.
They were looking for Isa. They stood in the house of Allah and asked each other, "What do you think? Will he come to the eid or not?"
The leading ahbar and the Pharisees had issued a fatwa. It required anyone who knew where Isa was to inform on him so they could arrest him.
Six days before the Passover Eid, Isa came to Bethany, the village of Lazarus, whom he had resurrected alive.
They made a dinner feast for him there. Martha served them, and Lazarus reclined with them.

metadata.item: Meals were served at low tables or on the floor, and people ate by leaning on their left side and eating with their right hands.

verse.content: Mariam poured expensive, perfumed oil, on the feet of Isa. Then she wiped them with her hair, and the house was full of the pleasant smell of the spice.

metadata.item: This may have been her life savings. Women often saved money by buying perfume and keeping it a jar.

verse.content: But Yahuda Iscariot, the hawari that was going to betray him, said,
"Would it not have been better to sell this perfume for three hundred dinars and gives alms to the poor with it?"
Yahuda said these words because he was a thief, not because he had compassion on poor people. He was responsible for the money box, and he took money from it.
Isa said, "Do not bother her. She has saved it for the day of my burial.
You will always have poor people with you. But I will not be with you always!"
So large crowds of Al-Yahud came when they knew that he had come. They did not only want to see him. They also wanted to see Lazarus, whom Isa had resurrected alive.

metadata.item: Isa

verse.content: The leading ahbar conspired to kill Lazarus also,
because many Yahud were leaving them and believing in Isa because of him.
The next day, the crowds of people doing hajj heard that Isa was on his way to Al-Quds.

So they cut palm branches and went out to meet him. They praised Allah, "Al-hamdu Lillah the Savior! The person who comes in the name of Rabb Al-Alamin has a baraka! The king of Bani Israil has a baraka!"

metadata.item: This is a quotation from the Zabur, Psalms 118:25-26. It was used as a greeting to acknowledge al-masih.
