Those Yahud were more honorable and more open than Al-Yahud in Thessalonica, because they received the word with all seriousness. They studied the kitab carefully every day to make sure that these things were correct.
Therefore, many of them believed, along with a number of leading Greek women and men.
Al-Yahud in Thessalonica heard that Paul was preaching the word of Allah in Beroea, so they came there and stirred up and incited the crowd.
Immediately, some of the brothers took Paul to the coast, but Silas and Timothy remained there.

metadata.item: The word brothers here is not literal. Here it means fellow believers.

verse.content: As soon as they delivered Paul to Athens, they returned, and Paul commanded that Silas and Timothy join him as soon as possible.
While Paul was waiting for them in Athens, he was greatly disturbed in his spirit when he saw that the city was full of idols.
He discussed with Al-Yahud and pious Greeks in the house of salat, and he discussed daily with those he met in the market.

metadata.item: Probably on Al-Sabt.

verse.content: Some Epicurean and Stoic philosophers argued with him, and some of them said, "What is this ignorant talker trying to say?" Another group said, "We think he is preaching strange gods." (He was giving good news of Isa and the resurrection.)

metadata.item: Isa was masculine and resurrection was feminine in the original language. They may have thought Paul was talking about a god and a goddess.

verse.content: So they took him to the Areopagus council and asked him, "May we know what new teaching you are giving?

metadata.item: The council of the leading citizens, especially the philosophers, of Athens.

verse.content: We have heard strange things from you, and we want to know their explanation."
(It was a habit of all citizens of Athens and the foreigners who lived there to fill their time with talking about and listening to new ideas.)
So Paul stood in the middle of the Areopagus council and spoke to them, "Men of Athens, I see that you are very religious in every way.
On my way, I was looking at your temples, and I saw an altar with the inscription: to the unknown god. This god whom you worship ignorantly is the one I proclaim to you:

metadata.item: The Athenians believed they had been saved from a plague by a god, but they did not know who it was.

verse.content: He is Allah, the Rabb of the heavens and the earth, who created everything in them. He does not live in temples built by human hands.
He is Allah, the rich, who does not need human hands to serve him. He does not need anything. He is the enricher who gives life and breath and everything to everyone.

metadata.item: This refers to the Arabic name Al-Ghani, one of the 99 names of Allah.
This refers to the Arabic names Al-Mughni and Al-Muhyi, two of the 99 names of Allah.

verse.content: He is the creator who made all nations on the earth from one soul, and predestined the times and the borders for them to inhabit.
This was so that they would seek and find the face of Allah, and be guided to him, since he is near to every one of us.
Our life, our movements, and our existence is in him. As some of your poets said: We are truly his family.

metadata.item: This is a quotation from a Greek poet, Epimenides.
This is a quotation from another Greek poet, Aratus.

verse.content: Since we are the family of Allah, we must not consider that the essence of Allah is like an idol of gold or silver or stone which was created and imagined by an artist.
Allah overlooked the days of ignorance, but now he commands all people in every place to repent.
He has appointed a day to judge all people in truth through a man he has appointed as judge. And he confirmed that to everyone by resurrecting him alive from death."
When they heard of the resurrection of dead people, some of them mocked, but another group said, "We want to hear from you about this matter again."
Then Paul left them.
Some people followed him and believed, including Dionysius, a member of the Areopagus council, a woman named Damaris, and others.
After that, Paul left Athens and went to Corinth.
He met a Yahudi from Pontus named Aquila, who had arrived from Rome recently, along with his wife Priscilla. Caesar Claudius had commanded all Yahud to leave Rome. So Paul went to visit them.
Paul was a maker of tents like them, so he stayed with them and worked with them.
He spoke in the house of salat every Sabt to convince Al-Yahud and Greeks.
When Silas and Timothy arrived from Macedonia, Paul spent all his time spreading the word and giving shahada to Al-Yahud that Isa was the expected al-masih.

Al-Yahud opposed him and cursed at him, but he showed that he was innocent of their kufr by shaking his robe in front of them. He said, "You are responsible for your own destruction. I am innocent. From now on, I will go to other nations."
Then he left the house of salat and went to the house of a man from another umma who worshiped Allah, whose name was Titus the just. His house was next to the house of salat.
Crispus, the leader of the house of salat, and all his family believed and trusted in our mawla. Many people from Corinth heard the message of Paul, believed, and did the ghusl of faith.
Our mawla commanded Paul in a vision at night, "Do not fear, and do not be silent,
because I with you. No one will attack you to harm you. I have many people in this city."
So Paul remained there one year and six months, teaching the word of Allah.
When Gallio was governor of the province of Achaia, Al-Yahud made a unified attack on Paul, and led him to the court.

metadata.item: Achaia was a province in southern Greece.

verse.content: They accused him, "This man leads our people to worship Allah in a sirat that is contrary to our law."
Paul was ready to begin his defense, but Gallio interrupted him and said to Al-Yahud, "Yahud, if you had accused him of wickedness or a crime, it would be reasonable for me to bear you.
But since the matter is a matter of words, names, and your religious doctrines, you judge it. I refuse to judge such matters!"
Then he cast them out of the court.
Al-Yahud grabbed Sosthenes, the leader of the house of salat, and beat him in front of the court, but Gallio did not pay attention to that.
Paul stayed there many days, then said goodbye to the brothers and sailed toward Syria with Priscilla and Aquila. He had shaved his head as a vow in Cenchreae.

metadata.item: The word brothers here is not literal. Here it means fellow believers.
This practice of shaving to be tahir was based on the Tawrat, Numbers 6:18.

verse.content: After they arrive to Ephesus, he left them there. But he entered the house of salat and spoke to Al-Yahud.
They asked him to stay longer with them, but he declined.
He said goodbye to them and said, "I will return to you inshallah." Then he sailed from Ephesus.
He arrived to Caesarea and went to say assalaamu alaikum to the umma of chosen people in Al-Quds. Then he traveled from there to Antioch.
After he remained with them for a time, he left and traveled through the region of Galatia and Phrygia. He strengthened all the followers.
A Yahudi from Alexandria named Apollos came, and he was an eloquent speaker who had studied the kitab deeply.
He had been taught about the sirat of our mawla, and he spoke with zeal. He taught about Isa accurately even though he only knew about the ghusl of Yahya.
He began speaking boldly in the house of salat, and Aquila and Priscilla heard him. Then they took him home and explained the sirat of Allah more exactly to him.

Apollos wanted to sail to the province of Achaia, and the brothers encouraged him and sent a letter with him to the followers there to receive him warmly. When he arrived, he was a great help to the people who had trusted in Isa by the grace of Allah.

metadata.item: The word brothers here is not literal. Here it means fellow believers.

verse.content: For he showed the errors of Al-Yahud clearly and in public. Based on the kitab, he proved that the expected al-masih was Isa.
When Apollos was in Corinth, Paul went to Ephesus by land, and he found some followers there.
He asked them, "Did Allah give Holy Ruh Allah to you when you trusted in Isa?" They answered, "No. We have not even heard of the existence of Holy Ruh Allah."
So he asked them, "What ghusl did you receive?" They said, "The ghusl of Yahya."
Paul told them, "The ghusl Yahya did for people was a ghusl of repentance, calling for people to trust in the person who came after him, who is Isa."
When they heard that, they did the ghusl of faith in the name of our mawla Isa.
Then Paul put his hands on them and Allah sent down Holy Ruh Allah on them. They began to speak in other languages and to prophesy.
They were about twelve men.
Then Paul entered the house of salat and spoke there boldly for three months. He had discussions with people and tried to convince them of the kingdom of Allah.

A group of them were stubborn and showed their kufr at what Paul said. They insulted al-sirat in front of the people doing salat. So Paul and the followers withdrew and Paul began to teach them daily in the hall of Tyrannus.

metadata.item: Or school.

verse.content: Paul continued to teach them for two years, until all the inhabitants of Asia Minor, both Yahud and Greeks, heard the word of our mawla.
Allah did great ayat by the hands of Paul.
They even took handkerchiefs and aprons that had touched the body of Paul to sick people, and they were healed of their sicknesses. Evil spirits also came out of them.

But some Yahud, who were traveling professionals in casting out evil spirits, tried to use the name of our mawla Isa to cast them out of people who had been touched. They said, "I command you to leave in the name of Isa whom Paul preaches. "
Among those professionals were seven sons of Sceva, the chief habr.
The evil spirit answered them, "I know Isa, and I know about Paul. But who are you?"
And the man who was touched by the evil spirit attacked them, conquered them, and defeated all seven of them. They fled out of the house naked and wounded.
The news of that spread among all the Yahud and Greeks who lived in Ephesus. They were all afraid, and the name of our mawla Isa became highly honored and exalted.
Many of those who had become believers came. They confessed and admitted the things they had done.
Many of the magicians gathered their books and burned them in front of everyone. The value of the books was calculated, and they found that it was fifty thousand silver dinars.
So the word of our mawla spread and ruled strongly.
After these things, Paul decided in Al-Ruh to go to Al-Quds through the provinces of Macedonia and Achaia. He said, "After going there, I must visit Rome also."
So he sent his helpers Timothy and Erastus to Macedonia before him, and he remained for a time in Asia Minor.
At that time there was a great disturbance because of the way.
Demetrius was a silversmith and maker of statues for the temple of the goddess Artemis. He and the other craftsmen benefited greatly from this trade.
He gathered the workers in their trade and similar trades and told them, "Men, you know that we make a lot of money from this trade.
You also see and hear that this Paul has convinced large crowds in Ephesus and in all the province of Asia Minor. He has misled them by his words that idols made by hands are not gods.

If we ignore this danger, not only our craft will be insulted, but also the temple of the great goddess Artemis will be despised. And the goddess will lose her loftiness and majesty. All Asia Minor and the whole world worships her!"
The workers were angry, and shouted, "Artemis, the goddess of the Ephesians, is great!"
Then a riot filled the city, and a crowd made a united attack on Gaius and Aristarchus, Macedonian companions of Paul. They dragged them into the stadium.
Paul wanted to enter to face the crowds, but the followers prevented him.
His friends the rulers also sent him a message, begging him not to enter the stadium.
Some of them shouted one thing, and some shouted something else. The assembly was so confused that most of them did not know the reason they had gathered.

metadata.item: The word assembly in the rest of this chapter is the same word in the original language elsewhere translated "umma of chosen people."

verse.content: Al-Yahud put Alexander in front of the crowds, and some of them asked him to speak. He gestured with his hand, asking for silence so that he could present his defense to the people.
But when they realized that he was a Yahudi, they shouted together loudly, "Artemis, the goddess of the Ephesians, is great!" They kept repeating this for about two hours.

Then the clerk of the mayor was able to quiet them, and he said, "Men of Ephesus, who does not know that the city of Ephesus is the guardian of the temple of the great goddess Artemis and the holy stone which fell from the sky?
No one can deny these truths. So you must keep quiet and not start a riot.
You have brought these two men, who have not robbed the temple of Artemis, and they have not insulted our goddess.
If Demetrius and his artisan companions have a complaint against anyone, let them bring a case and present their accusations in front of the court and judges.
If you want to complain about anything else, wait for a legal assembly of the court.
There is danger that the Romans will charge us with stirring up the riot that happened today, and we have no justification for this disorder and chaos."
After saying this, he dismissed the assembly.
After the riot, Paul called the followers and encouraged them. Then he said goodbye to them and traveled to Macedonia.
He passed those regions, encouraging the believers with many words, and then he came to Greece.
He stayed there three months. While he was preparing to sail to Syria, Al-Yahud plotted against him, so he decided to return by land through Macedonia.
Sopater from Beroea, Aristarchus and Secundus from Thessalonica, Gaius from Derbe, Timothy, and Tychicus and Trophimus from Asia Minor accompanied him.
They came to us and waited for us in Troas.
After the Eid of Unleavened Bread, we sailed from Philippi and arrived to them in Troas after five days. We remained there seven days.
And on Sunday, we met to break bread. Paul started speaking to the people who were present. Paul extended his speech until midnight because he wanted to travel in the morning.
There were many lamps in the room on the upper floor where they were meeting.
A young man named Eutychus was sitting in the window, and he fell asleep because Paul's speech was so long. And he fell from the third floor and was dead when they found him.
So Paul went down to him, threw himself down on him, hugged him, and said, "Do not be disturbed. He is still alive."
Then Paul went up, broke bread, and ate. He talked with them a long time, until sunrise, and then left.
The people who were present felt great comfort because the young man was alive.
After that, we boarded the ship and sailed towards the city of Assos to take Paul with us from there. He had arranged his trip that way.
We met him there, he boarded the ship with us, and we headed for Mitylene.
Then we continued on our way, and on the next day, we were near Chios. Then we crossed over to Samos the next day. On the fourth day, we reached Miletus.
Paul had decided to avoid Ephesus so that he would not stay so long in Asia Minor. He was in a hurry to celebrate the Eid of Pentecost in Al-Quds if possible.

metadata.item: Or be present for.

verse.content: From Miletus, Paul sent a message to Ephesus calling the elders of the umma of chosen people.
When they came to him, he said to them, "You know my manner of life among you from the first day I came to Asia Minor.
I obeyed the will of our mawla as a humble slave with many tears. There were many trials caused by the plots of Al-Yahud.
I did not hesitate to announce anything beneficial to you. I taught you in public and in homes.
I gave shahada to Al-Yahud and to Greeks that they should repent to Allah and trust in our mawla Isa al-masih.
Now I am on my way to Al-Quds. I am bound by Ruh Allah and I do not know what will happen to me there.
But Holy Ruh Allah tells me that in every city I enter, I will be imprisoned and suffer.
But I consider my life worthless to me, if I can complete my sirat and my message that our mawla Isa entrusted to me, to give shahada to the good news of the grace of Allah.
I gave the good news of the kingdom of Allah to you. But now I know that none of you will see me again after today.
So I give shahada in front of you today that I am innocent of the blood of everyone.

metadata.item: I have been faithful in giving shahada to you of everything that Allah gave me, so if you do not obey it, it is your own fault.

verse.content: I did not hesitate to announce all the will of Allah to you.
So be careful for yourselves and for the flock that Holy Ruh Allah made you overseers of. Take care of the umma of chosen people of Allah, which Isa ransomed with his blood.

metadata.item: The believers.

verse.content: After I leave, I know that people who are like ferocious wolves will come to you and they will not have mercy on the flock.
People among them will mislead people and change the truth, to gather the followers after themselves.
So be alert. Remember that I warned every one of you with tears, night and day for three years.
So I commit you to Allah and the word of his grace, which can strengthen your confidence and give you a portion with all the pure, holy people.
I was not greedy for the silver, gold, or clothing of anyone.
You know that I earned my living and the living of my companions with these two hands.
By all this work, I showed you that by our efforts, we must help the weak. We must remember the words of our mawla Isa: Giving has more baraka that getting.
After his speech, Paul kneeled with them and prayed in dua'.
Everyone cried a lot and hugged him and kissed him.
They were very sad because of his words that they would not see his face again. Then they accompanied him to the ship.
After we left them, we sailed directly toward Cos, and then on the next day to Rhodes. From there, we went to Patara.
There we found a ship headed to Phoenicia, and we boarded it and sailed.
After we approached Cyprus, we sailed on its right and headed for Syria, arriving at Tyre. The ship unloaded its cargo there.
We looked for the followers and stayed as guests with them for seven days. They told Paul many times by inspiration of Ruh Allah not to enter Al-Quds.
When this time with them was finished, we headed for the port. They all, with their wives and children, went with us outside the city, and on the beach we knelt together and prayed in dua' to Allah.
Then we said goodbye to each other and we boarded the ship, and they returned to their homes.
We continued our trip from Tyre until we reached Ptolemais, and we greeted the brothers there, and stayed one day with them.

metadata.item: The word brothers here is not literal. Here it means fellow believers.

verse.content: The next day, we headed for Caesarea, and there we entered the house of Philip, the preacher of good news. He was one of the seven men who were chosen. We stayed with him.

metadata.item: See chapter 6.

verse.content: He had four unmarried daughters who had the gift of prophesying.
We stayed several days with him, and then a man with the gift of prophesying named Agabus came from Yahudia.

He approached us and took the belt of Paul. With it, he tied his hands and feet and prophesied, "Holy Ruh Allah says: The Yahud in Al-Quds will bind the owner of this belt and give him to the hands of nations of the kuffar."
When we heard this, we and the brothers there begged him not to go to Al-Quds.
But Paul answered, "Why are you crying and crushing my heart? I am ready to be imprisoned, but also to die in Al-Quds for the sake of the name of my mawla Isa."
He was not convinced by our words, so we were silent and said, "Let the will of our mawla be done."
Then after those days, we prepared to travel and headed for Al-Quds.
The brothers from Caesarea accompanied us. They hosted us at the house of Mnason from Cyprus. He was one of the first followers.
when we arrived to Al-Quds, the brothers welcomed us joyfully.

metadata.item: The word brothers here is not literal. Here it means fellow believers.

verse.content: The next day, we went to a meeting with Yacoub. All the elders were present.
Paul greeted them and told them the details of the ayat that Allah had done among the other nations through his message.
When they heard his speech, they praised the glory of Allah and told him, "Brother, as you see, there are many tens of thousands of believers among Al-Yahud. All of them are zealous for the Tawrat.

metadata.item: The word brother here is not literal. Here it means fellow believer.

verse.content: They have heard that you teach all the Yahud who are abroad to leave the religion of Musa, not to circumcise their sons, and to leave their traditions.

metadata.item: There is no record of Paul teaching this. It seems to be a false accusation.

verse.content: So what can be done? They will hear that you have come, of course.
So do what we tell you. We have four men who have a vow.
Go with them and be tahir with them. Pay the expenses of their vows so they can cut their hair. Then it will be clear to everyone that what they heard is a lie, since you follow the Tawrat.

metadata.item: See the Tawrat, Numbers 6:18.

verse.content: But we have written to the other nations who have believed about our decision for them to avoid meat sacrificed to idols, blood, unsacrificed meat, and adultery."

The next day, Paul took the four men who had a vow and he and they were made tahir. Then he entered the house of Allah with them to record the date of the completion of the days of being tahir, as well as the time for presenting the qurban for each of them.
When the seven days were almost completed, some Yahud from Asia Minor saw him in the house of Allah, stirred up the crowd, and grabbed him.

They were yelling, "Bani Israil, help! This is the man who teaches things against our people, against the Tawrat, and against this house. He teaches this everywhere. He also made Greeks enter the house of Allah and made this holy place unclean!"
They had seen Trophimus from Ephesus in the city with him, and they thought that Paul had brought him into the house of Allah.
The whole city was in turmoil, and the people gathered and grabbed Paul. They took him out of the house of Allah and immediately closed the doors.
While they were trying to kill him, the commander of the Roman guard heard that all of Al-Quds was in chaos.
So he took his soldiers and his officers and hurried toward the rioters. They stopped beating Paul when they saw the commander and his soldiers.
So the commander went to him, arrested him, and ordered that he be tied in chains. Then he asked who he was and what he did.
Some of them shouted one thing, and others shouted another thing. So the commander was unable to investigate the matter because of the noise. So he commanded that he be brought into the camp.
At the stairs, the soldiers carried Paul, because the crowds were attacking him violently.
The crowds were following him and shouting, "Take him away!"
Near the camp, Paul asked the commander, "Would you permit me to say something?" The commander asked him, "Do you know Greek?
Are you not the Egyptian who started a revolution and led four hundred assassins into the wilderness some time ago?"
Paul said, "I am a Yahudi from Tarsus in Cilicia. I am a citizen of that important city. Please let me speak to the people."
He gave him permission and Paul stood on the steps. He gestured with his hand to the crowd until they were quiet. Then he spoke to them in Hebrew.
"Brothers and fathers, listen to what I tell you in my defense."

metadata.item: The phrase brothers and fathers here is not literal. Here it means fellow Yahud and leaders.

verse.content: It became quieter when they heard him speaking in Hebrew. Paul said,

"I am a Yahudi, born in Tarsus in Cilicia. I was raised here in Al-Quds, and I was trained in the Tawrat of our fathers in precise detail under the supervision of Gamaliel. I was zealous for Allah as you are today. I persecuted this sirat to death. I bound men and women and threw them into prison.

The chief habr and all the council of elders can give shahada about this. They sent me with letters from them to the brothers in Damascus, so that I could arrest them and return them bound, for punishment in Al-Quds.

metadata.item: The word brothers is not literal. Here it means fellow Yahud.

verse.content: While I was on my way, near Damascus, at noon, suddenly bright light from heaven shined around me.

metadata.item: Most probably this took place in the city of Daraya, a southwestern suburb of Damascus, which in the original language mean house of the vision.

verse.content: I fell on the ground and heard a voice calling me: 'Talut, Talut, why are you persecuting me?'
I answered him: 'Who are you, master?' He said: 'I am Isa from Al-Nasira, and you are persecuting me.'
My companions saw the light, but they did not understand the voice of the one who spoke to me.
So I said: 'Master, I will obey!' My mawla told me: 'Get up and go into Damascus. There you will be commanded what you must do.'
Then my companions led me by the hand, because the glory of that light had blinded me, and we entered Damascus.
Ananias was a godly man and he observed the Tawrat. He had a good reputation with all Al-Yahud in Damascus.
He came to me, stood beside me, and said to me: 'My brother Talut, See again!' Immediately I saw him standing in front of me.

metadata.item: The word brother is not literal, here it means either fellow Yahudi or fellow believer.

verse.content: Then he said: 'Allah, the Rabb of our fathers, has predestined that you know his will, see Isa the righteous and just one, and hear his voice from his mouth.
You will give shahada about him to all people about what you have seen and heard.
Why are you waiting? Get up and do the ghusl of faith. Call on his name and you will be tahir from your sins.'
After I returned to Al-Quds, I had an unconscious vision in the house of Allah while I was doing salat.

metadata.item: Talut returned to Al-Quds several years later.

verse.content: I saw my mawla Isa telling me: 'Get up and leave Al-Quds quickly. The people here will refuse your shahada about me.'
So I answered him: 'My mawla, they know how I imprisoned and beat those who believed in you, how I searched for them in every house of salat,
and how I stood at the shedding of the blood of Stephen, who gave shahada to you. I had rida to stand as a guard for the cloaks of the people who stoned him.'
But he commanded me: 'Go! I will send you far away to the other nations.'"
The crowd listened to him until he said 'other nations,' but then they shouted, "Get rid of this man from the face of the earth! He does not deserve to live!"

metadata.item: Al-Yahud hated any person who was from an umma other than theirs.

verse.content: They shouted, threw off their cloaks, and threw dust into the air.
The commander commanded to bring Paul into the camp to be interrogated by whipping him in order to know what his crime was and why they were shouting so loudly.
When they stretched him out and tied him in preparation to whip him, Paul asked the officer in charge, "Do you have the right to whip a Roman citizen without a trial?"
When he heard this, the officer went to the commander and said to him, "What are you doing? This is a Roman citizen!"
The commander came and asked Paul, "Tell me! Are you really a Roman citizen? He answered him, "Yes."
The commander told him, "I bought my Roman citizenship for a large sum of money." But Paul said, "I was born a Roman citizen."
The team of whippers withdrew immediately, and the commander feared for himself, since he had bound him, though he was a Roman citizen.

The next day, the commander wanted to confirm the reason Al-Yahud had accused Paul, so he freed him and ordered a meeting with the leading ahbar and the rest of the high council. Then he summoned Paul and had him stand in front of them.
Paul looked at the council and spoke to them, "Brothers, I have followed the sirat of Allah with a clear conscience until today."

metadata.item: Here and in verse 5 and 6, the word brothers here is not literal. Here it means fellow Yahud.

verse.content: So Ananias the chief habr commanded the guards standing near Paul to slap him on the mouth.
Paul said, "Allah will slap you, you evil hypocrite, you white-washed wall! Do you sit as my judge according to the Tawrat, and you break the Tawrat by ordering me to be slapped?"
The people standing next to him said, "Do you insult the chief habr of Allah?
Paul said, "Brothers, I did not know that he was the chief habr, since the Tawrat says: Do not speak evil against a ruler of your people."

metadata.item: Paul was still a Yahudi, even though he was a follower of Isa.

verse.content: Then Paul realized that the highest council was divided in two groups between Pharisees and Sadducees. So he shouted in the council, "Brothers, I am a Pharisee, son of a Pharisee. I am being judged because of my certain hope in the resurrection of dead people."

metadata.item: The word brothers is not literal. Here it means fellow Yahud.
The word son here may be literal or it may mean a follower of.

verse.content: When he said that, there was strife between the Pharisees and the Sadducees and the group was divided.
The Sadducees deny the day of resurrection, angels, and spirits. But the Pharisees believe in all of them.
There was a lot of noise, and then the fuqaha of the Tawrat from the party of the Pharisees stood up. They said, "We find nothing wrong with this man. Maybe an angel or a spirit spoke to him."

The disagreement became stronger among them and the military commander was afraid that they would tear Paul into pieces. So he ordered his soldiers to grab him by force, take him out from among them, and take him into the camp.
At night, our mawla Isa came to him and spoke to him, "Be encouraged! You gave shahada about me in Al-Quds. You must also give shahada about me in Rome."
The next day, the Yahudi leaders plotted against Paul. They swore that they would not eat or drink until they had killed him.
There were more than forty people who plotted.
They told the leading ahbar and elders of the people, "We made a vow not to taste anything until we kill Paul.

So you and the members of the highest council should ask the military commander to bring Paul. Use the excuse that you want to continue to investigate his case. We are ready to kill him before he comes close to you."
The son of the sister of Paul heard about the trap, and he went in to the camp and told Paul.
Paul called the officer and told him, "Take this young man to the commander. He has something to tell him."
The officer took him to the commander and told him, "Paul the prisoner called me and asked me to bring you this young man. He has something to tell you."
The commander took him by the hand by themselves and asked him, "What do you want to tell me?"
He told him, "Al-Yahud have agreed to ask you to bring Paul to the council tomorrow. Their excuse is that they want to continue his investigation.
But do not be convinced by what they say. There will be more than forty men of them who are waiting. They have vowed to fast until they kill him. They are now ready and waiting for your approval."
The commander sent the young man away and commanded him, "Do not tell anyone that you have revealed these things to me."
Then he called two officers and commanded them, "Prepare two hundred soldiers, seventy horsemen, and two hundred spear men to go to Caesarea at nine o'clock at night.
Prepare horses to carry Paul so you can deliver him safely to the governor Felix."
Then he wrote a letter to the governor. It said,
"To your excellency Felix, from Claudius Lysias. Greetings.
Al-Yahud arrested this man and were ready to kill him. Some soldiers and I reached him and rescued him from them, because I knew he was a Roman.

metadata.item: This is the official report, and does not exactly fit with what really happened. The commander did not discover Paul was a Roman until he was ready to be whipped.

verse.content: I wanted to know what accusation they had of him, so I took him to their council.
I discovered that they accused him of things regarding details of their law, and nothing deserving death or imprisonment.
Then I discovered a plot against him, so I sent him to you immediately. I commanded his accusers to state their cause to you."
The soldiers got up and took Paul at night to Antipatris, as the commander had ordered.
The next day, they returned to the camp, and the horsemen continued on the way with him.
When they arrived to Caesarea, they gave the letter to the governor and presented Paul to him.
The governor read the letter and asked Paul what city he was from. When he knew that he was from Cilicia,
he told him, "I will listen to you when your accusers arrive." And he ordered that he be guarded in the palace of Herod.
After five days, Ananias, the chief habr, came with some elders of the people and a lawyer named Tertullus. They presented their case against Paul to the governor.
The governor brought Paul in front of them and Tertullus began to accuse him, "Your Excellency Governor Felix, you are the source of peace in our country. You make improvements to benefit our people.
We confirm our thanks and appreciate you, Excellency, at all times and in all places.
But I do not want to bother you, so I ask you to please listen to us for a little while with your exceeding kindness.
We found this man to be a troublemaker, stirring up riots among Al-Yahud in all the empire. He is the leader of a sect called Al-Nasara.

metadata.item: Or the Nazarenes. This was probably called this because Isa was from Al-Nasira.

verse.content: He tried to make the house of Allah unclean,
so we arrested him.
You can investigate this with him to confirm our accusations of him."
The Yahud who were there agreed with what he said.
Then the governor motioned to Paul, who said, "You have been a judge over our people for a long time. So I am happy to present my defense to you.
You are able to investigate that I came to Al-Quds to worship no more than twelve days ago.
Al-Yahud did not see me arguing with anyone, or stirring up a riot, neither in the house of Allah, nor in synagogues, nor anywhere in the city.
They do not have any proofs of their accusations of me.
But I admit that I worship Allah, the Rabb of our fathers according to al-sirat which they call a sect. I believe in everything that Allah revealed in the Tawrat and the scrolls of the anbiya.

metadata.item: The word fathers here is not literal. Here it means ancestors.

Sometimes the word Tawrat is used to mean all of the revelation to Bani Israil. Here and other times, it is divided into the part that Allah gave to Musa (Tawrat) and the part that Allah gave to other prophets (scrolls of the anbiya).

verse.content: I have the same certain hope that they believe in, the day of resurrection when Allah will resurrect good and bad people alive.
So I always struggle to keep my conscience clear with Allah and with people.
I came to offer qarabin and alms to the poor people of my umma after being far away for many years.
While I was offering them, some Yahud from Asia Minor came and found me in the house of Allah. I was tahir and there were no crowds with me. I was not causing any chaos.
If they have anything against me, they should appear in front of you with their accusation against me.
Now let the people here mention any crime that they found during my trial before their highest council.
The only thing I did was to shout among them: I am on trial in front of you because of my faith in the resurrection of dead people."
Felix knew the principles of al-sirat accurately. So he adjourned the case. He said, "I will judge between you when the military commander Lysias comes."
Then he commanded the officer who was responsible for guarding him to give him some freedom and to let his friends visit him and help him.
After a few days, Felix came with his wife Drusilla, who was a Yahudi, and he summoned Paul so they could listen to him about faith and trust in al-masih Isa.
He spoke to them about righteousness, self-control, and Yawm Al-Din. Felix was afraid and said, "Go away now, and I will call you at an appropriate time."
Felix was expecting that Paul would give him a bribe. So he summoned him many times and spoke with him.
After two years, Porcius Festus became governor instead of Felix. And Felix left Paul in prison to give rida to Al-Yahud.
Three days after he became governor, Festus went from Caesarea to Al-Quds.
The leading ahbar and the leaders of Al-Yahud complained to him about Paul.
They asked him a favor: to bring Paul to Al-Quds. They had plotted to attack him and kill him on the way.
Festus answered them that Paul would stay imprisoned in Caesarea, and that he would go there soon.
Then he said, "Let those who have authority accompany me and present their accusations, if this man has done anything wrong."
Festus remained in Al-Quds for eight or ten days and then went to Caesarea. The next day he sat as judge and summoned Paul.
The Yahud of Al-Quds met around Paul when he came and accused him of many crimes without any evidence.
Then Paul defended himself and said, "I have not sinned against the Tawrat of Al-Yahud or against the house of Allah or against Caesar."
Festus wanted to give rida to Al-Yahud, so he asked Paul, "Do you want to go to Al-Quds to continue your trial about these accusations in my presence?"
Paul answered him, "I am standing in front of the court of Caesar. This is where my trial should be. I have not sinned against Al-Yahud at all, as you know well.
If I am a criminal and I deserve death, I do not seek to escape from death. But if their complaint has no real basis, it is not right for me to be delivered to them. So I appeal my case to Caesar!"
Festus conferred with the members of his council and answered, "You have appealed to Caesar, so you will go to Caesar."
After a few days, King Agrippa arrived to Caesarea with Bernice to greet Festus.
They stayed with him many days, and Festus told the king about the case of Paul. He said, "Felix left him as a prisoner.
When I went to Al-Quds, the leading ahbar and elders of Al-Yahud complained about him, and asked that he be condemned.
I answered that Romans do not deliver a person to his accusers before he has faced them and has the opportunity to defend himself.
After they came here with me, I did not want to delay the case. The next day I sat to judge them and I summoned him.
His accusers did not accuse him of evil crimes as I supposed.
They disagreed with him about their religion, and about a man named Isa who died, but Paul claimed had been resurrected alive.
I did not know how to deal with these matters legally, so I asked him if he wanted to go to Al-Quds and be tried for these matters there.
But he appealed his case to be tried in the court of his majesty Caesar, so I commanded that he remain here until I had the chance to send him to Caesar."
Agrippa told Festus, "I want to listen to him if possible." He answered, "You will listen to him tomorrow."

The next day, Agrippa and Bernice came in a lavish procession and entered the courtroom. They were accompanied by military leaders and honored citizens of the city. Festus commanded that Paul be brought and they summoned him.

metadata.item: His sister and possibly his wife.

verse.content: Then Festus said, "King Agrippa and everyone who is present with us here, all the Yahudi people in Al-Quds and those Yahud who reside here have shouted for the execution of this man you see.
But I have found that he did not do anything deserving death. And since he has appealed to Caesar, I have decided to send him to him.

But I have no charge connected with his case that I can write to my master, Caesar. So I have brought him before you, and especially before you, King Agrippa. After interrogating him, it will be clear to me what to write.
It is unreasonable to send a prisoner to him without making the accusation against him clear."
Agrippa said to Paul, "We allow you to speak to defend yourself." Paul gestured with his hand and defended himself. He said,

metadata.item: Often a king speaks in the plural.

verse.content: "King Agrippa, I am happy to present my defense before you today in answer to all the accusations of Al-Yahud.
You know well all the traditions and discussions of Al-Yahud. So I ask you to be patient and hear my defense.
All of Al-Yahud know about my life since my youth in my city and in Al-Quds.
They have known me for a long time, if they were willing to give shahada, that I lived as a Pharisee, the strictest and most fanatical party in our religion.
I am being tried now because of my certain hope in the promise of Allah to our fathers.

metadata.item: The hope was in the resurrection from death to life. This was a particular belief that other parties (like the Sadducees) did not believe in.
The word fathers here is not literal. It means ancestors.

verse.content: This is the hope our twelve tribes want to see fulfilled as they worship day and night. King, Al-Yahud accuse me because of this hope!
Do you all not believe that Allah, the Life-giver, resurrects dead people alive?

metadata.item: This refers to the Arabic names Al-Muhyi and Al-Baith, two of the 99 names of Allah.

verse.content: So I was convinced that I should strongly resist the name of Isa Al-Nasiri.
This is what I did in Al-Quds. I imprisoned many of his holy followers with the authority of the leading priests. And I agreed with my vote to execute them.

metadata.item: Each member of the highest council voted on cases of life and death.

verse.content: I punished them many times in all the houses of salat, and tried to make them say kufr. I was so extremely angry that I persecuted them even in foreign countries.
The leading ahbar authorized me to go with their authority to Damascus.
King, I was on my way, and at noon, I saw a light from heaven. It shined brighter that the sun around me and my companions.
We all fell on the ground, and I heard a voice speaking to me in Hebrew: 'Talut, Talut, why are you persecuting me? You will get hurt because you resist me.'
So I asked him: 'Who are you, my mawla?' My mawla answered me: 'I am Isa, whom you are persecuting.
Stand up on your feet! I have appeared to you to appoint you as a servant to give shahada about what you have seen and will see from me.
I will save you from the Yahudi umma and the other nations I have sent you to.

You will open their eyes to turn from darkness to light, and from the power of Al-Shaitan to Allah. Then Allah will forgive their sins and give them a portion with those whom Allah has purified and made holy through their trust in me.'
King Agrippa, since that time, I have not disobeyed what I was commanded in the heavenly vision.

But I spoke to the people in Damascus first, and then the residents of Al-Quds and all Yahudia, and then to the other nations. I invited them to sincerely repent and to do good works that are appropriate for repentance.
This is why Al-Yahud arrested me in the house of Allah and tried to kill me.
But Allah has aided me until now. My shahada to all of you, both old and young people, is only what was described in the Tawrat and the scrolls of the anbiya.

metadata.item: Sometimes the word Tawrat is used to mean all of the revelation to Bani Israil. Here and other times, it is divided into the part that Allah gave to Musa (Tawrat) and the part that Allah gave to other prophets (scrolls of the anbiya).

verse.content: It was certainly written that al-masih would suffer pains and death, and that he would be the first to be resurrected from death. This was so he could be a shining lamp to Al-Yahud and other nations."

metadata.item: See, for example, the Tawrat, Shaya 53.
See, for example, the Zabur, Psalms 16:10.
This may be a reference to the Tawrat, Shaya 49:6.

verse.content: At this point, Festus interrupted the defense of Paul, and shouted, "You are crazy, Paul! Your deep learning has made you crazy!"
Paul answered him, "Your excellency Festus, I am not crazy. These words are true and logical.
His majesty the king, to whom I boldly speak now, knows these things. It is unreasonable that any of them be hidden from him. They did not happen in an isolated corner.
King Agrippa, do you believe in what Allah has revealed to the anbiya? I know you believe."
Agrippa said to Paul, "Do you want to make me a follower of al-masih that quickly?"

metadata.item: Or a Christian. This term was used by people who were not followers of Isa to describe followers of Isa to mock them.

verse.content: Paul said, "Quickly or slowly, I pray in dua' to Allah that you and everyone who hears me today will become a follower of Isa like me, except without these chains."
Then the king, the governor, Bernice, and those who were sitting with them stood.
They went out saying to each other, "This man has not done anything deserving execution or prison."
Agrippa said to Festus, "If he had not appealed to Caesar, he could be released."

When the appointment for us to sail to Italy had been set, they delivered Paul and some other prisoners to an officer named Julius, commander of one hundred soldiers in the regiment of his majesty Caesar.
We boarded a ship from Adramyttium that was on its way to various ports on the shore of Asia Minor. Aristarchus, the Macedonian from Thessalonica, was with us when sailed.

metadata.item: Luke the scribe of this book is included.

verse.content: The next day, we arrived to Sidon, and Julius in his kindness allowed Paul to visit his friends so that they could take care of him.
From there, we sailed near to Cyprus on the north, protected from the headwinds.
We crossed the sea many times across from Cilicia and Pamphylia, and arrived to Myra in Lycia.
There the officer found a ship from Alexandria headed to Italy and we boarded it.

Our trip was slow and after many days we arrived with difficulty to a place near Cnidus, because the winds prevented us from continuing. So we sailed near Crete opposite Salmone, protected from the winds.
We continued our trip, and then with difficulty arrived at a port called "Fair Havens" near the city of Lasea.
A long time had passed, and our journey had become dangerous because the autumn fast had finished. Paul advised the sailors,

metadata.item: Al-Yahud had to fast on the Day of Atonement in November.

verse.content: "Men, it seems to me that there will be a disaster in this trip, and a great loss, of the cargo, the ship, and our lives."
But the officer tended to follow the opinion of the captain and the owner of the ship more than what Paul said.
The port was not suitable to spend the winter in, so the majority decided to sail to the port of Phoenix on Crete, which faces southwest and northwest. They wanted to spend the winter there.
Then a mild southern wind blew and they thought that it would allow them to achieve their goal. So they raised the anchor and went parallel to the coast of Crete.
But then a hurricane-force wind from the northeast blew from Crete.
The ship could not resist it because it was so strong. So we let it guide us and take us along.
Then we arrived to a small island called Cauda. We controlled the lifeboat with difficulty.
The sailors lifted it up and tied the ship with ropes to save it, because they were afraid we would crash into the sandy Libyan coast. Then they raised the anchor and let the wind push it.
The next day, the storm was violent, and they started throwing out the cargo.

metadata.item: Throwing out the cargo was an emergency measure that lightened the ship in order for it not to sink.

verse.content: on the third day, with their own hands they threw out the equipment of the ship.

metadata.item: This was a very serious thing. Now the ship was without its equipment.

verse.content: The sun and stars did not appear for many days, and the pressure of the storm became harsher. So we lost all hope of saving our lives.
The travelers fasted for a long time. Then Paul stood up and said, "Men, if you had listened to my words, we would not have sailed from Crete. This disaster and loss would not have happened to us.
But listen to my words now and be encouraged! None of you will die when the ship crashes.
Last night, an angel from Allah (I belong to him and I am his servant), stood next to me.
He told me: Paul, do not fear. You must stand in front of Caesar. By the generosity of Allah, all the travelers with you will be saved.
So I have trusted in Allah and that his promise to me will be true. So be encouraged!
But we must crash into some island.
On the fourteenth day that the wind pushed us, we were floating in the Adriatic Sea near Italy. At midnight, the sailors thought that they were nearing land.
They measured the depth and found it was twenty fathoms. After a while, they measured again and found it was fifteen fathoms.

metadata.item: A fathom was about 1.8 meters.

verse.content: They were afraid of crashing into the rocks, so they lowered four anchors from the back of the ship. Then they waited for day.
Then the sailors pretended that they were lowering the anchors from the front of the ship. They were actually lowering the life boat so they could escape.
Paul warned the officer and the soldiers, "These men must remain in the boat or you cannot be saved."
The soldiers cut the ropes of the boat and let it fall.
At dawn, Paul encouraged them all to eat food. He told them, "For fourteen days you have abstained from food because you were worried.
I urge you, eat and get strong so that you may be saved. Not one hair of the heads of any of you will be lost."
Then Paul took a loaf, praised and thanked Allah in front of all of them, broke it, and ate.
Everyone was encouraged and ate.
We were two hundred seventy-six people on the boat.
When they were full, they threw the remaining wheat in the sea to lighten the boat.
Then the sun rose. They did not know the place they were, but they saw the beach of a small bay. So they headed for it so that the ship could crash into the sand.
They left the anchors in the sea, loosened the rudder controls, raised the sail, and headed for the beach of the bay.
But because of the shallow water, the front of the ship crashed into a sandbar between the sea and the bay. It got stuck there and the waves began to break the back of the ship.
The soldiers planned to kill the prisoners so they could not escape by swimming.

metadata.item: If a prisoner escaped, his guard would be killed as punishment. See note on 12:19.

verse.content: But the captain prevented them from doing that because he wanted to save Paul. So he commanded everyone who knew how to swim to swim toward the beach.
Then he ordered the rest to hold on to boards or remnants of the ship to arrive to the shore. In this way, we all reached the land in safety.
Afterward, we learned that the island we had reached was called Malta.
Its people welcomed us with wonderful kindness. They welcomed us and lit a fire for us because of the cold and the rain.
Paul had gathered fire wood and put it on the fire. But a snake came out of the wood because of the warmth and bit his hand.

When the Maltese saw it hanging on his hand, they said to each other, "No doubt this man is a murderer, because he escaped from death in the sea, but the goddess of justice has not allowed him to live."
But Paul shook off the snake into the fire and was not hurt.
The Maltese expected that he would swell up and die suddenly, but after a long while, they saw that nothing had happened to him. So they changed their opinion and said he was a god.
Around us were lands of the chief of the island, who was named Publius. He welcomed us and gave us wonderful hospitality for three days.
The father of Publius was sick in bed with diarrhea. So Paul visited him and prayed in dua' to Allah for him. Then he put his hands on him and healed him.
Then the rest of the sick people on the island came to him and were healed.
They honored us with many gifts and provided us what we needed when we sailed.
After three months, we boarded a ship from Alexandria which spent the winter there. In the front of the ship was a statue of the twin gods.

metadata.item: Pollux and Castor. "They were worshipped by the Romans and Greeks.

verse.content: We arrived to Syracuse and stayed there for three days.
From there we went to Rhegium, and the next day we sailed with a south wind to arrive the following day to Puteoli.
There we found brothers, and they hosted us for seven days. Thus we came to Rome.

metadata.item: The word brothers here and in the next verse is not literal. In these places, it means fellow believers.

verse.content: The brothers in Rome heard that we had arrived to the villages of the Forum of Appius and the Three Taverns. When he saw them, Paul was encouraged, and he praised and thanked Allah.
When we entered Rome, the commander allowed Paul to live by himself with the soldier who guarded him.

After three days, Paul called together the leaders of Al-Yahud in that place. When they met, he told them, "Brothers, I did nothing against our people or the traditions of our fathers. But they imprisoned me in Al-Quds and delivered me to the hands of the Romans.

metadata.item: The word brothers here and in verse 21 is not literal. In these places, it means fellow Yahud.
The word fathers is not literal. Here it means ancestors.

verse.content: After questioning me, they wanted to release me. They did not find any evidence to support an accusation against me that deserved execution.
But the Yahud objected, so I was forced to appeal to Caesar, though I do not accuse my people of anything.
This is why I invited you for a conversation. I am bound with chain because of the certain hope of Bani Israil."
They told him, "No one from Yahudia has written to us about you. And none of the brothers coming from there has mentioned anything against you.
But we want to hear your opinions about the doctrine of this sect. We know that people everywhere criticize it."

They appointed a day for that, and a large number of them came to his house. He gave shahada about the kingdom of Allah from early morning until sunset, and convinced them about Isa. He based his message on what is written in the Tawrat and the books of the anbiya.

metadata.item: Sometimes the word Tawrat is used to mean all of the revelation to Bani Israil. Here and other times, it is divided into the part that Allah gave to Musa (Tawrat) and the part that Allah gave to other prophets (scrolls of the anbiya).

verse.content: Some of them believed and some of them disbelieved.
Then Paul told them as they were leaving him and disagreeing among themselves, "Holy Ruh Allah had a true saying that he gave by the tongue of nabi Shaya to your fathers.

metadata.item: The word fathers is not literal. Here it means ancestors.

verse.content: He said: 'Go and tell this people: You will listen but will not understand. You will look but will not see.

The hearts of this people are hard. Their ears are deaf and they have closed their eyes. This was so they would not see with their eyes, hear with their ears, and understand in their hearts, and repent, so that I would heal them.'

metadata.item: This is a quotation from the Tawrat, Shaya 6:9-10.

verse.content: So you should know that Allah has sent his saving mercy to other nations. They will listen to him!"
Paul stayed in Rome for two complete years.
In a house he rented, he would receive anyone who visited him.
He announced the kingdom of Allah to them. And he taught them the message of our mawla Isa al-masih openly and with freedom.
